0;Covid-19: WHO chief optimistic disease will be beaten in 2022;2021-12-31T19:28:26.000Z;[];['world health organization (who)'
column2: 'coronavirus vaccines'
column3: 'coronavirus pandemic'];['dose'

column1: This video can not be played
The World Health Organization (WHO) chief says he is optimistic that the coronavirus pandemic will be defeated in 2022
column2: provided countries work together to contain its spread.

column1: Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesu warned against ""narrow nationalism and vaccine hoarding"" in a new year statement.
His comments come two years since the WHO was first notified of cases of an unknown pneumonia strain in China.
Global Covid cases now stand at 287m
column2: while nearly 5.5m people have died.

column1: Across the world people are marking the new year but celebrations are muted
column2: with many countries wanting to discourage crowds gathering.

column1: Coronavirus remains part of daily life: a disease that has shut borders
column2: split families and in some places made it unthinkable to leave the house without carrying a mask.

column1: Despite all this
column2: Dr Tedros sounded a positive note in his speech
column3: noting that there are now many more tools to treat Covid-19.

column1: But he warned that continuing inequity in vaccine distribution was increasing the risk of the virus evolving.
Narrow nationalism and vaccine hoarding by some countries have undermined equity and created the ideal conditions for the emergence of the Omicron variant
column2: and the longer inequity continues
column3: the higher the risks of the virus evolving in ways we can't prevent or predict

column1: If we end inequity
column2: we end the pandemic
column3: he added.

column1: In other developments:
In his comments
column2: Dr Tedros also alluded to low vaccination rates.

column1: While most of the population in Europe and the Americas have received at least one dose
column2: a WHO target of full vaccination rates in 40% of every country by the end of 2021 has been missed across most of Africa.

column1: Dr Tedros has previously criticised wealthier nations for ""gobbling up"" the global vaccine supply
column2: fully vaccinating much of their populations while others wait for their first doses.

column1: The WHO has set a new goal for 2022: vaccinate 70% of people in all countries by July to end the pandemic.

column1: Lawyers for a US woman who has accused Prince Andrew of sexual assault are seeking proof of the British royal's alleged inability to sweat.
Virginia Giuffre's legal team made the request as part of a civil case against the prince in a New York court.
Ms Giuffre
column3: alleges that Prince Andrew sexually assaulted her when she was a teenager at the homes of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.

column1: Prince Andrew has consistently denied the allegations.
In a 2019 interview with BBC Newsnight
column2: he said a ""problem"" with her account was that a medical condition at the time meant he could not have been sweating
column3: as she claims he was.

column1: This video can not be played
A civil case filed in the US alleges that the prince sexually abused Ms Giuffre - then known as Virginia Roberts - at Maxwell's London home
column2: and at Epstein's homes in Manhattan and Little St James in the Virgin Islands.

column1: Epstein
column2: a convicted sex offender
column3: killed himself in prison in 2019 while awaiting a sex trafficking trial. British socialite Maxwell was found guilty this week of grooming underage girls to be abused by him.

column1: The motion filed by Ms Giuffre's lawyers calls on Prince Andrew to supply ""all documents concerning your alleged medical condition of anhidrosis
column2: hypohidrosis
column3: or your inability to sweat"".

column1: Prince Andrew's lawyers said he objected to the request ""on the grounds that it is harassing and seeks confidential and private information and documents that are irrelevant
column2: immaterial and not reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of admissible evidence"".

column1: They added that Prince Andrew had no such documents in his possession to hand over.
The motion also includes requests for details of Prince Andrew's trips on Epstein's planes
column2: and communication he had with Epstein and Maxwell.

column1: In a separate development
column2: a request by Prince Andrew's lawyers to pause the proceedings against him has been turned down by a US judge.

column1: His lawyers had wanted Ms Giuffre to take part in a two-hour deposition to discuss her country of residence.
Ms Giuffre has been living in Western Australia and Prince Andrew's lawyers had argued that this may disqualify her from filing a lawsuit in a US court. The judge rejected the demand.
Meanwhile Ghislaine Maxwell
column2: who was found guilty on Wednesday of recruiting and trafficking young girls for Epstein
column3: awaits sentencing
column4: a date for which has not yet been set. The verdict could see her spend the rest of her life behind bars.

column1: The jury's decision was welcomed by the survivors
column2: with Annie Farmer - the only witness to use her real name during testimony - saying she was ""so relieved and grateful"".

column1: Ms Giuffre
column2: who was not one of the four women who testified in the case but was referenced on many occasions in court
column3: said she would ""remember this day always"".

column1: Maxwell's brother Ian told the BBC that she would appeal against the verdict ""on legal grounds - both in terms of the pre-trial process and the trial process as well""
column2: but did not give further details.

column1: He described the victims' testimony as ""heart-rending"" but said he still believed his sister's innocence.
Another of Epstein and Maxwell's accusers
column2: Sarah Ransome
column3: criticised Mr Maxwell's remarks.

column1: This sex trafficking pyramid wouldn't exist without Ghislaine
column2: she told the BBC.

column1: I really think Ghislaine's brother should sit in a room full of Ghislaine's survivors because then he might have a different opinion of what his sister actually has done. She has destroyed hundreds of lives.""

column2: 'hong kong'
column3: 'air travel'

column1: Cathay Pacific has announced immediate major cuts to its flight schedule
column2: including cancelling passenger and cargo services to and from Hong Kong.

column1: The airline did not provide details on how many flights would be grounded but it said it would operate a skeleton passenger schedule in January.
It comes after Hong Kong announced tighter Covid-19 quarantine rules for air cargo crew earlier this week.
The move was aimed at tackling the threat of the Omicron Covid variant.
Cathay pilots have previously told the BBC the restrictions have affected their mental health and personal lives.
Late on Thursday Cathay Pacific said it was tentatively planning to cancel some passenger flights in and out of the Asian financial hub in the first three months of the new year.
It also said that long haul freight and cargo-only passenger flights including from Europe
column2: Riyadh and Dubai would be suspended until 6 January.

column1: Cathay Pacific had already announced last week that it would cancel some flights in January.
The latest decision is likely to put further strain on the already struggling global supply chain.
Like much of the rest of the global aviation industry
column2: Cathay has been hit hard by the pandemic. It posted a net loss of $2.8bn (£2bn) in 2020 and lost $972m in the first half of 2021.

column1: Airlines around the world have cancelled thousands of flights in the Christmas period alone due to the coronavirus.
In line with mainland China
column2: Hong Kong has a zero-Covid policy as it aims to persuade Beijing to allow cross-border travel.

column1: As a result the city has some of strictest quarantine rules in the world
column2: raising concerns that it may be left behind as other major financial centres open up as they adopt approaches that see them live with the coronavirus rather than remaining closed off to keep case numbers low.

column1: Hong Kong is one of the world's biggest aviation hubs but also has some of the strictest coronavirus regulations in the world. Two pilots with Cathay Pacific recently told the BBC that the rules have seriously affected their mental health and putting a strain on their personal lives.
You're just in a perpetual state of quarantine
column2: one pilot
column3: who has spent almost 150 days in isolation this year alone

column1: Though Hong Kong has recorded barely any local coronavirus cases in recent months
column2: the city has imposed an extensive testing and quarantine regime
column3: in line with mainland China's zero Covid policy.

column1: Tesla is to recall more than 475
column2: 000 cars in the US
column3: according to documents filed with the US safety regulator.

column1: The electric vehicle firm announced it was recalling 356
column2: 309 vehicles because of potential rear-view camera issues affecting 2017-2020 Model 3 Teslas.

column1: A further 119
column2: 009 Model S vehicles will also be recalled because of potential problems with the front trunk
column3: or boot.

column1: The total recall figure is almost equivalent to the 500
column2: 000 cars Tesla delivered last year
column3: Reuters reports.

column1: The BBC has approached Tesla for comment.
A safety report
column2: submitted this month
column3: estimates that around 1% of recalled Model 3s may have a defective rear-view camera.

column1: Over time ""repeated opening and closing of the trunk lid"" may cause excessive wear to a cable that provides the rear-view camera feed
column2: says a Safety Recall report submitted by Tesla to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) in the US on the 21 December.

column1: If the wear causes the core of the cable to separate ""the rear-view camera feed is not visible on the centre display""
column2: the report notes.

column1: The loss of the rear-view camera display may ""increase the risk of collision""
column2: it adds.

column1: The Model S recall involves vehicles manufactured between 2014-2021
column2: some of which may have a problem with a ""secondary latch"" on the front trunk
column3: or boot.

column1: In another Safety Recall report
column2: also filed on 21 December
column3: Tesla notes the fault could mean
column4: if the primary latch is inadvertently released
column5: the front trunk ""may open without warning and obstruct the driver's visibility
column6: increasing the risk of a crash"".

column1: Around 14% of recalled Model S's may have the defect
column2: the report notes.

column1: In both cases
column2: the reports state that ""Tesla is not aware of any crashes
column3: injuries
column4: or deaths"" relating to the potential faults.

column1: The latest recall is not the first safety issue to have prompted action from the electric vehicle firm.
Last week Tesla agreed to make changes to its Passenger Play feature
column2: which allows games to be played on its touchscreen while the car is in motion.

column1: It took action after an investigation was launched by the NHTSA.
The feature will now be locked and unusable while the car is moving.

column1: Tens of thousands of people awoke on Christmas morning to a surprise from an unexpected benefactor - Santander.
The bank mistakenly deposited £130m into 75
column2: 000 accounts on 25 December.

column1: Santander's staff are now rushing to claw back the money
column2: although the job is being made more difficult because much of it was deposited in accounts at rival banks
column3: according to The Times.

column1: The error occurred when payments from 2
column2: 000 business accounts were made twice.

column1: We're sorry that due to a technical issue
column2: some payments from our corporate clients were incorrectly duplicated on the recipients' accounts
column3: the bank said in a statement.

column1: None of our clients were at any point left out of pocket as a result and we will be working hard with many banks across the UK to recover the duplicated transactions over the coming days.""
It said the mistake may have meant that some people were
column2: in effect
column3: paid twice from their employer's account
column4: although the second payment was funded by Santander.

column1: One payroll manager
column2: who asked not to be named
column3: told the BBC the blunder had cast a shadow over Christmas and Boxing Day.

column1: It ruined my holiday period because I thought I'd paid out hundreds of thousands in error - I thought I had done something wrong
column2: they told the BBC.

column1: I thought it was just me and that I was going to get in trouble at work.""
They said that Santander had not given any information about how firms should explain the second payment to staff or about how it should be repaid.
It's just a complete shambles
column2: the payroll manager said. ""How they are going to recover it
column3: I just don't know.""

column1: The bank stressed that it had already begun speaking to the rival banks - which The Times said included Barclays
column2: HSBC
column3: NatWest

column1: Santander said those banks would ""look to recover the money from their customers' accounts.""
However
column2: it was not clear how the banks would respond if their customers had already spent the money
column3: meaning returning it would push them into overdraft.

column1: Santander indicated that it may contact people directly to get the money back.

column1: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Global has seen its losses deepen after Beijing ordered online stores not to offer the company's app.
The firm reported an operating loss of $6.3bn (£4.7bn) for the first nine months of year as revenues in China fell by 5% in the third quarter.
The Chinese crackdown came just days after Didi made its New York stock market debut at the end of June.
This month
column2: it said it will move its share listing to Hong Kong from the US.

column1: In recent months
column2: Didi has become one of the most high profile targets of Beijing's clampdown on the country's technology industry.

column1: The restrictions placed on it by authorities in China have hit its share price in the US hard.
The company's value on the New York Stock Exchange has fallen by 65% since its debut less than six months ago.
In its latest report to investors the firm also said that its board had authorised it to pursue a listing of its shares on the main board of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
The company is executing above plans and will update investors in due course
column2: Didi said.

column1: Didi's announcement early in December that it planned to leave the US stock market came on the same day that the US Securities and Exchange Commission said it had finalised rules that would mean US-listed foreign companies can be delisted if their auditors do not comply with requests for information from regulators.
Following careful research
column2: the company will immediately start delisting on the New York stock exchange and start preparations for listing in Hong Kong
column3: the company said at the time.

column1: Didi also said in Thursday's announcement that Daniel Zhang
column2: the chief executive of Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba
column3: who had served as a director on its board since 2018

column1: As well as coming under intense scrutiny from Chinese regulators
column2: Didi now faces tough competition in its home market from ride-hailing services launched by car makers Geely and SAIC Motor.

column2: 'business in africa'

column1: Mining trucks are monstrous machines that guzzle fuel at a scarcely believable rate.
Weighing 220 tonnes
column2: they can get through 134 litres of diesel every hour.

column1: Little wonder then that mining companies are focusing their attention on these vehicles as the first step to reducing their carbon footprint.
Anglo American
column2: in collaboration with several partners
column3: is retrofitting a mining haul truck with hydrogen power technology.

column1: A first of its kind
column2: the monster mining vehicle is being piloted in Limpopo
column3: South Africa
column4: at the firm's Mogalakwena platinum mine.

column1: Due to be launched in early 2022
column2: the truck will be hybrid
column3: with a hydrogen fuel cell providing roughly half of the power and a battery pack the other half.

column1: Instead of having a tank of diesel that powers the motor
column2: hydrogen enters the fuel cell and mixes with oxygen to create water in a chemical reaction catalysed by platinum
column3: which generates the electricity needed to power the motors that drive the wheels.

column1: It only emits water vapour and the company says it has the potential to reduce on-site diesel emissions by up to 80%.
By rolling out this technology across its global truck fleet
column2: Anglo American says it will be ""taking the equivalent of half a million diesel cars off the road"".

column1: The trucks also harvest regenerative energy created when driving downhill and braking
column2: which is stored in the battery and extends the range of the vehicle.

column1: Anglo is developing the truck along with partners Engie
column2: NPROXX
column3: First Mode

column1: However

column1: Some 30

column1: Nearly 1

column1: Winds of up to 105 mph (169 km/h) are fanning flames across the region amid a historic drought.
While previous fires in Colorado have been in rural areas
column2: these latest blazes are burning in more suburban parts of the state. Thursday's fires
column3: named the Marshall Fire and Middle Fork Fire
column4: are coming relatively late in the season.

column1: At least some were sparked when power lines were toppled by strong winds
column2: and they have quickly become the most destructive wildfires in the state's modern history. Experts say that wildfires in western North America have grown more intense in recent years.

column1: This is our community so to watch it burn so quickly

column1: Snow had began falling near the fires on Friday morning

column1: At least one first responder and six others were injured

Patrick Kilbride

It's just a strange feeling to go from having everything to make your life comfortable to having nothing

column1: Colorado has been experiencing extreme droughts in recent years. Climate change increases the risk of the hot

column1: A truck driver who was facing a 110-year jail term for a deadly crash has had his sentence reduced to 10 years
column2: following widespread outcry.

column1: Rogel Aguilera-Mederos' lorry crashed into traffic in 2019
column2: killing four people in the US state of Colorado.

column1: At trial he was convicted on 27 counts
column2: and the judge said state law forced him to impose the lengthy sentence.

column1: But on Thursday
column2: Colorado Governor Jared Polis commuted what he called an ""unjust"" sentence.

column1: Aguilera-Mederos was transporting timber in the Rocky Mountains foothills when the deadly crash happened in April 2019.
The lorry careered downhill into stationary traffic
column2: bursting into flames and causing a major pile up in the city of Lakewood.

column1: Four people - Stanley Politano
column3: William Bailey

column1: Aguilera-Mederos
column2: a Cuban immigrant
column3: told officials that his brakes had failed
column4: and that he had tried his best to avoid other vehicles as he lost control of the truck.

column1: But prosecutors argued that the 26-year-old knew his brakes were failing.
They said he dangerously weaved between vehicles
column2: and that he drove past at least one runaway truck ramp - long lanes at the side of roads designed for vehicles with brake problems to drive into and stop safely.

column1: Judge Bruce Jones told the court that - under Colorado law - he had to impose the mandatory minimum sentence for all of convictions
column2: and that they must be served consecutively.

column1: If I had the discretion
column2: it would not be my sentence
column3: the judge said after Aguilera-Mederos was convicted.

column1: More than five million people
column2: including reality TV star and law student Kim Kardashian West
column3: signed a petition that called for a reduction in his lengthy prison sentence.

column1: Truck drivers also announced on social media that they would boycott Colorado over the sentencing.
As governor
column2: Mr Polis has constitutional power to grant pardons
column3: clemency and commutations.

column1: In a letter to Aguilera-Mederos
column2: he called the crash ""a tragic but unintentional act"" and said there was ""an urgency to remedy this unjust sentence and restore confidence in the uniformity and fairness of our criminal justice system"".

column1: You will struggle with this burden of this event for the rest of your life
column2: but never forget that... countless others will struggle with the loss of their loved ones or injuries as well
column3: he added.

column1: Aguilera-Mederos will be eligible to apply for parole in five years.
The timing of the governor's move has not been welcomed by everyone.
In a statement
column2: District Attorney Alexis King said she was ""disappointed in the Governor's decision to act prematurely"".

column1: A hearing to reconsider the verdict had already been planned
column2: and Ms King had previously said she would ask for Aguilera-Mederos to be resentenced to up to 30 years in prison.

column1: I joined the surviving victims and families of those who lost their loved ones in their wish to have the trial judge determine an appropriate sentence in this case
column2: said Ms King.

column1: Betty White was US television's Golden Girl with the heart of gold
column2: celebrated for her comic acting abilities from TV's early days up to the 21st Century
column3: while remaining committed to her animal activism.

column1: I have to keep acting so that I can afford to keep doing my charity work!"" she joked to The Hollywood Reporter in 2018.
Born in Illinois in 1922
column2: White became one of America's original screen stars
column3: enjoying a career that encompassed eight decades and earned her many accolades.

column1: As an only child
column2: she moved with her family to Los Angeles during the height of The Great Depression
column3: and in the late 1930s began working as an actress and model. Her fledgling career had to be put on hold
column6: when she went to work with the American Women's Voluntary Services.

column1: After the war
column2: White continued with her showbiz ambitions with mixed success
column3: before landing her own radio show and then appearing on Al Jarvis's Hollywood on Television variety talk show.

column1: She died on Friday
column2: weeks before her 100th birthday.

column1: Clearly a burgeoning talent
column2: she took over the reins of the TV show in the early 1950s
column3: and was subsequently nominated for her first Emmy Award for best TV actress in 1951. It was the new awards' first ever category to recognise the achievements of women on the box.

column1: Next came the TV sitcom Life with Elizabeth - a show she launched herself
column2: alongside George Tibbles. ""He wrote and I produced
column3: she explained. ""I was one of the first women producers in Hollywood.""

column1: White kept her profile high with many chat show appearances
column2: and met her third husband (and ""love of my life"") Allen Ludden on the game show Password in 1961. The couple were married from 1963 until Ludden's death in 1981.

column1: The actress's biggest role so far came as Sue Ann Nivens on The Mary Tyler Moore Show in the 1970s. Her sharp-witted character
column2: who had an eye for the men
column3: worked alongside the sitcom's titular star in a fictional Minneapolis television newsroom.

column1: The job won White two more Emmy Awards and set her up for what would become her most famous role
column2: as the naive-but-loveable Rose Nylund in The Golden Girls
column3: which carried her through the 1980s and 90s.

column1: Nylund was a Norwegian-American who moved to Miami after the death of her husband and formed a later life bond with three other women
column2: played by Beatrice Arthur
column3: Rue McClanahan and Estelle Getty.

column2: it won the Emmy for outstanding comedy and White scooped the individual award for best comedy actress.

column1: I am the lucky one who gets to come up and pick up this beautiful golden girl
column2: she said in her acceptance speech. ""But Estelle and Rue and Bea and I all thank you - we're a match-set
column3: you can't split us up.""

column1: After The Golden Girls went off air in 1992
column2: White - who was by then also a published author - appeared in the short-lived spin-off Golden Palace.

column1: She also had a recurring role on soap opera The Bold and the Beautiful from 2006 to 2009
column2: and hosted several other entertainment shows
column3: including the prank show Betty White's Off Their Rockers.

column1: But her career caught fire again in 2010
column2: when she starred in another sitcom
column3: Hot in Cleveland

column1: It's just a terrific show. The chemistry between the girls is so great
column2: White told Newsweek.

column1: The same year
column2: the veteran also became the oldest ever host of Saturday Night Live
column3: following a Facebook campaign to get her on the prime-time show.

column1: Her 90th birthday in 2012 was marked with an all-star television special featuring her old co-star Tyler Moore
column2: Ellen DeGeneres and Carl Reiner
column3: as well as Tina Fey and Ed Asner.

column1: Still making movies into her 90s
column2: White joined an all-star cast in 2019's Toy Story 4
column3: voicing a tiger teething toy named Bitey White.

column1: Animals (real ones
column2: not toys) were always a passion
column3: and she worked closely with the Los Angeles Zoo and the Morris Animal Foundation for more than four decades.

column1: I'm actually the luckiest old broad alive
column2: she said. ""Half my life is working in a profession I love and the other half is working with animals.""
she was honoured with a lifetime achievement Emmy Award - her eighth Emmy in total.

column1: She is one of the most beloved female performers in the history of television
column2: said Bob Mauro of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences
column3: who described White as an ""American institution"".

column1: Betty's career as a female pioneer has followed television from literally the beginning of the medium
column2: winning her first Emmy Award in 1952
column3: to the digital-streaming future

column1: Emmy vice-president David Michaels went on to say that White was ""also one of the nicest women in showbusiness"".

column1: 2021 introduced us to tech terms including Metaverse and NFT (non-fungible token).
Facebook took a dramatic new direction
column2: heading off into virtual reality.

column1: The internet
column2: which had held up remarkably well over a series of lockdowns
column3: experienced a few wobbles.

column1: And we learned that those chips in all our devices
column2: which we take for granted
column3: weren't infinite.

column1: Here's our rundown of some of the biggest stories on the BBC Technology site over the past year.
Even though he lost the presidential election at the end of 2020
column2: Donald Trump continued to make headlines into 2021.

column1: On the 7 January
column2: he was briefly locked out of his Twitter account after posting false claims of voter fraud. Just 12 hours later
column3: he was allowed to tweet again. but a few days later was permanently suspended.

column1: The tweet that led to the ban was seen as particularly inflammatory given the storming of the Capitol building just the day before.
The events acted as a wake-up call to social media networks which had previously allowed politicians to have
column2: more or less
column3: free rein posting online.

column1: Facebook also chose to ban the former US president; six months on
column2: in June
column3: it was decided that Trump would remain barred from Facebook for two years.

column1: During the course of the year both Facebook and Twitter adopted new rules on how to deal with the high-profile accounts of world leaders and politicians.
Of course it was not the last we heard from Mr Trump - but more on that later.
WhatsApp's plans to change its privacy policies to make it easier for people to message businesses
column2: faced a backlash as millions downloaded apps from its competitors
column3: worried that the plan meant large amounts of information on the messaging platform would be shared with Facebook.

column1: Facebook insisted the changes did not mark a dramatic shift
column2: but admitted that communication had been poor.

column1: Privacy advocates said it merely highlighted that WhatsApp was already harvesting huge amounts of data for its parent firm.
A few days after the backlash was reported in the media
column2: WhatsApp revealed that those who did not accept its updated terms and conditions would be unable to receive or send messages after the 15 May deadline.

column1: Later in the year
column2: WhatsApp was forced to rewrite its privacy policy following a £190m fine imposed by the Irish data protection authority. It subsequently had to provide much more information about what exactly it does with user information.

column1: In Spring
column2: anti-virus creator John McAfee
column3: who has always been a controversial figure
column4: was charged with fraud - accused of promoting crypto-currencies on Twitter in order to inflate the price.

column1: At the time
column2: he was already being detained in Spain on separate charges relating to tax evasion.

column1: A few months later
column2: a Spanish court agreed to extradite him to the US. But just a few hours later he was found dead in his cell - believed to have taken his own life.

column1: It has been a year dominated by chip shortages - the result of a combination of factors
column2: including the pandemic and the sharp increase in demand for certain goods as everyone adapted to working
column3: learning and socialising at home.

column1: In April
column2: Cisco became one of the first to warn that the computer chip shortage was a problem
column3: although its suggestion that it might last for six months proved to be rather optimistic.

column1: Later in the year
column2: the boss of chip firm Arm suggested that the problem could run until next Christmas.

column1: Trump was back in the headlines in May with news that he had launched his own communications platform which would publish content ""straight from the desk"" of the former US president.
Some pointed out that it seemed to be little more than a glorified 1990-style blog - and just a month later it was shut down.
Later in the year
column2: he unveiled a slightly more sophisticated effort to exert his influence on social media
column3: with plans to launch an app called Truth Social in 2022.

column1: It has raised $1bn to date
column2: but has also courted controversy and is facing an investigation from the SEC.

column1: In June
column2: a major internet outage affected a number of high-profile websites including Amazon
column3: Reddit
column5: the Guardian and the New York Times.

column1: Cloud computing provider Fastly admitted responsibility. It runs what is known as an edge cloud
column2: which is designed to speed up loading times from websites. Later it emerged that one customer changing their settings had triggered the bug.

column1: Similar problems plagued Amazon Web Services
column2: Akamai and Cloudflare during the year
column3: prompting some to question the reliance on a handful of companies to keep the internet working.

column1: One of Silicon Valley's original innovators
column2: Jeff Bezos
column3: stepped down from Amazon
column4: exactly 27 years after he founded the online retail giant. For many he was a business visionary
column5: and the company he started bears this out - worth $1.8trn at the time of his departure.

column1: But like all tech giants
column2: Amazon is facing increased scrutiny
column3: over how it treats its warehouse workers
column5: as well as questions over whether it monopolises online retail.

column1: Mr Bezos isn't planning to walk out of the limelight however. His latest obsession is Space - in October he and Star Trek's original Captain Kirk
column2: aka William Shatner
column3: blasted into sub-orbit in his rocket

column1: This year we learned that NFT stood for Non-Fungible Token. Less understood was what it meant - essentially a digital token that can be used as a way of paying for digital collectibles.
But for those who got it
column2: it was a great way to make a quick buck - like 12-year-old Benyamin Ahmed
column3: who made £290
column4: 000 from some pixelated artworks called Weird Whales that he had made during his school holidays.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: an NFT of an animated cat GIF sold for more than £365
column4: while Jack Dorsey's first ever tweet hit £2.5m and Tim Berners-Lee web source code NFT went for a cool $5.4m.

column1: But the NFT craze was not without its critics: author David Gerard describes NFTS as the ""new form of worthless magic bean"".
Either way
column2: it was hard to ignore
column3: and NFT made it into Collins dictionary of new words for 2021 - along with Metaverse.

column1: Every so often a strange tale hits tech - and none was stranger than the warning that iPhone owners should be wary that powerful motorbikes could damage their camera systems.
The document
column2: published by Apple and spotted by MacRumours
column3: suggested that engine vibrations could harm the phones' optical-image stabilisation or closed-loop autofocus systems.

column1: The BBC's retelling of the story got millions of hits.
In October
column2: there were two major Facebook stories - one of which broke all records for tech index readership. But strangely that accolade went not to the radical company rebrand to Meta
column3: but to a story about Facebook
column4: WhatsApp and Instagram being inaccessible for a few hours.

column1: It was also the month that Facebook announced its new focus on the metaverse - a concept that has rapidly become one of the most hyped words of 2021
column2: and one which Mark Zuckerberg seems to have endless enthusiasm for.

column1: Essentially
column2: it is a virtual reality version of the internet in which Meta
column3: along with some other big names in tech
column5: play and work at some point in the future.

column1: Of course
column2: the more cynical wondered if the newfound enthusiasm for the metaverse - which came with not just a company rebrand
column3: but a plan to hire 10
column4: 000 people in the EU to build it - was a distraction from Facebook's ongoing issues with real-world content.

column1: Its been quite a year for cyber crime
column2: with record numbers of ransomware attacks and some serious bugs uncovered. In November our cyber reporter
column3: Joe Tidy
column4: set off to find some of the most wanted hackers from the notorious network Evil Corp - many of whom are based in Russia.

column1: It took him to a golf course and a shiny skyscraper in Moscow. He didn't find the hackers
column2: but he did learn that they were making a huge amount of money - alongside driving the requisite Lamborghinis
column3: hosting plush weddings and keeping exotic pets.

column1: Any direct links to the Russian state are denied by the Kremlin
column2: but experts believe that hackers are allowed to flourish in the country provided they don't target Russian nationals. While US law enforcement claims they are also enlisted for state hacking.

column1: This year there has been a renewed surge of disinformation around vaccinations
column2: Covid and politics.

column1: Technology has not been immune to conspiracy theories either
column2: with attacks on 5G transmitters from those who believe they omit dangerous radio waves.

column1: Despite no evidence the transmitters cause any harm
column2: the theory has spawned a range of products which claim to protect people against them.

column1: The BBC has previously reported on the issue
column2: from anti-radiation stickers for sale on Amazon
column3: to a USB stick which UK Trading Standards described as a ""scam"".

column1: Then
column2: as the year ended - in an ironic twist - an anti-5G necklace was found to be radioactive by the Dutch authority for nuclear safety and radiation protections.

column1: 27;A $10bn 'glittering space jewel' begins its mission;2021-12-30T15:59:53.000Z;[];['astronomy'
column2: 'nasa'
column3: 'european space agency'

column1: This video can not be played
A $10bn glittering space jewel recedes into the distance.
This is the moment the James Webb telescope came off the top of its rocket to begin its mission to image the first stars to shine in the cosmos.
The video was transmitted in near real-time last Saturday
column2: but the feed to Earth was very glitchy and broken up.

column1: The European Space Agency (Esa) has since had the sequence cleaned up and set to music by the UK artist Charlotte Hatherley.
It's the last view we'll ever get of the telescope scientists believe will go on to make transformative discoveries about the early Universe
column2: and about planets circling far-off stars.

column1: Webb is currently heading to an observing position some 1.5 million km from Earth on its nightside. It should arrive at this location in late January.
Already the astronomical facility is beyond the orbit of the Moon.
Saturday's launch on an Ariane rocket from French Guiana was a spectacular affair - and a very precise one.
The European booster performed flawlessly
column2: putting Webb at just the right altitude and inclination to the equator
column3: and with the required velocity.

column1: Indeed
column2: the flight performance was so good
column3: mission controllers now believe the telescope's lifetime has been significantly extended because it didn't have to use so much of its own fuel when making a later course refinement.

column1: Another indicator of the Ariane dividend is the speed at which Webb's solar array is seen to deploy in the video. It comes out just 70 seconds after the telescope's ejection from the rocket's upper-stage.
The event was not expected for several minutes but Webb's onboard computers determined that all conditions for a safe deployment had been met and commanded the array's immediate release.
The telescope was launched in a folded configuration - a tightly packed cuboid a little under 10.7m by 4.5m by 4.5m. It's now being directed to unfold itself
column2: with the tricky unfurling of a giant sunshield scheduled to take place over the next few days.

column1: The camera system used to obtain the separation video was manufactured by Irish start-up Réaltra Space Systems Engineering.
Arianespace
column2: which manages the launches from French Guiana's Kourou spaceport
column3: will be putting the Réaltra technology on Europe's next-generation Ariane vehicle - the Ariane-6 - when it enters service next year.

column1: Charlotte Hatherley has previously worked with Esa on outreach projects. The title of the track used to accompany the Webb video is called Lonely Waltz
column2: which featured on her 2017 album
column3: True Love.

column1: Apple has placed an iPhone factory in southern India ""on probation"" following protests over food poisoning and living conditions.
An audit by Apple found that remote dining rooms and dormitories used by workers did not meet requirements.
Around 250 women who worked at the Foxconn plant were affected by food poisoning
column2: with more than 150 ending up in hospital
column3: local media reported.

column1: Foxconn apologised and said it was investigating the situation.
We are very sorry for the issue our employees experienced and are taking immediate steps to enhance the facilities and services we provide
column2: the Taiwanese firm said in a statement.

column1: The factory has been closed since 18 December
column2: when the protests began.

column1: Apple has not specified what being on probation means but in the past it has declined to award new business to facilities on probation until problems are resolved.
An Apple spokesman said: ""Following recent concerns about food safety and accommodation conditions at Foxconn Sriperumbudur
column2: we dispatched independent auditors.

column1: We found that some of the remote dormitory accommodations and dining rooms being used for employees do not meet our requirements
column2: and we are working with the supplier to ensure a comprehensive set of corrective actions are rapidly implemented.""

column1: The iPhone factory
column2: which is about 25 miles (40km) from Chennai
column3: employs 17

column1: The food-poisoning cases and subsequent protests also led the Tamil Nadu state government to ask Foxconn to review its worker facilities.
Last year
column2: Apple had to place another iPhone manufacturing partner on probation after worker riots broke out over unpaid wages at the partner's factory near Bangalore.

column1: The combination of Delta and Omicron variants is driving a dangerous tsunami of Covid-19 cases
column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) chief has said.

column1: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus' words came as the US and countries across Europe reported record new cases.
France reported Europe's highest ever daily figure for the second day in a row
column2: at 208
column3: 000 cases.

column1: And the US has reported a record average of 265
column2: 427 cases a day over the last week
column3: according to Johns Hopkins.

column1: Denmark
column2: Portugal
column3: the UK and Australia have all also reported record-breaking figures.

column1: Poland reported 794 Covid-related deaths on Wednesday
column2: the highest number in its fourth wave of the pandemic. More than three-quarters of these were unvaccinated people.

column1: Studies suggest that Omicron - which has quickly become dominant in numerous countries - is milder than the Delta variant
column2: but far more contagious. It is believed to be driving the surge in cases
column3: with French health minister Olivier Véran telling reporters he would ""no longer speak of a wave when it comes to Omicron"" but a ""tidal wave"".

column1: However
column2: Dr Tedros warned it was the ""twin threat"" of the two variants that was behind the overall case load.

column1: This is and will continue to put immense pressure on exhausted health workers
column2: and health systems on the brink of collapse
column3: the WHO chief added.

column1: At the moment
column2: some 900
column3: 000 new cases are being reported around the world every day

column1: Dr Anthony Fauci
column2: America's top infectious disease expert
column3: has told CNN Omicron infections are likely to peak at the end of January in the US
column4: given its population size and vaccination rate.

column1: Several wealthy nations have launched booster drives to give third doses of Covid vaccines
column2: including the UK where 57% of people over 12 have now received three jabs.

column1: This video can not be played
However
column2: Dr Tedros told reporters richer countries' large-scale booster campaigns were ""likely to prolong the pandemic""
column3: as they diverted supplies away from poorer
column5: thereby ""giving the virus more opportunity to spread and mutate"".

column1: He went on to ask ""everyone to make a New Year's resolution to get behind the campaign to vaccinate 70%"" of the world by mid-2022. Almost 100 countries are yet to meet the original target of vaccinating 40% of their populations
column2: the WHO says.

column1: According to a WHO report published on Tuesday
column2: the number of new Covid infections of all variants grew by 57% in Europe in the week before 26 December
column3: and by 30% in the Americas.

column1: Those numbers still seem to be climbing
column2: with yet more records set on Wednesday:

column1: Officials have warned that some of the high figures may be partly due to delays in reporting because of Christmas.
One effect of the record infections has been staff shortages in some essential services
column2: due to people isolating so as not to spread the virus.

column1: In Britain
column2: the Fire Brigades Union says about a third of fire engines in London were unavailable for use earlier this week because of staff testing positive for coronavirus or having to isolate.

column1: And in the US state of Texas
column2: members of the National Guard are being used in support roles at several juvenile detention centres.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: Spain - which has seen a record 1
column3: 360 cases per 100
column4: 000 over the past fortnight - cut its isolation period from 10 days to seven
column5: to alleviate staffing strains. The US has already reduced the period
column6: while the UK has said those who test negative for two days will be allowed to leave isolation after a week.

column1: US health officials have halved the recommended isolation time for people with asymptomatic Covid-19 from 10 to five days
column2: amid a surge in cases.

column1: The measure is expected to alleviate disruption caused by staff shortages in many areas because of infections.
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) says most transmissions happen in the two days before and three days after symptoms develop.
But experts have criticised the lack of testing requirements to end isolation.
The sharp rise in cases has been fuelled by the Omicron variant of the virus
column2: which is now dominant in the US. Early studies suggest Omicron is more contagious than other variants
column3: although milder.

column1: The growing number of people having to isolate has put pressure on several industries
column2: including air travel
column3: with thousands of flights cancelled during the Christmas holiday.

column1: Leaders of major US airlines were among those calling for the change
column2: as cancellations continued for a fourth day on Tuesday.

column1: The CDC said the new guidance was ""motivated by science""
column2: and that the isolation must be followed by five days of wearing a mask around others. The announcement came as more than 200
column3: 000 daily infections were confirmed in the past two days nationwide.

column1: CDC director Dr Rochelle Walensky said the recommendation ""balances what we know about the spread of the virus and the protection provided by vaccination and booster doses"".
These updates ensure people can safely continue their daily lives
column2: Dr Walensky said in a statement.

column1: This video can not be played
But there was no recommendation for people to take rapid at-home tests before the end of their isolation periods. Many experts say such tests help to show whether people continue to spread the virus.
Dr Michael Mina
column2: an assistant professor at Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health
column3: called the lack of such requirement ""reckless"".

column1: I absolutely don't want to sit next to someone who turned Positive 5 days ago and hasn't tested [negative]
column2: he said on Twitter.

column1: In England
column2: people are now required to isolate for seven days
column3: instead of 10
column4: with two negative lateral flow tests needed to end their self-isolation - the first no earlier than day six of isolation and a second 24 hours later.

column1: Speaking on CNN
column2: the top US infectious disease expert said the CDC decision would allow people to return to work more quickly
column3: calling it ""very prudent"" and a ""good choice"".

column1: With the sheer volume of new cases that we're having and that we expect to continue with Omicron
column2: one of the things we want to be careful of is that we don't have so many people out
column3: Dr Anthony Fauci
column4: who also serves as President Joe Biden's chief medical adviser

column1: Infectiousness is not like a switch. It does not just go on to off. Instead
column2: people with Covid gradually go from a period of peak infectiousness to lower infectiousness.

column1: The most infectious period starts a few days before symptoms develop. This is one of the reasons why the virus is so hard to contain. After about five days
column2: the risk of passing on the virus will start to decline for most people.

column1: But it is still possible to pass on the virus. That is why when countries started introducing isolation periods many went for 14 days. It was a belt-and-braces approach. But over time these isolation periods have been reduced
column2: reflecting the reduced threat the virus presents as vaccines have been rolled out.

column1: In England it has now been set at seven days if you are negative using a rapid test. That should give people a good idea if they have passed peak infectiousness and reflects the fact the UK has made these rapid tests easily accessible to everyone.
The US approach for people without symptoms is grounded in research that suggests these cases are likely to be less infectious to start with. At the end of the day
column2: it is all about balancing the risks - from both the virus and our responses to it.

column1: The CDC also shortened the quarantine period for people exposed to someone infected. Unvaccinated people will be required to quarantine for five days after exposure
column2: down from 14.

column1: The same applies to people who were more than six months on from their second dose of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines
column2: or two months after a Johnson & Johnson dose
column3: and had not yet received a booster shot.

column1: Last week
column2: the CDC reduced the recommended isolation time for asymptomatic health workers from 10 to seven days. But they were required to take a test to end their isolation period.

column1: While the new recommendations are not mandatory
column2: they are closely followed by many businesses and policymakers across the US.

column1: On Monday
column2: President Biden pledged to deal with a shortage of tests as Omicron threatens to overwhelm hospitals.

column1: Seeing how tough it was for some folks to get a test this weekend shows that we have more work to do
column2: he said as he joined a call with the administration's Covid response team and state governors. ""It's clearly not enough.""

column1: New steps will include improving at-home test manufacturing and making it easier to use Google to locate nearby test centres
column2: he said.

column1: Different states and local authorities in the US are introducing new measures in a bid to combat rising cases. New vaccine requirements have come into force in New York City
column2: including a vaccine mandate for private-sector workers in the city.

31;Omicron: Good news
column2: bad news and what it all means;2021-12-24T00:47:27.000Z;[];['coronavirus vaccines'
column3: 'omicron variant'

column1: The world is being hit by a tsunami of Omicron. Scientists
column2: politicians and indeed all of us are grappling with what it means for our lives.

column1: Restrictions are tightening in parts of the UK and other European countries in order to tackle the new variant.
There's a constant stream of new information - some worrying
column2: some positive. So where do we stand?

column1: It is easy to forget
column2: but we are in a much brighter place than this time last year when many of us could not meet family on Christmas Day.

column1: The ""Christmas bubble"" rules meant in parts of the country you could spend the day only with those you lived with. But there were limits on the size of gatherings across the UK.
The rise of the Alpha variant in late 2020 led to lockdowns in November and a long one in the New Year as the vaccination programme was only just getting going.
The rules currently in place or coming into force on Boxing Day in Scotland
column2: Wales and Northern Ireland are much gentler by comparison.

column1: If you catch Omicron then you are less likely to become seriously ill than with previous variants.
Studies from around the world are painting a consistent picture that Omicron is milder than the Delta variant
column2: with a 30% to 70% lower chance of people infected ending up in hospital.

column1: Omicron can cause cold-level symptoms such as a sore throat
column2: runny nose and a headache
column3: but that does not mean it will be mild for everyone and some will still be seriously ill.

column1: Changes to the virus seem to have made it less dangerous
column2: but most of the reduced severity is down to immunity as a result of vaccination and previous bouts of Covid.

column1: The worry is severity is only one half of the equation if you care about whether hospitals can cope.
If Omicron is half as likely to land you in hospital
column2: but twice as many people are infected then the two cancel out and you're back to square one.

column1: And Omicron's real talent is infecting people. It spreads faster than other variants and can bypass some of the immune protection from vaccines and prior infections.
The UK has record levels of Covid with confirmed cases on Thursday reaching nearly 120
column2: 000 - and this is an underestimate of what is really going on as not everyone gets a test and people who catch it more than once aren't included in the figures.

column1: Old age has always been the biggest risk-factor for becoming seriously ill with Covid.
In the UK
column2: most of the Omicron cases and people ending up in hospital are under the age of 40 so we do not know for sure what will happen when it reaches old and vulnerable populations.

column1: The ability of Omicron to partially evade immunity means there is the potential for more older people to be infected than during the Delta wave.
Two doses of a vaccine offer little protection against catching Omicron
column2: which led to a massive expansion of the booster campaign.

column1: Now more than 31 million people in the UK have enhanced their immune defences.
However
column2: protection against catching Omicron seems to wane after about 10 weeks. Protection against severe disease is likely to hold up much longer.

column1: New medicines should keep even more patients out of hospital.
They are being given to people who are at high risk from Covid
column2: including cancer patients and people who have had an organ transplant.

column1: Molnupiravir is an anti-viral drug that disrupts Omicron's ability to replicate inside our bodies and cuts hospital admission by 30%. Sotrovimab is an antibody therapy that sticks to the virus and cuts hospital visits by 79%.
Both suppress the virus which buys time for the immune system to react.
A surge in Omicron could put more people in hospital at the same time as taking away the people needed to care for them.
The sheer volume of people catching Omicron is also affecting doctors
column2: nurses and the rest of the NHS workforce as they have to isolate too.

column1: Nearly 19
column2: 000 NHS staff were off with Covid on 19 December
column3: which is 54% higher than the week before.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: NHS Providers
column3: which represents hospital and ambulance services in England
column4: says the health service is facing its busiest Christmas period ever. And that overall
column5: 94.5% of adult beds were occupied compared with 89% last year.

column1: The question is whether everything in our favour - milder
column2: antivirals
column3: boosters - is enough to deal with a variant that spreads faster than anything we've seen before.

column1: Or will it take more restrictions to manage the Omicron wave?
The speed this is happening means we will know very quickly how this is going to shake down.

column1: The ceremonial order

column1: Mr Blair becomes Sir Tony from 1 January

column4: public service and all parts of our society

There have been several fictional on-screen depictions of the relationship between the head of state and her former prime minister - but this might be seen as an act of personal recognition from the Queen.
Baroness Amos becomes a ""lady companion""
column2: honouring her career as international development secretary
column3: a United Nations under-secretary for humanitarian affairs. and her current role - master of University College

column1: She is the first black member appointed to the order in more than 700 years.
Baroness Amos
column2: 67 and Tony Blair
column4: become two of the order's younger members
column7: in a post held until death.

column1: Camilla
column2: the Duchess of Cornwall
column3: is appointed as a ""royal companion"" - a move likely to be seen as showing the Queen's endorsement for Camilla's role as a senior member of the royal family and spouse of the future monarch.

column1: The duchess has had an increasingly high profile with her own campaigns

column1: The order

column1: The modern criteria

column4: who have contributed in a particular way to national life or who have served the sovereign personally"".

column1: A banner of the heraldic arms of the knights are on display at St George's Chapel at the castle.

column1: 37;Why it matters No 10's press chief was at the Downing Street party;2021-12-09T23:16:19.000Z;[];['conservative party'
column2: 'boris johnson'];['matters'
column3: 'quit'

column1: There have already been many twists and turns in the saga of the Downing Street party
column2: or ""gathering"" as government ministers have now taken to calling it.

column1: There's been a resignation already
column2: leaked footage
column3: questions in Parliament and now a formal investigation.

column1: Why therefore does it matter that we know the identity of one of those who was there?
Well it's understood that Jack Doyle
column2: the current Downing Street director of communications was
column3: and he made a speech to as many as 30 people in the press team and handed out a series of awards.

column1: We've been told that it was a weekly occurrence for him to thank staff each Friday night.
But on that evening of 18 December last year he gave out multiple
column2: light-hearted awards and we've been told there was food
column3: drink
column4: and party games. We've also been told the event went on past midnight.

column1: There is now an official investigation into what happened. And at the heart of government there is no desire for other staff to quit or be forced out before it has run its course.
There is still a determination to challenge the assertion that the gathering of several dozen people was really a party
column2: rather than a permitted get-together of work colleagues.

column1: There is no question that the press team in No 10 work hard and put in extremely long hours. At that point in time they were dealing with the pandemic and the final crescendo of the Brexit talks too.
But other sources in Westminster are now questioning whether it is possible for Mr Doyle to stay in his job.
In part that's because one of the problems this week for No 10 has been their efforts to deny and explain what did or didn't happen.
Ministers
column2: and the prime minister himself have been stuck in the Kafka-esque position of saying that they are sure no rules were broken
column3: but they also don't know what went on.

column1: If they don't know what happened
column2: how can they be sure that nothing went wrong?

column1: And if multiple sources have said there was a gathering of several dozen people
column2: and people who were not on the Downing Street payroll were invited
column3: how can that have been just a few work drinks at the desk in a Covid-secure office?

column1: Mr Doyle
column2: well liked by his colleagues
column3: is - as director of communications - in charge of the government's messaging.

column1: This week that message has misfired
column2: which makes his confirmed attendance a very big problem.

column1: And as government spinners over the years have often found
column2: there is one fundamental error which they cannot make. That's to become part of the story themselves
column3: an uncomfortable position that Boris Johnson's press chief now finds himself in.

column1: For governments to function
column2: the public has to be able to put their faith in the message they are hearing day to day.

column1: When that falters
column2: as it has this last few torrid days
column3: that can be costly for a government.

column1: Right now that's a price that the prime minister can ill afford.

column1: South Africa has lifted overnight curfew rules
column2: with officials saying the country may have passed the peak of its fourth wave of Covid-19 infections.

column1: A government statement said the Omicron variant
column2: while highly transmissible
column3: had seen lower hospitalisation rates than previous waves.

column1: There had been a marginal increase in the number of deaths
column2: it added.

column1: The variant - first reported by South Africa last month - is spreading fast elsewhere leading to widespread curbs.
The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of a ""tsunami"" of infections from Delta and Omicron variants that could overwhelm health systems.
But in South Africa
column2: a statement released after a special cabinet meeting said cases and hospital admission rates had dropped in almost all provinces across the country.

column1: For the week ending 25 December 2021
column2: the number of confirmed infections stood at 89
column3: 781 - down from 127

column1: The changes announced include lifting restrictions on movement between midnight and 04:00. Businesses will also be allowed to sell alcohol under normal licensing rules
column2: instead of closing at 23:00.

column1: Overnight curfew rules of varying severities have been in place since a national state of disaster was declared in late March 2020.
The country still has ""spare capacity for admission of patients even for routine health services"" despite the Omicron wave
column2: officials said.

column1: The public are still being urged to get vaccinated and follow public health protocols
column2: including mandatory mask-wearing.

column1: Gatherings remain capped at 1

column1: California's giant sequoias are symbols of permanence - with some living for thousands of years. But the fierce wildfires ravaging the state threaten even these mighty trees
column2: which are among the longest-lived organisms on Earth.

column1: There is something primeval about giant sequoias. Their weird
column2: broccoli-like branches wouldn't seem out of place with a long-necked dinosaur plodding by.

column1: And they are impossibly big: 30 or 40 people would have to link hands to hug the largest ones. The tallest trees are 90m (295ft) high. That's like a 30-storey tower block.
They make you feel deep time""
column2: sighs Christy Bingham
column3: as she looks up at the biggest tree in the world - known as the General Sherman.

column1: You can just sense standing here that this tree was born before Jesus.""
Christy lowers her voice as she says this
column2: as if out of respect. She's in charge of conserving these magnificent trees in the Sequoia National Park in the Sierra Nevada mountains - their last redoubt.

column1: Sequoias live so long because they are exquisitely adapted to their environment
column2: Christy tells me.

column1: There have always been fires in California and
column2: in response
column3: sequoias have developed insulating bark which can be up to a metre thick and which stops all but the hottest fires damaging the trees.

column1: But California's fires are changing. Christy leads me deeper into the forest
column2: to show me what she means.

column1: All you can hear is the sound of the wind in the leaves
column2: the occasional cry of a raven and our footsteps crunching in the leaf litter. It is heaven. Until
column3: that is
column4: we walk over a ridge and the scene changes dramatically.

column1: This is what I wanted to show you
column2: this was a giant sequoia grove""
column3: she says. The landscape is monochrome now: grey or black
column4: ash or cinders. Many of the huge trees have been reduced to columns of charcoal.

column1: Before 2015 no one saw a sequoia that looked like this
column2: says Christy. She is crying now. ""You never saw a tree become a candle and burn up in this way before."" She points to the blackened remains of one of the biggest trees.

column1: This 1
column3: 000-year-old tree should have lived another 500 to 800 years but it's gone.""

column1: Christy wipes her tears with the sleeve of her jacket. ""It will not sequester any more carbon. It will not be a spotted owl house. It's dead.""

It isn't just California's trees that have been suffering. Several hours' drive north we visit the Gold Rush-era town of Greenville. It used to be famous for its Wild West-style clapboard shops and its white painted church with its elegant wooden spire.
All that is gone now
column2: incinerated in the massive Dixie Fire this summer which burnt a million acres and cost some 600 million dollars to fight.

column1: Nichoel Farris tells me how she got a text telling her to get out of town. An hour later the whole place - 1
column2: 500 buildings in total - had been erased
column3: and her ""forever home"" with it.

column1: It took all the colour out of my life. Look
column2: everything is just a shade of grey""
column3: says Nichoel
column4: gesturing towards the ashes of her house. ""We lost the future we'd planned for and built."" She's crying now. ""We lost our story""

column1: But Nichoel hasn't lost all hope. She talks about how she wants to see the town rebuilt using the latest fire protection knowhow. She and her husband grew 80% of their food on their land and she hopes others will do the same.
Greenville could actually be a lighthouse community of sustainability and climate adaptation. And how we live in our new normal - because big fires are now the new normal
column2: she says.

column1: And
column2: in the forest
column3: Christy hasn't given up hope either. She expects to see baby sequoias sprouting here next year. They like burnt soil. And she says the forests need to be better managed
column4: with dead wood and brush that can fuel fires cleared away.

column1: What's more
column2: a few of the trees
column3: even here amongst the destruction
column4: will survive. Christy starts to scrape with her fingers at the charred bark of a giant sequoia at the very edge of the grove.

column1: Not far in - about an inch or a couple of centimetres - and the charcoal gives way to reddish bark. ""This is just surface damage
column2: she says. ""Look up at the leaves
column3: lots of them have survived. This tree will live!""

column1: The resilience of the sequoias should inspire us
column2: says Christy: ""It is telling us we need to act on climate change now and that every little bit counts"". She turns to look me in the eye.

column1: Every carbon reduction will help these forests persist
column2: she says. And I notice her smile has returned as we walk on through the trees.

column1: The heavily mutated Omicron variant has led to a serious dent in the ability of vaccines to protect us from catching the Covid virus.
Two doses of some vaccines offer almost no protection from an Omicron infection
column2: although they should still greatly reduce the risk of becoming so ill you need hospital care.

column1: The vaccines were all developed to fight the first form of the virus that emerged two years ago.
So can a third or ""booster"" dose of those original vaccines make the difference or has Omicron already outwitted the protection they can give?
Fortunately for us - while the contents of the syringe may be identical
column2: a booster is not just more of the same for the immune system.

column1: The protection you're left with after the third dose is bigger
column2: broader and more memorable than you had before.

column1: Fighting coronavirus is something your immune system has to learn.
One option is to figure it out on the job when you encounter the virus for real. However
column2: there is a risk of getting it wrong and ending up seriously ill.

column1: Vaccines are more like a school - a safer environment to further your immune system's Covid education.
The first dose is the primary school education that nails the fundamentals.

Your second and third doses are comparable to sending your immune system to secondary school and then university to dramatically deepen its understanding. It's not just repeating primary school over and over.
The immune system is left with a richer knowledge and understanding of the virus
column2: said Prof Jonathan Ball
column3: a virologist from the University of Nottingham.

column1: He said for all the talk of the dastardly tricks of Omicron
column2: a highly-trained immune system is ""an incredibly difficult and hostile environment"" for the virus and its variants.

column1: Antibodies are a major beneficiary of this education.

These are the sticky proteins that attach themselves to the outside of the coronavirus. Neutralising antibodies can gum up the virus so it can't invade your cells. Others sit there as the biological equivalent of a flashing neon sign spelling out ""kill this virus"".
A flurry of laboratory studies and real world data showed the neutralising antibodies you have after two doses of a Covid vaccine were far less effective against Omicron.
Prof Danny Altmann
column2: an immunologist from Imperial College London
column3: said you were left with ""absolutely zilch"" and were a ""sitting duck for infection"".

column1: So back to school.

Every dose of the vaccine triggers another round of antibody evolution within the immune system. It seeks out better antibodies that attach themselves more firmly to the virus. It's a process called affinity maturation.
Your antibodies are a better fit as time goes on
column2: they are getting fancier and more sophisticated
column3: said Prof Altmann.

column1: If the antibodies are able to bind more tightly to the coronavirus then it will be harder for Omicron's mutations to help it wriggle free. And while the new variant is heavily mutated
column2: it is still the same fundamental virus and has parts that have not changed at all.

column1: Further rounds of vaccination also lead to the immune system broadening its antibody repertoire as it finds new ways of attacking the virus.
It's not just about the quality of antibodies
column2: the quantity goes up with boosting too.

column1: Prof Charles Bangham
column2: from Imperial
column3: said: ""You get more of them
column4: the concentration in the blood increases and we don't know how long this is going to last
column5: but the more times you're vaccinated the longer-lasting the immune memory is.""

column1: The impact of all this is clear in the same studies that showed two doses were weaker against Omicron. The protection against getting any Covid symptoms shot up to around 75% after the booster.
Elsewhere in the immune system
column2: boosting is giving our bodies the upper hand against future variants too.

column1: B-cells are the part of the body that mass produce antibodies. Some mature to produce those super-sticky
column2: highly refined antibodies after boosting. Others can spot coronavirus
column3: but remain half-baked and flexible.

column1: These can go off in different directions and when they proliferate they start to go after the new variant
column2: said Prof Ball.

column1: And then there's T-cells
column2: which again become more plentiful and better at attacking Covid viruses in response to boosting.

column1: T-cells use a different trick to spot the virus and patrol our body looking for any sign of cells being infected with Covid. T-cells recognise parts of the coronavirus that the virus finds harder to mutate.
So while Omicron is squirming away from our immune system
column2: each vaccine dose and indeed each infection is giving our body's defences more tools to hunt it down.

column1: All this bodes well for vaccines protecting us from becoming seriously ill.
Immunity against a virus is almost never absolute - you can almost always get re-infected and what you want to do is get re-infection so trivial you don't know you've got it or it's very mild
column2: said Prof Bangham.

column1: Scientists are warning of dramatic changes at one of the biggest glaciers in Antarctica
column2: potentially within the next five to 10 years.

column1: They say a floating section at the front of Thwaites Glacier that until now has been relatively stable could ""shatter like a car windscreen"".
US and UK researchers are currently engaged in an intense study programme at Thwaites because of its melt rate.
Already it is dumping 50 billion tonnes of ice into the ocean each year.
This is having limited impact on global sea-levels today
column2: but there is sufficient ice held upstream in the glacier's drainage basin to raise the height of the oceans by 65cm - were it all to melt.

column1: Such a ""doomsday"" scenario is unlikely to come about for many centuries
column2: but the study team says Thwaites is now responding to a warming world in really quite rapid ways.

column1: There is going to be dramatic change in the front of the glacier
column2: probably in less than a decade. Both published and unpublished studies point in that direction
column3: said glaciologist Prof Ted Scambos
column4: US lead coordinator for the International Thwaites Glacier Collaboration (ITGC).

column1: This will accelerate the pace (of Thwaites) and widen
column2: effectively
column3: the dangerous part of the glacier

column1: Thwaites is a colossus. It's roughly the size of Great Britain
column2: or Florida
column3: and its outflow speed has doubled in the past 30 years.

column1: The ITGC has established how this is happening. It is the result of warm ocean water getting under - and melting - Thwaites's floating front
column2: or ice shelf as it's known.

column1: The warm water is thinning and weakening this ice
column2: making it run faster and pushing back the zone where the main glacier body becomes buoyant.

column1: At the moment
column2: the leading edge of the eastern ice shelf is pinned in place by an offshore underwater ridge
column3: which means its flow speed is a third of that seen in the ice shelf's western sector which has no such constraint.

column1: But the ITGC team says the eastern shelf is likely to become uncoupled from the ridge in the next few years which will destabilise it. And even if the pinning persists
column2: the ongoing development of fractures in the shelf ice will almost certainly break up the area anyway.

column1: This video can not be played
I visualise it somewhat similar to that car window where you have a few cracks that are slowly propagating
column2: and then suddenly you go over a bump in your car and the whole thing just starts to shatter in every direction
column3: explained Dr Erin Pettit from Oregon State University.

column1: The affected area is very small when considered in the context of the glacier as a whole
column2: but it is the shift to a new regime and what this means for further ice loss that is the real significance.

column1: At present
column2: the eastern shelf
column3: which has a width of about 40km
column4: moves forward at about 600m per year. The coming change in status will probably see the following ice jump in speed to about 2km per year - the same as the current velocity recorded in the 80km-wide western sector.

column1: Jointly funded by the US National Science Foundation and the UK's Natural Environment Research Council
column2: the five-year ITGC project is putting Thwaites under unprecedented scrutiny.

column1: Each Antarctic summer season
column2: teams of scientists are investigating the glacier's behaviour in every way possible. From satellite
column3: on the ice
column4: and from ships in front of Thwaites.

column1: Those teams are en route for the new season right now
column2: some in Covid quarantine ahead of their deployment to the field.

column1: One of the projects for the New Year will see the tubby yellow submarine known as ""Boaty McBoatface"" dive under Thwaites' floating ice to gather data on water temperature
column2: current direction and turbulence - all factors that influence melting.

column1: The autonomous vehicle will go on missions lasting one to four days
column2: navigating its own path through the cavity beneath the shelf. This is high risk as the seafloor terrain is extremely rugged.

column1: It's scary. We might not get Boaty back
column2: conceded Dr Alex Phillips from the UK's National Oceanography Centre.

column1: We've put a lot of effort this past year into developing collision avoidance for the vehicle
column2: to make sure it doesn't crash into the seabed. We also have contingencies whereby if it does get into trouble
column3: it can retrace its steps and retreat to safety.""

column1: The latest science on Thwaites Glacier is being presented this week at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting in New Orleans.
