Sony has said its £50m investment in the Welsh makers of His Dark Materials could propel it to become Europe's biggest drama producer.
Cardiff-based Bad Wolf sold a majority stake to Sony Pictures and said the deal would allow it to expand.
Sony's Wayne Garvie said Bad Wolf had yet to reach its ""zenith"" and would continue to grow.
It is the largest UK production company outside London and will co-produce Doctor Who with the BBC from 2023.
The investment by Sony Pictures is understood to be between £50m and £60m.
Mr Garvie
column2: Sony Pictures' president of international production
column3: worked with Bad Wolf founders Jane Tranter and Julie Gardner at the BBC.

column1: Tranter and Gardner were responsible for bringing the production of Doctor Who to Cardiff in 2005
column2: and cited that positive experience as one of the reasons why they established Bad Wolf in Splott in 2015.

column1: The name Bad Wolf is a reference to an entity in the first series of Doctor Who that was made in Wales.
Since 2015
column2: it has produced the Philip Pullman trilogy His Dark Materials
column3: the drama Industry for the BBC - which it has just finished the second series of - as well as A Discovery of Witches for Sky.

column1: Mr Garvie said: ""We have invested in a company that has not reached its zenith.
We have [another] company called Left Bank Pictures who make The Crown
column2: which you may have watched
column3: and which is Britain's biggest drama company. And we built that together with the founders of the company over about eight years or so.

column1: And we want to do the same with Bad Wolf. There is no reason why Bad Wolf should not be or could not be the biggest drama producer in Britain and in Europe. And that is our ambition.""
Mr Garvie said Wales' recent history in producing high-end TV and film helped the decision to invest.
One of the things we found really attractive about Bad Wolf was the passion they had for Wales
column2: the people in Wales and their commitment to Wales
column3: he added.

column1: Tranter
column2: Bad Wolf's chief executive
column3: said: ""The kind of television dramas that Bad Wolf produces are huge. It is a very scary thing to do.

column1: We love it
column2: and we want to go on and do bigger shows. But there comes a point when we have to acknowledge that in order to produce on an increasing scale and ambition
column3: we need to take a partner and collaborator and investor with us on that journey.""

column1: Ms Tranter said Sony's experience would help ""stabilise"" the company
column2: but she wanted the investment to propel it into the ""next phase of its journey"".

column1: Tom Ware
column2: director of production and performance at the University of South Wales (USW)
column3: said Bad Wolf had boosted the creative industries.

column1: The kind of content they produce - big
column2: high-end TV dramas that can be distributed globally - has put Welsh screen industries on the map.

column1: It has also contributed massively to the development of talent across a wide range of areas - obviously production
column2: but also animation
column3: visual effects and lots of other areas of the screen industries that were here before they came
column4: but Bad Wolf's presence has kick-started their development.""

column1: To address sometimes chronic shortages of crews

column1: Mr Ware said more than 100 USW graduates had gone on to work at the production company
column2: adding: ""It has been great for all educational institutions in Wales
column3: but more to the point it has been a huge boost for the Welsh economy.""

50;Omicron: Three vaccine doses key for protection against variant;2021-12-10T20:34:44.000Z;[];['coronavirus vaccines'
column2: 'omicron variant'

column1: Two doses of a Covid vaccine are not enough to stop you catching the Omicron variant
column2: UK scientists have warned.

column1: Early analysis of UK Omicron and Delta cases showed the vaccines were less effective at stopping the new variant.
But a third booster prevents around 75% of people getting any Covid symptoms.
Meanwhile
column2: Levelling Up Secretary Michael Gove
column3: who chaired a meeting with first ministers of the devolved nations this afternoon
column4: warned the UK faces a ""deeply concerning situation"".

column1: Speaking after the meeting of the government's emergency committee Cobra
column2: he said measures taken so far were ""proportionate""
column3: but ministers were ""absolutely"" keeping everything under review.

column1: Action is absolutely required
column2: and as new data comes in we will consider what action we do require to take in the face of that data
column3: he added.

column1: It comes as another 448 cases of Omicron were confirmed in the UK
column2: taking the number reported so far to 1
column3: 265. The total number of Covid cases recorded on Friday was 58

column1: The government has said it is updating its guidance for care homes in England - limiting the number of visitors allowed per resident
column2: and increasing testing ""in order to balance the current Covid-19 risk"".

column1: One of the main concerns since the heavily-mutated Omicron variant first emerged was that it would make vaccines less effective.
The UK Health Security Agency report analysed data from 581 Omicron cases and thousands of Delta cases to calculate how effective the vaccines were against the new variant.
The analysis is based on limited data
column2: but showed a dramatic drop in effectiveness for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine and a significant drop off for two doses of Pfizer.

column1: The 75% protection against Covid symptoms after a booster is not as high as against previous variants.
There was not enough data to analyse the Moderna or Janssen vaccines
column2: but there is no reason to think they would have different results.

column1: However
column2: the UK Health Security Agency said vaccines were still likely to offer good protection against severe Covid that needed hospital treatment.

column1: So far
column2: around 22 million people have received a booster dose
column3: but even if everyone was boosted the lower vaccine effectiveness would still leave millions of people susceptible.

column1: The real-world data backs up laboratory studies that showed a 40-fold reduction in the ability of antibodies from double-vaccinated people to take out the virus.
There is optimism that vaccines will still keep many people out of hospital even if more do get Covid. Data on severity could be published next week.
However
column2: an Omicron wave could be problematic even if it was milder. A large and sudden wave could lead to everyone who is still vulnerable needing hospital care at the same time.

column1: The rapid surge in Omicron cases was already hinting that the variant was getting around some of the protection given by vaccines.
It is estimated that the number of Omicron cases is doubling every two to three days.
The UKHSA estimates that more than half of all cases in the country will be Omicron by mid-December and that if growth continues unabated there will be more than 100
column2: 000 cases a day by the end of the month.

column1: Dr Mary Ramsay
column2: head of immunisation at the UKHSA
column3: said: ""These early estimates should be treated with caution but they indicate that a few months after the second jab
column4: there is a greater risk of catching the Omicron variant compared to Delta strain.""

column1: We expect the vaccines to show higher protection against the serious complications of COVID-19
column2: so if you haven't yet had your first two doses please book an appointment straight away.""

column1: The research comes amid concern about the growing numbers of Omicron cases in the UK. Scotland's First Minister
column2: Nicola Sturgeon
column3: has warned of a ""tsunami"" of cases as she tightened Covid isolation rules and encouraged people to cancel Christmas party plans.

column1: Under the new guidance for care homes in England
column2: residents will only be permitted to receive visits from three people
column3: plus one essential care giver.

column1: The Department of Health and Social Care said testing would also increase for fully-vaccinated residents making visits outside and for staff
column2: and there vaccination teams were being expanded to increase the take-up of the booster jab.

column3: 'kim'

column1: North Korea's leader Kim Jong-un has said the faltering economy will be the national priority this year as the country faces a ""great life-and-death struggle"".
He was speaking at the end of a key ruling party meeting
column2: which coincides with him being in power for 10 years.

column1: A self-imposed coronavirus blockade has left North Korea struggling with food shortages.
There was no direct mention of the US or South Korea in his speech.
Mr Kim said increasing development and improving people's living standards was the main task.
He acknowledged the ""harsh situation"" in 2021 and and set ""an important task for making radical progress in solving the food
column2: clothing and housing problem for the people""
column3: the official Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported.

column1: He said battling the pandemic was one of the main goals for the coming year: ""Emergency epidemic prevention work should be made a top priority in the state work
column2: he is quoted as saying by KCNA.

column1: But he also said Pyongyang would continue to strengthen its defence capabilities because of an increasingly unstable military environment on the Korean peninsula.
He was speaking on Friday at the end of the 4th Plenary Meeting of the 8th Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK)
column2: which began on Monday.

column1: There were reports earlier this year that people in the country were going hungry
column2: giving rise to concerns as winter approached about a full-blown food crisis.

column1: The border has been closed since January 2020 to prevent the spread of Covid-19 from China.
Following a year in which leader Kim Jong-un repeatedly stressed North Korea's dire economic condition and food shortages
column2: these challenges were once again in the spotlight at the ruling Workers' Party's year-end plenum.

column1: Kim's warning of a ""great life-or-death struggle"" in 2022 echoes last April's rhetoric urging officials to prepare for another ""Arduous March""
column2: referencing North Korea's greatest economic crisis and famine in the 1990s.

column1: While such comparisons overexaggerate the situation
column2: North Korea's economic woes have indeed been exacerbated by Covid-19-related border closures
column3: international sanctions and natural disasters.

column1: These have all contributed to what Kim described in June as a ""tense"" food situation
column2: and international agencies also warn of growing food insecurity and starvation.

column1: Kim's emphasis on implementation of the national economic plan
column2: rural development and advancing ""scientific farming"" now serves to remind citizens that their leader is prioritising their needs
column3: while setting expectations for another year of economic struggles.

column1: Mr Kim's new year speeches have previously included messages to South Korea and the US
column2: but there were no explicit mentions this time.

column1: If we consider this report on the plenum as a replacement of Kim Jong-un's annual New Year's speech
column2: it can be said that it's by far the shortest mention of inter-Korean relations and foreign policy ever
column3: Cheong Seong-chang
column4: a senior researcher at Sejong Institute

column1: At the end of last year
column2: North and South Korea
column3: the US
column4: and China agreed in principle to declare a formal end to the Korean War which ended in an armistice.

column1: But talks have yet to begin because of North Korea's demands
column2: South Korea has said.

column1: A new law banning plastic packaging on most fruit and vegetables comes into effect in France from New Year's day.
Cucumbers
column2: lemons and oranges are among the 30 varieties banned from being wrapped in plastic.

column1: Larger packs as well as chopped or processed fruit will be exempt.
President Emmanuel Macron called the ban ""a real revolution"" and said it showed the country's commitment to phase out single use plastics by 2040.
More than a third of fruit and vegetable products in France are thought to be sold in plastic wrapping
column2: and government officials believe that the ban could prevent a billion items of single use plastics being used every year.

column1: In a statement announcing the new law
column2: the Environment Ministry said that France uses an ""outrageous amount"" of single use plastics and that the new ban ""aims at cutting back the use of throwaway plastic and boost its substitution by other materials or reusable and recyclable packaging"".

column1: The ban forms part of a multi-year programme introduced by Mr Macron's government that will see plastics slowly eased out in many industries.
From 2021
column2: the country banned plastic straws
column3: cups and cutlery
column4: as well as polystyrene takeaway boxes.

column1: And later in 2022 public spaces will be forced to provide water fountains to reduce the use of plastic bottles
column2: publications will have to be shipped without plastic wrapping
column3: and fast-food restaurants will no longer be able offer free plastic toys.

column1: However
column2: industry figures have expressed concerns over the speed at which the new ban is being introduced.

column1: Philippe Binard
column2: from the European Fresh Produce Association
column3: said the ""removal of plastic packaging from most fruit and vegetables at such short notice does not allow alternatives to be tested and introduced in a timely manner and stocks of existing packaging to be cleared"".

column1: Several other European countries have announced similar bans in recent months as they pursue commitments made at the recent COP26 conference in Glasgow.
Earlier this month Spain announced that it will introduce a ban on the sale of fruit and vegetables in plastic packaging from 2023 to allow business to find alternative solutions.
Mr Macron's government also announced several other new environmental regulations
column2: including rules calling on car adverts to promote greener alternatives such as walking and cycling.

column1: At least 12 people were killed and several others injured after a stampede at a religious shrine in India.
Pilgrims were visiting the shrine of Mata Vaishno Devi in Indian-administered Kashmir on Saturday when the tragedy unfolded.
Prime Minister Narendra Modi said he was ""saddened"" by the loss of life.
Tens of thousands of people usually visit the shrine every day
column2: and it is thought there was a peak in visitors because of the holiday season.

column1: According to a senior police officer
column2: 14 people were injured in the stampede
column3: with all of them taken to hospital.

column1: One senior government official told AFP news agency that the death toll could rise as the shrine was incredibly busy with people trying to visit for the New Year.
The shrine
column2: located near the town of Katra
column3: is among India's most revered pilgrimage sites. Visitor numbers have been capped to around 25

column1: It is not yet clear caused the stampede in the early hours of the morning
column2: but some eyewitnesses claimed crowds at the site were not being managed properly.

column1: An investigation into the incident has been launched.
In a tweet
column2: Mr Modi said: ""Extremely saddened by the loss of lives due to a stampede at Mata Vaishno Devi Bhawan. May the injured recover soon.""

column1: 59;New Year's Day is warmest on record in the UK
column2: Met Office says;2022-01-01T15:36:07.000Z;[];['met office'];['north'
column3: 'real'

column1: The UK is having the warmest New Year's Day on record
column2: with new high temperatures set for the second day in a row
column3: the Met Office says.

column1: St James's Park in central London saw temperatures of 16.2C (61.2F) on Saturday as 2022 was ushered in.
Warm air from the Azores has been reaching the UK in recent days
column2: bringing unusually mild weather.

column1: The previous New Year's Day record was set in 1916
column2: when it reached 15.6C (60.1F) in Bude
column3: Cornwall.

column1: Saturday's record is still provisional as temperatures could get even higher as the day progresses.
Friday became the warmest New Year's Eve on record.

BBC weather forecaster Ben Rich said: ""We've had winds coming from the south and south west bringing very warm air from the Azores - nearly all the way from the tropics - wafting across the UK and it's that which has lifted the temperatures.
It's been with us for a few days now and warming up day by day.""
Sunday will be a little colder but temperatures will be still well above normal for this time of year
column2: he added.

column1: The mild weather currently being seen is widespread across the UK
column2: he added.

column1: Around Tuesday it will be much colder as the southerly winds are replaced by northerly winds
column2: he said. ""There could be some wintery showers
column3: especially in the north of the UK. It will be a real change.""

column1: It will drop to somewhere between 6C and 9C
column2: he said - in line with the average temperatures of 7C or 8C for the start of January.

column1: In Edinburgh
column2: it could get to as low as 3C on Tuesday.

column1: The Met Office say the UK's record temperatures have all been elevated by manmade climate change which has raised temperatures globally by 1.1C.
Cold records are still being broken
column2: as in the Beast from the East storm in 2018.

column1: But the Met Office say warm weather records are being broken nine times more frequently - a clear sign of an over-heating planet.
The winter wildfires in Colorado are arguably even more alarming than unseasonal warmth in the UK.
It's too soon to say what role human-driven climate change may have played in the disaster - but it's the latest episode of regular weather patterns being disrupted.
Meanwhile
column2: different regions of Alaska are experiencing record high and low temperatures at the same time.

column1: Climate scientists warn that we can expect many more extremes as the planet continues to heat. And attempts to reduce emissions have been undermined by several factors
column2: including President Biden's struggle with climate policies in the USA.

column1: The Met Office said Scotland had also recorded its warmest New Year's Day temperature
column2: which was 15.9C in Achnagart in the Highlands.

column1: The previous record was 14.5C in Inverurie in 1992.
Overnight on Friday
column2: it reached 16.5C in Bala
column3: Gwynedd
column5: making it the hottest New Year's Eve on record.

column1: It has been so warm that the skating rink at London's Somerset House had to close on New Year's Day because the ice was being affected.

60;South Africa holds state funeral for Archbishop Desmond Tutu;2022-01-01T13:14:50.000Z;[];['apartheid'
column2: 'desmond tutu'

column1: This video can not be played
The funeral mass for South African anti-apartheid campaigner Archbishop Desmond Tutu has taken place at the Anglican cathedral in Cape Town.
Tutu
column2: a Nobel Peace Prize winner who helped end the racist regime in South Africa
column3: died last Sunday aged 90.

column1: In his eulogy
column2: President Cyril Ramaphosa described Tutu as ""the spiritual father of our new nation"".

column1: Tutu had insisted there should be no ""lavish spending"" on the funeral. He wanted ""the cheapest available coffin"".
Family
column2: friends
column3: clergy and politicians were among those who gathered at St George's Cathedral for Saturday's service
column4: which had limited numbers because of coronavirus restrictions. Tutu's widow Nomalizo Leah sat in a wheelchair at the front of the congregation wearing a purple shawl - the colour of her late husband's clerical robes.

column1: Tutu was one of the driving forces behind the movement to end the policy of racial segregation and discrimination enforced by the white minority government against the black majority in South Africa from 1948 until 1991.
In the main eulogy at the official state funeral on Saturday
column2: Mr Ramaphosa described the archbishop as a ""crusader in the struggle for freedom
column3: for justice
column4: for equality and for peace. Not only in South Africa… but around the world as well"".

column1: If we are to understand a global icon to be someone of great moral stature
column2: of exceptional qualities
column3: and of service to humanity there can be no doubt that it refers to the man we're laying to rest today

column1: Saturday's funeral was given a special status
column2: usually designated for presidents and very important people.

column1: Tutu had requested that the only flowers in the cathedral should be a ""bouquet of carnations from his family""
column2: according to the Archbishop Tutu IP Trust and the Desmond and Leah Tutu Legacy Foundation.

column1: His ashes are to be interred behind the pulpit at St George's Cathedral - the Anglican diocese he served as Archbishop for 35 years.
It was earlier revealed that Tutu is to be aquamated - a process using water that is described as an environmentally friendly alternative to cremation.
Nomsa Maseko
column2: BBC News
column3: Cape Town

column1: Even though only 100 invited guests physically attended Archbishop Desmond Tutu's funeral service at the St George's cathedral
column2: many turned up to honour him by watching proceedings from public viewing areas. Most were visibly emotional.

column1: One man described his attendance of Tutu's funeral as a full-circle moment because he also witnessed the release of Nelson Mandela from prison and watched Tutu and Mandela hold hands with their fists in the air as South Africa became a democracy.
It's the end of an era.
The last of South Africa's well-known freedom fighters leaves behind a difficult task for the leaders of the nation: to rid the country of corruption and racial divisions and lead the way forward
column2: in the spirit of the moral compass which was the guiding force of Tutu's leadership.

column1: In a video message at the mass
column2: the Archbishop of Canterbury described how Tutu ""lit up the world"". He said that his paying tribute to Tutu was ""like a mouse giving a tribute to an elephant"".

column1: Tutu's daughter said the outpouring of love for her father had ""warmed the cockles of our hearts"".
Because we shared him with the world
column2: you share part of the love you held for him with us
column3: she said.

column1: Many people in Cape Town turned up to file past the archbishop's coffin as it lay in state.
One man
column2: Wally Mdluli
column3: hitchhiked more than 1
column4: 000km (620 miles) across the country from Bloemfontein to Cape Town - enlisting the help of family and friends to pay for some of the trip and even sleeping at a petrol station on the way.

column1: I feel fulfilled after I saw the coffin. It's like his spirit is in me
column2: he told the BBC's Nomsa Maseko in Cape Town.

column1: Tutu used his high profile to speak out against the oppression of black people in his home country
column2: always saying his motives were religious and not political.

column1: After Nelson Mandela became South Africa's first black president in 1994
column2: Tutu was appointed by him to a Truth and Reconciliation Commission set up to investigate crimes committed by both white and black people during the apartheid era.

column1: Tutu was awarded the Nobel prize in 1984 for his role in the struggle to abolish the apartheid system.
He was also credited with coining the term Rainbow Nation to describe the ethnic mix of post-apartheid South Africa
column2: but in his latter years he expressed regret that the nation had not coalesced in the way in which he had dreamt.

column1: The United Arab Emirates has announced that it will ban citizens who have not had three doses of a vaccine against Covid-19 from travelling abroad.
Officials said the exit ban
column2: which comes into force on 10 January
column3: would not apply to those who are medically exempt from receiving the vaccine.

column1: It is the latest country to announce new curbs amid a rise in infections.
Many countries impose strict restrictions on unvaccinated people before they are allowed in.
This varies from a requirement for a negative Covid test before travel to mandatory quarantine upon arrival.
More than 90% of the population in the UAE has been fully vaccinated against Covid-19. About 34% had received the booster jab as of 24 December
column2: according to Our World in Data.

column1: Studies have found that a booster shot offers better protection against the heavily-mutated Omicron variant.
column2: which has been spreading rapidly in countries around the world.

column1: The new travel rules in the UAE were announced by the National Emergency Crisis and Disaster Management Authority and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
They were devised to ""ensure that health and safety are prioritised""
column2: the Emirates News Agency reported.

column1: They said the ban on unvaccinated passengers would also be lifted in ""humanitarian cases"" and in cases where people were travelling for medical treatment.
Foreign workers make up the vast majority of the resident population in the Gulf state and will not be affected by the new restrictions
column2: which only apply to citizens.

column1: Fireworks have killed three people and injured scores others in Europe despite bans being in place against their use.
In the Netherlands
column2: a 12-year-old boy was killed and another seriously injured watching an adult set off a home-made device
column3: local media reported.

column1: Dutch police have arrested a man.
In Germany
column2: a 37-year-old man was killed in a fireworks explosion on New Year's Eve in the western town of Hennef. Police are investigating.

column1: There were several people injured in incidents around Germany
column2: German news agency DPA reported

column1: At least 80 people were hurt by fireworks in the Netherlands
column2: according to De Telegraaf
column3: including people losing feet and hands in explosions.

column1: Both the Netherlands and Germany banned the sale of fireworks over the New Year period because of the coronavirus pandemic.
Dutch officials justified the move by saying firework-related injuries would put too much strain on hospitals fighting the virus.
Despite this
column2: enthusiasts in both countries have not been deterred
column3: with people crossing borders to buy up festive pyrotechnics or in some cases making them themselves.

column1: In Austria there were also several incidents
column2: including one in which a 23-year-old man was killed returning to a firework that did not detonate.

column1: A Belgian scientific research station in Antarctica is dealing with an outbreak of Covid-19
column2: despite workers being fully vaccinated and based in one of the world's remotest regions.

column1: Since 14 December
column2: at least 16 of the 25 workers at the Princess Elisabeth Polar Station have caught the virus.

column1: Officials say cases remain mild so far.
The situation isn't dramatic
column2: Joseph Cheek
column3: a project manager for the International Polar Foundation

column1: While it has been an inconvenience to have to quarantine certain members of the staff who caught the virus
column2: it hasn't significantly affected our work at the station overall
column3: Mr Cheek said.

column1: All residents of the station were offered the opportunity to leave on a scheduled flight on 12 January. However
column2: they all expressed their wish to stay and continue their work
column3: he added.

column1: News of the outbreak was first reported in Belgian title Le Soir.
The first positive test was recorded on 14 December
column2: among a team who had arrived seven days earlier.

column1: They and others who tested positive were placed in quarantine but the virus continued to circulate.
Staff arriving at the station must be vaccinated and tested for the virus.
There are two emergency doctors at the station and new arrivals to the outpost have been suspended until the virus dissipates.
Princess Elisabeth station is operated by the International Polar Foundation and went into service in 2009.
It isn't the first time research stations in Antarctica have been affected by a coronavirus outbreak.
Last year
column2: a number of Chilean military personnel based at Bernardo O'Higgins research station were infected after sailors on a supply ship tested positive for the virus.

Adding to travellers' woes

column1: A Chinese man who was abducted over 30 years ago has been reunited with his biological mother after drawing a map of his childhood village from memory.
Li Jingwei was just four-years-old when he was lured away from his home and sold into a child trafficking ring.
On 24 December he shared a hand-drawn map to the video sharing app
column2: Douyin
column3: which police matched to a small village and a woman whose son had disappeared.

column1: After DNA tests
column2: they were reunited in Yunnan province on Saturday.

column1: Video footage of the reunion showed the pair meeting for the first time in over three decades  and shows Li Jingwei carefully removing his mother's coronavirus mask to examine her face before breaking down in tears and embracing her.
Thirty-three years of waiting
column2: countless nights of yearning
column3: and finally a map hand-drawn from memory
column4: this is the moment of perfect release after 13 days
column5: Mr Li wrote on his Douyin profile ahead of the anticipated reunion. ""Thank you
column6: everyone who has helped me reunite with my family.""

column1: Mr Li was abducted near the south-western city of Zhaotong in Yunnan Province in 1989 and subsequently sold to a family living over 1
column2: 800km away.

column1: Now living in Guangdong Province in southern China
column2: he had no success asking his adoptive parents or consulting DNA databases about his origins. So he turned to the internet.

column1: I'm a child who's finding his home. I was taken to Henan by a bald neighbour around 1989
column2: when I was about four years old
column3: he said in the video
column4: which was shared thousands of times.

column1: This is a map of my home area that I have drawn from memory
column2: he said holding up a rough guide of the village
column3: which included features like a building he believed to be a school

column1: Child abductions are not uncommon in China
column2: a society which places high value on having a son.

column1: Many children are abducted at a young age and sold to other families. In 2015
column2: it was estimated that 20
column3: 000 children were being abducted each year.

column1: In 2021 there were numerous examples of young men being reunited with their biological parents after long absences.
Last July
column2: Guo Gangtang was reunited with his son 24 years after he was abducted in the province of Shandong.

column3: 'national association of head teachers'

column1: Face masks are to be worn in secondary classrooms in England's schools to reduce the spread of the Omicron variant
column2: the government has announced.

column1: The temporary reintroduction of face coverings aims to address concerns about schools remaining open for face-to-face learning this coming term.
Meanwhile
column2: six school staff unions have issued a demand for urgent action to limit the spread of the virus.

column1: They warned national exams would be put at risk without further measures.
They also called for air-cleaning units
column2: financial support for absence cover
column3: help with on-site testing and a relaxation of the Ofsted inspection regime.

column1: Schools across the UK are re-opening after the Christmas break over the next week
column2: with pupils being asked to take part in onsite Covid testing.

column1: Until now
column2: England was the only one of the four UK nations where face masks were not recommended for pupils in classrooms. Teachers will not have to wear them under the new guidelines.

column1: Announcing the change - just a few days before schools reopen - Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said face coverings would be required until 26 January.
This is when the current national Plan B Covid measures run out
column2: although they will be reviewed on or close to 4 January.

column1: He said: ""I'm looking forward to welcoming pupils back next week to continue their face-to-face learning
column2: which is so important for their education and wellbeing.

column1: There is no doubt that the Omicron variant presents challenges but the entire education sector has responded with a Herculean effort
column2: and for that I thank each and every one of you.

column1: The prime minister and I have been clear that education is our number one priority. These measures will bolster our support to schools as we do everything in our power to minimise disruption.""
The government also announced it would be making 7
column2: 000 air cleaning units available to early years setting
column3: schools and colleges.

column1: Staff absences and rising Covid rates at the end of last term - caused by the rapid spread of the Omicron variant - have led to fears of further disruption to education.
The four main teaching unions covering England
column2: Wales and Northern Ireland - ASCL
column3: NAHT
column4: NEU and NASUWT - plus the GMB and Unison
column5: have issued a joint statement calling for urgent steps to help schools.

column1: We need the minimum amount of educational disruption this term in order to avoid a third successive year where GCSEs
column2: A-levels and other exams have to be cancelled
column3: and thereby removing the uncertainty and additional workload for students and teachers

column1: It is essential
column2: therefore
column3: that the government takes immediate and urgent steps to mitigate the risk of Covid transmission and that it provides more support to minimise disruption in schools and colleges.""

column1: Geoff Barton
column2: General Secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders
column3: said while there were obvious drawbacks to using face coverings in classrooms
column4: it was clear that the Omicron variant poses a very significant additional risk.

column1: It is absolutely essential that everything possible is done to reduce transmission and ensure that children remain in school.""
He added that the government's decision on masks was recognition that the spring term will be extremely challenging.
The biggest problem they face is the likelihood of high levels of staff absence caused by the prevalence of the Omicron variant.""
He added that while schools and colleges will do their best to minimise the impact on pupils
column2: there was a real possibility that some classes and year groups may have to be sent home for short periods of remote learning.

column1: General Secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers Paul Whiteman said reintroducing face masks in secondary classrooms was a sensible move
column2: but that more should be done.

column1: Where schools need air filtration units to improve areas of poor ventilation
column2: they should be provided with them
column3: without delay.""

column1: He welcomed the 7
column2: 000 new units but said ""adequate ventilation in classrooms should not be limited to first come
column3: first served"".

column1: The process by which schools can obtain these units is due to be set out by the DfE shortly.
Dr Mary Bousted
column2: Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union
column3: said ""finally
column4: the government has been forced to recognise
column6: the scale of the Omicron variant and its potential impact on education"".

column1: The recommendation on wearing facemasks in secondary school classrooms is overdue - but it should be a requirement.""

column1: Three people are missing and presumed dead
column2: after a devastating wildfire in the central US state of Colorado.

column1: The blaze swept through several towns
column2: destroying hundreds of homes and forcing tens of thousands of people to flee.

column1: The local sheriff had initially said there were no fatalities
column2: calling it a ""miracle"".

column1: But a spokeswoman for Boulder County admitted a mistake had been made.
I think the sheriff probably wasn't adequately briefed by us
column2: Jennifer Churchill said
column3: in comments carried by the Colorado Sun. ""That was an unfortunate error. We feel terrible.""

column1: No details have been released about those missing
column2: but local media reported that one of them was a 91-year-old woman whose family said got trapped by the incoming flames.

column1: Boulder County Sheriff Joe Pelle said it was unlikely any of the three will be found alive. He added that the county is set to bring in human-remains detection dogs to help search for victims.
The wildfire burned 6
column2: 000 acres across Boulder County
column3: destroying at least 1
column4: 000 homes and businesses. It started under unusually dry conditions and came under control in part because of snowfall.

column1: More than 10 inches (25cm) of snow has fallen on the Boulder area and is now hampering efforts to find those missing.
Images showed eerie scenes
column2: with charred buildings buried under thick snow.

column1: This video can not be played
Residents hit by the wildfire are coming to terms with what happened
column2: in some cases returning home to find complete destruction.

column1: I feel like I made it out with my life and that's I think the most important thing
column2: Jessi Delaplain
column3: who lost her home to the fire

column1: I gathered myself and I gathered my cats which was no easy feat to stuff them into the car. And I pulled out of the driveway and there were flames surrounding us.""
The cause of the wildfire is being investigated.
Climate change increases the risk of the hot
column2: dry weather that is likely to fuel wildfires
column3: and experts say that fires in western North America have grown more intense in recent years.

76;BBC Sound of 2022: Colourful rapper Central Cee kicks off the countdown;2022-01-02T00:00:35.000Z;[];['sound of 2022'
column2: 'music'];['shepherds'
column3: 'times'

column1: One of the fastest-rising stars of UK rap
column2: Central Cee has won fifth place in BBC Radio 1's Sound Of 2022.

column1: Hailing from west London
column2: his melodic take on drill has already earned him two Mobo Awards
column3: and he's nominated for three Brits - including best newcomer - in February.

column1: He burst on to the scene in 2020 with the straight-talking Day In The Life
column2: in which he taunted his peers: ""Turn off the auto-tune
column3: let's hear how you really rap.""

column1: Freestyled while driving his car
column2: the track was the culmination of 15 years of hard work. Born Oakley Caesar-Su in London's Shepherd's Bush in 1998
column3: he's been cultivating his lyrical style since writing his first verse at the age of eight.

column1: I recorded my first song when I was 13 - recorded and released it
column2: he told the BBC.

column1: I'm 22 now
column2: so it's coming up to 10 years. But I wasn't really in the game. I was still in school
column3: balancing things and just going through life. It was only literally last year
column5: where I got to take this stuff serious.""

column1: Day In The Life and its follow-ups
column2: Molly and Loading
column3: framed him as a playful
column5: eschewing the austere beats of drill for a more colourful sound - full of jazz samples and witty wordplay.

column1: Amassing tens of millions of streams
column2: the music quickly attracted the attention of record companies - but the rapper knocked them all back.

column1: Take that risk and go independent
column2: he explained on the 2021 single Pinging. ""I just turned down six figures.""

column1: The risk paid off
column2: though. February's Commitment Issues secured Cee a number nine spot on the UK chart
column3: and his first mixtape
column5: debuted at number two in March.

column1: He celebrated the release by riding on horseback through Shepherd's Bush Market
column2: and installing a giant mural on the nearby Goldhawk Road.

column1: When Cee turned up to have his photo taken in front of it
column2: ""50 to 60 school kids turned up after
column3: like

column1: There's a lot of love
column2: man.""

column1: He ended the year with a guest verse on Ed Sheeran's Bad Habits remix
column2: and another top 10 single
column3: Obsessed With You - a street love song that samples fellow Sound Of 2022 nominee PinkPantheress.

column1: Central Cee is the first act to be announced for the BBC's Sound Of 2022
column2: which aims to predict the biggest new stars of the coming year.

column1: The rest of the top five will be revealed daily on BBC Radio 1 and BBC News. Now in its 20th year
column2: previous winners of the prize include Adele
column3: Celeste

column1: Hey there - how has your 2021 been?
It's been an eventful one
column2: to say the least!

column1: You sold out the Shepherd's Bush Empire in October. Did you ever walk past it as a kid and think
column2: ""I'll play there one day""?

column1: Every time I passed Shepherd's Bush Empire - which was two to three times a day for 10 to 15 years
column2: I would look at it and I would just look and see who was on the bill
column3: taking it in subconsciously. We could have sold a lot more tickets than that -  but it was a conscious decision to make sure I did that one. It's important to me that I did that venue no matter how many tickets I could sell.

column1: At the Mobos
column2: you said you weren't sure how you felt about winning awards. Has your opinion changed now it's had time to sink in?

column1: I still feel the same way but if I could reiterate it
column2: what I meant is that I don't think people should feel like they need award shows to make them feel validated. We're all winners if we're in that room or releasing music
column3: regardless of who gets the actual award.

column1: When you started making music
column2: you'd record with just a MacBook and a pair of iPhone headphones. How did you teach yourself those skills?

column1: I'm just quite observant
column2: I'd say. So when I've downloaded the software I kinda just messed around with it. I didn't even watch no tutorials or nothing. Because I've been in the studio so many times
column3: when I'm in the sessions I'm just watching what they do. I'm a fast learner - it was pretty straightforward.

column1: Where did the names Cench and Central Cee come from?
Central Cee just came. There's no interesting story behind it. And then Cench is just short for Central.
Loading became your first chart hit in the middle of the pandemic. What was it like to see your numbers soaring while you were stuck at home?
It was strange. I couldn't get out there and interact with the fans
column2: or perform
column3: so I felt quite detached - just looking and experiencing everything through my phone

column1: Do you feel it had to happen that way?
Timing is everything. It's God's timing. It had to happen that way.
You recorded Six For Six the same day that Loading hit the charts. How significant is that line
column2: ""this ain't no coincidence""?

column1: It's just the truth.
Was there ever a time when you thought it might not happen?
Yeah - a couple times but I've been doing it for many years. For around 10 years. Within those 10 years there's obviously been bumps in the road and whatever but I was determined for the most part.
A lot of your songs feel rooted in real situations… What's your writing technique?
My writing technique has changed since Day in A Life.  Day In A Life
column2: I wrote outside of the studio and them times
column3: studio time wasn't as accessible.  I was selective with it. The money was obviously coming out of my pocket - and it still is - but studio wasn't on tap the same way. So them times I'd write outside the studio and just go and record and then cut. Since Day In A Life I haven't written a song outside of the studio. I just write in the studio basically.

column1: The Wild West mixtape doesn't have any collaborations or features. Was that important to you?
It wasn't really premeditated
column2: as such. By the time I had all the songs laid out
column3: they just happened to be all on my own.

column1: I haven't linked up to much people yet. I'm only just coming into the industry. I'm not in a rush to jump in the studio and work with everyone and this and that.
Commitment Issues and Obsessed With You are more emotional than a lot of UK rap. You could almost call them love songs. How important is it not to be boxed in by convention?
I don't try to not be boxed in by convention. It's not something I think about
column2: but I have different emotions. I'm just a human being. So sometimes I might feel a bit more emotional or a bit more ""whatever"".

column1: Obsessed With You samples another Sound Of 2022 nominee
column2: PinkPantheress... What do you think makes her special?

column1: There's a whole list of things
column2: which would take ages to run through
column3: but she's one of my favourite artists though - no cap. I love everything about her.

column1: That song is the first track from your 23 mixtape. What can we expect when that comes out next year?
Expect big things. If you thought 'Wild West' was hard...
And finally
column2: what's your grand plan for 2022?

column1: Stay alive and get richer!

column1: 81;EU plans to label gas and nuclear energy 'green' prompt row;2022-01-02T05:30:50.000Z;[];['cop26'
column2: 'climate change'
column3: 'nuclear power'];['row'

column1: The European Commission has proposed plans to label some gas and nuclear power as green
column2: prompting criticism from Germany.

column1: The proposal argues that gas and nuclear are key to helping transition to cleaner power.
But Germany's environment minister called the plan ""absolutely wrong"".
It comes months after countries pledged to keep temperature rises within 1.5C at the COP26 climate summit.
It is necessary to recognise that the fossil gas and nuclear energy sectors can contribute to the decarbonisation of the Union's economy
column2: the Commission's proposal says.

column1: Under the proposal
column2: only gas and nuclear plants with the highest standards would be considered green. Nuclear plants would also have to have strict waste disposal plans
column3: Deutsche Welle reports. While gas plants would have a limit of how much carbon dioxide is released per kilowatt-hour of energy produced.

column1: If a majority of EU members back the proposal then it will become law from 2023.
France had reportedly pushed for nuclear power to be included. The country relies on nuclear energy for 70% of its electricity
column2: although this will be cut to half over the next 15 years.

column1: France has also pledged to reduce its reliance on nuclear power by shutting down 12 nuclear reactors by 2035.
The move has been criticised by Germany
column2: which is in the process of phasing out nuclear completely and only has a few plants remaining.

column1: German Environment Minister Steffi Lemke described the proposal as ""wrong""
column2: adding that nuclear energy could lead to environmental disasters and large amounts of nuclear waste.

column1: Economy and Climate Protection Minister Robert Habeck called the plan ""greenwashing""
column2: saying it ""waters down the good label for sustainability.""

column1: A large fire is raging at the Houses of Parliament in the South African city of Cape Town.
Video footage shows a plume of black smoke filling the sky
column2: with huge flames coming out from the roof of the building.

column1: Dozens of firefighters are at the site battling the blaze; it is not yet clear what caused the fire.
It comes hours after Archbishop Desmond Tutu's state funeral at St George's Cathedral
column2: near Parliament.

column1: The roof area had caught fire and the National Assembly building was on fire too
column2: the city authorities said.

column1: The fire is not under control and cracks in the walls of the building have been reported
column2: a spokesman for the city's emergency services told the AFP news agency.

column1: The fire was currently on the third floor
column2: with initial reports indicating it started in the office space of the building and was spreading towards a gym at the site
column3: city officials said.

column1: The Houses of Parliament in Cape Town are made up of three sections
column2: with the oldest dating back to 1884. The newer sections built in the 1920s and 1980s house the National Assembly.

column2: 'north korea'];['world'
column3: 'north'

column1: A South Korean citizen has crossed the heavily fortified border into North Korea in an apparent defection
column2: South Korea's military says.

column1: The person was able to evade detection for several hours despite a search operation by South Korean troops.
Military chiefs in Seoul said they did not know if the person was still alive
column2: but had sent a message to the North asking for them to be protected.

column1: North Korea has implemented a shoot-on-sight policy during the pandemic.
The person was detected in the Demilitarised Zone (DMZ)
column2: which separates the two Koreas
column3: at a point on the east coast at about 21:20 local time (12:20 GMT) on Saturday
column4: South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff (JCS) said.

column1: Defence officials in Seoul had pledged to overhaul the border defence system after similar breaches in the past.
In September 2020 North Korean troops shot and burned a South Korean fisheries official who went missing at sea. The incident sparked uproar. Pyongyang blamed the anti-virus rule and apologised.

North Korea's leader Kim Jong-un had earlier declared a national emergency and sealed off a town after a North Korean defector who Mr Kim said had Covid symptoms crossed into the North from the South.
North Korea's pandemic-related lockdowns and restrictions on movement within the country have also reduced the number of defections from the North to the South.
The border between North and South Korea is one of the most heavily fortified areas in the world. It is filled with landmines
column2: surrounded by electric and barbed wire fencing and surveillance cameras and armed guards are supposed to be on alert 24 hours a day.

column1: Denmark's government has announced a goal to make domestic flights fossil fuel free by 2030.
In her New Year's address
column2: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said she wants to ""make flying green"".

column1: However she acknowledged that the solutions to reach her target were not yet in place.
Denmark is aiming for a 70% cut in overall carbon emissions by 2030
column2: compared to 1990 levels.

column1: To travel is to live and therefore we fly

102;Sound Of 2022: Lola Young's slow-burning anthems are bubbling over;2022-01-03T00:02:56.000Z;[];['sound of 2022'
column2: 'music'];['suddenly'
column3: 'world'

column1: Are you joking? No way! Oh my God. That's amazing. Such good news.""
Singer-songwriter Lola Young has just learned she's placed fourth in BBC Radio 1's Sound Of 2022 - which aims to predict the biggest new stars of the coming year.
She's in good company. In previous years
column2: fourth place has gone to artists like Jorja Smith
column3: Khalid
column5: who've all shaped the sounds of pop and soul in their own mould.

column1: Young's deep
column2: expressive vocals will be familiar to millions after she covered Together In Electric Dreams for this year's John Lewis Christmas Advert.

column1: But the 21-year-old has been on the path to stardom since she wrote her first song
column2: an ode to Santa Claus
column3: when she was 11.

column1: Before long
column2: she'd won the Open Mic UK contest and booked a place at the Brit School
column3: while playing as many gigs as she could around her native south London.

column1: I've done so many [awful] open mic pub gigs where I've rocked up and played to three old men drinking beer and talking through my performance
column2: she says. ""But I had to do that.""

column1: It was at one such showcase that she caught the attention of Amy Winehouse's ex-manager Nick Shymansky - who loved her husky
column2: soulful sound
column3: but was reluctant to take her on.

column1: He said he was too busy and too hurt from his past experiences
column2: Young explains. So he introduced her to Nick Huggett
column3: who discovered and signed Adele... before having second thoughts.

column1: Nick S decided that he couldn't miss out - so they ended up managing me together. They're like my uncles now!""
Signed to Island Records
column2: Young released an assured debut album
column3: Intro
column4: at the age of 18. More recently
column5: the attention-grabbing singles Fake and Bad Tattoo have seen her played on BBC Radio 1
column6: and Elton John's Rocket Hour show.

column1: She ended 2021 with a nomination for the Brits Critics' Choice award; and starts 2022 with the endorsement of the 130 pundits who voted for the BBC Sound Of list (the top three will be announced over the next three days).
It feels like things are getting better and better
column2: she beams. ""The bubbling under the surface is starting to really
column3: really bubble over!""

column1: We caught up with her over Zoom to find out more about her backstory - and what she's got in store for the year ahead.
Have you always wanted to be a musician?
Yeah
column2: I think for some people it comes a little bit later on
column3: but I had it in my head that I wanted to be in music since I was maybe 10 or 11.

column1: I've seen interviews where you said you weren't a natural singer. How much work did you have to do?
I think in other interviews
column2: I've maybe been a little bit misunderstood in the sense that people thought I couldn't sing at all. It wasn't that. I had a voice
column3: I was able to hold a note
column4: but I didn't have the technical things like vibrato at all.

column1: So
column2: it was more the case that I had to work hard to get power and strength. Like with Beyoncé
column3: I can imagine she just popped out singing to the heavens. I didn't have that.

column1: I think she actually cried in perfect pitch when she was born.
Yeah
column2: literally.

column1: What did you enjoy singing when you were a kid?
The first album I remember putting on and really enjoying was Paolo Nutini's These Streets. Then
column2: growing up
column3: I listened to a lot of Eminem and Biggie and old school rap; and then eventually a lot of David Bowie
column4: Prince. So my inspirations are quite different.

column1: Do you remember the first time you recorded yourself singing?
Yeah
column2: I was probably about 13
column3: 14 and I went into a studio. Hearing my voice back was pretty mad - but it confirmed that's what I wanted to do.

column1: You entered the Open Mic UK competition around the same time. What was that experience like?
Back when I was a kid
column2: I thought X Factor or Britain's Got Talent was the way that people blew up. I didn't really understand the business side of things. So Open Mic UK was something I thought was going to change my life and
column3: obviously
column4: it helped a little bit - but it wasn't a game changer.

column1: You won with an original song
column2: right?

column1: Yeah
column2: it was called Never Enough and it's a song that's never gonna get released!

column1: Has your writing changed since then?
A hell of a lot! I'm very careful about each lyric now. It can't just be a throwaway. And if it is
column2: then we scrap it.

column1: I guess when you start out
column2: you're almost impersonating your favourite artists. Then as you grow and get more experience
column3: you put more of yourself into the songs?

column1: That's true - but I think people sometimes underestimate the real power that a young person has. I have one song that I wrote when I was 13
column2: that I still really believe [in] and that's going to be on the album.

column1: Is that I Learned From You?
Yeah
column2: you know my music!

column1: Why did that song survive when other ones got cast away?
It had quite an interesting concept. It was about a close relative and how I was trying to understand our relationship. It's kind of complex and
column2: although I didn't really realise at the time
column3: it's quite a mature song.

column1: You went to the Brit school after that. Was it what you expected?
Um
column2: no
column3: it wasn't. There's a tendency for people to assume the Brit school is the way to the top
column4: but it's still a school. You still do lessons
column5: you still meet bitchy people and there's still bullying. Even the headmaster would say
column6: ""We're not trying to create famous people. That's not why we're here.""

column1: I'm not saying I expected more than that because it was a really great experience. It helped me understand my style and where I wanted to go with my music.
You released your first album
column2: Intro
column3: when you were 18.

column1: I was 18
column2: yeah.

column1: One of the tracks
column2: Blind Love
column3: is still your most played song on Spotify. Why do you think people love that song

column1: Just because it's a classic
column2: sad love song. It's about the journey of a relationship and how it ends
column3: but also trying to come to peace with that. I think a lot of people can relate to that feeling.

column1: On Six Feet Under
column2: you sing about being depressed and thinking about death. What's it like to share dark feelings like those in your music?

column1: It's very complex suffering from mental health
column2: I think. Especially as a person who has gone through life without really thinking about mental health - and then suddenly it hits you. You suddenly understand the stigma around it
column3: because you start feeling ashamed about saying certain things
column4: or feeling certain things. So I feel really strongly that I have to be super-honest in my lyrics. I'm sharing [those feelings] with the world but also
column5: I'm trying to share it with myself

column1: What do your friends and family think of those songs?
Sometimes it can be hard but my family and my friends are super-understanding. They know already what I've gone through. So as scary as it is to talk about the dark side of your mind
column2: the importance of sharing
column3: of honesty

column1: The Intro album was just starting to make waves when you developed cysts on your vocal cords. Were you ever worried you'd lose your voice?
It was very frightening
column2: for sure
column3: especially because I had a new type of vocal surgery. But I had the best surgeon and it was fine. I mean
column4: I'm still in recovery.  My high register still cracks
column5: so I might need to go for a check-up.

column1: Just as you came out of hospital
column2: the world went into lockdown. How did you find that?

column1: For me. being indoors and being in my own space is quite hard. I hate it. I can't be alone. And I got Covid as well - not badly
column2: but I did have Covid.

column1: But it was a very tough year for a lot of people. People were very low and lost their jobs
column2: you know? So my year was hard
column3: but it wasn't the worst.

column1: The other thing you did in 2020 was release Woman
column2: which is one of your best songs. And it's quite political as well...

column1: Woman was a process of me trying to understand how much one could be a feminist without being radical.
I think that people really don't understand what that word [feminist] means. I remember getting cat-called as a teenager going to school by an old man in a van and
column2: as you grow up
column3: you start to question why the world lets you believe this is normal.  So in that song
column4: I'm explaining what happens when you feel like you're less [important] than a man. It was something that I felt really strongly about.

column1: The songs you've released subsequently
column2: like Ruin My Make Up and Fake
column3: have a similar sense of strength and defiance. I'm interested in why that's a theme that you've focused on lyrically in the last two years.

column1: I don't really know why.... I think it's more that I wanted to change my sound up. I was listening a lot to The Cure
column2: and using a lot of vintage sounds and baritone guitars. And I think when the sonic changed
column3: the lyrics changed with it. Like Fake
column5: I think the drama goes well with the sound of the record.

column1: It sounds like something off a Tarantino soundtrack.
Yeah
column2: that was the intention!

column1: You ended 2021 by singing the John Lewis Christmas advert. I've always wondered how much input you get in that process? Like
column2: do you get to choose the song?

column1: The advertising company suggested the song. The only change I made was to sing it in a joyous way
column2: with a tone of hope. That was a bit of a challenge
column3: because the movement of the track is quite melancholic - but obviously it's supposed to be a Christmas song so it's not supposed to be too depressing!

column1: Since then
column2: I've started hearing your music more and more on the radio and in places like H&M. What's that like?

column1: It's weird - but it's all I've ever wanted
column2: so obviously that's really good.

column1: And so
column2: on to 2022. Are you working on a new album?

column1: It's in the works! I've got a good few songs that I'm happy with but I don't know when exactly it will be released. Hopefully end of next year.

column1: Richard Leakey
column2: a world-renowned Kenyan conservationist and fossil hunter has died aged 77.

column1: His groundbreaking work contributed to the recognition of Africa as the birthplace of humankind.
He also spearheaded campaigns to stop poaching in Kenya
column2: famously burning the country's stockpile of poached ivory.

column1: Kenyan President Uhuru Kenyatta said Leakey had ""served our country with distinction"".
Leakey served in various positions in the Kenyan government including the National Museums of Kenya
column2: the Kenya Wildlife Service and as head of the civil service.

column1: Besides his distinguished career in public service
column2: Dr Leakey is celebrated for his prominent role in Kenya's civil society where he founded and successfully ran a number of institutions
column3: Mr Kenyatta said.

column1: Leakey followed in his parents' footsteps in paleoanthropology - the practice of seeking to understand human evolution by studying fossils and ancient tools.
In his 20s
column2: Leakey made his own important finds
column3: and in two ground-breaking books (Origins and People of the Lake)
column4: he explained the emergence of Homo erectus

column1: His work contributed to the growing body of evidence that the earliest humans had lived on the African continent.

column2: he fronted a seven-part BBC television series called ""The Making of Mankind""
column3: which made him a household name.

column1: In the late 1980s
column2: he switched careers to take over as head of Kenya's Wildlife Service at a time when poachers were wiping out the country's entire elephant and rhino populations.

column1: He told his rangers to shoot poachers on sight and organised the spectacular public burning of a huge haul of ivory.

column2: the small plane he was flying in lost power and crashed. He survived but both of his legs were amputated below the knee.

column1: That did not stop him from entering Kenyan politics
column2: setting up a new political party. But his political career did not last and in 1998 he took up a role as head of Kenya's civil service
column3: with a mission to fight official corruption.

column1: He lasted three years in the role before returning to the Kenya Wildlife Service.
At the time of his death
column2: he was serving as chairman of the Turkana Basin Institute at Stony Brook University in the US. The institute works to facilitate research and education in palaeontology and archaeology in northern Kenya.

column1: Kenya's Deputy president said Leakey ""inspired many Kenyans with his loyalty to his country. He loved Kenya"".

column2: 'statement'
column3: 'website'

column1: Crisis-hit Chinese real estate giant Evergrande has suspended trade in its shares on the Hong Kong as investors await news on its restructuring plan.
The statement to the stock exchange did not give a reason for the trading halt.
Evergrande has more than $300bn (£222bn) of debts and is scrambling to raise cash by selling assets and shares to repay suppliers and creditors.
Last week
column2: the company dialled back plans to repay investors in its wealth management products.

column1: Evergrande said on Friday that each investor in its wealth management product could expect to receive $1
column2: 257 each month as principal payment for three months irrespective of when the investment matures.

column1: The company had earlier not mentioned any amount and had agreed to repay 10% of the investment by the end of the month when the product matures.
Evergrande said in a statement posted on the wealth unit's website that the situation was not ""ideal"" and that it would ""actively raise funds""
column2: and update the repayment plan in late March
column3: without giving further details.

column1: The announcement was seen as highlighting the deepening cash squeeze at the struggling property developer.
Last week
column2: Evergrande did not make some interest payments on its offshore bonds.

column1: The company's $19bn in international bonds were deemed to be in default by rating agencies after it missed a payment deadline last month.

106;Gas prices: MPs and peers urge PM to act on energy bills;2022-01-02T13:58:05.000Z;[];['energy customer switching'
column2: 'uk economy'
column3: 'energy service companies'

column1: Twenty Conservative MPs and peers have called on the prime minister to tackle the spiralling cost of living.
Five ex-ministers are among those who have written to the Sunday Telegraph arguing for a cut in environmental levies and the removal of energy taxes.
Their call follows big increases in wholesale gas prices. Experts say average bills could hit £2
The government says it is meeting suppliers and the regulator regularly to work out how to help consumers.
Health minister Edward Argar told Times Radio there were a range of measures to help those who ""feel the squeeze with particular house bills""
column2: adding that the economy was ""bouncing back"".

column1: The letter to the Telegraph has been organised by the Net Zero Scrutiny Group of Conservatives
column2: which keeps an eye on the potential consequences of the government's environmental commitments.

column1: The group's chairman Craig Mackinlay is one of the letter's signatories
column2: along with former Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey and senior MPs Robert Halfon and Steve Baker.

column1: We hardly need to point out that high energy prices
column2: whether for domestic heating or for domestic transport
column3: are felt most painfully by the lowest paid

column1: It argues that by scrapping the 5% VAT rate on energy bills and suspending environmental levies which fund renewable energy schemes
column2: the average household could save £200 on their energy bill.

column1: Cabinet Office minister Stephen Barclay said: ""It is a matter for the Chancellor in terms of tax policy but the key issue for us all is to get the economy re-opened
column2: to get businesses firing up again.""

column1: But Mr Halfon said he had ""huge worries"" about the rising energy costs for people across the country.
With the energy price cap going up in the spring
column2: he said the government should look at other measures
column3: including suspending green levies which he said were ""actually 25% of everybody's energy bill"".

column1: He added that he was not suggesting to ""get rid of them forever"" but to pause them at a time when people could really struggle.
Labour has also called for the lifting of VAT on fuel bills for the winter to help households
column2: while Ovo Energy firm boss Stephen Fitzpatrick last week suggested that some ""environmental social policy costs"" should be removed by the government.

column1: Other suppliers including Good Energy
column2: EDF and trade body Energy UK have called for government intervention
column3: after the cost of gas in wholesale markets rose by more than 500% in less than a year.

column1: The charity National Energy Action (NEA) has warned that a record six million UK households will be in fuel poverty when the next increase in the energy price cap comes into force in April.
Prior to the most recent rise in the price cap in October
column2: around four million homes in the UK were classed as being in fuel poverty. That number increased by 500
column3: 000 after prices rose and NEA estimates it will increase again by 1.5 million this year.

column1: More than 20 energy suppliers have gone out of business since the start of September
column2: with their customers shifted to new providers.

column1: But many will find themselves on a different - and potentially more expensive - tariff than their previous energy deal.
Last week the Resolution Foundation think tank warned that millions of UK families face a ""year of squeeze"" in 2022 thanks to rising energy bills
column2: stagnant wages and tax rises. The Bank of England has said it expects inflation to reach 6% by the spring.

column1: The Resolution Foundation says that an increase in National Insurance contributions from April
column2: along with an expected rise in energy bills in the same month could amount to a £1
column3: 200 hit to household finances.

column1: And the foundation warned that poorer families will bear the brunt of these rises as they spend a greater proportion of their income on electricity and gas.
The government says it has taken steps to help
column2: including reducing the Universal Credit taper
column3: providing cold weather payments and freezing alcohol and fuel duty.

107;"China: Why some think ""small eyes"" are not beautiful";2022-01-03T00:28:55.000Z;[];['social media'
column2: 'china'
column3: 'beauty standards'];['weibo'

column1: Do I not deserve to be Chinese just because I have small eyes?""
That is what Chinese model Cai Niangniang wrote in a recent impassioned social media post
column2: after old pictures of her went viral for all the wrong reasons.

column1: For several days she had been attacked online for being ""deliberately offensive"" and ""unpatriotic""
column2: over a series of advertisements she had appeared in for Chinese snack brand Three Squirrels.

column1: Her apparent crime? Having narrow eyes.
Some social media users were so outraged that the company eventually removed the ads online
column2: and apologised for making people ""feel uncomfortable"" over them.

column1: But Ms Cai said that she did not know what she had done to get cyber-bullied
column2: noting that she was ""just doing my job"" as a model.

column1: My looks were given to me by my parents
column2: the 28-year-old wrote on the Twitter-like platform Weibo.

column1: Have I insulted China the day I was born just because of how I look?""
The ads
column2: originally shot in 2019
column3: were dug up by nationalist netizens amid a period of heightened sensitivity online in China over advertisements depicting Chinese people.

column1: In November
column2: a top Chinese fashion photographer apologised for her ""ignorance"" after a picture she shot for French luxury brand Dior sparked a backlash. It had featured a Chinese model with narrow eyes.

column1: In recent days
column2: there have been other incidents of social media outrage over adverts by Mercedes-Benz and Gucci that featured Chinese women with narrow eyes.

column1: Amid a growing sense of online nationalism and anti-West sentiment in China
column2: some have seized upon these advertisements as examples of racism towards Chinese people. By featuring models with narrow eyes
column3: critics say these companies are perpetuating Western stereotypes of Chinese faces.

column1: Many asked why these adverts did not feature the kind of models more commonly seen in Chinese advertisements who have fair skin and large round eyes
column2: which are typically considered ideal beauty features in China.

column1: A recent editorial by state news outlet China Daily highlighted how ""for too long
column2: Western criteria of beauty
column3: and Western tastes and likes and dislikes dominated aesthetics"". That included depicting Asian women in adverts as having narrow eyes

column1: The West no longer has an absolute say over everything
column2: the opinion piece read.

column1: The Chinese people do not need to follow their standards on what constitutes beauty and what kinds of women are considered beautiful.""
As a Chinese brand
column2: Three Squirrels ""should have known about the sensitivity of Chinese consumers to how they are portrayed in advertisements

column1: At the heart of the controversy is the perception that such depictions invoke the ""slanted eyes"" stereotype of Asian people which emerged in Western culture in the 19th century
column2: and which is considered hugely offensive by many Asians today.

column1: In Hollywood
column2: the quintessential Asian villain Fu Manchu was pictured with thin and narrow eyes. The character embodied and perpetuated ""yellow peril""
column3: the racist idea that Asian cultures threatened Western society.

column1: There is indeed a long history in the use of 'slanted eyes' to discriminate against Asians
column2: Dr Liu Wen from Taiwan's Academia Sinica told BBC Chinese.

column1: But the insistence among some Chinese on one particular beauty ideal also stands in marked contrast to the current global debate over diversity and the push for wider representation of Asian faces in the media.
Observers say that while it is understandable that some consumers would be offended over the adverts
column2: the outcry is also too simplistic as it rejects the idea that there can be in fact many different ways to look Chinese.

column1: Rejecting 'slanted eyes' is a very dangerous phenomenon
column2: because it is the rejection of aesthetic pluralism
column3: Dr Luwei Rose Luqiu from Hong Kong Baptist University said.

column1: It's stifling beauty that does not meet a certain standard.""
Experts have also pointed out that traditional standards of beauty in China had in fact favoured narrow eyes. For example
column2: paintings from what is widely considered as China's golden age for art and culture
column3: the Tang Dynasty period from 618 to 907 AD

column1: Despite some variations across different dynasties
column2: more narrow eyes were preferred in ancient China
column3: said Dr Jaehee Jung
column4: a consumer behaviour expert at the University of Delaware.

column1: The current preference for large round eyes
column2: ironically
column3: may be a recent phenomenon influenced by the West. Some experts believe the latest shift in beauty standards began around the late 1970s
column4: thanks to exposure to foreign advertising and entertainment when China opened its doors to the world.

column1: Women in contemporary China seem to endorse much of the Western standards for female beauty ideals pervasive in media images
column2: said Dr Jung.

column1: These days
column2: large round eyes are so prized that it is not uncommon for young Chinese women to wear makeup or even undergo cosmetic surgery procedures to make their eyes appear bigger
column3: such as creating a ""double eyelid"" crease.

column1: But for Ms Cai
column2: the model at the centre of the latest controversy
column3: she hopes that people can be ""kinder"" to those who look different. She said in her Weibo post that there was no need to attack her even if they did not appreciate her particular look.

column1: My eyes are just like this
column2: in fact they're even smaller in real life [than in the ads]... Everyone has their own charm!""

column1: Additional reporting by Sylvia Chang from BBC Chinese.
Standing in front of a smartphone and selling has become a serious career choice for China's young.

108;Top US phone firms reject call to delay 5G rollout;2022-01-03T05:40:24.000Z;[];['at&t'
column2: 'aviation safety'
column3: 'telecommunication'

column1: Two of the biggest US phone firms have rejected a government request to delay the rollout of 5G services this week.
The US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) made the request over concerns about aviation safety.
However
column2: AT&T and Verizon did say they will implement temporary safeguards.

column1: Plane makers have warned that C-Band spectrum 5G wireless signals may interfere with sensitive aircraft electronics and could disrupt flights.
In a joint letter
column2: the chief executives of AT&T and Verizon said the proposal to delay for a fortnight the introduction of 5G services
column3: which are due to start on 5 January
column4: would be ""an irresponsible abdication of the operating control required to deploy world-class and globally competitive communications networks.""

column1: However
column2: they also said that they will not deploy 5G around airports for six months
column3: similar to an approach adopted in France.

column1: The laws of physics are the same in the United States and France
column2: the letter said.

column1: If US airlines are permitted to operate flights every day in France
column2: then the same operating conditions should allow them to do so in the United States
column3: it added.

column1: But the FAA said circumstances in France are different
column2: including that telecom firms operating in that country use lower power levels for 5G than are allowed in the US.

column1: The aviation industry and the FAA had previously raised concerns about potential interference of 5G with aircraft equipment like radio altitude meters.
Last month
column2: the bosses of the world's two biggest plane makers
column3: Airbus and Boeing
column4: made an appeal to Mr Buttigieg in which they said ""5G interference could adversely affect the ability of aircraft to safely operate"".

column1: The letter cited research by trade group Airlines for America which found that if the FAA's 5G rules had been in effect in 2019
column2: about 345
column3: 000 passenger flights and 5
column4: 400 cargo flights would have faced delays

column1: The airline group urged the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) and the telecom industry to work with the FAA and aviation companies and said it may go to court on Monday if the FCC does not act.
On Sunday
column2: an FCC spokesperson said the agency is ""optimistic that by working together we can both advance the wireless economy and ensure aviation safety.""
