column2: 'showing'
column3: 'write'

column1: The creator and executive producer of the CSI franchise has said US TV can be too conservative.
Anthony E Zuiker told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: ""Sometimes America is a bit too uptight for its own good.""
The hugely successful CSI: Crime Scene Investigation series regularly features scenes of violence
column2: often gory injuries and some sex and nudity.

column1: It's hard to keep up with what people will like and not like hour-upon-hour
column2: Zuiker told guest editor Jacky Wright.

column1: He suggested attempts by writers and producers to keep up with changing audience expectations can stifle creativity. ""I just don't think it is good for the evolution of storytelling
column2: he said.

column1: Zuiker was speaking to Wright
column2: Microsoft's chief digital officer
column3: who is one of the programme's traditional guest editors over the festive period - and a big fan of the crime series.

column1: Asked to comment on the debate about showing violence on TV and changing audience expectations

column1: It's like
column2: some years it's OK
column3: some years it's not OK
column5: some years it's not OK. And sometimes America is a bit too uptight for its own good. And it's hard to keep up with what people will like and not like

column1: So my philosophy is we kind of write it like we see it. We get less flack for violence
column2: but we are very uptight in the sex department. So any kind of gyration
column3: showing the curvature of a buttock
column4: any enlarged breasts or too much cleavage
column5: we have propelled ourselves from 2020 to the Stone Age as of late
column6: just because America got too uptight for its own good.""

column1: Audience research and ratings guidance have previously indicated US audiences are particularly sensitive to scenes of a sexual nature.
Zuiker added: ""If you look at the show from 2000 to this year's finale
column2: we've definitely gone in a more conservative
column3: nervous fashion
column4: which I just don't think is good for the evolution of storytelling.""

column1: CSI: Crime Scene Investigation first aired in 2000

column1: The show has been credited with improving the public's understanding of forensics and how evidence gathered from a crime scene can be used to build a case against a criminal.

column2: the storylines of which often centre around often gory crimes.

column1: If we show gratuitous violence

column1: What I don't want to do is have the writers to be restricted. If you're going to have someone hanging from a chandelier in a casino with no head
column2: that's because it's a mystery

column1: He added: ""I just think when we begin to defensively hamper our creativity or defensively write or overly edit before it gets to the next stage of the network reading the draft

column4: and the shows go from A+ to C+ very fast.""

column1: Richard Leakey
column2: who has died days after celebrating his 77th birthday
column3: was a pugnacious man whose achievements were as remarkable as they were diverse.

column1: Born on 19 December 1944 in Kenya's capital Nairobi
column2: he was a world-famous fossil expert
column3: author and conservationist
column4: as well as being an opposition MP
column7: and head of the country's civil service.

column1: He was beaten up
column2: threatened and badly injured in a plane crash which saw him lose both his legs.

column1: I think pressure probably suits me
column2: Leakey once said with urbane understatement.

column1: His first job was studying fossils. His parents
column2: Louis and Mary
column3: were famous archaeologists and palaeontologists who spent decades exploring Kenya's Rift Valley
column4: searching for the origins of mankind.

column1: In his 20s
column2: Leakey almost eclipsed his parents' work
column3: making his own important finds and writing books.

column1: In the late 1980s
column2: Leakey switched careers to take over as head of Kenya's Wildlife Service (KWS) at a time when the organisation was close to collapse and poachers were busy wiping out the country's entire elephant and rhino populations.

column1: Energetic
column2: ruthless and seemingly incorruptible
column3: Leakey told his rangers to shoot poachers on sight and organised the public burning of a huge cache of ivory as a publicity stunt to draw global attention to the threat faced by elephants.

column1: People were genuinely shocked that ivory was causing elephants to become extinct
column2: he told the BBC's Vivienne Nunis in an interview in September 2021.

column1: Leakey's methods were successful but his combative style earned him plenty of enemies. It was a pattern that would be repeated again and again.
When
column3: the single-engine plane he was flying lost power and crashed
column4: many speculated that it was sabotage. Both of his legs were amputated below the knee.

column1: In 1994 Leakey changed careers once again
column2: quitting the KWS to enter the equally ruthless world of Kenyan politics and helping to form an opposition party called Safina to campaign for multi-party democracy.

column1: Looking back at my careers
column2: the political side of my life was most rewarding in terms of the country
column3: he told the BBC.

column1: But it was far from being an easy ride.
On one occasion he was whipped by hired thugs. President Moi described him as a racist
column2: an atheist and a foreigner.

column1: But in 1999 President Moi shocked the country by appointing Leakey as head of Kenya's civil service
column2: and of a so-called dream team of reformers hired to rescue a country branded one of the world's most corrupt
column3: from a deepening economic crisis.

column1: Supporters said Leakey had been recognised by the president as the only man tough enough and honest enough to pull Kenya out of its troubles
column2: but questioned whether he would last long enough in the job to do any real good.

column1: Critics said the appointment of a white man with no university education was an insult to Kenyans and one which had clearly been orchestrated by colonial mentalities still lurking in the IMF and World Bank.

In his new job Leakey certainly helped to improve relations between Kenya and international lending institutions. His appointment may well have been crucial in persuading the IMF to resume lending the government money.
For a while Leakey enjoyed unprecedented popularity as his dream team started a radical overhaul of the country's bloated
column2: corrupt
column3: nepotistic bureaucracy.

column1: But as usual
column2: Leakey ran into trouble. Some complained again about his uncanny ability to make unnecessary enemies. Others said his anti-corruption drive was threatening the interests of too many powerful figures. Leakey stepped down in 2001 - without giving any public explanation.

column1: Leakey said he planned to retire from active political life. He wanted instead to grow grapes on his farm in the Rift Valley.
But in 2015
column2: he returned to public life with current President Uhuru Kenyatta appointing him as chairman of the board of the KWS. He brokered a controversial deal that allowed a Chinese-funded railway line to be built through the Nairobi National Park.

column1: We cannot say to the people of Kenya: 'Oh the railway can't come through Nairobi Park so you won't have a railway for five years'
column2: he was quoted as saying at the time.

column1: More recently
column2: his focus had moved to what he saw as the biggest environmental threat - climate change.

column1: We've created a terrible mess
column2: he said.

column1: He feared that Kenya's national parks would one day cease to exist because they ""would have dried out or washed out"".
Poaching
column2: I think we can deal with. But habitat loss and human expansion to encroach on water systems and forests and pollute the air - no
column3: I don't see anything being done in Africa

column1: He died with his dream of building a museum on the edges of Kenya's Rift Valley
column2: to celebrate evolution and the common history from Africa that all humans share
column3: unfulfilled.

column1: I want to build a cathedral of life
column2: with no God
column3: he said.

column1: We are one species
column2: we came out of Lake Turkana three million years ago and we have to recognise we're all in the same house
column3: he said.

column1: Having lived in Kenya all his life
column2: Leakey also called for greater investment in Africa to help create jobs
column3: which he said would allow the continent to ""leap ahead"".

column1: I'm full of confidence that we have the human resources
column2: Africa has just got to be given a little bit of a lift.""

column1: South Korea's military suspects a man who crossed the heavily fortified border into the North on New Year's Day previously defected to the South.
Officials believe he is a gymnast who jumped the barbed wire fence into South Korea in 2020.
It is not clear why he made the perilous return crossing
column2: or if he is alive or dead.

column1: North Korea has implemented a shoot-on-sight policy at the border to prevent the spread of Covid-19.
Thousands of North Koreans have resettled in South Korea
column2: but crossings through the Demilitarised Zone (DMZ)
column3: which separates the two countries
column4: are rare. Most make their way via China.

column1: Instances of defections from South to North are rarer still
column2: with only a handful of cases recorded in recent years.

column1: This video can not be played
South Korean troops were sent to investigate on New Year's Day after surveillance cameras issued an alert that someone was roaming within the military border zone at a point on the east coast.
They could not find the man but discovered he had crossed into North Korea several hours later.
Citing surveillance footage
column2: a high-level military official confirmed to the BBC that it was indeed the same man who had earlier crossed from North to South Korea in November 2020
column3: using a similar route.

column1: The man
column2: believed to be in his 30s
column3: worked as a cleaner in South Korea
column4: the Yonhap news agency reported. At the time he was detained
column5: he said he was a North Korean gymnast. Other details about him were not immediately known.

column1: Footage showed he had a identical look and dress as the person who defected from the North in 2020
column2: a defence ministry official told reporters.

column1: Military chiefs in Seoul said at the weekend they did not know if the person observed crossing was still alive but had sent a message to the North asking for them to be protected.
North Korea acknowledged receiving the message
column2: but there are no details about the man's fate or his possible motives for returning. An investigation is under way into how he could have made his crossing undetected.

column1: The border between North and South Korea is filled with landmines and surrounded by electric and barbed wire fencing. Surveillance cameras and armed guards are supposed to be on alert 24 hours a day.
Defence officials in Seoul had pledged to overhaul the border defence system after similar breaches in the past.

column1: An Israeli wildlife photographer has captured a remarkable momentary image of a flock of birds forming the shape of a spoon with a heap of sugar.

column2: where thousands of starlings fly and swoop in clusters.

column1: Albert Keshet also snapped what appeared to be the spoon bending
column2: posting it on social media.

column1: The images caught the attention of famed Israeli spoon bender Uri Geller
column2: who has framed them in his museum.

column1: Mr Keshet took the images when he went on an early morning excursion to a spot in the northern Jordan Valley to photograph wild plants and birds.
When I was in the valley looking for birds
column2: I met the flocks of starlings. I stayed there for about five or six hours
column3: watching and following them in order to capture some beautiful pictures

column1: At one point they began to ascend to the sky and began the dance of starlings. To my huge surprise
column2: in the space of only about five seconds the starlings formed the shape of the spoon. They held it for a few seconds then the shape changed to a bent spoon - just like the one Uri Geller is famous for!

column1: In the 10 years that I have been travelling and taking photos
column2: this is one of the most amazing pictures of starlings I have ever taken!""

column1: After posting the images on social media
column2: Mr Keshet was flooded with messages from people expressing amazement.

column1: Among them was Uri Geller

column3: and a ""natural gift"" for his 75th birthday just days earlier.

column1: The self-described ""mystifier"" and psychic has placed the blown-up images in his recently opened museum in Jaffa
column2: in southern Tel Aviv.

column1: A devastating fire that swept through South Africa's Houses of Parliament in Cape Town has reignited - hours after it was said to be under control.
Flames have been billowing from the building's roof. Firefighters are at the scene
column2: trying to douse the blaze.

column1: The fire first broke out on Sunday
column2: totally destroying the National Assembly
column3: or lower chamber.

column1: Police have arrested a suspect who will appear in court on Tuesday on charges of arson
column2: housebreaking and theft.

column1: Authorities had warned that flare-ups would be possible because of carpets and wooden floors in the building.
The void beneath the roof sheeting of the National Assembly is on fire
column2: city officials said.

column1: On Sunday
column2: President Cyril Ramaphosa called the fire a ""terrible and devastating event"".

column1: He said the building's sprinkler system had not functioned properly
column2: and praised firefighters for responding to the fire in minutes.

column1: The parliament is not currently in session because of the holidays
column2: and no-one was injured.

column1: Government minister Patricia de Lille said Sunday's fire had led to the ""complete burning down"" of the National Assembly chamber.
CCTV cameras were not being monitored at the time the fire started on Sunday
column2: she said.

column1: Other areas of the parliamentary complex - parts of which date back to 1884 - were also badly damaged.
Ms De Lille said it was still too hot for people to go inside the building to check the extent of the damage
column2: but a drone was being used to ""assess the structure of the building until the temperatures can cool down"".

column1: The building is home to thousands of treasures including historic books
column2: photographs and important works of art.

column1: There is particular concern that the valuable Keiskamma Tapestry
column2: which is 120m (394ft) long and documents South Africa's history
column3: may have been damaged or destroyed.

column1: This video can not be played
The Houses of Parliament in Cape Town are made up of three sections
column2: with the oldest dating back to 1884. The newer sections built in the 1920s and 1980s house the National Assembly. The government is based in Pretoria.

column1: Mr Ramaphosa on Sunday spoke of his sadness at ""this destruction of the home of our democracy"".
Parliament said ""all efforts"" would be made to limit any disruption to its work.
Cape Town Mayor Geordin Hill-Lewis said the city's Council Chamber would be made available as an alternative place for parliament to meet.
It was the second fire at the parliament in under a year. In March there was a fire caused by an electrical fault.
Last year
column2: a fire ravaged part of the University of Cape Town's library
column3: which was home to a unique collection of African archives.

column3: 'turmoil'

column1: Turkey's annual inflation rate has soared to a 19-year high
column2: underlining the country's financial turmoil and alarm over its president's policies.

column1: Prices hit more than 36% December as the cost of transport
column2: food and other staples ate into household budgets.

column1: Most central banks raise interest rates to help cool inflation but Turkey has gone the other way.
It has meant a collapse in the value of the lira
column2: as Tayyip Erdogan prioritises exports over currency stability.

column1: The lira shed 44% of its value against the dollar last year
column2: and fell another 5% on Monday before recovering to trade flat.

column1: The drop in the lira has made the price of inflation-fuelling imports more expensive
column2: ranging from energy to many of the raw materials Turkey's manufacturers turn into exports.

column1: Mr Erdogan has described interest rates as ""the mother and father of all evil
column2: and has used more unorthodox policy to try to dampen prices including intervening in foreign exchange markets.

column1: In a speech on Monday he said Turkey was ""going through a transformation in economy and rising to the next league"".
He said the nation is ""reaping the fruits especially in exports of our country's efforts and hard work in the past 20 years to bolster our foreign trade"".
One economist forecast that inflation could reach as high as 50% by the spring unless the direction of monetary policy was reversed.
Rates should be immediately and aggressively hiked because this is urgent
column2: said Ozlem Derici Sengul
column3: founding partner at Spinn Consulting
column4: in Istanbul. But she accepted the central bank was unlikely to act.

column1: Mr Erdogan overhauled the central bank's leadership last year. The bank has slashed rates to 14% from 19% since September.
The subsequent accelerating surge in prices and drop in the lira have upended household and company budgets.
There were pictures last month of people queuing for subsidised bread in Istanbul
column2: where local officials have said the cost of living was up 50% in a year.

column1: The cost of living is expected to rise further
column2: especially after recent hikes in the price of electricity and gas bills of around 50% and 25% respectively.

column1: The central bank has argued that temporary factors have been driving prices
column2: and had forecast in October it would end the year at 18.4%. The bank's official inflation target is 5%
column3: but the rate has remained in the double digits for the past two years.

column1: To curb the lira's weakness
column2: Mr Erdogan unveiled a scheme three weeks ago in which the state protects converted local deposits from losses versus hard currencies. That sparked a sharp 50% rally in the lira with support from the central bank.

column1: But the lira then sank again last week
column2: prompting a call on Friday from the president for people to keep all their savings in lira and shift gold into banks.

column1: The economic turmoil has hit President Erdogan's opinion poll ratings ahead of planned elections scheduled for no later than mid-2023.

column1: A Canadian court has awarded C$107m (£62m; $84m)
column2: plus interest
column3: to the families of six people who died when a plane was downed near Tehran in 2020.

column1: The family members awarded compensation by Ontario's Superior Court of Justice lost spouses
column2: siblings
column3: children

column1: Ukraine International Airlines flight PS752 was hit by two missiles after taking off. Iran has said it mistook the aircraft for a US missile.
All 176 people on board died.
They included 55 Canadians and 35 permanent residents of Canada. The relatives had filed a civil lawsuit against Iran and other officials who they say were to blame for the incident.
It was not immediately clear how the money would be collected from Iran. The relatives' lawyer
column2: Mark Arnold
column3: said his team would look to seize Iranian assets in Canada and abroad

column1: This is the first time that compensation has been awarded to the families of the victims
column2: CBC reports
column3: adding that Iran did not defend itself in court.

column1: Last year a report by the Canadian government said Iran was ""fully responsible"" for the downing of the plane
column2: and that it had been a result of ""incompetence"" and ""recklessness"".

column1: Iranian authorities initially denied responsibility for the incident
column2: which happened on 8 January 2020. But as evidence mounted
column3: the Revolutionary Guards' Aerospace Force said an air defence unit had mistaken the Boeing 737-800 for a US missile.

column1: Iran's air defences had been on high alert because the country had just fired ballistic missiles at two Iraqi military bases hosting US forces. That was in retaliation for the killing of top Iranian general Qasem Soleimani in a US drone strike in Baghdad five days earlier.

121;Covid-19: French MPs get death threats over support for vaccine pass;2022-01-03T16:13:44.000Z;[];['france'
column2: 'coronavirus vaccines'
column3: 'coronavirus pandemic'];['support'

column1: Several French MPs say they have received death threats as they debate a Covid-19 pass that would bar the unvaccinated from much of public life.
The government is seeking to pass a law that would require people to show proof of vaccination to access public venues and transport with some exceptions.
The legislation is expected to be approved in a vote this week but has angered vaccine opponents.
France has one of the highest Covid vaccination rates in the EU.
At least 91% of the adult population have been fully jabbed
column2: according to the French government.

column1: On Sunday Agnès Firmin Le Bodo of the centre-right Agir party tweeted an email she received containing graphic threats to kill her over her support for the vaccination pass.
Our democracy is in danger
column2: wrote Ms Firmin Le Bodo
column3: who is also a pharmacist and vaccinates people against Covid.

column1: In an interview with BFM TV
column2: she said she had reported the threats to the police and would not be deterred from supporting the vaccine pass.

column1: Another MP
column2: Naïma Moutchou of the Horizons party
column3: shared a similar tweet which included a screenshot of an emailed threat.

column1: In parliament on Monday
column2: Health Minister Olivier Véran condemned the death threats and the ""selfishness"" of vaccine opponents.

column1: Last week Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin said police would strengthen protections for elected officials ahead of the vote on vaccine passes.
Barbara Bessot Ballot of the ruling En Marche! party said MPs had received messages threatening to kill them for ""attacking our freedom"".
Those death threats are unacceptable
column2: she wrote on Twitter.

column1: Throughout the pandemic
column2: critics have accused French President Emmanuel Macron's government of violating freedoms by imposing Covid rules. Protests against these rules have been held regularly.

column1: For months France has asked people to show either proof of vaccination or a negative Covid test to access many public venues.
But the French government has decided to remove the option to show a negative test in response to record increases in infections
column2: driven by the highly contagious Omicron and Delta variants of Covid.

column1: The government is aiming to bring the vaccine pass into force in mid-January
column2: once it has been approved by parliament.

column1: Most parties back the vaccine pass
column2: which is expected to be passed by the lower house early this week
column3: before being debated in the Senate on Wednesday.

122;David Bowie: Singer's estate sells rights to his entire body of work to WCM;2022-01-03T19:55:28.000Z;[];['david bowie'
column2: 'music'];['bowie'
column3: 'singers'

column1: David Bowie's estate has sold the publishing rights to his ""entire body of work"" to Warner Chappell Music
column2: including hundreds of songs such as Space Oddity
column3: Changes and Let's Dance.

column1: WCM now has global music publishing rights to his song catalogue
column2: the singer's estate told the BBC.

column1: Variety suggested the deal was worth ""upwards of $250m (£185m)""
column2: but the terms of the agreement were not given.

column1: WCM head Guy Moot said they were ""proud"" to be ""chosen as caretakers"".
Bowie died of cancer in 2016. He was hailed as an extraordinary artist and genius in a huge global outpouring of tributes from fellow music stars
column2: including Sir Paul McCartney
column3: the Rolling Stones
column4: Brian Eno and Madonna among others.

column1: The agreement with WCM includes the 26 studio albums released during Bowie's lifetime and the posthumous studio album release
column2: Toy
column3: plus the two studio albums from Tin Machine - the rock supergroup fronted by Bowie.

column1: Tracks released as singles from soundtracks and other projects are also included.
Given the ups and downs of the music industry over the last 20 years
column2: the appeal of a big cheque is
column3: perhaps

column1: Streaming may not quite have replaced the billions lost by the decline of the CD
column2: but it is
column3: for many established artists
column6: income stream; and for record labels and a number of new firms who have entered the market

column1: With the music industry becoming ever more complicated
column2: with licensing deals over streaming
column3: adverts
column5: video games and online video to negotiate
column6: the artists - or their estates and families - have a large and hassle-free deposit in the bank
column7: and the complicated job of turning music into money is left to the experts.

column1: With Spotify adding 60
column2: 000 songs to its catalogue every day
column3: the chance of a new act making a splash seems tougher than ever - legacy artists with 50 years of fame and proven sales look like a relatively safe bet.

column1: Bowie released a total of 111 singles
column2: averaging two per year during his career
column3: and 51 music videos.

column1: This deal follows huge names
column2: including Bruce Springsteen
column3: Bob Dylan and Paul Simon
column4: recently selling the rights to their music catalogues.

column1: Moot
column2: who is WCM's co-chairman and chief executive
column3: said Bowie's was ""one of the most ground-breaking
column5: and enduring catalogues in music history""
column6: adding he had ""inspired millions of fans and countless innovators

column1: These are not only extraordinary songs
column2: but milestones that have changed the course of modern music forever
column3: he said.

column1: This video can not be played
He described Bowie's ""vision and creative genius"" driving him to ""push the envelope
column2: lyrically and musically - writing songs that challenged convention
column3: changed the conversation
column4: and have become part of the canon of global culture"".

column1: The executive added they were looking forward to ""tending his unparalleled body of songs with passion and care"".
WCM said the agreement followed last year's announcement of a deal between Bowie's estate and Warner Music Group [WMG]
column2: for it to oversee his full back catalogue of albums between 1968 and 1999.

column1: Warner Music has licensed worldwide rights to Bowie's recorded music catalogue from 1968. With this new deal with Warner Chappell
column2: WMG is now home to Bowie's body of work as both a songwriter and recording artist
column3: WCM added.

column1: Warner Chappell Music is the global music publishing company of Warner Music Group. WCM co-chair and COO Carianne Marshall said they were ""pleased"" the estate felt they had the "" knowledge
column2: experience
column3: and resources to take the reins and continue to promote a collection of this stature"".

column1: She called Bowie's music a ""living
column2: breathing collection of timeless songs that are as powerful and resonant today as they were when they were first written"".

column1: Allen Grubman
column2: speaking on behalf of Bowie's estate
column3: said: ""We are truly gratified that David Bowie's body of music will now be in the capable hands of Warner Chappell Music Publishing. We are sure they will cherish it and take care of it with the greatest level of dignity.""

column1: Bowie's innovation was not just in the recording studio and in front of the camera - he was also involved in the world of finance. In the mid-90s
column2: Bowie
column3: his financial manager Bill Zysblat
column4: and banker David Pullman came up with a new scheme to generate cash from the singer's extensive back catalogue.

column2: Bowie sold asset-backed securities
column3: dubbed ""Bowie bonds""
column4: which awarded investors a share in his future royalties for 10 years. The securities
column5: which were bought by US insurance giant Prudential Financial for $55m
column6: committed him to repay his new creditors out of future income
column7: and gave a fixed annual return of 7.9%.

column1: He struck a deal with record label EMI which allowed him to package up and sell bonds on royalties for 25 albums released between 1969 and 1990 - which included classics such as The Man Who Sold The World
column2: Ziggy Stardust
column3: and Heroes

column1: But in 2004
column2: rating agency Moody's Investors Services downgraded Bowie bonds to only one level above ""junk""
column3: the lowest rating
column4: after a downturn in the music industry.

column1: Bowie had already predicted the decline in traditional music sales
column2: telling the New York Times in 2002 that music would become ""like running water or electricity"".

column1: 124;UK steel future uncertain without US tariffs deal;2022-01-04T00:07:07.000Z;[];['steel industry'

column1: UK steel companies have been operating at a significant disadvantage compared to their European rivals since the beginning of 2022.
The EU has done a deal with the US
column2: which took effect on 1 January
column3: to allow companies to export steel to the US again without any tariffs.

column1: The UK is yet to reach a similar agreement though it is hoping for more talks with America this month.
It means British companies still face a 25% tariff on exports to the US.
And the effect of the change is already being felt.
At a foundry in Chesterfield
column2: raw materials are being melted in a furnace to make cast iron bars.

column1: Steel and cast iron are no longer a huge chunk of the British economy but they are about to get a little bit smaller.
Because of the US tariffs on products from the UK
column2: United Cast Bar Limited (UCB)
column3: the company that runs this foundry
column4: is moving some of its production to a factory in Spain.

column1: 60% of the products we can make here we can also make in Spain
column2: says James Brand
column3: managing director of foundries at UCB. ""And our customers don't want that extra 25% cost.""

column1: But if the UK manages to do a deal of its own with the US
column2: will that production come back?

column1: Probably not
column2: ' he says. ""It really depends on how early the deal is done.""

column1: Once US importers get used to consignments arriving from Spain
column2: a new trade pattern will have been established and the way the tariffs have been set up means they can't be avoided if any part of a product originates in the UK.

column1: It is highly likely we will just leave it over there (in Spain)
column2: Mr Brand says. ""Lost to the UK completely
column3: then.""

column1: It was President Donald Trump who signed an order in 2018 to introduce the steel tariffs on national security grounds
column2: which he claimed was to help protect US jobs.

column1: If the UK government had hoped that Joe Biden's administration would change course quickly
column2: it has been disappointed.

column1: Neither public diplomacy nor private negotiation has yet led to any breakthrough.
Following Mr Trump's move
column2: both the UK and the EU retaliated with tariffs of their own against US products. But it is the EU that has got a deal done first
column3: to resolve the dispute.

column1: That's partly because in trade
column2: size matters.

column1: They (the EU) are just bigger so they account for more steel exports to the US
column2: and that means there is more interest from US importers in getting it resolved
column3: says Soumaya Keynes
column4: Britain economics editor at The Economist.

column1: And because there is more trade involved with the EU
column2: the retaliation hurts more.""

column1: The EU was also more explicit about how it intended to accelerate retaliation against the American tariffs.
The UK was
column2: says Ms Keynes
column3: ""a bit friendlier
column5: and that could mean the EU had more leverage.""

column1: For the UK government
column2: there is an added complication.

column1: There is political concern in Washington about British threats to suspend parts of the post-Brexit deal with the EU on Northern Ireland.
The two issues are quite separate
column2: but it is possible that one could delay the other.

column1: The government argues that the steel dispute could in fact lead to further complications in Northern Ireland
column2: because of its special status as part of the EU single market for goods.

column1: But it is an awkward mix.
There is also the question of stepping up UK retaliation against the US tariffs.
The government's formal response to a public consultation on further counter-measures has already been delayed
column2: and it cannot be put off forever

column1: Trade secretary Anne-Marie Trevelyan issued a careful warning when she spoke to the BBC last month
column2: after returning from a visit to Washington

column1: We had a very frank conversation
column2: and I was very clear that the pressures that we are under to use countervailing measures if we can't solve the problem are becoming more and more acute.""

column1: The government certainly hopes the dispute can be resolved soon
column2: before it gets worse.

column1: A solution later this month would be a great relief
column2: and the message from industry is pretty clear.

column1: Crack on
column2: please
column3: says UCB's James Brand. ""Let's get a deal brokered as soon as possible and put us on a level playing field with the rest of Europe.""

column1: It wasn't supposed to be like this. After Brexit
column2: the UK was relying on a closer relationship with the US than it had when it was part of the EU.

column1: But in matters of trade
column2: many things are easier said than done.

column2: 'medical technology'];['separate'

column1: Theranos founder Elizabeth Holmes has been convicted of defrauding investors after a months-long landmark trial in California.
Prosecutors said Holmes knowingly lied about technology she said could detect diseases with a few drops of blood.
Jurors found Holmes guilty of four charges
column2: including conspiracy to commit fraud against investors and three counts of wire fraud.

column1: The 37-year-old could face up to 20 years in prison.
Holmes faced 11 charges in total and was found not guilty of four charges relating to defrauding the public.
The split verdict came after the judge said the jury
column2: having deliberated for seven days
column3: could deliver a partial verdict after being unable to reach consensus on another three counts.

column1: Theranos
column2: at one point valued at $9bn (£6.5bn)
column3: was once the darling of Silicon Valley.

column1: The firm promised it would revolutionise the healthcare industry
column2: but its claims began to unravel in 2015 after a Wall Street Journal investigation reported that its core blood-testing technology did not work.

column1: For nearly four months at trial
column2: the jury of eight men and four women were presented with two starkly different accounts of the former self-made billionaire
column3: whose downfall shook Silicon Valley.

column1: Calling some 30 witnesses
column2: the prosecution sought to prove that Ms Holmes knew the product she was selling to investors was a sham
column3: but remained hell-bent on the firm's success.

column1: At trial
column2: multiple lab directors testified they told Holmes about the flaws in Theranos' technology but were instructed to downplay their concerns. At the same time
column3: they said
column4: Holmes told investors the technology was operating as planned.

column1: Holmes ""chose fraud over business failure. She chose to be dishonest with investors and patients""
column2: said prosecutor Jeff Schenk in closing arguments. ""That choice was not only callous
column3: it was criminal.""

column1: The defence countered with descriptions of a dedicated and driven businesswoman
column2: making waves in a male-dominated industry.

column1: This video can not be played
Testifying in her own defence
column2: Holmes acknowledged mistakes in Theranos' operation
column3: but maintained she never knowingly defrauded patients or investors.

column1: The defence also laid blame on Ramesh ""Sunny"" Balwani
column2: Holmes' former business partner and long-term boyfriend.

column1: Holmes has accused Mr Balwani
column2: 19 years her senior
column3: of emotional and sexual abuse - allegations he denies. Their decade-long relationship came to an end around the same time he stepped down as CEO in May 2016. He faces a separate trial next month.

column1: Holmes founded Theranos as a teenager
column2: shortly after dropping out of chemical engineering at Stanford University.

column1: She was able to raise more than $900m from billionaires such as media magnate Rupert Murdoch and tech mogul Larry Ellison.
The firm officially ceased operations in 2018 following the scandal.

column1: Gunmen tried to kill Haitian Prime Minister Ariel Henry during an event on Saturday to mark the anniversary of the country's independence
column2: officials say.

column1: The incident happened as Mr Henry took part in the ceremony at a church in the northern city of Gonaïves.
Video posted online showed the prime minister and his entourage scrambling toward their cars amid intense gunfire.
The security situation has deteriorated significantly since the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse last July.
Mr Henry has pledged to crack down on powerful gangs that are blamed for a wave of kidnappings and for seizing control of much of the gas distribution around the country
column2: causing severe fuel shortages.

column1: The prime minister's office said ""bandits and terrorists"" were behind the assassination attempt
column2: and that arrest warrants had been issued for the suspects.

column1: The office accused the group of hiding behind walls to attack the convoy and of threatening the bishop by surrounding the church
column2: according to the Associated Press.

column1: One person was killed and two others were injured in the gunfight between the armed men and security forces
column2: local media reported.

column1: The attack is another blow to the fragile administration led by Mr Henry
column2: who became Haiti's acting head of state two weeks after Moïse was killed. The circumstances of the assassination
column3: believed to have been carried out by a group of mercenaries

column1: No date has been announced for a vote to elect a new president.
The rise in violence and a dire economic situation
column2: made worse by several natural disasters in recent years
column3: have led to a growing number of Haitians seeking opportunities in other countries.

127;Sound Of 2022: Mimi Webb makes music to break up to... as her ex-boyfriend found out;2022-01-04T00:00:10.000Z;[];['tiktok'
column2: 'sound of 2022'
column3: 'music'

column1: When Mimi Webb started recording her EP
column2: Seven Shades Of Heartbreak
column3: last year
column4: she had no idea it would prove prophetic.

column1: Writing songs about the loves she'd lost focused her attention on her current relationship - and she wasn't keen on what she discovered
column2: as her boyfriend quickly learned

column1: The EP helped me realise that that relationship wasn't right for me
column2: she confesses. ""It really helped me figure out what I felt was missing... And he probably struggles with it
column3: you know? When he listens to the EP

column1: Still
column2: she wouldn't change a thing.

column1: It's just so crazy how I look back on that EP now
column2: she says during our conversation in mid-December. ""It came out two months ago and I was in such a different place. It's really showed how much can change within a short period.""

column1: That applies equally to her personal and her professional life. Seven Shades Of Heartbreak became the 21-year-old's first top 10 album
column2: and she ended the year performing her single
column3: Good Without
column4: on the Top of the Pops Christmas special.

column1: Now
column2: she's earned third place on BBC Radio 1's Sound Of 2022 list - which means she's been identified by a panel of more than 130 record industry experts and fellow musicians as one of next year's breakthrough stars.

column1: I think Mimi is a real talent
column2: and definitely one of the most exciting breakthrough artists
column3: says pop star Tom Grennan
column4: who voted in the poll. ""Her voice and song craft combined are incredibly potent.""

column1: Oh my god
column2: that's insane
column3: says Webb on hearing she's made the top three.

column1: The Sound Of list is something I'd look out for every year. I always thought I'd love to be on there one day
column2: so this is incredible!""

column1: A precocious talent with a powerful
column2: octave-destroying vocal range
column3: Webb has been performing ever since she was a child in Canterbury.

column1: A talent show regular
column2: she had a brief role on EastEnders
column3: before Adele's 19 gave her ""goosebumps"" and made her fall in love with the idea of becoming a songwriter.

column1: She honed her skills at the British Institute of Modern Music (BIMM)
column2: discovering a talent for what she calls ""powerhouse sing-your-heart out songs"" and nabbing a record deal at the tender age of 18.

column1: Her very first release
column2: Before I Go
column3: blew up on TikTok after she sang it a capella in a New York restaurant for social media star Charli D'Amelio.

column1: 85 million views later
column2: she began to unleash a barrage of emotionally-charged pop songs - Good Without
column3: Dumb Love
column4: 24/5 - which have made her a constant presence on Radio 1 over the last 12 months.

column1: But while her songs dig deep
column2: she's unabashedly positive in real life. Everything is ""incredible"" and ""exciting"" and ""crazy""
column3: suggesting that
column5: Webb is savouring her success with unabashed glee.

column1: Here's what she had to say about her career so far - from the piano teacher who spotted her talent
column2: to her surprisingly modest tour rider.

column1: When did you discover you could sing?
I think I was probably eight years old. I always sang
column2: since I was a toddler - but I think the moment when I first thought
column3: ""Oh
column4: there's something going on here"" was when I was eight and doing choir and musical theatre at school.

column1: Who was the first person who encouraged you?
It was my piano teacher at secondary school. In my first lesson
column2: he asked me what could I play and I said
column3: ""Oh
column4: I can play Someone Like You by Adele and I can sing it
column7: this is a piano lesson"" but when I sang
column8: he just was blown away. He then called up the guitar teacher
column10: and they basically got my mum on the school phone and told her
column11: ""This is something you need to pursue"".  I was so excited!

column1: What was the first song you wrote for yourself?
Actually
column2: I've been writing since I was 10 years old. I'd sing these random songs I made up in my head in the back of the car. My mum used to assume they were real songs
column3: but they weren't! And the more I did it
column4: the more she would be like

column1: You ended up leaving home at 16 to attend BIMM in Brighton. What was that like?
BIMM was two hours away from Canterbury - so it was very intense and scary. I had to move in with a host family and make a whole new friendship group.  But I kept saying to myself
column2: ""I want to be an artist and this is the way I need to go about it. If I go two stairs up
column3: I won't be going back down.""

column1: One of the first songs you uploaded was a drum and bass track that attracted the attention of your manager
column2: is that right?

column1: Yeah. It was indeed.
Is it still available anywhere?
No
column2: it actually got taken down in the end. It's an interesting one because I basically sang a melody over this DJ's track and then I dropped it online. I wanted to just get someone to hear my voice - and that's how I found my manager Rob and we've been smashing it ever since.

column1: If you had to rate that song out of 10 from today's perspective
column2: what would it get?

column1: Erm
column2: a six? It wasn't bad - but obviously my music is very different now.

column1: How soon after that did you write Before I Go?
I wrote Before I Go when I was 18
column2: in the summer and it was probably sitting there for a good year before we released it in February of 2020. It's my first baby!

column1: And how did you end up singing it on Charli D'Amelio's TikTok?
So basically
column2: I didn't even know what TikTok was - but I met Charli in New York around Christmas 2019
column3: and I told her about my music and she just started supporting it
column5: amazingly. The amount of people that heard that song just from a few videos that she did was just unbelievable. Just to see that reaction

column1: You've got your own TikTok account now
column2: and I love how much your family get involved in the videos. How do they feel about it?

column1: Oh my God
column2: they just love seeing how happy I am. They're just so proud and I'm just so grateful that they're so supportive.

column1: There's a video where you put your dad in the front seat of your car and play him Halfway for the first time. What's it like sharing something so emotional and raw with him?
He definitely asked
column2: ""What's going on here? Did he break your heart?""  But that's one of the things - from this experience of playing my music
column3: I've built a very honest relationship between me my parents where they can get to know me through my lyrics. And it's been so nice to be able to go to my dad and get advice.

column1: In Halfway
column2: you sing about a five-year relationship - so is the whole EP about the same person?

column1: Half of the EP's about my first ever boyfriend
column2: and then the second is probably about my ex-boyfriend. It's crazy because I was in a relationship when I was writing this EP
column3: and the EP kind of helped me realise that that relationship wasn't right for me.

column1: The song Good Without feels like it might be about that realisation... The lyric ""I'm good without you"" is all about moving on and building back your confidence
column2: right?

column1: It really is. It's not about that break-up from two months ago - but it's got that empowerment to it. And I went back to it when I was going through all that stuff
column2: and it really helped me out. I was just so grateful that it was there.

column1: If you didn't have the music
column2: what would be your top tip for getting over heartbreak?

column1: Get into a routine
column2: take your time
column3: going out with good friends and having a little laugh really helps. And put yourself first. ""You can't love anyone else until you love yourself
column4: that's always what my mum used to say to me.

column1: Are your family helping to keep you grounded now that your career's taking off?
One hundred per cent. I just moved to my own place in London about a month ago
column2: but I'm always
column3: on the phone to them
column5: catching up. They keep my feet on the floor.

column1: You haven't started asking for puppies on your rider
column2: then?

column1: Oh gosh
column2: no. Just sausage rolls.

column1: Amazing! Are sausage rolls good for the voice?
Do you know what? I think they're alright. A bit of pastry doesn't do you any harm!
Until a flake gets stuck in your throat...
Oh my gosh
column2: you're right. No more sausage rolls then.

column1: There's a vocal run in the chorus of Dumb Love that covers an octave and a half in two bars. Is that tricky to sing live?
Oh
column2: it's great live. The song has a nice pace
column3: so getting to the high note isn't too hard because I have time to breathe.

column1: Do you know what your vocal range is like? How many octaves you can cover?
Quite a few. I can go very high and I can go pretty low. You'd think with my husky voice that upper register would be tough for me
column2: but I can get a high
column3: sweet-sounding note.

column1: The video for Halfway was filmed in an empty theme park. What was the best ride?
Oh
column2: we had so much fun on the teapots. I have three of my best friends in the video and we all had such a laugh. We were so dizzy.

column1: Is that the best pop star perk you've had so far?
Actually
column2: it's more about when people come up to you at the end of a show. Those are the moments that really take your breath away and make you think
column3: ""Wow

column1: But the whole thing is exciting. You're in the studio one minute being a songwriter
column2: and then the next minute you're on stage
column3: then you're doing an interview or you're filming a new music video. I just love every part of it.

column1: That's cool
column2: because I think a lot of people feel frazzled by all of that - but you're clearly throwing yourself into it
column3: full force.

column1: Straight in and thrashing it out!
And what does 2022 hold for you?
The start of 2022 is in the studio. I'll be in LA writing for a little bit
column2: then I'll be off on my Europe and UK tour. It's going to be so good.

128;Is there a better way to make new resolutions stick?;2022-01-04T00:03:53.000Z;[];['apps'
column2: 'fitness'
column3: 'life'

column1: Run. Work on doctorate."" So begin all my to-do lists but progress is elusive. With New Year's resolution season here - perhaps technology can make me into a more productive machine.
An extraordinary amount of what we do is habit
column2: says Brendan Kelly
column3: professor of psychiatry at Trinity College Dublin.

column1: It is estimated that between 45% and 95% of what we do is habitual
column2: ""but I'd reckon towards the higher end of that range
column3: says Prof Kelly.

column1: We act according to our habits
column2: ""from the time we rise and go through our morning routines
column3: until we fall asleep after evening routines
column5: a neuroscientist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

column1: We develop those habits by encoding them in a part of our brain called the striatum
column2: which deals with reward and releases the ""feel-good"" neurotransmitter dopamine
column3: her research shows.

column1: Now a new cohort of apps - with names like SnapHabit
column2: Habitica and Strides - reckon we can reprogram our habits to improve our lives and be happier.

column1: SnapHabit
column2: for instance
column3: arrives with two default habits: to take a daily walk

column1: At the bottom appear ""guided journeys""
column2: or sample practices you can select to exercise in the habit app gym. For example
column3: becoming a more committed opponent of racism is one
column4: doing 100 press-ups a day is another.

column1: Or
column2: you can choose your own. I add ""Run for an hour""
column3: and ""Colour two boxes"" on the days I selected. It is strangely satisfying.

column1: Short-term rewards like this are important for changing our habits
column2: says Prof Kelly. Doing physical exercise just to be healthier ""is not enough to sustain a daily habit""
column3: he warns.

column1: And to get a new habit or change an old one
column2: the change ""needs to be small
column3: should ideally be tied to an existing habit
column4: and must be rewarding in the short term

column1: So
column2: apps can help contribute toward short-term rewards. And also tie our new habits to existing ones. Like checking our mobiles
column3: or sharing things we've done with our friends.

column1: Telling people in our lives about our attempts to change a habit can also make us work harder - because we then have friends to hold us accountable.
We did a correlation analysis. How many friends you had on the app was correlated with how successful you were in changing your habits
column2: says Jake Bernstein
column3: SnapHabit's co-founder.

column1: Similarly
column2: Habitica
column3: another app
column4: includes ""a quest function that incorporates social accountability
column6: who was an early user of the app and then became chief executive of the company behind it.

column1: More technology of business:
If you don't do any of the things that you've committed to for the day
column2: then the app takes away points from you and from everyone else who's opted in to participating in the quest with you
column3: explains Ms Hsu.

column1: And collecting ""random pets"" as part of the game helped her stay on top of meditating
column2: exercising
column3: and going to bed on time

column1: I found the visual representation of the work I was doing extremely helpful
column2: especially since I do a lot of intangible work that doesn't necessarily feel productive
column3: says Ms Hsu
column4: who also practises as a lawyer.

column1: On SnapHabit
column2: the largest group
column3: 32.7% of users
column4: is trying to exercise more. In second place
column5: 15.9% are trying to build habits to learn or study.

column1: Mr Bernstein says he was surprised by some of the habits people set up -  for example
column2: ""not masturbating"".

column1: If an app successfully helps us change our habits
column2: it's likely because it mirrors behavioural principles for how we can best train the basal ganglia in the striatum in our brain.

column1: One aspect is cognitive load: this is the mental effort involved in completing a task or learning new information.
We're more likely to learn a new habit when this is low
column2: so by marking tasks we've completed
column3: an app can reduce it
column4: and make forming the habit easier for us.

column1: Another is called the ""Zeigarnik effect"": we remember incomplete tasks more than ones we've completed.
So
column2: by showing progress bars or percentages
column3: an app can help remind us of our tasks in progress.

column1: Talking about the origin of his own app
column2: ""I originally built it to solve my own problem
column3: says Mr Bernstein.

column1: I know the things that I enjoy doing and that give me fulfilment
column2: so how can I map the way I spend my time to those things.""

column1: He had begun quantifying his time with a Fitbit
column2: but when Covid started he wanted to make it ""more social
column3: make us more connected and help us meet our goals together"".

column1: It's a similar story to Kyle Richey's
column2: founder of the Strides habit app. ""In 2011
column3: I was using to-do list and calendar apps to manage my day

column1: These were ""awesome replacements for their analogue counterparts
column2: but I felt like something was missing
column3: he observes.

column1: I wanted to do more than put an ""!"" on a task. I needed a way to prioritise the right things and use behavioural science techniques to stay motivated and focused.""
Apps that show you the number of consecutive days you've followed a new habit represent ""a super powerful tactic but can also be incredibly frustrating if you drop them""
column2: says Mr Bernstein.

column1: It's important ""to be compassionate to yourself when you fail
column2: he says. And take away something positive
column3: like insight about what motivates you.

column1: An app ""will never tell you to take a break and look after yourself
column2: says Shubhangi Karmakar
column3: a junior doctor in Dublin and an editor of the British Journal of Psychiatry. ""The important thing isn't just to form a habit
column4: but to form a healthy one

column1: Changing our behaviour is ""the hardest thing""
column2: adds Mr Bernstein. And ultimately
column3: apps like these on their own can only go so far.

column1: After all
column2: for me
column3: the consecutive number of days spent working on my doctorate still remains stubbornly stuck at zero.

column1: Electric car maker Tesla has been criticised in the US after opening a showroom in China's controversial Xinjiang region.
The company
column2: headed by billionaire Elon Musk
column3: opened the showroom in the city of Urumqi on New Year's Eve.

column1: However
column2: the move has been welcomed by some in China.

column1: China has been accused of slavery and genocide against the Uyghur minority group in the resource-rich western region of the country.
Republican senator Marco Rubio
column2: who sponsored a bill signed into law by President Joe Biden in December that requires firms to prove that goods imported from Xinjiang were not produced with forced labour
column3: spoke out about Tesla's decision.

column1: Mr Rubio tweeted: ""Nationless corporations are helping the Chinese Communist Party cover up genocide and slave labour in the region.""
Scott Paul
column2: the president of the Alliance of American Manufacturing industry body
column3: said: ""I'll be blunt: Any company doing business in Xinjiang is complicit in the cultural genocide taking place there. But Tesla's actions are especially despicable.""

column1: Tesla did not immediately reply to a request for comment from the BBC.
However
column2: the opening of the new Tesla showroom was widely welcomed by users of China's Twitter-like Weibo social media platform.

column1: One user posted: ""Thank you for expanding in Xinjiang
column2: happy new year!"". Another said: ""You see
column3: Tesla supports the development and construction of Xinjiang

column1: Late last year
column2: US microchip giant Intel apologised after a backlash over a letter it sent urging suppliers not to source products or labour from Xinjiang.

column1: The company's letter sparked criticism in China
column2: with calls for a boycott.

column1: Intel was not the first company to come under pressure over aims to comply with sanctions related to Xinjiang while continuing to operate in China.
Retail giants Nike and H&M also faced a backlash last year after they expressed concern about the alleged use of Uyghur forced labour in cotton production.
The Xinjiang region of China is home to many of country's Muslim Uyghur population and there have been allegations of forced labour and possibly genocide.
In December 2020
column2: the BBC published an investigation based on new research showing China was forcing hundreds of thousands of minorities
column3: including Uyghurs
column4: into manual labour in Xinjiang's cotton fields.

column1: Beijing has repeatedly denied the claims.

130;Elizabeth Holmes: Has the Theranos scandal changed Silicon Valley?;2022-01-04T00:56:41.000Z;[];['companies'
column2: 'theranos trial'
column3: 'silicon valley'

column1: For years Elizabeth Holmes was the darling of Silicon Valley
column2: a woman that could do no wrong.

column1: The start-up she founded
column2: Theranos
column3: attracted hundreds of millions of dollars in investments.

column1: Yet the company she had built was based on fantasy science.
The technology Theranos was producing - supposedly testing for hundreds of diseases with a pin prick of blood - seemed incredible. And it was.
Millions of dollars were squandered and some who used the company's tests
column2: including a cancer patient
column3: say they were misdiagnosed.

column1: Now
column2: years after Theranos collapsed
column3: Holmes has been found guilty in California on four counts of conspiring to defraud investors.

column1: For an outsider to Silicon Valley the story sounds nonsensical. How were so many people taken in?
Yet in Silicon Valley
column2: many believe that Theranos - far from being an aberration - speaks of systemic problems with start-up culture.

column1: In Silicon Valley
column2: hyping up your product - over-promising - isn't unusual
column3: and Holmes was clearly very good at it.

column1: A Stanford University drop-out
column2: she was
column3: by all accounts articulate
column4: confident and good at presenting a vision - a mission as she described it - to revolutionise diagnostics.

column1: Sceptical experts told her that her idea was just that - an idea - and wouldn't work.
But she projected an unfaltering confidence that the technology would change the world.
It's baked in to the culture"" said Margaret O'Mara
column2: author of The Code: Silicon Valley and the Remaking of America.

column1: ""If you are a young start-up in development - with a barely existent product - a certain amount of swagger and hustle is expected and encouraged"" she said.
Particularly at an early stage
column2: when a start-up is in its infancy
column3: investors are often looking at people and ideas rather than substantive technology anyway. General wisdom holds that the technology will come with the right concept - and the right people to make it work.

column1: Ms Holmes was brilliant at selling that dream
column2: exercising a very Silicon Valley practice: 'fake it until you make it'.

column1: Her problem was she couldn't make it work. Her lawyers argued that Holmes was merely a businesswoman who failed
column2: but was not a fraudster.

column1: The problem in Silicon Valley is that the line between fraud and merely playing into the faking it culture is very thin.
Theranos was an early warning of a cultural shift in Silicon Valley that has allowed promoters and scoundrels to prosper
column2: said tech venture capitalist Roger McNamee
column3: who is critical of big tech and did not invest in Theranos.

column1: He believes that a culture of secrets and lies in Silicon Valley
column2: a culture that allowed Theranos' tech to go un-analysed
column3: is ""absolutely endemic"".

column1: Ambition can be good. Promising a brighter future
column2: and then trying to realise that vision
column3: brought about computers and smartphones.

column1: But for investors
column2: trying to separate the charlatans from the revolutionaries is a constantly evolving challenge.

column1: Last month
column2: Silicon Valley phone app start-up HeadSpin's CEO and founder
column3: Manish Lachwani
column4: was arrested for allegedly defrauding investors. For people putting money on the line
column5: there are great fortunes to be made and lost.

column1: In Silicon Valley intellectual property is closely guarded. The 'coke' recipe
column2: the secret sauce
column3: is often the thing that gives a company value
column4: and new technology firms are particularly sensitive to having their ideas copied or stolen.

column1: Secrecy is important for these companies to succeed - but that culture of secrecy can also be used as a smoke screen
column2: particularly when even employees and investors don't understand or aren't given access to the technology itself.

column1: This is what happened at Theranos. Journalists
column2: investors
column3: politicians
column5: were all told the science was there. Yet when questions were asked they were told the technology was so secret that it could not be fully explained

column1: Walgreens
column2: a major client of Theranos
column3: became exasperated with the lack of information given by the company about how the system worked.

column1: There are many Silicon Valley companies I've reported on that will not fully explain how their tech actually works. They claim to have ""proprietary"" systems that cannot yet be revealed or peer-reviewed.
The system is based on trust
column2: yet it is fundamentally at odds with a culture of ""faking it"" and creates the perfect environment for Thernanos-type scandals
column3: where claims that aren't true are left unchallenged.

column1: A system that places so much emphasis on secrecy needs lawyers
column2: and lots of them. Companies don't want their employees running off with ideas. Non-disclosure agreements (NDAs) are endemic in the start-up world - and by no means confined to tech.

column1: But Silicon Valley's culture of secrecy makes it notably difficult for whistle-blowers.
After the company's collapse
column2: former Theranos employees spoke of intense pressure to withdraw negative public remarks or stay quiet altogether. The company hired aggressive
column3: expensive and very active lawyers to protect Theranos's reputation.

column1: This is not uncommon in Silicon Valley
column2: says Cori Crider from Foxglove
column3: a group that helps whistle-blowers come forward.

column1: I spent more than a decade working in national security and I very often feel like Silicon Valley types play from the playbook of the CIA on this stuff""
column2: she said.

column1: They have managed to scare people and make them think they don't have the right to raise legitimate issues.""
If founders and chief executives aren't being honest
column2: employees need to feel comfortable raising the alarm. All too often they don't.

column1: Amid the hype
column2: it can be easy to forget that many investors looked at Theranos and passed - especially those with a knowledge of healthcare.

column1: Among those who were notable investors were people and groups without expertise in health
column2: such as the media mogul Rupert Murdoch.

column1: For these investors with capital
column2: often their decision to put in a stake assumes that smaller early stage funders have done their homework on the tech.

column1: They're kind of taking third party validation at its word
column2: said Ms O'Mara.

column1: Once again
column2: it's a system based on trust - later investors trusting that earlier ones know what they're doing. The problem here is
column3: with so much money sloshing around

column1: In the end
column2: Theranos got caught. As a health technology company doing real life diagnostics
column3: results and regulators would eventually prove it real or fake.

column1: But with many Silicon Valley companies selling the supposedly new and the cutting edge in fields far less tightly regulated
column2: scrutiny is more lax.

column1: Today
column2: the 'fake it until you make it' culture is still alive and well - as is the repressive culture of secrecy and the aggressive use of NDAs for employees.  It's a model that has its advantages - and helps churn out extremely valuable and sometimes innovative companies.

column1: But it also means the ingredients are still in place for another Theranos scandal.

131;Omicron stats are huge
column2: but look beyond them;2022-01-04T03:28:53.000Z;[];['nhs'
column3: 'omicron variant'

column1: Covid infections have risen to unprecedented levels in recent weeks because of the Omicron variant.
But
column2: as early evidence suggested it would
column3: this variant is causing milder illness

column1: A fall in the proportion of detected cases ending in hospital
column2: shows this. It is now five times lower than it was a year ago.

column1: This is largely thanks to a huge amount of immunity that has built up across the population either through vaccination or infection.
And with better treatments for those who do become ill
column2: one way or another everyone is less at risk to some degree than they were previously.

column1: But the sheer weight of infections means while Omicron is milder
column2: patient numbers in hospital have been going up.

column1: The total has doubled in just under a fortnight in England to more than 14
column2: 000. That
column3: however
column5: 000 peak last winter when more than a third of beds were occupied by Covid patients. Rises are being seen elsewhere in the UK
column6: although gaps in publishing data over the festive period make it hard to judge how quickly.

column1: But to fully understand what's happening you need to look beyond the headline figures.
A hospital case this winter is not the same as one from earlier in the pandemic.
For one thing
column2: a growing proportion of hospital patients with Covid are being treated for something else. They just happen to have the virus.

column1: Latest data
column2: from last week
column3: suggested a third of those admitted to hospital in England were in this position. That's up from a quarter in the autumn. This data is not published in the UK's other nations but there is no reason to think it is any different.

column1: Yet
column2: as the chart above shows
column3: the absolute number in hospital with Covid
column5: is still climbing. And even those who are not in primarily for Covid add pressure to the NHS because of the need for extra infection control measures.

column1: Another sign of how Covid has changed is that the patients who are being treated for it are not getting as sick.
There have been early reports that patients are not spending as long in hospital and the numbers needing critical care has hardly changed. All this puts the NHS in a stronger position to cope.
But make no mistake
column2: the pressures on the front line are severe.

column1: The number of people coming to hospital ill with Covid is well above what the NHS would normally get for all types of respiratory infections combined - and the numbers are rising.
How high they will go is still uncertain. Much depends on whether there will be a big wave of older
column2: frail patients being admitted if Omicron infections move from younger people into older age groups.

column1: There is growing confidence this may not happen though as hospital bosses are reporting even the outbreaks in care homes are not translating into the hospital admissions you would expect. What's more
column2: London as a whole may have already peaked. The boosters
column3: it seems

column1: If you can't see the lookup
column2: click here

column1: But the situation is further complicated by the high number of staff absences driven by large numbers having to isolate.
Again England has the most comprehensive data. Pre-pandemic NHS staff absence in winter was around 5%. The latest data shows it was 8% in the week up to Christmas.
The combined pressures have led at least half a dozen NHS trusts to declare major incidents - when demand exceeds capacity - in the past week.
All this begs the question why something more is not being done to suppress the wave in England - Scotland
column2: Wales and Northern Ireland all have tougher restrictions in place.

column1: The problem now - illustrated by modelling produced for the government by Warwick University - is the window may already have passed. The research suggests even a return to lockdown with only schools open would have virtually no effect on hospitalisations if introduced today.
To have had a significant impact measures would need to have been introduced by Boxing Day or earlier
column2: before Omicron had spread so much.

column1: Even then the argument in favour of tougher action was unclear as infections and hospitalisations would rebound once restrictions were lifted. Largely all it would have achieved is delaying and spreading out illness.
That may have helped the NHS
column2: but would have had to be balanced against wider costs of restrictions to society
column3: the economy and mental health from another lockdown.

column1: What does seem likely is the wave will come and go pretty quickly - even in other parts of the UK the restrictions in place are expected to only have a limited impact.
And once it does
column2: experts believe the extra immunity acquired will mean the population will be even better protected for the future.

column1: US technology giant Apple has become the first company to hit a stock market valuation of $3tn (£2.2tn).
The firm's share price has risen by around 5
column2: 800% since co-founder and former chief executive Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone in 2007.

column1: However
column2: its value slipped a little from that milestone
column3: to end Monday's trading session in New York at $2.99tn.

column1: Apple has been one of the big winners of the pandemic
column2: as coronavirus lockdowns saw spending on gadgets jump.

column1: Hitting $3 trillion is another historical moment for Apple as the company continues to prove the doubters wrong
column2: Dan Ives
column3: an analyst from Wedbush said.

column1: It took just over 16 months for Apple's stock market valuation to rise from $2tn to $3tn
column2: as the world's biggest technology companies saw demand soar as people became more reliant on smartphones
column3: tablets and laptops during lockdowns.

column1: The company became the first company to hit a stock market valuation of $1tn in August 2018.
The iPhone typically accounts for around half of the company's sales
column2: while it is also well-known for its iPad tablets and Mac computers.

column1: Increasingly important parts of the business are software
column2: sold through the Apple store
column3: storage space via the iCloud and services such as its music

column1: The linchpin to Apple's valuation re-rating remains its Services business which we believe is worth $1.5 trillion
column2: Mr Ives said.

column1: In August
column2: Apple's chief executive Tim Cook received more than five million shares in the firm
column3: as he marked ten years in the job.

column1: A company filing with the US Securities and Exchange Commission showed that he sold most of the shares for more than $750m.
It was part of a deal he struck when he took over from co-founder Steve Jobs.
The award was dependent upon on how well Apple's shares had performed compared to other firms on the S&P 500 stock index.
Cupertino
column2: California-based Apple was founded in 1976 by Steve Jobs and his business partners Steve Wozniak and Ronald Wayne.

column1: The company made its stock market debut in 1980 with a market valuation of $1.8bn.
In November
column2: the original Apple computer built by Mr Wozniak and Mr Jobs fetched $400
column3: 000 at auction in the US.

134;China: Xi'an residents in lockdown trade goods for food amid shortage;2022-01-04T11:53:39.000Z;[];['coronavirus lockdown measures'
column2: 'china'];['scale'
column3: 'undermine'

column1: People quarantined in the Chinese city of Xi'an are bartering supplies amid continuing worries over food shortages.
Social posts show locals swapping cigarettes and tech gadgets for food. About 13 million have been confined to their homes since 23 December.
The strict measures come ahead of the Lunar New Year and the Winter Olympics due to be held in Beijing next month.
Overnight
column2: the city of Yuzhou was shut down after the discovery of just three cases
column3: all of them asymptomatic.

column1: Yuzhou
column2: with a population of 1.1 million
column3: has closed its transport system and entertainment venues and banned almost all vehicles from the roads. All but essential food shops are shut
column4: with only workers involved in epidemic prevention allowed out.

column1: The outbreak in the much larger city to the west is the worst China has seen in months as it continues a ""zero Covid"" strategy
column2: seeking to stamp out the virus rather than try to live with it.

column1: Authorities in Xi'an have been providing free food to households
column2: but there have been numerous complaints on social media. Some residents said their supplies were running low or that they had yet to receive aid.

column1: Videos and photos on social media site Weibo showed people exchanging cigarettes for cabbage
column2: dishwashing liquid for apples
column3: and sanitary pads for a small pile of vegetables.

column1: One video showed a resident appearing to trade his Nintendo Switch console for a packet of instant noodles and two steamed buns.
People are swapping stuff with others in the same building
column2: because they no longer have enough food to eat
column3: a resident surnamed Wang told Radio Free Asia. The news outlet also reported that another man had wanted to trade a smartphone and tablet for rice.

column1: Helpless citizens have arrived at the era of bartering - potatoes are exchanged for cotton swabs
column2: one Weibo user said
column3: while another described it as a ""return to primitive society"".

column1: Some were more optimistic though
column2: and commented on how ""touched"" they were by their neighbours' kindness in sharing their supplies with them.

column1: Xi'an is at the epicentre of China's current Covid outbreak
column2: and local authorities have enacted drastic measures which have attracted significant criticism online.

column1: In a recent incident
column2: residents in the Mingde 8 Yingli housing compound in the south of the city were reportedly told just after midnight on 1 January that they had to leave their homes and go to quarantine facilities.

column1: Netizens were also shocked by an unverified post that went viral on Monday. A Xi'an resident said their father had died after he suffered a heart attack and was turned away from a hospital due to the city's Covid situation. The hospital has yet to respond.
Covid first appeared in China and up until a few weeks ago the government had managed to contain it to such a level that new cases were negligible and mainly coming from people arriving from abroad.
What Beijing calls its ""dynamic zero Covid"" strategy combines mass vaccination with a regime of constant testing
column2: nationwide monitoring of people's movements
column3: temperature-taking and phone apps to prove you don't pose a threat. All of that amounts to hyper vigilance about any new outbreak - if and when one is spotted the reaction is severe.

column1: China has been wedded to this approach since the beginning because it's likely the leaders from Xi Jinping down consider anything less would cause illness and death on a scale that would be politically
column2: economically and socially unacceptable. The ruling Communist Party took much of the credit for containing the virus early on - after it had spread beyond China's borders - and diverting from that would undermine its credibility.

column1: There is a broad acceptance of this approach
column2: and the stringent restrictions it can bring
column3: among many Chinese who for decades have not felt they can rely much on the public health system. So illness and the prospect of losing your job

column1: Add to that the prestige attached to - safely - hosting another Olympic Games in a few weeks' time and the fast approaching Chinese New Year mass migration of millions across this country and there is clearly little doubt the government will remain committed to ""zero Covid"" for the foreseeable future.
