column1: Many vintage BlackBerry phones will stop working on Tuesday as the company turns off support for its operating system. For journalist Bill Wilson
column2: it means the retirement of a faithful workhorse.

column1: Is that a Blackberry
column2: I didn't know they were still going?"" has been many a conversation opener over the past decade
column3: and particularly over the past five or six years.

column1: From airport security to pubs and restaurants
column2: even in hospital intensive care
column3: strangers have looked on curiously and even asked to hold and look at my Q10 phone with its distinctive qwerty keyboard.

column1: But my stock answer of ""yes they are still going"" would now have to add ""but not their classic phones"".
Launched in 2013
column2: that particular model
column3: and BlackBerry's phones since then
column4: have faced an increasingly impossible battle as Apple and Samsung set about their battle for global smartphone domination.

column1: Hard to believe that in the late 2000s and early 2010s
column2: BlackBerrys were a ubiquitous sight on commuter trains
column3: trams and planes across the UK - as business professionals scrolled through their emails and tap-tapped away their replies.

column1: But now
column2: after reports of the demise of BlackBerry's operating system on many previous occasions
column3: it really is the final curtain.

column1: For on 4 January
column2: the Canadian firm - which is now a specialist in cyber-security software - is to turn off its BlackBerry OS support.

column1: Announcing the termination
column2: BlackBerry thanked ""our many loyal customers and partners over the years"".

column1: It means remaining die-hard owners of their devices won't be able to make or receive calls
column2: send texts
column3: use wi-fi or access mobile data.

column1: That includes all smartphones running on BlackBerry 7.1 OS and earlier
column2: the BlackBerry 10 operating system and the tablet-based BlackBerry PlayBook OS.

column1: Phones such as my antique Q10 ‎will completely cease to function
column2: though it may remain handy as a back-up for contact numbers.

column1: The only glimmer of sustained life is that post-2016 Blackberry-branded phones
column2: which were made under licence by Chinese firm TCL
column3: will still work as they use the Android operating system.

column1: Over the years it's not just Blackberry phone user numbers that have dwindled
column2: but support and functions have dropped away one by one.

column1: Support for many apps
column2: including BBC iPlayer and WhatsApp
column3: was withdrawn from BlackBerry OS devices
column4: and not long ago YouTube stopped working too.

column1: Somehow or other I was able to circuitously get the latter two to work again by downloading links from far corners of the planet.
Apps have become a non-existent element for users of BlackBerry devices.
For example
column2: at the start of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020 I found myself unable to download the various NHS apps
column3: and had to sign in to places manually.

column1: So
column2: why go to all this trouble?

column1: In short
column2: it is still great for emails
column3: with five or six different addresses all in one stream. I also love the qwerty keyboard with keys that depress and are not like pressing a hard plank of wood.

column1: As phones have become progressively bigger
column2: the BlackBerry still fits beautifully
column3: and fairly lightly

column1: It's a feeling with which Ben Wood
column2: an industry analyst for CCS Insight and founder of the Mobile Phone Museum
column3: agrees.

column1: The dedicated qwerty keyboard was an iconic design
column2: he says. ""The devices became so comfortable in people's hands that they developed muscle memory delivering fast and accurate text input.""

column1: Mr Wood says: ""It always makes me smile when I show kids some of the mobile phones of yesterday.
They are enthralled by the design diversity. I even had a 14 year-old ask me the other day 'why don't they bring keyboards back?' which made me smile.""
It is almost exactly 23 years since BlackBerry launched its 850 phone
column2: and the company soon became the leader in providing emails when out and about on the move.

column1: There was also the attraction of BBM - BlackBerry's Instant Messenger service - although this facility attracted unwanted publicity during the riots that swept through many UK cities in 2011.
There were outraged cries of protest that the police could not monitor the encrypted nature of BBM messages to find out where looters would strike next.
But the models that followed the iconic BlackBerry Bold would face increasing competition from Apple and Android phones.
So what happens next?

column2: TCL's licence ended and was picked up by a firm called Onward Mobility. It promised a 5G BlackBerry running Android for 2021
column3: but nothing emerged.

column1: For now I shall try my luck with a second-hand Android Blackberry KeyOne - itself five years old now - (from Canadian eBay this time)
column2: and bought long ago in preparation for just this such day.

column1: And I shall also hold on to my useless Q10 - you never know when in the future someone may ask...""is that an antique BlackBerry?""

column1: Shares in crisis-hit Chinese property developer Evergrande rose on Tuesday afternoon as they resumed trading in Hong Kong.
The heavily-indebted firm suspended its shares on Monday pending the release of ""inside information"".
It comes after Evergrande said its sales for 2021 plunged 39% from the year before to $69.5bn (£51.6bn).
The company also confirmed it had been ordered to demolish 39 buildings on the island of Hainan.
The firm said the buildings affected by the demolition order are at its Ocean Flower Island project
column2: and added the decision does not involve other plots of land in the project.

column1: The company will actively communicate with the authority in accordance with the guidance of the decision letter and resolve the issue properly
column2: Evergrande said in a filing to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

column1: The announcement also addressed concerns about the firm's financial position: ""With regard to the company's current liquidity situation
column2: the company will continue to actively maintain communication with creditors
column3: strive to resolve risks and safeguard the legitimate rights and interests of all parties.""

column1: Evergrande has more than $300bn of debt and is scrambling to raise cash by selling assets and shares to repay suppliers and creditors.
Last week
column2: the company did not make some interest payments on its offshore bonds.

column1: Its $19bn in international bonds were deemed to be in default by rating agencies after it missed a payment deadline last month.
The company has also dialled back plans to repay investors in its wealth management products.
Evergande's shares have lost almost 90% of their value in the last year as investors fret that it may be close to collapsing under the weight of of its debts.

column1: Rail passengers are facing cancellations or fewer services as train companies face high levels of staff absences due to Covid.
The Rail Delivery Group said almost one in 10 rail workers were off.
Train companies including ScotRail
column2: CrossCountry and LNER have announced reduced timetables and passengers have been warned of cancellations.

column1: Alex Hynes
column2: boss of ScotRail
column3: said the company had ""hundreds"" of staff off work due to having Covid or isolating.

column1: He told the BBC's Today programme the company usually operates 2
column2: 000 services a day
column3: but it would be reducing this by 160 (8%) from Tuesday.

column1: Over the last few weeks because of record numbers of Covid cases we have been cancelling too many trains so we have decided to proactively put this revised timetable in to give our customers greater certainty on the service we can offer
column2: he said.

column1: Mr Hynes said the operator was ""pretty confident"" the reduced timetable would ""prove to be a robust service for customers in the coming weeks"".
We have said we will offer this timetable until the end of the month but of course one of the lessons we have learnt from Covid is that we would be foolish to predict the future
column2: he added.

column1: There will be a few twists and turn in this Covid tale until it's over.""
Rising Covid case numbers have led to large numbers of people self-isolating and being unable to go to work
column2: which has acutely affected industries where staff are unable to work from home.

column1: Rail operator CrossCountry said its staff absences were ""worsening each day""
column2: with more than one in 10 staff now absent.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: South Western Railway said its services would be ""subject to short notice cancellations"" ahead of the company introducing a ""consolidated timetable"" from 17 January.

column1: LNER has announced it has cancelled 16 trains for this week
column2: but warned passengers there could be ""other non-planned changes"" to the timetable.

column1: On Monday
column2: there were widespread cancellations across Britain's train services with the Rail Delivery Group estimating that more than 6
column3: 000 staff

column1: The industry body said there would be ""some short-notice cancellations so our advice to anyone travelling is to check online before they set out or to sign up for automatic alerts from National Rail Alert Me"".
We are working hard to provide the most reliable service possible and so that passengers can travel with confidence when fewer rail staff can work
column2: a number of operators are introducing amended timetables
column3: it added.

column1: The website of Transport for Wales showed 49 train journeys were cancelled on Monday
column2: while TransPennine Express cancelled 37 and Avanti West Coast cancelled 25.

column1: Southern has said it is not putting on any direct services to London Victoria - a major commuter station - until next Monday.
Rail Minister Wendy Morton said she would ""continue to monitor the situation closely"".
The government has warned rising cases could see up to a quarter of staff off work and ministers have been tasked with developing ""robust contingency plans"" to deal with workplace absences.
Public sector leaders have been asked to prepare for ""worst case scenarios"" of 10%
column2: 20% and 25% absence rates
column3: the Cabinet Office said.

column1: The transport sector is not the only area affected by staff absences
column2: with worker shortages also hitting retailers and hospitality firms.

column1: The US has recorded more than one million new Covid cases
column2: as officials warn the peak of a fast-spreading Omicron surge is still to come.

column1: A record 1
column3: 211 cases were reported on Monday - the highest one-day tally of new cases anywhere in the world

column1: The Omicron variant accounts for the majority of cases in the US.
The top US pandemic adviser Anthony Fauci has said the country is facing ""almost a vertical increase"" in cases.
He said the peak may be weeks away.
While rates of death and hospital admissions in the US have been far lower in recent weeks than in previous infection spikes
column2: the number of hospital admissions has been steadily rising.

column1: But Dr Fauci said the example of South Africa - where Omicron first spread rapidly before subsiding - offered some hope.

Omicron has also led to school districts across the country postponing the return of students to classrooms following the winter break due to the rapid spread of the variant and subsequent staffing shortages. There are also concerns over challenges in securing rapid tests for students and teachers.
In Detroit
column2: Michigan
column3: for example - which is experiencing an all-time high infection rate of 36% - city school officials announced that schools will remain closed through Wednesday.

column1: A number of other major school systems
column2: including Atlanta
column3: Milwaukee
column6: have announced postponements or a return to virtual classes.

column1: In New York City
column2: the largest school district in the US
column3: schools remained open. On Monday
column4: Mayor Eric Adams said that school is ""the safest place or our children"".

column1: The New York Times reported
column2: however
column3: that approximately one third of parents kept their children at home over Covid-19 fears.

column1: In terms of hospital admissions
column2: data from the US Department of Health and Human Services shows that more than 103
column3: 000 people are currently in hospital with Covid-19 - the first time the tally has crossed the six-figure mark since September.

column1: State health officials have reported that the vast majority of Covid hospital admissions are among the unvaccinated. In Illinois
column2: for example
column3: officials over the weekend said that nearly 85% of patients with Covid-19 or related diseases are unvaccinated.

column1: I'm still very concerned about the tens of millions of people who are not vaccinated at all because even though many of them are going to get asymptomatic and mildly symptomatic
column2: a fair number of them are going to get severe disease
column3: Dr Fauci told ABC on Monday.

column1: Officials have also said that the number of children in hospital is rising.
Some 8
column2: 652 people are reported to have died from the disease in the past week
column3: according to Johns Hopkins.

column1: The previous US record of cases was 590
column3: reported four days ago.

column1: The highest number outside the US came during India's Delta surge
column2: when more than 414
column3: 188 people were confirmed as having the disease in May 2021.

column1: Studies suggest that Omicron is milder than the previously dominant Delta variant
column2: but fears remain that the sheer number of cases stemming from the highly infectious Omicron could overwhelm hospitals.

column1: To mark the first anniversary of the trade deal between the UK and the EU
column2: Downing Street issued a press release about how prime minister Boris Johnson plans to ""maximise the benefits of Brexit"".

column1: It gave examples of ""key successes"" so far:
The crown stamp had been used on pint glasses for more than 300 years to show they are large enough to hold a full pint.
An EU directive
column2: which took effect in 2006
column3: required the use of an EU-wide ""CE"" mark which stands for Conformité Européenne -  French for ""European Conformity"".

column1: CE appears on many other products
column2: from toys to medical devices
column3: and it shows that they meet the EU's safety
column4: health and environmental rules and can move freely across its countries with no additional checks.

column1: But the European Commission has rejected the idea that EU rules stopped the UK from having the crown stamp on glasses as well.
A spokesperson told us: ""EU law does not prevent markings from being placed on products
column2: so long as it does not overlap or be confused with the CE mark.""

column1: Following Brexit
column2: goods will now have to use the UKCA marking - ""UK Conformity Assessed"". However
column3: to allow businesses time to adjust
column4: products with the CE mark can still be sold and used in Great Britain until 1 January 2023.

column1: Former Brexit minister Lord Frost said in September 2021 that the government ""will permit the voluntary printing of the crown stamp on pint glasses"".
A 5% rate of VAT on sanitary products - the so-called ""Tampon Tax"" - was scrapped by the government from 1 January 2021.
EU laws require member states to tax tampons and sanitary towels at a minimum rate of 5%.
But the EU is in the process of abolishing the tax.
The Republic of Ireland - an EU member - already had 0% VAT on sanitary products
column2: because this rate was in place before the EU legislation imposed the 5% minimum rate.

column1: As we've pointed out before
column2: the majority of these involve taking the deal that the EU has with those countries and replicating the terms for the UK.  The government has been successful at doing these ""rollover deals"" in a relatively short space of time.

column1: With a few of the countries the terms have been slightly different to the EU's
column2: such as Japan
column3: Norway and Iceland.

column1: And a deal has been signed with Australia and agreed in principle with New Zealand
column2: which are not the same as the EU deals with them.

column1: How do you get to a total value of £760bn?
Add up the value of imports and exports with countries that also have deals with the EU
column2: which you'll find on this table. Add Australia and New Zealand and you get to just over £200bn.

column1: The rest comes from trade with EU countries
column2: which are covered by the Trade and Cooperation Agreement.

column1: But there is less trade with the EU now than there was when the UK was a member state. So
column2: overall UK trade with the rest of the world has actually gone down since the government came to power.

column1: While Covid will clearly have been a factor
column2: the UK did about £220bn less global trade in 2020 - about 18% down on its 2019 figure.

column1: And to say that the deals are ""worth over £760bn"" assumes that without them there would be no trade done at all
column2: which is not the case.

column1: This was delivered by ""avoiding cumbersome EU bureaucracy""
column2: according to the press release.

column1: The UK approved the Pfizer vaccine in November 2020
column2: nearly three weeks before EU regulators.

column1: But - as the head of the UK medicines regulator pointed out at the time - the UK's approval was permitted under EU law.
The vaccine rollout started in the UK on 8 December 2020 - weeks before the EU.
And initially
column2: the pace of vaccination in the UK was faster than in the EU - which ran into problems with its rollout early on.

column1: However
column2: EU countries have since caught up.

column1: Currently
column2: 13 EU countries
column3: as well as Norway and Iceland
column4: have a higher proportion of their populations fully vaccinated - according to figures from Our World in Data
column5: which looked at those who have received all doses prescribed by the initial vaccination protocol.

column1: However
column2: according to the latest data
column3: the UK has given more booster doses of the vaccine to its population than any other country in Europe

column1: In Germany and France
column2: the booster jab has been given to 39% and 33% of the population respectively.

column1: Canadian filmmaker Jean-Marc Vallée
column2: whose work included Dallas Buyers Club and Wild has died aged 58.

column1: The Oscar-nominated director also won an Emmy award for his work on the HBO series Big Little Lies.
He died over the weekend in Quebec City
column2: his long-time producing partner Nathan Ross confirmed in a statement provided to The Hollywood Reporter
column3: though no cause of death was given.

column1: Ross said Vallée ""stood for creativity"" and ""authenticity"".
He was a true artist and a generous
column2: loving guy
column3: he wrote. ""Everyone who worked with him couldn't help but see the talent and vision he possessed.

column1: He was a friend
column2: creative partner and an older brother to me. The maestro will sorely be missed but it comforts knowing his beautiful style and impactful work he shared with the world will live on.""

column1: US actress Reece Witherspoon
column2: who starred in both Wild and Big Little Lies
column3: tweeted on Monday: ""My heart is broken. My friend

column1: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau wrote that Vallée's ""passion for filmmaking and storytelling was unmatched - so too was his talent.
Through his work and with his art
column2: he left a mark in Quebec
column3: across Canada

column1: Montreal-born Vallée began his career making music videos before moving into film in 1995
column2: with his debut thriller Black List
column3: and then the critically-lauded 2005 coming-of-age movie C.R.A.Z.Y.

column1: His 2009 feature
column2: The Young Victoria
column3: starring British actress Emily Blunt as Britain's Queen Victoria

column1: But perhaps his best-known work arrived in 2013
column2: with Dallas Buyers Club - the emotional story of Ron Woodroof
column3: who sold experimental drugs to fellow Aids patients in Texas.

column1: Stars Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto both put in Oscar-winning performances in the movie
column2: which was nominated for six Academy Awards
column3: including best picture and best original screenplay.

column1: The next year
column2: Vallée directed Reese Witherspoon in Wild
column3: a film based on the bestselling memoir about of a former heroin addict who tries to re-discover herself by backpacking and hiking the Pacific Crest Trail.

column1: He worked with her again on HBO's Big Little Lies
column2: which saw him win the Emmy for best directing on a limited series
column3: movie or special.

column1: The Emmy and Golden Globe-winning show
column2: a screen adaptation of Liane Moriarty's top novel

column6: Zoë Kravitz and Shailene Woodley as five California-based women who become embroiled in a murder investigation.

column1: Paying her respects on Monday
column2: Dern posted: ""The world has lost one of our great and purest artists and dreamers. And we lost our beloved friend.""

column1: Vallée went on to direct Amy Adams and Patricia Clarkson in another HBO series
column2: Sharp Objects

column1: HBO commented that he was ""a brilliant
column2: fiercely dedicated filmmaker
column3: a truly phenomenal talent who infused every scene with a deeply visceral

column1: He was also a hugely caring man who invested his whole self alongside every actor he directed
column2: the network added in a statement.

column1: We are shocked at the news of his sudden death
column2: and we extend our heartfelt sympathies to his sons
column3: Alex and Émile

column1: Speaking to The Hollywood Reporter in 2016
column2: Vallée revealed what he enjoyed most about making movies and TV shows. ""The dream
column3: he said. ""Dreams can come true. I'm living the dream right now.""

column1: Cameron Bailey
column2: CEO of the Toronto International Film Festival
column3: paid tribute by describing the director as ""a prodigious talent"".

column1: He is survived by two children.

column1: At least 13 people have been killed and several more have been injured after a fire broke out in an apartment building in the US city of Philadelphia.
At least seven children are among the dead
column2: an official from the Philadelphia Fire Department told reporters.

column1: The blaze began at around 06:00 local time (11:00 GMT) in a public housing block in the north of the city.
Deputy Fire Commissioner Craig Murphy told reporters it was one of the worst fires he had ever seen.
We plan on making sure that this tremendous loss of life did not happen in vain
column2: he said on Wednesday.

column1: He added that eight other residents had managed to escape the building.
It is believed there were 26 people in the three-storey block at the time of the fire.
The building is owned by the government funded Philadelphia Housing Authority
column2: and it has been legally divided into two apartments since the 1950s.

column1: Officials said that at the last inspection of the building in 2020 there had been four working smoke detectors
column2: but none of them went off during the fire.

column1: Mr Murphy told reporters that while authorities do not currently consider the cause of the fire to be suspicious
column2: there will still be a thorough investigation due to the loss of life.

column1: Speaking during the press conference
column2: the city's Mayor Jim Kenney said: ""This is without a doubt one of the most tragic days in our city's history
column3: the loss of so many people in such a tragic way.""

column1: Losing so many kids is just devastating
column2: he added.

column1: Labour has again called for the 5% VAT rate on energy bills to be scrapped
column2: demanding ""serious solutions"" for the rising cost of living.

column1: Speaking at Prime Minister's Questions
column2: the party's deputy leader Angela Rayner said working families were ""picking up the tab"" for Boris Johnson's ""incompetence"" over the issue.

column1: But the PM insisted the government was providing a number of schemes to help.
A spike in wholesale gas prices has led to soaring energy bills in the UK.
A total of 27 energy companies have also gone bust as the energy price cap - limiting how much consumers can be charged - saw some businesses forced to sell energy for less than they bought it for.
But there are fears an expected rise in the cap
column2: due in April
column3: could see households hit with even higher bills.

column1: Labour has been calling for the government to slash the 5% VAT rate on energy bills to zero since October
column2: with shadow chancellor Rachel Reeves calling it a ""simple"" and ""immediate"" measure to help people deal with costs over the winter.

column1: A group of 20 Conservative MPs and peers - including five ex-ministers - joined the call last week
column2: writing to Mr Johnson to urge him to cut VAT
column3: as well as going further by suspending environmental levies which fund renewable energy schemes.

column1: Backers of the plan said VAT receipts had come in more than £3bn higher than forecast because of rising prices
column2: giving the government extra funds to cover the cost.

column1: But a Treasury source has told the BBC that rising bills overall mean consumers are spending less elsewhere on products with higher VAT
column2: so the overall income to the government has remained flat.

column1: Standing in for Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer - who has tested positive for Covid - Ms Rayner said ""working people across the country are facing rising bills and ballooning prices""
column2: due to a mixture of inflation
column3: rising energy costs and an incoming tax rise to pay for the NHS and social care.

column1: She added: ""The prime minister pretends it is not his fault. He blames the global forces
column2: he blames the market.

column1: But the prime minister has made political choices that have led us into this place.""
The deputy leader claimed the government had ""failed to invest in long term energy security"" and ""let the energy market run out of control""
column2: adding: ""Can't the prime minister see what is happening?

column1: Yet again working families are picking up tab for his incompetence.""
But Mr Johnson said a number of government initiatives - including the warm homes discount
column2: winter fuel payments and cold weather payments - were supporting people
column3: especially those on low incomes.

column1: He also accused Labour of ""bare-faced cheek"" for calling for the VAT cut
column2: as the party campaigned to stay in the EU - when it would not have been an option.

column1: Everybody knows full well it would be absolutely impossible if they were to do what Labour would do and go back into the EU [and] remain aligned with the EU single market
column2: said the PM.

column1: That is the objective of the Labour Party. They can't be trusted on Brexit and they can't be trusted with the economy.""

column1: 150;James Webb Space Telescope: Sun shield is fully deployed;2022-01-05T07:59:38.000Z;[];['astronomy'
column2: 'nasa'
column3: 'european space agency'

column1: The new James Webb telescope has passed a major milestone in its quest to image the first stars to shine in the cosmos.
Controllers on Tuesday completed the deployment of the space observatory's giant kite-shaped sun shield.
Only with this tennis court-sized barrier will Webb have the sensitivity to detect the signals coming from the most distant objects in the Universe.
Commissioning work will now concentrate on unpacking the telescope's mirrors
column2: the largest of which is 6.5m wide.

column1: This video can not be played
The deployment of the five-membrane sun shield is a triumph for the engineering teams at the US space agency (Nasa) and the American aerospace manufacturer Northrop Grumman.
There were many who doubted the wisdom of a design that included so many motors
column2: gears
column3: pulleys and cables.

column1: But years of testing on full-scale and sub-scale models paid dividends as controllers first separated the shield's different layers and then tensioned them.
The fifth and final membrane - which like the other four had the thickness of a human hair - was locked into place at 16:58 GMT.
Unfolding Webb's sun shield in space is an incredible milestone
column2: crucial to the success of the mission
column3: said Greg Robinson
column4: Webb's program director at Nasa Headquarters.

column1: Thousands of parts had to work with precision for this marvel of engineering to fully unfurl. The team has accomplished an audacious feat with the complexity of this deployment - one of the boldest undertakings yet for Webb.""
It's worth noting that all the previous testing was done on Earth
column2: under gravity conditions. This was the first time the shield had been unfurled in the unique ""Zero-G"" environment of space. ""The first time
column3: and we nailed it

column1: There was a lot of joy
column2: a lot of relief
column3: added Hillary Stock
column4: the sunshield deployments lead at Northrop.

column1: James Webb was launched on 25 December on an Ariane rocket from French Guiana.
The telescope is regarded as the successor to the Hubble space observatory which is now 31 years old and nearing the end of its operational life.
Webb will do similar science to Hubble but with the next-generation technologies that allow it to see deeper into the cosmos and
column2: therefore
column3: further back in time.

column1: The expectation is that it will even catch the light from the pioneer stars that were first to ignite shortly after the Big Bang more than 13.5 billion years ago.
Critical to the whole endeavour
column2: however
column3: will be Webb's sensitivity in the infrared. The light coming to the telescope from its targets at the edge of the observable Universe will arrive in this longer wavelength domain. And that means Webb must be cooled to fantastically cold temperatures or its own infrared glow will swamp the signals it's trying to detect.

column1: Hence the shield. The shade it casts will lower the environment around Webb's mirrors and instruments to below minus 230C.
The controllers
column2: who are based at the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI) in Baltimore
column3: Maryland
column4: now have Webb's golden mirrors in their sights.

column1: Like the sun shield
column2: the telescope's two principal reflectors had to be folded to fit inside the nosecone of the Ariane.

column1: Wednesday should see the 74cm-wide secondary mirror extended on 8m-long booms in front of the primary mirror.
The main mirror has ""wings"" that were tucked back for launch but which must now be rotated through 90 degrees to make a full
column2: 6.5m-wide surface. Assuming things continue to run like clockwork
column3: this should happen at the end of the week.

column1: Webb is currently moving out to a position 1.5 million km from Earth on the planet's ""midnight"" side. It's from this location that it will study the Universe.
James Webb is a joint venture between the American
column2: European and Canadian space agencies.

column2: 'reality check'];['world'
column3: 'sri'

column1: China has faced criticism for its lending practices to poorer countries
column2: accused of leaving them struggling to repay debts and therefore vulnerable to pressure from Beijing.

column1: But that is rejected by China
column2: which accuses some in the West of promoting this narrative to tarnish its image.

column1: It says: ""There is not a single country that has fallen into [a] so-called 'debt trap' as a result of borrowing from China.""
China is one of the world's largest single creditor nations.
Its loans to lower and middle-income countries have tripled over the past decade
column2: reaching $170bn (£125bn) by the end of 2020.

column1: However
column2: China's overall lending commitments are likely to be significantly greater than these figures suggest.

column1: Research by AidData
column2: an international development body at William & Mary University in the US
column3: finds that half of China's lending to developing countries is not reported in official debt statistics.

column1: It is often kept off government balance sheets
column2: directed to state-owned companies and banks
column3: joint ventures or private institutions
column4: rather than directly from government to government.

column1: There are now more than 40 low and middle-income countries
column2: according to AidData
column3: whose debt exposure to Chinese lenders is more than 10% of the size of their annual economic output (GDP) as a result of this ""hidden debt"".

column1: Djibouti
column2: Laos
column3: Zambia and Kyrgyzstan have debts to China equivalent to at least 20% of their annual GDP.

column1: Much of the debt owed to China relates to large infrastructure projects like roads
column2: railways and ports
column3: and also to the mining and energy industry
column4: under President Xi Jinping's Belt and Road Initiative.

column1: In an interview with the BBC
column2: Richard Moore
column3: the head of Britain's foreign intelligence agency MI6
column4: said China uses what he called ""debt traps"" to gain leverage over other countries.

column1: The claim is that China lends money to other countries
column2: which end up having to cede control of key assets if they can't meet their debt repayments - an accusation that's been long denied by Beijing.

column1: One example often cited by critics of China is Sri Lanka
column2: which years ago embarked on a massive port project in Hambantota with Chinese investment.

column1: But the billion dollar project using loans and contractors from China became mired in controversy
column2: and struggled to prove viable
column3: leaving Sri Lanka saddled with growing debts.

column1: Finally
column3: Sri Lanka agreed to give state-owned China Merchants a controlling 70% stake in the port on a 99-year lease in return for further Chinese investment.

column1: Analysis of the port project by UK-based think tank Chatham House has questioned whether the ""debt trap"" narrative strictly applies
column2: given that the deal was driven by local political motivations
column3: and that China never took formal ownership of the port.

column1: It points out that a large proportion of Sri Lanka's overall debt was owed to non-Chinese lenders
column2: and that there's no that evidence China has taken advantage of its position to gain strategic military advantage from the port.

column1: Despite that
column2: there's little doubt China's economic involvement in Sri Lanka has grown in the past decade
column3: and concerns persist that this could be used to advance its political ambitions in the region.

column1: There are other parts of the world where Chinese lending has also proved controversial
column2: with contracts whose terms could give China leverage over important assets.

column1: But there are no cases
column2: among the hundreds of loan arrangements studied by AidData and some other researchers
column3: of Chinese state-owned lenders actually seizing a major asset in the event of a loan default.

column1: China does not publish records of its foreign loans
column2: and the majority of its contracts contain non-disclosure clauses which prevent borrowers from revealing their contents.

column1: It argues that such confidentiality is common practice for international loan contracts.
Confidentiality agreements are very common in international commercial loans""
column2: says Professor Lee Jones at Queen Mary University of London.

column1: And much of China's development financing is fundamentally a commercial operation.""
Most of the major industrialised nations share information about their lending activities through membership of what's known as the Paris Club.
China has chosen not to join this grouping
column2: but using available World Bank data
column3: the rapid growth in China's reported lending compared to others can be clearly observed.

column1: China tends to lend at higher rates of interest than western governments.
At around 4%
column2: these loans are close to commercial market rates and about four times that of a typical loan from the World Bank or an individual country such as France or Germany.

column1: The required repayment period for a Chinese loan is also generally shorter - less than 10 years
column2: compared to around 28 years for other lenders' concessional loans to developing countries.

column1: Chinese state-owned lenders also typically require borrowers to maintain a minimum cash balance in an offshore account to which the lender has access.
If a borrower fails to repay its debt
column2: says Brad Parks
column3: Executive Director of AidData
column4: ""China can simply debit funds from [this] account without having to collect on bad debt through a judicial process.""

column1: This approach is rarely seen in loans issued by western lenders.

There's currently an initiative by G20 nations - those countries which have the largest and fastest-growing economies - to offer debt relief for poorer countries to help them deal with the impact of the pandemic.
China has joined this and says it has contributed ""the highest amount of debt repayment"" of any country taking part in the plan.
The World Bank says that since May 2020
column2: a total of more than $10.3bn has been delivered in debt relief by G20 countries under this scheme.

column1: But when we asked the World Bank for a breakdown by country
column2: it said it could not share the information.

column1: 156;Census 1921 - 100-year-old secrets revealed;2022-01-06T06:00:53.000Z;[];['history'];['likely'
column2: 'given'
column3: 'season'

column1: A unique snapshot of life one midsummer night - just over 100 years ago - reveals
column2: among other things
column3: life in the real Downton Abbey
column4: how slum families pleaded for better homes
column5: and why a man from Yorkshire wasn't able to divorce his wife.

column1: Pages from the 1921 Census - made available for the first time - reveal glimpses of some of the lives of the 38 million people living in England and Wales on the evening of 19 June that year. At the time
column2: the country was recovering from the shocks of World War One and the Spanish flu pandemic.

column1: The future crime writer Dorothy L Sayers was living in central London and working from home in June 1921
column2: when the census was carried out. She was a boarder in the Bloomsbury home of Elinor James
column3: an Irishwoman of 57 who - like her five female tenants - was single.

column1: Almost all boarding-house keepers were women in 1921
column2: the census shows.

column1: Elinor James's house
column2: in Mecklenburgh Square
column3: had eight rooms - generous compared with many other homes. Her lodgers were aged between 25 and 32 - among the 1.7 million so-called ""surplus women"" who supposedly found it hard to find a husband. So many men of their age had been killed in World War One.

column1: Many of those young women entered the workplace instead. The census shows more were working in professions. Most were teachers and nurses
column2: but more were training to become lawyers
column3: architects and doctors.

column1: At Mecklenburgh Square
column2: all five boarders worked.

column1: Dorothy L Sayers had studied modern languages at Oxford and described herself on the form as a translator. Her first detective novel ""Whose Body?"" would be published two years later
column2: introducing the amateur sleuth Lord Peter Wimsey.

column1: The youngest tenant
column2: Kitty Wood
column3: worked as a solicitor's clerk in Lincoln's Inn. The eldest
column4: Edith - whose surname is hard to make out - was a librarian at the Daily News.

column1: Ursula Murphy
column2: from Dublin
column3: worked as a temporary civil servant in the Foreign Office. Alice Saxty - from Queensland
column6: as a ""craft worker"" who made dresses for ""Dora McLaren artist"". Dora McLaren had designed posters for the London Underground
column7: and in the 1920s illustrated a comic strip for the Daily Herald newspaper.

column1: For the first time
column2: the 1921 Census allowed respondents to identify themselves as being divorced. Just 16
column3: 000 people did so.

column1: It would be another 50 years before a marriage could end with neither party at ""fault"" and so the shame of getting a divorce - plus the cost of legal proceedings - meant formal separation from a partner was not an option.

column2: there were many single mothers - but relatively few from divorce. Almost all were as a result of World War One. The number of widows rose sharply - from 642
column3: 311 in 1911 to more than 1.6m at the start of the 1920s.

column1: Yorkshireman William Ambler
column2: a Bradford factory worker
column3: wrote on his form that he was married - but hadn't lived with his wife for 20 years. He explained how she had been unfaithful to him and had given birth to a daughter.

column1: Mr Ambler said he could not afford to divorce his wife
column2: although she had successfully applied to the court for maintenance which he had to pay.

column1: Is it not high time there was [sic] divorce laws to dissolve such unions
column2: he wrote.

column1: Have I to serve life-long misery
column2: for her infidelity?"" he asked.

column1: Edith White
column2: a housekeeper from West Yorkshire
column3: living with her grown-up son and daughter
column4: scrawled ""We favour divorce law reform"" across her form.

column1: But for others
column2: ending a marriage was just plain wrong. Henry Forrest of Stretford Road in Manchester stated his objection to even asking a divorce question on the census form.

column1: Divorce was a ""CURSE to the country"" wrote the school teacher - who was 42
column2: unmarried
column3: and living with his five younger sisters and brother.

column1: On the evening of the census
column2: the Earl of Carnarvon was at home in Highclere Castle - familiar today to millions as the fictional Downton Abbey.

column1: Joining him upstairs was his wife
column2: their 19-year-old daughter Lady Evelyn Herbert
column3: the archaeologist Howard Carter and a female visitor.

column1: Downstairs that evening were four members of staff.
Cook Minnie Lynch
column3: was originally from Killarney in Ireland.  Ivy Cestell
column9: were both kitchen maids. Thirty-year-old Louise Villepinte
column11: was a ladies' maid. Only Ivy was married - the others listed themselves as single.

column1: Highclere is a grand stately home with 35 principal bedrooms and - just like in ITV's Downton Abbey - employed many servants. The 1911 census recorded 18 resident staff including 10 maids. So why were there so few in 1921?

The most likely explanation - according to the current Lady Carnarvon - is that it was the London ""season"" and many aristocrats from large country homes would have been enjoying social events in and around the capital. Some of the staff were probably there too - while others might have been given time off.
Lady Carnarvon says the then Earl
column2: his wife and daughter
column3: could have made a special trip back to Highclere from London to meet Howard Carter. The Earl funded the archaeologist's journeys to Egypt in winter

column1: There were 1
column2: 712 Jamaican-born people living in England and Wales in 1921 - according to the census.

column1: Dr Harold Moody was one of the most prominent. He had finished at the top of his class studying medicine at King's College London.
His census return shows him living on King's Road (now King's Grove) in Peckham
column2: south-east London
column3: in a 10-room house. He was then 38 - and his wife
column6: was 32. The couple had five young children.

column1: Also living with them was a ""general domestic"" servant - a 17-year-old girl called Frances Hinds
column2: who had been born in Hampstead.

column1: Moody described himself as a ""medical practitioner"" working from home. He had set up his own practice in 1913 after struggling to find employment.

column2: he established the League of Coloured Peoples to campaign for black rights in the UK.

column1: James Bartley was 33 in the summer of 1921. He worked as a gas fitter and lived in Montgomery Street in Hove
column2: Sussex
column3: with his wife May and three children under five.

column1: Two-bedroom houses in that road now sell for about half a million pounds - but 100 years ago
column2: the Bartley family lived in one room.

column1: Stop talking about your homes for heroes
column2: wrote Mr Bartley at the bottom of his form. ""Start building some houses and let them at a rent a working man can afford to pay.""

column1: Homes Fit for Heroes"" had been the promise made by Liberal Prime Minister David Lloyd George
column2: two years before at the end of the Great War. He had pledged to build half a million new homes for returning veterans.

column1: Across the country
column2: most tenants lived in privately-rented housing
column3: often in squalid conditions.

column1: Mr Bartley would most likely have fought in the war himself - but while the National Archives holds medal cards for several James Bartleys
column2: none are from local Sussex Regiments and no dates of birth are listed.

column1: At least Bartley was employed - he worked for the Brighton Gas Company. Two hundred miles away near Liverpool
column2: ""master tailor"" Robert Stevens - a father of 13 - stated he was ""out of work"".

column1: Mr Stevens
column3: and his wife Agnes - who according to their form was busy with ""Home Duties"" - lived with their children in five rooms on Park Street

column1: Ivy
column3: and Gerty
column5: were both milliners. The eldest boy
column7: worked at St Paul's Mills in Birkenhead. Florrie
column11: helped their mother at home. Five younger children were at school
column12: and the youngest three were at home.

column1: Robert Stevens wrote simply: ""Can you help us times are hard.""
There was no category for disability on the census forms
column2: but some householders chose to note their own conditions anyway - including former soldiers still struggling three years after their return from war.

column1: Harold Samuel Orpen of St Mary's Mansions
column2: in Paddington central London
column3: was nearly 47 and a retired regular Army officer. He lived in six rooms with his wife Joan and a 20-year-old servant

column1: Orpen's form is noticeable for its lack of fountain-pen ink. Instead
column2: he used a typewriter to fill it out and felt obliged to explain: ""I lost half my right hand in the late war and cannot write properly.""

column1: Other former service personnel added handwritten notes. One simply wrote: ""Ruined by War doing odd work"" in the section for occupation.
The forms were hand-delivered to eight and a half million households by 38
column2: 000 census staff. They then had to return to collect them. The enumerators - as they were called - told newspapers at the time it was a ""wearying job"". One complained that children had used the forms to play noughts and crosses.

column1: You walk from house to house trying to look pleasant and important
column2: and doing your best to make believe you're loving the job
column3: while all the time you feel you would welcome the Earth to open and swallow you up

column1: Nevertheless
column2: a century on
column3: their determined efforts are being revealed in a unique and valuable resource. It's accessible online - either for free by visiting the National Archives in Kew
column4: west London - or through the Findmypast website for a fee.

column1: You and Yours on BBC Radio 4 has more stories from the 1921 Census

column1: 158;Caviar sales soar as more people get a taste for posh fish eggs;2022-01-06T00:04:16.000Z;[];['fish'
column2: 'fish farming'];['15'
column3: 'roll'

column1: When high-end restaurants around the globe had to close their doors during the Covid lockdowns
column2: things didn't look good for the world's caviar producers.

column1: Add glitzy events being cancelled
column2: and cruise liners not being able to leave port
column3: and you might think that it spelled disaster for the sellers of wincingly expensive fish eggs.

column1: But the reality has been very different. Online sales are booming as the well-heeled increasingly eat their caviar at home.
I think people in lockdown wanted to enjoy themselves
column2: and everybody decided to spend money on caviar
column3: either at home
column4: or in restaurants [when they were able to open again]
column6: general manager of Italy's Agroittica Lombarda

column1: But what exactly is caviar? It is the salt-cured eggs of numerous species of the sturgeon fish. Long considered a delicacy
column2: the industry was historically centred on wild stocks in the Caspian Sea
column3: which is today surrounded by Russia

column1: But by 2006
column2: severe overfishing in the Caspian led to a ban on the global sale of almost all wild caviar from the sea. This is still enforced by the Switzerland-based Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora.

column1: The ban led to a big growth in the farming of sturgeon around the world specifically for the production of caviar. As a result
column2: almost all of the caviar sold legally worldwide is now from farmed stocks - sturgeon reared in man-made lakes and ponds.

column1: This global farmed sturgeon industry was worth €750m ($848m; £640m) in 2019
column2: according to the most recent figures from Norwegian firm Kontali
column3: which monitors the worldwide fish farm sector. Meanwhile
column4: the European Union estimated that global caviar volumes reached 380 tonnes in 2018
column5: its most up to date figures.

column1: Ms Sora says that sales at Agroittica Lombarda soared last year
column2: especially in the US
column3: where they doubled.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: US firm Sterling Caviar
column3: owner of four farms in California
column4: and the largest caviar producer in the country
column5: said its sales were up 10% in 2021. In the UK
column8: sold out of all of its then stock at the end of 2020.

column1: Kontali analyst
column2: Maren Boe
column3: says that online sales have ""been the saving grace"" for producers since the arrival of the coronavirus pandemic.

column1: By selling smaller tins of caviar
column2: both in shops and online
column3: producers have been able to sell to consumers looking to increase everyday luxury by buying caviar to consume at home

column1: Sterling owner
column2: Eugene Fernandez
column3: says that its online sales soared 60% last year
column4: helped by launching a new website in August. He thinks that caviar fans now want to eat it on a more regular basis.

column1: I think going forward the caviar market will probably be less of an occasional product for holidays
column2: and more something that's bought regularly
column3: he says.

column1: Ms Sora adds that producers in the US and Europe have also benefitted from less caviar exports coming from China
column2: whose farms account for 70% of global production. China's domestic consumption of caviar has soared in recent years
column3: at the same time as there might have been some staff shortages caused by the pandemic.

column1: New Economy is a new series exploring how businesses
column2: trade
column3: economies and working life are changing fast.

column1: But why is caviar so expensive? At Exmoor
column2: its cheapest tin costs £14
column3: but that only gets you 10 grams - less than a teaspoon's worth. By contrast

column1: Much of the high cost is down to the fact that female sturgeon take a long time to reach egg-laying maturity. For the Siberian sturgeon
column2: the main species farmed at Exmoor
column3: this takes between four and five years. For the white sturgeon at Agroittica Lombarda the females don't start laying eggs until they are 14 years old.

column1: Critics of sturgeon farms
column2: such as People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
column3: argue that farming any fish is cruel
column4: as it keeps them in an artificially confined space. The female sturgeons are also generally killed before their eggs are harvested.

column1: Caviar is something no-one needs
column2: says Sascha Camilli
column3: Peta's senior PR coordinator. ""On fish farms
column4: sturgeons are smashed together to swim in crowded
column6: or netted areas polluted with the waste from thousands of fish.""

column1: The caviar industry counters that the sturgeon meat is also sold for eating
column2: that farmed stocks can bolster critically endangered wild numbers
column3: and that the welfare of the fish has to be their main priority.

column1: Exmoor's chief executive Kenneth Benning says that
column2: despite the recent boom
column3: there is no certainty that caviar sales will continue to rise so strongly because demand for the expensive premium product is greatly affected by economic uncertainty.

column1: The reality is that disposable income is [likely] going to be less
column2: particularly in the UK
column3: he says. ""There's a lot of people out there in the world who basically cannot justify spending £20 on a 10 gram tin.

column1: We've been on an upward trajectory
column2: but I think that that's from the marketing perspective
column3: and from building customers who've come back to buy the product again.""

column1: By contrast
column2: Mr Fernandez expects growth to continue to grow rapidly
column3: and Sterling intends to acquire a further 240 acres of land to expand its existing farms.

column1: We'll do a roll up of another five or 15 farms over the next three to four years and take the company public
column2: says Mr Fernandez. ""This is going to be a hot sector for the next five to 10 years - at least.""

column1: At Exmoor
column2: the plans for the future are more high tech - it has filed a patent for the development of lab-grown caviar from sturgeon stem cells. This technology is already under development for other fish
column3: such as tuna.

column1: With cellular aquaculture
column2: we believe we can produce the egg we need within 40 days
column3: says Mr Benning. ""If we had excess demand
column4: we could meet it in a moment.

column1: In a room that is less than 300 square meters
column2: we can produce more caviar than the entire annual global production. If you can provide the products
column3: it's the same genetic material and it doesn't involve the captivity or killing of an animal - it's a no-brainer.""

column1: If all goes to plan
column2: Exmoor - which is working with partners in Switzerland
column3: Germany and Eastern Europe - intends to launch its cell-cultivated caviar in 2023.

column1: But would this mean the end of the farmed sturgeon industry? Mr Benning doesn't think so. He says that some people will always want to buy natural rather than lab-grown caviar.

column1: 160;US Capitol attack: Rioters 'held dagger to the throat of America' - Biden;2022-01-06T16:23:35.000Z;[];['us capitol stormed'
column2: 'jimmy carter'
column3: 'donald trump'

column1: This video can not be played
President Joe Biden has said rioters who stormed the US Capitol on 6 January 2021 ""held a dagger at the throat of America and American democracy"".
In a televised speech marking the first anniversary of the events
column2: Mr Biden said they came ""in rage""
column3: and ""in the service of one man"".

column1: He accused his predecessor Donald Trump of spreading ""a web of lies"" that led to the attack on the Congress building.
Investigators have so far arrested 725 suspects in connection with the riot.
Those who stormed this Capitol and those who instigated this incidence
column2: held a dagger at the throat of America and American democracy""
column3: Mr Biden said in Statuary Hall
column4: a section of the Capitol complex that was breached by rioters.

column1: They came here in rage
column2: not in the service of America
column3: but rather
column4: in the service of one man.

column1: The former president of the United States of America has created and spread a web of lies about the 2020 election... His bruised ego matters more to him than our democracy or our constitution""
column2: he added.

column1: On 6 January 2021
column2: Trump supporters stormed the building as Congress was meeting to certify Mr Biden's presidential election victory. Images of US lawmakers cowering from the mob in the gallery of the House of Representatives on that afternoon shocked the world.

column1: Mr Trump had urged protesters at a rally outside the White House shortly beforehand to ""peacefully"" march on Congress
column2: but he also encouraged them to ""fight"" and stirred up the crowd with unsubstantiated claims of mass voter fraud in the election he had just lost.

column1: The former president released an angry statement hitting out at his successor shortly after Mr Biden's speech. In it
column2: he accused Mr Biden of ""failure"" and repeated false claims about the election.

column1: This video can not be played
Several other events are planned by Democrats
column2: who have control over the US Congress
column3: to mark the one-year anniversary of the attack.

column1: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi will preside over a moment of silence at noon on the chamber floor. She will also lead a moment of reflection with congressional staff members.
Meanwhile
column2: some Republicans plan to skip the day's commemorative events. The party's Senate leader
column3: Mitch McConnell
column4: is leading a delegation to the funeral of a former senator in Atlanta

column1: Florida congressman Matt Gaetz and Georgia congresswoman Marjorie Taylor Greene - two provocative pro-Trump members of the House - will hold a news conference later in the afternoon. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham has already accused Mr Biden of ""brazen politicisation""
column2: of the 6 January riot.

column1: Last January
column2: Joe Biden gave an inaugural address outside the US Capitol that focused on national healing and unity.

column1: Now
column2: standing in the centre of the building nearly a year later - after it has become clear that the nation is as divided as ever - Biden put unifying rhetoric aside and took dead aim at Donald Trump and his supporters.

column1: In some of the sharpest words directed at his predecessor since the 2020 presidential campaign
column2: Biden condemned Trump's continued efforts to question the legitimacy of that election.

column1: Not only that
column2: he blasted Republicans who continue to stand behind the former president and endorsed national efforts to enact election reform to counter what he said were Trump-backed attempts to undermine voting rights.

column1: This is an election year in America
column2: with control of the US Congress and several key states hanging in the balance.

column1: Biden's rhetorical shift could represent a strategic shift
column2: as well - a decision that the Democratic base can most effectively be rallied with anger
column3: not hope.

column1: 164;The man who ran all of Glasgow's 6
column2: 000 streets;2022-01-06T07:51:09.000Z;[];['every single glasgow street – a journal of running 6
column3: 000 streets by michael shanks'];['match'

column1: I get lost quite a lot
column2: Michael Shanks admits. ""My map reading is atrocious.

column1: And inevitably you end up running the same street several times.""
Over the past two years Michael has run along every single street
column2: road and lane on the map of Glasgow - but he says he is more of an explorer than an athlete.

column1: In total he has run more than 2
column3: 400 miles)
column4: double the actual length of the city's 6

column1: Michael
column2: a 33-year-old modern studies teacher
column3: started his mammoth task as a way of making the most of his limited exercise hours during the first Covid lockdown in March 2020.

column1: I realised I tended to run broadly the same route round the west end of Glasgow where I live
column2: he says.

column1: Even streets that were pretty close to me I had just never gone down.""
He started adding new streets and venturing to different areas
column2: then eventually started to consult maps and plan his routes.

column1: His research led him to Rickey Gates
column2: who had run every street in San Francisco in 2018. The ultra runner did it in just 45 days
column3: clocking up an average of 29 miles a day.

column1: Michael says he never intended to match the American's speed
column2: but he had written about the challenges such as trying to avoid the inefficiency of running the same street again and again.

column1: This creates a mathematical conundrum - how do you travel along every road in a city with the least possible distance?
Cul-de-sacs are a nightmare
column2: Michael says.

column1: There is nothing you can do but run all the way to the end of it and then all the way back.
New housing schemes are the worst because they are just full of dead ends. That adds a lot of mileage.""
But Michael reserved the accolade of ""least favourite street"" for a bit of Moray Gardens in the south of the city. When he finally found it
column2: the road turned out to be an extremely steep
column3: muddy track surrounded by a forest.

column1: Some parts of the city are well-suited to his task
column2: such as Garthamlock and Craigend
column3: which were built in the 1950s and 1960s with roads that are linked by pedestrian lanes.

column1: The traditional gridiron layout of many of Glasgow's tenements is also good for methodically ticking off streets
column2: but there are some areas where it is less clear.

column1: Parts of Easterhouse and Possilpark are full of streets where the tenements were demolished 20 years ago and nature has reclaimed most of it.
However
column2: these ""ghost streets"" are still mapped so Michael had to run them.

column1: I nearly got run over by a dirt bike in Possilpark
column2: he says.

column1: I turned a corner and there it was right in front of me.
I think my mother would rather I did not run down some of these streets.""
Michael is quick to add that despite Glasgow's enduring ""no mean city"" reputation
column2: he has never encountered any trouble on any of his runs through some of the most deprived communities in the UK.

column1: I can honestly say there is not a single run in any part of the city where I have thought: 'I need to get out of here quickly'
column2: he says.

column1: I think that is testament to the fact the city has changed a lot.
I have found people unfailingly friendly when it is obvious I don't know where I'm going.""
He adds: ""I'm not a very good runner so usually I pretend to check the map to get my breath back.
I see people looking and I say: 'I'm not lost
column2: I'm just trying to run every street.' That's an obvious conversation starter.""

column1: People are usually keen to tell him all about their area
column2: which helps Michael collect information for a book he is planning on the social history of Glasgow.

column1: He has been inspired by a book from 1860 called Rambles Around Glasgow by Hugh Macdonald.
I am never really going to be an athlete so it is not really a fitness challenge
column2: it is an adventure
column3: he says.

column1: I have been exploring.""
His exploration has uncovered some strange recurring themes.
I have actually become a bit obsessed with 'no ball games' signs because they absolutely infuriate me
column2: he says.

column1: It's not a relic of a bygone era because they are absolutely everywhere.
That mentality which says kids should be seen and not heard really annoys me as a teacher.""
While ball games are often banned in housing schemes
column2: Michael is also intrigued by football goalposts that crop up in the most unlikely places.

column1: He also thinks he must be the only person to take a picture of every single Welcome to Glasgow sign
column2: which he comes across every time he reaches the city council boundary.

column1: Michael finished his challenge on Wednesday when he ran down the city centre's George Square
column2: which he had saved for last. There he was greeted by family and friends.

column1: He says he has enjoyed the challenge but is glad to see the back of it.
I'm relieved but it's quite sad in a way
column2: he says.

column1: I've enjoyed going on the adventure and I guess there is nowhere left to visit in Glasgow. I've been literally everywhere.
But the map will update soon. There is housing being built all over and I won't be at 100% for very long. So I'll be back at it in a few weeks.""

165;I understand anxiety over rising prices
column2: says Chancellor Rishi Sunak;2022-01-06T14:23:17.000Z;[];['angela rayner'
column3: 'jacob rees-mogg'

column1: This video can not be played
Chancellor Rishi Sunak has said he ""understands people's anxiety... about rising prices"" and insisted he will ""always be listening"" to concerns.
He pointed to a living wage rise and the winter fuel payment as ways the government is helping people.
But the chancellor is coming under pressure from Labour and some of his own MPs to cut the VAT on energy bills.
And minister Jacob Rees-Mogg is reported to have raised concern about a tax rise coming into force in April.
On Wednesday
column2: the Financial Times said the leader of the House
column3: Mr Rees-Mogg
column4: had argued against a hike in National Insurance in a Cabinet meeting
column5: calling instead for savings to be made in government spending.

column1: The government says the rise will initially help tackle the backlog in the NHS
column2: and later be invested in social care.

column1: Asked if there were splits in the Cabinet over the tax
column2: Mr Sunak said he had respect for his colleagues but added that it was ""not a responsible thing to do"" to ""duck difficult decisions"" and that people wanted the government to invest in the NHS and social care.

column1: The tax rise is due to kick in during April
column2: around the same time households could see a big rise in their energy bills.

column1: Soaring global gas prices on the wholesale market have put pressure on suppliers
column2: and 27 energy companies have gone bust.

column1: Speaking in the Commons on Thursday
column2: Conservative MP Peter Bone urged the government to cut VAT on energy bills to help consumers.

column1: Energy costs are not a luxury
column2: they are a necessity
column3: something that you can't avoid. You need to heat your home

column1: Labour are also urging the government to scrap VAT on energy bills with the party's deputy leader Angela Rayner accusing the prime minister of failing ""to invest in long term energy security"" and that ""yet again working families are picking up tab for his incompetence"" at Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday.
Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey says the warm homes discount should be increased from £140 per year to £300 and offered to more people.
Speaking to the Today programme
column2: he said: ""We've got to pay for it. But one of the other effects of the big rising global gas prices
column3: as well as hitting people with their heating bills
column4: is it's resulted in record profits for the oil and gas sector.

column1: I think at this stage
column2: when people are going to face an average increase in energy bill of nearly £700
column3: and these oil and gas sectors are making super-profits
column4: it's not unreasonable to ask them to make a contribution.""

column1: Speaking from a vaccination centre in West Sussex
column2: the chancellor said the government had put in place a series of measures to help people with energy costs.

column1: We announced half a billion pounds towards the end of last year to help millions of families - £100-£150 to help them get through the winter
column2: he said.

column1: The chancellor also cited the warm homes discount which reduces energy bills by £140
column2: cold weather payments and winter fuel discounts.

column1: There is support there for people
column2: he said
column3: but added that he was ""always listening making sure the policy we've got will support people in the way we want it to
column4: and that's what our track record over the last year or two shows"".

column1: Abolishing VAT of 5% on energy bills would be quick and easy
column2: but is considered a blunt instrument
column3: as it would provide support to well-off customers who don't need it.

column1: And for those that do need it
column2: 5% of a possible £700 price rise is pretty small.

column1: The government could temporarily suspend the additional levies on bills that fund green policies.
But that would be a tricky sell in some quarters
column2: after the UK hosted a major global climate summit
column3: and these levies are designed to reduce dependence on volatile fossil fuels.

column1: One other option is to extend and expand the Warm Homes Discount. Currently
column2: customers in receipt of certain benefits can apply for a one-off payment of £140.

column1: And another option - suggested by the industry - would be to subsidise the energy companies themselves
column2: by establishing a fund or facility which would allow them to draw down government cash when wholesale prices were very high and then pay it back when prices dipped again.

166;Kazakhstan unrest: Why have there been riots and deaths?;2022-01-06T15:54:20.000Z;[];['kazakhstan'
column2: 'russia'
column3: 'nursultan nazarbayev'];['nazarbayev'

column1: Security forces in Kazakhstan say they have killed dozens of protesters in the main city
column2: Almaty
column3: to quell massive riots.

column1: Some 13 security officers have been killed
column2: with hundreds more wounded in the unrest.

column1: The protests followed a hike in the price of fuel.
Kazakhstan is a huge country
column2: the size of western Europe
column3: situated in Central Asia and bordering Russia and China.

column1: Made up mostly of mountains and arid steppe land
column2: it has a population of only 19 million people.

column1: It gained independence in 1991
column2: following the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: The country has some of the largest oil reserves in the world. It produces 1.6 million barrels of oil a day and has attracted billions of dollars in foreign investment.
However
column2: the wealth has not trickled down to the population
column3: who have an average income of less than £2

column1: For 18 years
column2: Kazakhstan was ruled by President Nursultan Nazarbayev - a former Communist Party politburo member with strong links to Russian President Vladimir Putin. Statues of Mr Nazarbayev were erected and he built a new capital
column3: Astana
column4: which was later renamed Nur-Sultan in his honour.

column1: He stood down in 2019
column2: making way for current President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev.

column1: Public protests in Kazakhstan are illegal without a government permit
column2: and previous strikes and demonstrations have been dealt with very harshly.

column1: Demonstrations started on 2 January in the town of Zhanaozen
column2: an oil hub and the site of deadly clashes between protesters and police just over 10 years ago.

column1: Protests then spread across the rest of the country.
The security forces say they killed rioters in Almaty while trying to restore order. Police say protesters tried to take control of police stations in the city.
At least 12 members of the security forces have been killed and 353 injured
column2: according to police.

column1: Nationwide
column2: about 1
column3: 000 people have reportedly been injured in the unrest
column4: with 400 being treated in hospital and dozens in intensive care.

column1: The protests began when the government lifted its price cap on liquefied petroleum gas (LPG).
Many Kazakhs converted their cars to use LPG because it was cheaper than other fuel.
However
column2: the government said it could not afford to continue subsidising LPG and its decision to remove the cap virtually doubled its price.

column1: However
column2: the rioters appear to have other grievances. Some chanted the name of Mr Nazarbayev and tried to tear down a bronze statue of him.

column1: After stepping down as president
column2: Mr Nazarbayev continued to hold a strong position in government as head of Kazakhstan's Security Council. He also appeared to be grooming his daughter Dariga as a future leader
column3: according to observers.

column1: To placate the protesters
column2: Mr Nazarbayev has been removed from his post.

column1: Russian paratroopers have been sent to Kazakhstan at the request of the Kazakh president to help ""stabilise"" the country.
They were sent under the authority of the Collective Security Treaty Organization (CSTO).
This is a group of countries comprising Russia
column2: Kazakhstan
column3: Belarus
column6: which was set up after the collapse of the Soviet Union.

column1: The CSTO
column2: which is currently chaired by Armenia
column3: has blamed the trouble in Almaty on ""an invasion of bandit formations trained from abroad"".

column1: Russia is keen to increase the military presence it already has in Kazakhstan protecting assets such as gas pipelines
column2: Russian military bases and the Russian space station at Baikonur.

column1: Kazakhstan's government is making concessions.
It has put off removing its price cap on LPG - ordering the prices of all vehicle fuel to be regulated for six months.

Ministers have also resigned. President President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev said the government had failed to carry out ""one of its main tasks -  keeping inflation in check"". The president has appointed Alikhan Smailov as acting prime minister.
The United States urged Kazakh authorities to show ""restraint""
column2: saying protesters should be able to ""express themselves peacefully"".

column1: Peter Bogdanovich
column2: the US film director known for films such The Last Picture Show and Paper Moon has died aged 82
column3: his agent confirmed on Thursday.

column1: The New Yorker's work became synonymous with the New Hollywood of the 1970s.
His coming-of-age drama
column2: 1971's The Last Picture Show
column3: which he also co-wrote
column4: earned him eight Oscar nominations including best director.

column1: The film
column2: set in a Texas town
column3: had an ensemble cast of rising stars including Jeff Bridges and Cybill Shepherd.

column2: he returned with his first movie in 13 years. She's Funny that Way
column3: starring Owen Wilson and Imogen Poots
column5: wrote BBC Culture's Nicholas Barber at the time.

column1: Bogdanovich also starred on the small screen
column2: appearing on HBO's The Sopranos where he played the role of a psychotherapist.

column1: Born in 1939
column2: Bogdanovich became interested in cinema from an early age.

column1: Between the ages of 12 and 30
column2: he kept a record of every film he watched along with a small review on an index card.

column1: As a teenager
column2: he attended acting school and upon leaving took up small roles in theatre and on television
column3: the New York Times reports.

column1: Bogdanovich is survived by his two children.
Francis Ford Coppola
column2: director of The Godfather
column3: released a statement to Deadline to say he was ""devastated"" by the news.

column1: May he sleep in bliss for eternity
column2: enjoying the thrill of our applause forever""
column3: he said.

column1: Guillermo del Toro
column2: the director of Pan's Labyrinth
column3: tweeted: ""He was a dear friend and a champion of Cinema... He single-handedly interviewed and enshrined the lives and work of more classic filmmakers than almost anyone else in his generation.""
