171;Farmers could be paid for post-Brexit 'rewilding' land changes;2022-01-06T02:40:08.000Z;[];['agriculture'
column2: 'nature'
column3: 'george eustice'

column1: Farmers and landowners in England could be paid to turn large areas of land into nature reserves
column2: or to restore floodplains
column3: under new government agriculture subsidies.

column1: When the UK was part of the EU
column2: farmers were given grants based on how much land they farmed.

column1: Following Brexit
column2: the government has pledged to pay based on how farmers care for the environment.

column1: But environmental groups say the new plans lack detail and may not deliver.
In what the government describes as ""radical plans""
column2: landowners and farmers will be allowed to bid for funding to turn vast areas of land - between 500 and 5
column3: 000 hectares - over to wildlife restoration

column1: What we're moving to is a more generous set of incentives for farmers doing the right thing
column2: Environment Secretary George Eustice told the BBC.

column1: We can have both sustainable
column2: profitable food production
column3: and see a recovery for nature as well.""

column1: Agriculture is a devolved issue meaning that each UK nation has its own plans. Wales
column2: for example
column3: has said its new funding scheme will promote environmental benefits and be in place from 2025.

column1: Under the EU's Common Agricultural Policy
column2: farmers were given taxpayers' money largely based on the amount of land they farmed: the more land they held
column3: the more cash support they got. In 2020 about £3.5bn was handed out.

column1: Now the government says that instead of rewarding farmers for how much land they work
column2: it wants to encourage farmers to introduce practices that improve the environment.

column1: Farming creates 10% of the UK's greenhouse gas emissions
column2: and large-scale agriculture has long been accused of degrading the environment.

column1: Applications will shortly open for the first wave of ""Landscape Recovery"" projects. Mr Eustice said the scheme would lead to ""fundamental land use change"" creating new woodlands
column2: restoring peatlands
column3: and other ""intensive interventions"".

column1: The aim of these pilot projects is to create 10
column2: 000 hectares of restored wildlife habitat
column3: which could help sequester carbon and restore England's rivers and streams. Mr Eustice said he hoped it would lead to more large-scale rewilding projects like the Knepp estate in West Sussex.

column1: But Craig Bennett
column2: chief executive of the Wildlife Trusts
column3: said the ""golden opportunity"" of the agricultural transition was in danger of being ""wasted"" .

column1: While we're hearing the right noises from the government
column2: the devil will be in the detail
column3: and the detail is still not published nearly six years after the EU referendum

column1: James Robinson
column2: a farmer in Cumbria with 300 acres of land
column3: said it was difficult to judge the proposals because they still lacked detail.

column1: It will make a difference but we need action now. The way farming has been run for the last 40-50 years has been for field production at the expense of environment. We can't keep going as we are
column2: we need to make a change now
column3: and as farmers we need to step up and make a change. But we also need government support to do that and it's still not quite there yet

column1: There were also concerns among tenant farmers about how they could take part. George Dunn of the Tenant Farmers Association said: ""Payments are being removed from tenant farmers in real time while we have a vague commitment for further work to be undertaken on how tenants can access schemes"".
Dr Alexander Lees
column2: from Manchester Metropolitan University
column3: said the schemes fitted well with the challenges of reversing declines in Britain's most endangered species - those on the Red List. But the aspirations of the pilot seemed ""simultaneously low and over-ambitious""

column1: It would seem very hard to reverse biodiversity loss for the 'most threatened species' in just 10
column2: 000 hectares
column3: he added.

column1: If we are serious
column2: then we need to be racing towards the 300
column3: 000 hectare target as fast as possible.""

column1: An additional plan
column2: called the Local Nature Recovery scheme
column3: will pay farmers to deliver on small-scale environmental priorities
column6: or restoring peat and wetland areas"".

column1: Mr Eustice said it was ""about individual farms or groups making space for nature on part of their holding
column2: perhaps creating water features on some of the less productive land
column3: or hedgerows for breeding sites for birds.""

column1: The government says
column3: the policy aims to:

column1: Details of the broader Sustainable Farming Incentive (SFI)
column2: which aims to support sustainable farming practices
column3: were revealed in December.

column1: The Wildlife Trusts
column2: National Trust and RSPB were highly critical of the SFI plans
column3: saying they were ""deeply concerned"" that they did not go far enough.

column1: According to the Wildlife Trusts
column2: the SFI allows 30% of arable soils to be left bare over winter
column3: which is damaging to soil health. The standards also do not address the damaging impact of pesticides and artificial fertilisers on soil

column1: It also claimed that farmers would be left to measure and assess their own management plans.
Mr Eustice said judging how successful the plan is would be a ""complex"" thing to do in the years ahead.
He said: ""We've been running agri-environment schemes in one form or another for well over 20 years
column2: and each of those have been evaluated. It may not be perfect
column3: but we think it's reasonably accurate. And you have to work on something.""

column1: Kazakhstan's authoritarian leader says he has authorised security forces to ""fire without warning"" amid a violent crackdown on anti-government protests.
President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev also said ""20
column2: 000 bandits"" had attacked the main city of Almaty
column3: the epicentre of protests sparked by a fuel price hike.

column1: He has blamed foreign-trained ""terrorists""
column2: without giving evidence.

column1: The interior ministry says 26 ""armed criminals"" and 18 security officers have been killed so far in the unrest.
In a televised address
column2: Mr Tokayev said the peacekeeping forces sent from Russia and neighbouring states had arrived on his request and were in the country on a temporary basis to ensure security.

column1: The force from the Russian-led Collective Security Treaty Organisation (CSTO) reportedly has about 2
column2: 500 soldiers. Mr Tokayev gave ""special thanks"" to Russian President Vladimir Putin for sending troops.

column1: Earlier on Friday
column2: fresh gunfire was heard near the main square of Almaty.

column1: Where is it? Kazakhstan shares borders with Russia to the north and China to the east. It is a huge country the size of Western Europe
column2: dwarfing in land mass the other former Soviet republics of Central Asia.

column1: Why does it matter? It has vast mineral resources
column2: with 3% of global oil reserves and important coal and gas sectors. A mainly Muslim republic with a large Russian minority
column3: it has largely escaped the civil strife seen in other parts of Central Asia.

column1: Why is it making the news? Fuel riots have rocked the government
column2: resulting in resignations at the top and a bloody crackdown on protesters.

column1: The unrest began on Sunday when the cost of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) - which many people in Kazakhstan use to fuel their cars - doubled
column2: drawing protesters onto the streets.

column1: The government has said that fuel price caps will be restored for six months. But the announcement has failed to end the protests
column2: which have broadened to include other political grievances.

column1: Kazakhstan is often described as authoritarian
column2: and most elections are won by the ruling party with nearly 100% of the vote. There is no effective political opposition.

column1: 174;'Crisis actor' conspiracy theory: How anti-vax activists targeted a Covid patient;2022-01-07T03:31:59.000Z;[];['anti-vaccination movement'
column2: 'fake news'];['antivax'
column3: 'dyne'

column1: A man was targeted with hundreds of abusive messages after being featured in a year-end BBC News report. The source? Anti-vaccine activists who falsely believed he was a so-called ""crisis actor"" pretending to be sick with Covid-19.
A few days after Christmas
column2: Henry Dyne nonchalantly checked his phone while ordering a couple of drinks at a bar. As he unlocked it
column3: he was greeted by more than 600 notifications.

column1: He began to despair - it was something he'd experienced before - but
column2: says the 29-year-old from Surrey
column3: this time was ""a hundred times worse"".

column1: The messages were nasty
column2: abusive
column3: even threatening.

column1: Next time you're in a hospital bed
column2: one read
column3: ""it won't be with Corona.""

column1: Dyne's misfortune began when he contracted the virus in summer 2021. He hadn't been vaccinated
column2: he said
column3: thinking that his relative youth would make any infection pretty mild.

column1: But the IT consultant - who also enjoys posting jokes on his Instagram account - was unlucky.
Every time I'd sleep
column2: I'm not sleeping. I'm all over the place. And then one day
column3: I just woke up at about six in the morning and said I'm calling an ambulance
column4: he says. ""The scariest part was the fever and the hallucinations.""

column1: In July
column2: he ended up in hospital
column3: hooked up to an oxygen tank
column4: and spoke to BBC journalists who were visiting to report on a rise in Covid cases in young people for the News at Six.

column1: I just thought it probably would be quite good to go on record and say 'this is my experience
column2: it is a lot worse than I thought
column3: so get the vaccine'

column1: He didn't think he'd soon find himself the focus of a group of anti-vaccine activists. It was the start of allegations that he was a so-called ""crisis actor"".
The idea of ""crisis actors"" - people who pretend or are hired to act out some particular tragedy or disaster - is part of many contemporary conspiracy theories.

The concept was notoriously used to allege that parents of dead children in the Sandy Hook shooting were somehow faking their personal tragedies. The idea allows motivated activists to explain away real suffering by pretending it was somehow staged.
Of course
column2: BBC News does not use ""crisis actors""
column3: and does not pay interviewees. Dyne was not paid for his contribution.

column1: But that did not stop committed anti-vaccine activists from making up false information and going on the attack.
How much did the BBC pay you to pretend you had Covid-19?"" one message read. Another said: ""You're a dirtbag
column2: mate. Karma is real my friend.""

column1: There were much worse comments as well - many too explicit to share here.
Wild theories spiralled further out of control as activists trawled through his online accounts. Some discovered his LinkedIn profile
column2: which listed one of his former employers
column3: a company that had secured government contracts providing laptops to schools during the pandemic.

column1: The detail was true
column2: but he was no longer employed by the company - the connection was both tenuous and coincidental.

column1: After the initial wave of abuse tailed off and Dyne was on the road to making a full recovery
column2: he tried to joke about it on his Instagram bio
column3: sarcastically describing himself as a ""1x Academy Award Winning Crisis Actor"".

column1: Humour is my way of coping
column2: all you can do is laugh
column3: he explains
column4: ""Little did I know this joke would get me in so much trouble.""

column1: Round two came after a BBC News Special broadcast on 27 December
column2: called Review 2021: The Coronavirus Pandemic. It included the clip of Dyne's original interview.

column1: Someone posted a video of themselves watching the special
column2: googling Henry Dyne's name
column3: finding his Instagram bio and reading the phrase ""crisis actor"".

column1: It's unclear who made the original video - but it was quickly reposted in anti-vaccine circles on YouTube and Facebook
column2: before really taking off on Twitter.

column1: One of the main drivers of the Twitter storm was an aspiring Welsh politician
column2: Richard Taylor. He posted the video on Facebook and racked up thousands of reactions with a tweet.

column1: Taylor received 20% of the vote in Blaenau Gwent standing for the Brexit Party in the 2019 General Election. He recently set up a crowdfunding campaign that raised £61
column2: 000 for a Swansea cinema closed after breaching Covid regulations.

column1: Taylor's posts read ""We see you"" along with the video
column2: but when contacted said via email: ""In my original post
column3: I was not implying anything... It us up to my social media followers to draw a conclusion from what they see or read.

column1: It is unfortunate that Mr Dyne decided to reference himself sarcastically in his social media accounts
column2: Taylor wrote
column3: ""I have lived believing that when someone tells you who or what they are
column5: so I would have taken Mr Dyne at face value when he referenced himself as a crisis actor.""

column1: He also condemned the abuse and threats.
I would never intentionally contribute to abusing or threatening another individual
column2: having spent a large part of my vocation life helping and serving others
column3: he wrote.

column1: But the viral video did result in Dyne receiving hundreds more abusive and threatening messages - he estimates three times as many as in the initial wave in July
column2: including several death threats and fake accounts set up in his name.

column1: Taylor's post on Facebook was labelled as false by fact-checkers. A video on YouTube remains live
column2: as do several viral tweets showing the video on Twitter.

column1: Meta - which owns Instagram and Facebook - has since taken down the fake accounts.
We apologise to Henry for the distress that this must have caused
column2: a Meta statement said.

column1: Accounts that impersonate someone else are not allowed on Instagram and we have removed the accounts reported to us.""

Twitter said in a statement: ""We continue to take enforcement action on content and accounts that advance demonstrably false or misleading claims about Covid-19 and that may lead to significant risk of harm.""
YouTube is investigating the video in question.
All three social media companies condemned online harassment and say they have rules and tools to protect against it.
While lamenting the repeated rounds of abuse
column2: Henry Dyne has continued to poke fun at his accusers
column3: joking that he's available to ""fake"" other disasters.

column1: That's literally all you can do
column2: he says. ""Something does need to happen with social media. It's just so obvious that it's blown so far out of control.""

column1: While he would consider a career in stand-up comedy
column2: he says his bout with Covid-19 wasn't very funny - and was all too real.

column1: Not many people can say they have a doctorate in interplanetary navigation
column2: but Tim Crain can.

column1: While working on his PhD in Austin
column2: Texas
column3: in the 1990s he hoped one day to work on missions to Mars and in 2000 he landed his dream job with Nasa
column4: at the Johnson Space Center in Houston.

column2: the idea was
column3: we would finish the space station in just a matter of years
column4: and then the next big human spaceflight project would be to move on to Mars

column1: But things didn't quite work out that way and shortly after he joined Nasa the agency's priorities changed.
Things took a turn
column2: we lost [the Space Shuttle] Columbia
column3: had the global war on terrorism

column1: He shifted to another Nasa programme called Constellation
column2: an ambitious plan to return to the Moon and eventually Mars
column3: but by 2010 it too had fallen by the wayside.

column1: I became a little bit disillusioned that the Moon was no longer an option with Nasa
column2: says Mr Crain.

column1: So
column2: after a decade with Nasa he left to form Intuitive Machines with co-founders Steve Altemus and Kam Ghaffarian.

column1: Their plan was to apply their expertise to complicated engineering projects
column2: which they did for a few years.

column1: But in 2018 an opportunity came along that the partners could not resist.
In April of that year Nasa launched Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS)
column2: a programme to commission private companies to take cargo to the Moon.

column1: That cargo would include instruments and devices designed to pave the way for Artemis
column2: Nasa's latest plan to return to the Moon
column3: this time by 2025.

column1: We said: 'Hey
column2: wait a minute. That's something we could go after
column3: '"" remembers Mr Crain.

column1: So
column2: they dropped everything and scrambled to get a proposal together.

column1: That was a new experience - to write a proposal for a lunar mission of 30 days. And we won
column2: along with two of our competitors Astrobotic and Orbit Beyond and our lives changed
column3: he says.

column1: But winning the contract was only the first step
column2: next came the design and development of a spacecraft that could get to the Moon.

column1: We quickly discovered we needed to assemble a whole programme - we needed operations
column2: we needed launch system integration
column3: we needed an entire payload integration group.

column1: When you take that whole thing
column2: we actually have a mini space programme
column3: says Mr Crain.

column1: Starting with nothing more than a blueprint it took Intuitive Machines three years to build their spacecraft
column2: Nova-C.

column1: Their engineers used knowledge of existing space technology and blended that with their own development.
The company even developed its own propulsion system which uses methane and liquid oxygen
column2: a well-tried combination.

column1: It is also a fuel that could
column2: one day
column3: be made in space to power future missions.

column1: Any place there's carbon and water
column2: two of the most abundant chemicals in the universe
column3: as far as we know. We'll be able to make methane.""

column1: I think that LOX (liquid oxygen) and methane is the propulsion [system] that will drive commerce through the solar system
column2: says Mr Crain.

column1: The spacecraft
column2: Nova-C is capable of transporting a payload of 130kg
column3: but for its first flight is only carrying 80kg.

column1: Mr Crain says that once Nova-C has proven itself
column2: they will build bigger spacecraft. The company has plans for one that can carry a payload of five tonnes.

column1: But before those more ambitious missions
column2: the first launch has to go to plan.

column1: A US spacecraft has not made a soft landing on the Moon since the last of the Apollo missions in 1972. (The LCROSS mission in 2009 deliberately crashed a vehicle into the Moon to examine the material kicked up by the impact.)
Nova-C could change that when it blasts into space atop a SpaceX rocket in the first quarter of 2022.
It will decouple from that rocket after about 18 minutes and head to the Moon on a journey that will take about four days.
More technology of business:
Once there Nova-C will enter a low lunar orbit for around 24 hours. Then it will use its main engine to brake for a soft touchdown between Mare Serenitatis and Mare Crisium
column2: two of the dark lava seas on the Earth-facing side of the Moon.

column1: Once safely down
column2: it will operate for around 13 and a half days during the lunar day
column3: during which time the Nasa and commercial payloads will be deployed and start work.

column1: The experiments and data gained will be sent back to Earth using Intuitive Machines' own lunar data relay service.
Once it has run out of energy
column2: everything shuts down and Nova-C will sit on the Moon's surface forever
column3: or perhaps until some future astronaut comes along and recycles it.

column1: One of the biggest engineering challenges has been managing the extreme temperatures that Nova-C will encounter on the Moon
column2: where temperatures can be as high as 140C (284F) and fall to minus 170C (minus 275F).

column1: If it was just the spacecraft and its flight computers
column2: that would be relatively easy. But now we have to take care of our payloads
column3: says Mr Crain.

column1: Heating and cooling systems have been designed to keep the cargo safe
column2: even in the extreme environment of the Moon.

column1: Simeon Barber is a senior research fellow at the Open University and has spent his career developing instruments that will work in space
column2: on planets and other bodies including the moon.

column1: His current project is a Exospheric Mass Spectrometer
column2: which will head into space on the first mission of a rival to Intuitive Machines
column3: Astrobotic. His device will analyse the composition of the lunar atmosphere around the lander.

column1: I think we are entering a new era
column2: for sure
column3: he says.

column1: Previously
column2: scientists like him might have worked on one or possibly two big space missions in their career
column3: but now there are new possibilities with the prospect of more regular trips to the Moon.

column1: There are several missions on the slate now and this gives you the opportunity to do things quickly
column2: to be a bit more risky
column3: and not have all your eggs in one basket. So it kind of frees you from that fear of failure

column1: Lunar transport systems from Intuitive and its rivals
column2: as well as government-led programmes like Nasa's Artemis will be the start of a new era of human activity on the moon
column3: says Mr Crain.

column1: Unlike the first time around
column2: where we had to invent a lot of the technology from scratch
column3: we have a lot of technology in terms of electronics
column6: and composite materials [that] has changed the game.""

column1: I think within the next 20-30 years
column2: you will see civilians paying for for trips to the Moon
column3: for holidays.

column1: Predicting the future is hard
column2: so maybe not. But I think it's feasible.""

column1: Dr Barber is cautiously optimistic. He highlights how hostile the Moon will be for humans
column2: with the huge temperature range and lunar dust which
column3: if not managed
column4: will damage machinery and human lungs. He is also keen that further human exploration has a minimal environmental impact.

column1: But would he go
column2: if he could?

column1: I like my home comforts. But yeah. I think you'd have to say
column2: yes wouldn't you?""

column1: A tree that is new to science has been named after Leonardo DiCaprio.
Scientists at the Royal Botanic Gardens
column2: Kew
column3: say they wanted to honour the star for his help in saving a rainforest from logging.

column1: The tree
column2: which has been given the official name
column3: Uvariopsis dicaprio
column4: grows only in the Cameroon forest known for its incredible biodiversity.

column1: We think he was crucial in helping to stop the logging of the Ebo Forest
column2: said Dr Martin Cheek of Kew.

column1: Scientists and conservationists were horrified when they heard of plans to allow vast swathes of the Ebo Forest to be opened up for logging.
One of the largest relatively untouched rainforests in Central Africa
column2: it is home to the Banen people and an array of unique flora and fauna
column3: including threatened gorillas

column1: International experts wrote a letter to the government documenting the precious animal and plant species at risk of extinction. The issue was picked up by DiCaprio
column2: whose social media posts to his millions of followers added momentum to the campaign.

column1: The government later revoked plans to allow logging
column2: although the forest has yet to be officially designated a national park.

column1: This could just be a stay of execution
column2: Dr Cheek added.

column1: The ""dicaprio"" tree is the first plant new to science to be officially named by Kew scientists in 2022
column2: through publication in the scientific journal
column3: PeerJ.

column1: The small tropical evergreen tree has glossy yellow flowers that grow from its trunk. A member of the ylang ylang family
column2: it has been found only in a small area of the forest and is critically endangered.

column1: Last year
column2: more than 200 plants and fungi from across the word were officially named by Kew scientists and their collaborators
column3: including a pink lily from the same forest
column4: an insect-trapping wild tobacco plant found in Australia and an orchid with star-like flowers from the island of Madagascar that can grow in darkness.

column1: Several of these new species are already extinct and many are threatened due to deforestation
column2: land clearance and droughts
column3: floods and fires driven by climate change.

column1: Of 16 new species of orchids found in Madagascar
column2: three are thought to be extinct in the wild due to destruction of their habitat. One has disappeared due to forests being chopped down to grow plants for geranium oil used in the aromatherapy industry in Europe.  And a new Cape primrose from Katanga in Congo is at risk from copper mining.

column1: Until a species has a scientific name
column2: assessment of its extinction risk is near impossible
column3: which makes protection from extinction very difficult.

column1: Dr Martin Cheek said the list of show-stopping discoveries from 2021 is another reminder that this is our last chance to find unknown species
column2: name them and protect them before they become extinct.

column1: There are still thousands of plant species and maybe millions of fungal species out there that we don't know about
column2: he said. ""This natural habitat that they're growing in - especially forests
column3: but other habitats too
column4: is increasingly and more rapidly being destroyed by us humans without knowing what's there.""

column1: 179;Obituary: Iconic black actor Sidney Poitier;2022-01-07T15:35:51.000Z;[];['obituaries'];['iconic'

column1: Sidney Poitier
column2: who has died aged 94
column3: once turned down the role of Othello because he did not want to be typecast as a black actor.

column1: It underlined the dilemma faced by a man who broke down many of Hollywood's racial barriers.
As the first black winner of the Academy Awards' Best Actor statuette
column2: he was always aware of being the standard-bearer for greater racial integration.

column1: But often he felt he had become something of a racial token
column2: and this denied him the opportunity of taking on more varied roles.

column1: He died on Friday
column2: aged 94
column3: the Bahamian foreign minister announced.

column1: Sidney Poitier was born on 20 February 1927 in Miami
column2: Florida.

column1: His parents were Bahamian farmers who had travelled to the US to sell tomatoes. His premature birth meant he gained US citizenship as well as Bahamian.
Relatives believed his father's family originated in Haiti and that his ancestors were runaway slaves.
He was brought up on Cat Island in the Bahamas before the family moved to the capital
column2: Nassau.

column1: Aged 15 he went to live with his brother in Miami before moving to New York
column2: where he worked as a dishwasher.

column1: It was in the US that he experienced racism for the first time.
I lived in a country where I couldn't get a job
column2: except those put aside for my colour or my caste.""

column1: After a spell in the US Army he joined the American Negro Theatre
column2: which had been set up as a community project in Harlem in 1940.

column1: Unfortunately Poitier was tone-deaf and was unable to sing
column2: something audiences felt was a prerequisite of black actors at that time.

column1: Instead he decided his future lay as a serious stage actor and he was offered a leading role in a production of Aristophanes' comedy Lysistrata in 1946.
It was a sign of the times that the production featured only black actors.
In 1949 he took the difficult decision to move away from stage productions and into films.
It was a sound decision. His performance in the 1950 film No Way Out
column2: in which he played a newly-qualified doctor confronted by a racist patient
column3: brought him to the attention of the studios.

column1: His breakthrough came in The Blackboard Jungle in 1955
column2: in the role of a disruptive pupil in an inner-city school.

column1: The film was immensely popular
column2: not least because it was one of the first to have a soundtrack featuring rock 'n' roll
column3: including Bill Haley's classic Rock Around the Clock.

column1: The Defiant Ones
column3: saw Poitier nominated for best actor at the Academy Awards
column4: and he won a Bafta for the same film.

column1: Five years later he was awarded an Oscar for Lilies of the Field
column2: the first black winner of the Best Actor trophy.

column1: With the growing civil rights movement in the US
column2: it was inevitable Poitier would find himself lauded as an example of black achievement. It was a role he gladly accepted.

column1: I was a pretty good actor and I believed in brotherhood. I hated racism and segregation. And I was a symbol against those things.""
However
column2: he was concerned that his Oscar may have been indicative of Hollywood's need for a token black actor
column3: rather than something he achieved on merit.

column1: Then 1967 saw him at his commercial peak with three films
column2: making him Hollywood's most bankable star that year.

column1: He played a newly-qualified teacher in a tough London school in To Sir
column2: With Love
column3: based on the autobiographical novel by E R Braithwaite.

column1: His character's experience of being an immigrant in London mirrored that of many West Indians who came to Britain during the 1950s and '60s.
Acting isn't a game of 'pretend'
column2: he once said. ""It's an exercise in being real.""

column1: Poitier was nominated for Bafta and Golden Globe awards for Norman Jewison's film In the Heat of the Night.
He played a Philadelphia detective who found himself stranded in a red-necked Mississippi town on the night a businessman is murdered.
His developing relationship with the bigoted local sheriff
column2: played by Rod Steiger
column3: gave Poitier his strongest role and the film won five Oscars

column1: Poitier's response to Steiger's question ""What do they call you
column2: boy?"" produced one of cinema's most famous lines: ""They call me Mr Tibbs.""

column1: Guess Who's Coming to Dinner featured Poitier as the boyfriend of a white
column2: middle-class girl who takes him to meet her parents.

column1: Played by Spencer Tracey and Katherine Hepburn
column2: her parents were torn between their liberal values and their reaction to a prospective black son-in-law.

column1: At the time filming began
column2: interracial marriage was still illegal in 17 US states. These laws were only revoked by the Supreme Court months before the film was released.

column1: But Poitier faced criticism from some black civil-rights activists who complained his characters were just too good to be true.
It helped to persuade him to move away from acting roles. He involved himself in the campaign for Bahamian independence
column2: achieved in 1973
column3: and began a new career as a director.

column1: By the end of the 1970s
column2: Poitier had formed his own production company with other stars
column3: including Paul Newman and Barbra Streisand.

column1: Successes behind the camera included Stir Crazy
column2: with Richard Pryor and Gene Wilder
column3: and the thrillers Shoot to Kill and Little Nikita.

column1: Poitier became the first black actor to receive a life achievement award from the American Film Institute in 1992.
Five years later
column2: he was appointed the Bahamas' ambassador to Japan and he received a knighthood in 1974.

column1: As a Bahamian citizen this was a substantive rather than an honorary award
column2: although he did not use it in the US.

column1: Poitier married  Juanita Hardy in 1950
column2: but the union ended in 1965. In 1976 he married the Canadian actress
column3: Joanna Shimkus
column4: and had six daughters from his two marriages. His daughter
column5: Sydney Tamiia Poitier is also an actress.

column1: In 2016 He was awarded a Fellowship by Bafta
column2: a recognition of his outstanding contribution to cinema. Poor health prevented him travelling to London to receive the award so he appeared via a video link.

column1: Poitier's noted ability to play intelligent leading roles helped to break down racial taboos in American cinema and wider society
column2: although he played down his importance as a role model.

column2: he once said
column3: ""and if my presence here has sparked some good energies

column1: At least 21 people have died after heavy snow trapped them in their vehicles in northern Pakistan.

column1: Mystery surrounds the Darvaza crater's creation in the Karakum Desert.

column2: the huge crater formed in the 1960s but was only lit in the 1980s.

column1: The crater is one of Turkmenistan's most popular tourist attractions.
We are losing valuable natural resources for which we could get significant profits and use them for improving the well-being of our people

column1: A group of green-minded Tory MPs says the government should fund environmental and social energy policies from the Treasury
column2: instead of from consumer bills.

column1: The Conservative Environment Network (CEN)
column2: which includes 116 MPs
column3: says the temporary measure would ease the surge in household costs.

column1: But the group opposes a separate proposal to abolish the 5% VAT on energy bills
column2: saying it would effectively provide a subsidy for fossil fuels.

column1: The CEN is urging ministers to reduce bills and emissions in the long term by ensuring the UK's homes are better insulated.
The plea is endorsed by the Energy Efficiency Infrastructure Group - an alliance of businesses and charities who will write to the prime minister on Monday
column2: arguing better insulation for people in sub-standard housing could cut bills by £500 a year.

column1: But the current crisis over energy bills has revealed divisions among Conservative backbenchers.
The plan to scrap VAT on energy has been pushed by the Net Zero Scrutiny Group (NZSG) of Tory MPs and peers.
The caucus
column2: with around 20 followers
column3: has been linked to the anti-green pressure group formerly known as the Global Warming Policy Foundation
column4: which was founded by the former Chancellor Nigel Lawson.

column1: Although its numbers are small
column2: it is well connected in Conservative media.

column1: Its leader
column2: the Tory MP for South Thanet
column3: Craig Mackinlay has regularly voted against measures to tackle climate change.

column1: He doesn't deny climate change science
column2: but believes the costs of climate policies are falling unfairly on the UK.

column1: In December
column2: Mr Mackinlay tweeted that he blamed ""the rush to Net Zero"" for creating the ""madness in the energy market"".

column1: But this view is disputed by the industry body Energy UK
column2: which says the rise in gas prices has caused the crisis
column3: not Net Zero policies.

column1: Sam Hall
column2: director of the environmental CEN
column3: pointed out that his organisation had almost six times more members than the sceptic NZSG.

column1: He told BBC News: ""A clear majority of Conservative backbenchers supports the government's Net Zero agenda - the PM should know that we've got his back.""
The director added: ""Last year
column2: no Conservative MP voted against the government's sixth carbon budget
column3: which aims to cut emissions by 78% by 2035.

column1: Although a small minority of MPs are raising concerns about the cost of achieving the target
column2: it is perfectly possible to deliver Net Zero in a way that is fair and keeps down energy costs for consumers and businesses.""

column1: Mr Hall insisted the solution to the global gas crisis ""was not to deepen our dependence on gas by removing VAT"".
Instead
column2: he said the Treasury must urgently devise policies to fund environmental and social energy projects for the long term.

column1: The government has accepted that its current system of loading levies onto the cleaner fuel - namely electricity - is perverse.
Mr Hall said when the price of gas settles
column2: the levies should be shifted on to the dirtier home heating fuel
column3: gas.

column1: Because of the government's Net Zero policy
column2: the UK is set to reduce its gas demand significantly over coming decades
column3: he said.

column1: This will protect UK consumers from future gas price shocks by making us less dependent on volatile international gas prices.""
But Mr Mackinlay told BBC News he did not see any ""conflict"" between his group and the CEN
column2: ""nor anything to be gained by an 'ours are bigger than yours' approach"".

column1: He added: ""We all want to leave the planet in a better place than we found it.
The key difference is our perception of how best to achieve a lower carbon UK and to inject some realism when the UK is responsible for 1% of global CO2 whilst China
column2: India
column3: Indonesia go gangbusters for new coal.""

column1: Mr Hall said: ""Every country will need to hit Net Zero - and the UK should lead on this to gain the benefit of going first to develop new technology and services.""
The government is urgently seeking solutions for the cost of living crisis
column2: which is seeing bills and price tags rising in the UK.

column1: The idea of targeted financial support for fuel bills - along the lines of the current Warm Homes Discount scheme - is emerging as a frontrunner to tackle a cost of living squeeze
column2: which could see households £1
column3: 200 a year worse off as a higher energy cap comes in at whilst taxes rise for workers and employers.

column1: Marilyn Bergman
column2: the Oscar winning lyricist who collaborated with her husband Alan on The Way We Were and hundreds more songs

column1: The song-writing duo worked together on numerous shows for stage and screen and were known as ballad specialists.

column2: Fred Astaire and Frank Sinatra.

column1: She died on Saturday at her Los Angeles home with Alan and her daughter by her side
column2: her agent said.

column1: Bergman's cause of death has been reported as respiratory failure
column2: and is not Covid related. She is survived by her husband

column1: The Bergmans were nominated for 16 Academy Award nominations
column2: winning three times - for The Way We Were from the 1973 Barbra Streisand film of that name
column3: Windmills of Your Mind from The Thomas Crown Affair in 1968 and for their score for Streisand's Yentl in 1983.

column1: They also won several Grammy and Emmy awards
column2: and were inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1980.

column1: Bergman was a trailblazer for women in the industry and in 1985 was the first woman to be elected president and chairman of the board of the American Society of Composers
column2: Authors and Publishers (ASCAP).

column1: Among those paying tribute was US producer Quincy Jones
column2: who called her death ""crushing"".

column1: Born in Brooklyn
column2: New York City on 10 November 1928 in the same hospital as her husband
column3: Bergman studied music from a young age.

column1: While at New York's High School of Music & Art
column2: she often played piano for lyricist Bob Russell
column3: who encouraged her to consider becoming a professional songwriter.

column1: But her entry into writing lyrics was also a painful one - while in college
column2: Bergman fell down a flight of stairs and broke both of her shoulders. Unable to write or play piano
column3: she started speaking song lyrics into a tape recorder.

column1: Even though she and Alan grew up living close to each other
column2: they did not meet until they both moved to Los Angeles. For Bergman
column3: that was in the mid-1950s
column4: and she started writing lyrics for composer Lew Spence
column5: with whom Alan was also working with.

column1: Marilyn and Alan wed two years later in 1958. They had one daughter together
column2: Julie Bergman Sender
column3: who is a film producer.

column1: A Saudi princess and her daughter have been released from a high-security jail after being held for nearly three years without charge

column1: Some have speculated it may have been related to her advocacy on humanitarian issues and constitutional reform.

column1: Other supporters suggest it was her close links to former crown prince Mohammed bin Nayef
column2: who is reported to have been placed under house arrest.

column1: Princess Basma
column3: appealed to Saudi King Salman and Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to release her last April
column4: saying she had done nothing wrong and that her health was suffering.

column1: It is not known what treatment she was seeking abroad when she was detained in 2019.

column3: on the outskirts of the capital.

column1: I rang up the county council and I said I think I've found a dinosaur
column2: explained Joe Davis
column3: who works at Rutland Nature Reserve near Leicester.

column1: During landscaping work at the reserve's reservoir in February 2021
column2: he'd spotted something unusual poking out of the mud.

column1: It wasn't a dinosaur. But it was the fossilised remains of a ten-metre long sea predator called an ichthyosaur.
And it was the largest of its type ever discovered in the UK.
I looked down at what seemed like stones or ridges in the mud and I said this looks a bit organic
column2: a bit different
column3: Mr Davis told BBC News. ""Then we saw something that looked almost like a jawbone.""

column1: The council said to Mr Davis: ""We don't have a dinosaur department at Rutland County Council so we're going to have to get someone to call you back."" A team of paleontologists were brought in for a closer look.
They concluded it was an ichthyosaur - they were warm-blooded
column2: air-breathing sea predators not unlike dolphins
column3: and could grow up to 25 metres long. They lived between 250 million and 90 million years ago.

column1: Dr Dean Lomax
column2: a palaeontologist from Manchester University
column3: was brought in to lead the excavation effort. He called the discovery ""truly unprecedented"" and - due to its size and completeness - ""one of the greatest finds in British palaeontological history"".

column1: Usually we think of ichthyosaurs and other marine reptiles being discovered along the Jurassic coast in Dorset or the Yorkshire coast
column2: where many of them are exposed by the erosion of the cliffs. Here at an inland location is very unusual.""

column1: Rutland is more than thirty miles from the coast
column2: but 200 million years ago higher sea levels meant it was covered by a shallow ocean.

column1: When water levels at the Rutland reservoir were lowered again in the late summer of 2021
column2: a team of palaeontologists came in to excavate the remains. Special attention was paid to the removal of the huge skull.

column1: A large block of clay containing the ichthyosaur's head was carefully dug out before being covered in plaster and placed on wooden splints.
The block
column2: weighing almost a tonne
column3: was raised out of the mud and will now be examined further.

column1: It's not often you are responsible for safely lifting a very important but very fragile fossil weighing that much
column2: said Nigel Larkin
column3: palaeontological conservator and Visiting Research Fellow at Reading University. ""It is a responsibility

column1: Anglia Water
column2: which manages the Rutland reservoir
column3: is now looking for funding to enable the ichthyosaur to stay in the area and be enjoyed by the general public.

column1: A lot of people thought I was pulling their leg when I told them I'd found a large marine reptile at work
column2: Mr Davis said. ""I think a lot of people won't believe it until the TV programme goes out.""

195;Air pollution: Delhi's smog problem is rooted in India's water crisis;2022-01-10T00:03:39.000Z;[];['asia'
column2: 'delhi'
column3: 'india'

column1: Every winter
column2: Indian capital Delhi's toxic air is fuelled by farmers burning crop stubble. But the fires don't stop. Why? The answer lies in water
column3: writes climate expert Mridula Ramesh.

column1: India loses an estimated $95bn (£70bn) to air pollution every year.
From mid-March to mid-October
column2: when Delhi's air quality varies from good to moderate to unhealthy for sensitive groups
column3: chatter on air pollution and its causes is muted.

column1: But then comes winter. Pollution in any city mixes vertically in the atmosphere
column2: and the height at which this happens shrinks by more than half in the winter
column3: raising the concentration of pollution. Two new sources also enter the mix. By the end of October
column5: the winds begin to blow in from the northwest
column6: carrying fumes from burning fields. Then there is the Diwali
column8: where millions burst fire crackers to celebrate.

column1: Both of these play a large role in the spike in pollution. In the first week of November 2021
column2: when Delhi's air quality went beyond hazardous
column3: stubble burning accounted for 42% of the city's PM2.5 levels - these are tiny particles that can enter the lungs.

column1: Governments have banned the practice
column2: imposed fines and even suggested alternate uses for the straw and other crop residue. But farmers continue to burn stubble. Why?

column1: Think of the fields that are on fire. They get only between 500-700mm (19-27 in) of rainfall a year. Yet
column2: many of these fields grow a dual crop of paddy and wheat. Paddy alone needs about 1
column3: 240mm (48.8 in) of rainfall each year
column5: farmers use groundwater to bridge the gap.

column1: The northern states of Punjab and Haryana
column2: which grow large amounts of paddy
column3: together take out roughly 48 billion cubic metres (bcm) of groundwater a year
column4: which is not much less than India's overall annual municipal water requirement: 56bcm. As a result
column5: groundwater levels in these states are dropping rapidly. Punjab is expected to run out of groundwater in 20-25 years from 2019

column1: The burning fields is a symptom of the deteriorating relationship between India and its water.
Long ago
column2: farmers grew crops based on locally available water. Tanks
column3: inundation canals and forests helped smoothen the inherent variability of India's tempestuous water.

column1: But in the late 19th Century
column2: the land began to transform as the British wanted to secure India's north-western frontier against possible Russian incursion. They built canals connecting the rivers of Punjab
column3: bringing water to a dry land. They cut down forests
column4: feeding the wood to railways that could cart produce from the freshly watered fields. And they imposed a fixed tax payable in cash that made farmers eager to grow crops that could be sold easily. These changes made farmers believe that water could be shaped
column5: irrespective of local sources - a crucial change in thinking that is biting us today.

column1: After independence from the British in 1947
column2: repeated droughts made the Indian government succumb to the lure of the ""green revolution"".

column1: Until then
column2: rice
column3: a water-hungry crop
column4: was a marginal crop in Punjab. It was grown on less than 7% of the fields. But beginning in the early 1960s
column5: paddy cultivation was encouraged by showing farmers how to cheaply and conveniently tap into a new
column6: seemingly-endless source of water that lay underground.

column1: The flat power tariffs to run borewells were cheapened and finally not paid - removing any incentive to conserve water. Water did not need to be managed
column2: farmers were taught
column3: only extracted. In the heady first years of the revolution
column4: fields began to churn out paddy and wheat
column5: and India became food-secure. But after a couple of decades

column1: To conserve groundwater
column2: a 2009 law forbade farmers from sowing and transplanting paddy before a pre-determined date based on the onset of the monsoon. The aim was to make the borewells run less in the peak summer months.

column1: But the delay in paddy planting shrunk the gap between the paddy harvest and sowing of wheat. And the quickest way to clear the fields was to burn them
column2: giving rise to the smoky plumes that add to northern India's air pollution.

column1: So
column2: the toxic smog is but a visible symbol of India's trainwreck of a relationship with its water.

column1: To tackle this problem
column2: Indians need to respect their water again - a tall ask after decades of neglect.

column1: Take people's choices in food and crops. A century ago
column2: most Indians ate the hardy millet
column3: which could withstand the vicissitudes of India's water. Today
column5: and they eat rice and wheat rotis (flatbreads)
column6: making millets an unappealing crop for farmers to grow.

column1: And pricing water
column2: directly or through electricity that powers the borewells
column3: is seen as political suicide. Meanwhile
column4: as air quality improves from hazardous to (very) unhealthy
column6: courts and political leaders have moved on - at least until next November.

column1: But the time bomb - of depleting groundwater - ticks on. Once that runs out
column2: the November air might be cleaner.

column1: But what will India do about food?

Mridula Ramesh is a leading climate and water expert and author of Watershed: How We Destroyed India's Water and How We Can Save It and The Climate Solution: India's Climate-Change Crisis and What We Can Do about It.

column1: If you have ever dreamed of earning money from a stellar music career but were concerned you had little talent
column2: don't let that put you off  - a man called Alex Mitchell might be able to help.

column1: Mr Mitchell is the founder and boss of a website and app called Boomy
column2: which helps its users create their own songs using artificial intelligence (AI) software that does most of the heavy lifting.

column1: You choose from a number of genres
column2: click on ""create song""
column3: and the AI will compose one for you in less than 30 seconds. It swiftly picks the track's key
column4: chords and melody. And from there you can then finesse your song.

column1: You can do things such as add or strip-out instruments
column2: change the tempo
column3: adjust the volumes
column5: make everything sound brighter or softer

column1: California-based
column2: Boomy
column3: was launched at the end of 2018
column4: and claims its users around the world have now created almost five million songs.

column1: The Boomy website and app even allows people to submit their tracks to be listed on Spotify and other music streaming sites
column2: and to earn money every time they get played.

column1: While Boomy owns the copyright to each recording
column2: and receives the funds in the first instance
column3: the company says it passes on 80% of the streaming royalties to the person who created the song.

column1: Mr Mitchell adds that more than 10
column2: 000 of its users have published over 100
column3: 000 songs in total on various streaming services.

column1: Eighty-five per cent of our users have never made music before
column2: Mr Mitchell tells the BBC. ""And now we've got people who were paying their rent
column3: and augmenting their income
column4: with $100 (£74) or $200 a month from Boomy during Covid.""

column1: But
column2: how good are these Boomy created songs? It has to be said that they do sound very computer generated. You wouldn't mistake them for a group of people making music using real instruments.

column1: However
column2: using AI to help compose music isn't exactly new: US classical composer
column3: David Cope
column4: developed such a software system back in the 1980s
column5: following some episodes of writer's block.

column1: One day he set it up to write compositions similar to those by Johann Sebastian Bach. Mr Cope then popped out for a sandwich
column2: and returned to find that the computer had composed 5
column3: 000 Bach-inspired chorales. These were later released on an album called Bach by Design.

column1: More recently
column3: Berlin-based US electronic music composer
column5: made an album called Proto in collaboration with an AI system called Spawn that she had co-created. Ms Herndon is an expert in this field
column6: and has a doctorate in music and computing from Stanford University in the US.

column1: Mr Mitchell says that what has changed in recent years is that technological advancements in AI have meant song-writing software has become much cheaper.
So much so that Boomy is able to offer its basic membership package for free. Other AI song creator apps
column2: such as Audoir's SAM
column3: and Melobytes

column1: While AI composition inevitably grabs the headlines because of its novelty
column2: new tech is continuing to change many other aspects of the wider music industry.

column1: When the City and County of San Francisco imposed strict lockdowns back in 2020
column2: Matthew Shilvock says that keeping an opera company going proved ""extremely challenging"".

column1: He is general director of the San Francisco Opera
column2: and it could no longer have ""two singers
column3: or even a singer and pianist

column1: But when he tried running rehearsals with his performers online
column2: ""traditional video conference platforms didn't work""
column3: because of the latency
column4: or delays in the audio and video. They were out of sync.

column1: So
column2: Mr Shilvock turned to a platform called Aloha that has been developed by Swedish music tech start-up Elk. It uses algorithms to reduce latencies.

column1: Elk spokesman
column2: Björn Ehler
column3: claims that while video platforms like Zoom
column5: and Google Meet have a latency of ""probably 500 to 600 milliseconds""
column6: the Swedish firm has got this down to just 20.

column1: Mr Shilvock says that
column2: when working remotely
column3: Aloha has ""allowed me to hear a singer breathe again"".

column1: He adds that looking to wider tech to help solve problems is only natural for an opera house with Silicon Valley on its doorstep. ""The energy and the drive to find solutions through technology is just so much part of the DNA of this city.""
Meanwhile in Paris
column2: Aurélia Azoulay-Guetta says that
column3: as an amateur classical musician
column4: she ""realised how painful it is to just carry
column6: and travel with a lot of physical sheet music for rehearsals
column7: and how much time we waste"".

column1: So she and her fellow co-founder ""decided to junk our jobs"" and launch a start-up called Newzik
column2: which allows music publishers and composers to digitally distribute their sheet music to orchestras.

column1: New Tech Economy is a series exploring how technological innovation is set to shape the new emerging economic landscape.
Ms Azoulay-Guetta says that her solution replaces the stress of musicians having to turn physical
column2: paper pages with their hands during performance or rehearsal. Instead
column3: they now turn a turn a digital page via a connected pedal.

column1: And if the arrangement of a concerto or other composition is tweaked - which can be done by using an electronic pen on the app screen - this will update on every orchestra member's copy of the electronic music sheets.
Ms Azoulay-Guetta says that this feature particularly helped when concerts finally resumed after lockdowns
column2: because orchestras and ensembles faced last minute programme changes - for instance
column3: if musicians were absent

column1: Other tech firms are focusing on helping musicians more effectively deal with their paperwork. One such company is Portuguese start-up Faniak.
Founder and chief executive
column2: Nuno Moura Santos
column3: describes its app as ""like a Google Drive on steroids""
column4: allowing musicians - who are often freelancers -to more easily do their admin all in one place
column5: ""so they can spend more time writing and playing music"".

column1: Back at Boomy
column2: Mr Mitchell is himself a classically-trained violinist. He says that the firm's users are now popping-up everywhere.

column1: We have Uber drivers creating albums and playing them during their drives
column2: he says. ""And [last year] I woke up to a frantic call from my head of engineers
column3: asking if we were under attack.

column1: There was tons of traffic from Turkey
column2: and we don't have a Turkish version. It was just a YouTuber in Turkey
column3: who did a video about Boomy
column4: and [from that] we have tens of thousands of users there.""

column1: The past seven years have been the hottest on record
column2: according to new data from the EU's satellite system.

column1: The Copernicus Climate Change Service said 2021 was the fifth-warmest year
column2: with record-breaking heat in some regions.

column1: And the amount of warming gases in our atmosphere continued to increase.
Governments are committed to limiting global temperature rise to 1.5C to curb climate change. But scientists warn that time is fast running out.
The environmental
column2: human and economic costs of hotter temperatures are already being seen globally.

column1: Europe lived through its warmest summer
column2: and temperature records in western US and Canada were broken by several degrees. Extreme wildfires in July and August burnt almost entire towns to the ground and killed hundreds.

column1: These events are a stark reminder of the need to change our ways
column2: take decisive and effective steps toward a sustainable society and work towards reducing net carbon emissions
column3: Carlo Buontempo
column4: director of the Copernicus Climate Change Service

column1: The Copernicus data comes from a constellation of Sentinel satellites that monitor the Earth from orbit
column2: as well as measurements taken at ground level.

column1: Copernicus data showed that 2021 was the fifth-hottest on record
column2: marginally warmer than 2015 and 2018. Taken together
column3: the past seven years were the hottest seven years on record by a clear margin

column1: The 2021 average temperature was 1.1-1.2C above the pre-industrial level around 150 years ago.
It would be easy to dismiss the latest global temperature figure as a non-event. Who celebrates fifth place in anything?
If we were in a film
column2: these annual temperature updates would be the ominous drum beat signalling the plot is darkening.

column1: They measure out the pace of change in our world. The increments may be tiny - a fraction of a degree - but the direction of travel is inescapable.
And make no mistake
column2: the rhythm they mark out increasingly sets the pace for all our lives.  Think of the fires and floods that affected so many people in 2021.

column1: And now look again at what the data is telling us: the seven hottest years ever recorded have been the last seven years.
We can't say we weren't warned.
The agency said that the start of the year saw relatively low temperatures compared to recent years
column2: but that by June monthly temperatures were at least among the warmest four recorded.

column1: Places with above average temperatures included the west coast of US and Canada
column2: north-east Canada and Greenland
column3: large parts of north and central Africa

column1: The weather phenomenon known as La Niña - when surface sea temperatures are cooler - contributed to below-average temperatures in western and eastern Siberia
column2: Alaska
column3: and the central and eastern Pacific during the start and end of 2021.

column1: Overall Europe's annual temperature was outside the ten warmest years on record but the summer was the hottest.
A heatwave swept through Mediterranean in July and August
column2: particularly affecting Greece
column3: Spain and Italy.

column1: In Sicily
column2: 48.8C degrees was reported
column3: breaking Europe's record for highest temperature by 0.8C.

column1: The hot temperatures in the eastern and central Mediterranean was followed by intense wildfires particular in Turkey but also in Greece
column2: Italy
column3: Tunisia and Algeria.

column1: And Europe also saw extreme wet weather
column2: with huge floods devastating parts of Germany
column3: Belgium and the Netherlands.

column1: These events were part of the same picture of weather systems disrupted by climate change.
The concentration in the earth's atmosphere of two gases that significantly contribute to climate change rose in 2021
column2: said Copernicus.

column1: Carbon dioxide concentrations reached 414.3 parts per million last year
column2: growing at a similar rate to 2020.

column1: This video can not be played
But scientists remarked that methane levels in the atmosphere increased to reach an unprecedented approximately 1
column2: 876 parts per billion. The growth rate of methane was also higher than in 2020 - Copernicus said both rates were very high compared to the past two decades of satellite data.

column1: Scientist say it is important to reduce methane levels because it is more potent than CO2
column2: however it lasts much less time in the Earth's atmosphere.

column1: The increasing concentrations of these gases showed no signs of slowing down
column2: concluded Vincent-Henri Peuch
column3: Director of the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service.

column1: More data about 2021's temperatures will be released in the coming days from other agencies including from Nasa and the UK's Met Office.

column1: Amateur photographers have been cataloguing the wealth of wildlife on a farm after the land was opened up to them by a nature-loving farmer.
Tom Clarke
column2: who farms at Prickwillow in Cambridgeshire
column3: has dedicated part of his land as natural habitat.

column1: Members of Ely Photographic Club have captured striking images of deer
column2: hare
column3: owls and insects.

column1: I wanted to show that nature can thrive alongside commercial farming
column2: Mr Clarke said.

column1: He is one of a group of farmers who worked with the RSPB to set up the Ely Nature-Friendly Farming Zone with the aim of ""enhancing the environment within our farmed landscape"".
Last spring
column2: Mr Clarke invited members of the local photography club to use his land as their canvas.

column1: Lots of them were travelling to north Norfolk because that's where they thought nature was
column2: he said.

column1: But it's right here on their doorstep - and I wanted to record that.""
He was not surprised at the variety of animals and insects the group captured on his land.
I see this stuff all the time
column2: but I usually see nature's backside
column3: running away
column4: and I'm too busy in my tractor to stop and capture it on film.

column1: People's perception is that Fenland farmland is flat and boring and full of fields of crops - but nature is all around us.""
Mr Clarke and like-minded farmers have ""dedicated part of our farms and given it over to nature""
column2: he said.

column1: The food
column2: the shelter and the habitat is all here to encourage wildlife to thrive.""

column1: Is this for real?""
That might be your reaction to what we know now - that one of Boris Johnson's most senior aides emailed around 100 staff in Downing Street for outdoor drinks in May 2020
column2: during the intense early emergency of lockdown.

column1: Martin Reynolds
column2: the principal private secretary (for how much longer?) invited dozens and dozens of staffers to drinks in the garden
column3: socially distanced
column5: in contradiction to the very strict and very clear public guidance to the public at the time that banned socialising in any form.

column1: A jog with a friend in the park or a solitary trudge along the same canal path was just about it.
Is this for real?"" was in fact the reaction of one of the staff who was gobsmacked to receive the email
column2: written down in black and white
column3: in a message to another official shared at the time.

column1: Another
column2: shown to the BBC
column3: said: ""Um. Why is Martin encouraging a mass gathering in the garden?""

column1: Those exchanges make it pretty clear that there were concerns at the time. Yet the event went ahead
column2: with
column3: I'm told
column5: a long table set out in the garden for drinks
column8: the prime minister and his wife in attendance.

column1: Notwithstanding how many of you might feel reading the details of that event
column2: and the planning that went into it
column3: there are three main reasons why this latest bout of claims about what was happening in Number 10 are deeply troubling for Mr Johnson.

column1: First off
column2: the email
column3: a scoop for our colleagues at ITV
column4: is evidence in black and white of a social event that was planned in advance.

column1: That flies in the face of the prime minister's insistence so far that there were ""no parties"". Evidence of a planned event is not the same as ad hoc chats or the odd drink after hours outdoors or in the office in a Covid-secure environment - the kind of events some in government think could be justified.
With an official investigation under way by a senior and experienced official with a stringent reputation
column2: that is troublesome.

column1: Second
column2: the prime minister could lose a senior official over what happened
column3: and there has long been speculation about which moderately senior head might roll in the aftermath of the inquiry.

column1: But if
column2: as eyewitnesses have told us
column3: Mr Johnson was there himself
column4: he is personally right at the centre of the mess.

column1: Third
column2: for most of Monday the chatter among MPs and ministers getting back into the parliamentary routine was that the mood had calmed
column3: the Tory anger at No 10's chaos had eased off after a liberal application of mince pies and eggnog.

column1: Disillusionment with Downing Street was still extremely common but the heat
column2: and with it the political pressure
column3: had cooled somewhat.

column1: But now
column2: with this new damaging fodder for the opposition
column3: don't be so sure.

column1: This is the first of two Business of Technology articles examining the way wood pellets are produced and used as an energy source.
The areas in and around North Carolina's forests feel spacious. Canopies of lanky pine trees eventually give way to enormous car parks and long-term storage units
column2: underscoring the feeling of vastness.

column1: Many of these US trees are destined to be turned into small pellets for the biomass industry. At wood pellet mills
column2: wood is chipped
column3: dried
column5: easily storable pellets. They're then shipped mainly to the UK

column1: Most forest land in North Carolina is privately owned
column2: in holdings that can be as small as one acre (0.4ha). This can mean they are too small to qualify for conservation easements - agreements encouraging landowners to keep trees intact
column3: sometimes with tax benefits.

column1: Small forest owners here include a number of third-generation African Americans whose ancestors moved north and west as part of the Great Migration (the movement of six million African Americans between 1916-70 out of the rural southern US to the urban Northeast
column2: Midwest and West) leaving the cropland to turn back into forest.

column1: A lot of minority landowners are really disconnected from their land
column2: says Freddie Davis III
column3: a forester who leads the Rural Training and Research Center
column4: which is part of the Federation of Southern Cooperatives.

column1: Mr Davis believes that biomass is the best option on such low-value holdings for these owners - who typically live away from their forest land and often not even in the same state. ""I'm super passionate about it because it offers opportunity
column2: he says.

column1: Yet the racial justice aspect is complex. Sherri White-Williamson
column2: who leads environmental justice policy for the North Carolina Conservation Network
column3: works out of a cramped office in Clinton. The area has a large black population and is about 20 minutes away from a pellet mill. ""We've pretty much become the dumping ground for a lot of things for the sake of economic development

column1: While the wood pellet industry is an important local employer
column2: Ms White-Williamson argues that the effects on water
column3: air and noise mean that these companies aren't the best of neighbours.

column1: Volatile organic compounds from wood pellet manufacture
column2: especially softwood like pine
column3: are a problem because of the way they're converted into formaldehyde and other noxious substances
column5: a lawyer at the Southern Environmental Law Center.

column1: Enviva
column2: the world's main producer of wood pellets
column3: counters that its plants are in compliance with air quality regulations.

column1: Biomass is controversial
column2: not just locally for the affects on communities near pellet plants
column3: but also globally for the unusual way that its carbon emissions are counted. Many argue that the current carbon accounting rules on wood pellets are not fit for purpose.

column1: They are accounted at the harvest site
column2: such as in North Carolina
column3: rather than the place where they are actually burnt
column4: notably at the UK's Drax power station in Yorkshire.

column1: The reason for this is that because the trees are replanted
column2: this form of energy is renewable. Decades ago
column3: the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) agreed under the Kyoto Protocol that it would be simpler to account for the carbon emissions of land use only when harvested.

column1: But these decisions have been not just scientific but political
column2: says Peg Putt
column3: who coordinates biomass campaigns for the Environmental Paper Network: The negotiators mainly ""come out of the forest agencies of the various countries
column4: have close ties to industry and work to advantage the interests of the forest industry

column1: They have made the accounting seem so forbiddingly complicated and technical that higher level negotiators in the party delegations just leave it to them.""
More technology of business:
Lawyer Derb Carter says the US now has a ""proliferation"" of wood pellet mills ""where - they're all for export
column2: mostly to Europe - and essentially no utilisation of this material here in the US for energy production"".
all of the wood pellets fed into the UK's Drax power station were imported. Mr Carter says for the EU
column3: UK
column4: and increasingly Japan and South Korea
column5: this system is ""almost a free ticket in some ways"".

column1: The emissions from burning wood don't actually show up in these countries' emissions records
column2: because of what he says are the ""perverse accounting"" rules on wood pellets' carbon emissions.

column1: A growing number of scientists and policymakers understand that biomass is not an instantaneously carbon-neutral source of renewable energy. Mr Carter says it is a ""simplistic notion"" that trees are a renewable resource. Trees cut for biomass can take 30-100 years to fully grow back. Even if they store some carbon as they grow - the maximum amount of carbon dioxide is only absorbed by fully mature trees.
Drax defends it use of wood chips to make electricity.
Biomass is a reliable
column2: flexible renewable power source which is available regardless of what the weather does. It therefore has a vital role to play in the energy system
column3: displacing coal and supporting the grid to further decarbonise
column4: by enabling more renewables like wind and solar to come online

column1: Wood pellet producer Enviva points out it is not sourcing from pristine forests
column2: but managed forests which need to be thinned periodically to maintain good health
column3: yet whose wood quality isn't high enough for higher-value markets like paper.

column1: According to Enviva
column2: its wood pellet mix is made up of 20% sawmill residues
column3: 14% thinning

column1: Kim Cesafsky
column2: Enviva's director of sustainability
column3: is adamant that ""we directly displace coal"". She calls fossil fuels ""a one-way street""

column1: Yet biomass is actually even more polluting than coal. ""Burning wood for energy produces at least as much carbon dioxide as burning coal per unit of energy produced and usually more
column2: Ms Putt explains.

column1: Wood is less energy dense than coal
column2: so ""you have to put more into burning it to get the amount of energy that you want - therefore you release
column3: generally

column1: Prof Gert-Jan Nabuurs
column2: who researches forestry at Wageningen University
column3: the Netherlands
column4: is one of the coordinating lead authors of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). He acknowledges that wood does not burn as efficiently as natural gas or coal ""and that is why for the same amount of energy
column5: you are emitting more"". But he argues that ""this biomass for bioenergy is a short cycle"" as the trees are replanted.

column1: Yet this idea runs contrary to proforestation - the principle of keeping forests intact - because as diverse forests are replaced with plantations of a single tree species
column2: this makes them not only more vulnerable to disease but also generally less efficient at sequestering carbon.

column1: According to Ms Putt: ""Plantations are less carbon dense than are natural forests
column2: generally speaking
column3: and they get logged more frequently. So they have less opportunities to sequester carbon.""

column1: A video clip of an unvaccinated doctor challenging the health secretary over the government's plan to make NHS staff have a Covid jab - or risk losing their job - has been viewed more than a million times on social media.
Making vaccination a condition of employment already applies to care-home staff and
column2: from 1 April
column3: is being extended to NHS workers - about 90% of whom are already vaccinated.

column1: Dr Steve James - a critical care consultant who has chosen not to be vaccinated - told Sajid Javid
column2: during the health secretary's visit to King's College Hospital
column3: ""the science isn't strong enough"" to support the policy.

column1: The vaccines are reducing transmission only for about eight weeks with Delta
column2: he said.

column1: For Omicron
column2: it's probably less.""

column1: But that's not exactly what the evidence shows.
While vaccines remain very good at protecting against becoming severely ill with Covid
column2: the protection they give against catching it and passing it on does wane more quickly.

column1: Dr James was referring to a study that found a vaccinated person with Covid was just 2% less likely than an unvaccinated person to pass it on
column2: 12 weeks after a second Oxford-AstraZeneca jab - he acknowledges his reference to ""eight weeks"" was an error.

column1: But the same study found the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine
column2: which NHS staff are likely to have had
column3: endured better. Vaccinated people had a 25% lower risk of infecting others than unvaccinated people after 12 weeks.

column1: And this research alone doesn't tell the whole story - the vaccines also reduce people's risk to others by stopping them catching the virus in the first place.
One paper found those vaccinated with Pfizer 85% less likely than the unvaccinated to be infected with Covid after two weeks and 75% less likely after 12 weeks.
Vaccinated people also seem to clear the virus faster and have less of it in their system - reducing their chances of passing it on.
These studies all looked at the Delta variant
column2: first identified in India.

column1: Two vaccine doses appear to be less effective against catching and passing on Omicron infections - although
column2: they are still good at preventing severe illness - but much of the benefit is restored with a third booster jab.

column1: The second part of Dr James's argument was that he had probably had Covid
column2: providing him with some protection without a vaccine.

column1: I've got antibodies
column2: he said.

column1: I've been working on the Covid [intensive-care unit] since the beginning.""

So-called natural immunity - having immune cells such as antibodies and T-cells in your system that recognise and fight off the virus from an infection rather than a vaccine - can offer effective protection
column2: although it comes with the risk of becoming very ill or developing ""long Covid"".

column1: But what the doctor didn't mention is that
column2: as with his point about vaccines
column3: this protection also wanes and may be ineffective against infection with a different variant.

column1: An Imperial College London study suggests the protection from having had Covid against infection by the Omicron variant
column2: first identified in South Africa
column3: ""may be as low as 19%"".

column1: The best protection against Covid comes from having an infection and being vaccinated too
column2: several pieces of research have found.
