Dominic Wilkinson
column2: a professor of medical ethics
column3: at the University of Oxford
column4: says doctors have a clear ethical duty to be vaccinated but sacking someone who is not but can show they have had a recent infection that may provide similar protection may be unjustifiable.

column1: If the vaccines completely blocked transmission
column2: it would be a much simpler question
column3: he says.

column1: But since they are less effective against new variants
column2: it is ""no longer as clear"".

column1: Dr James says he is not against all Covid vaccination but feels he was framed as such online
column2: after opposing compulsory jabs.

column1: He describes himself as ""pro-choice and pro-vaccine""
column2: saying his point was specifically about the science behind the mandate not the vaccine itself.

column1: But another NHS hospital doctor
column2: Dr Meenal Viz
column3: who spends her spare time online correcting misinformation
column4: told BBC News she feared the clip of Dr James would be seized on by those who wanted to suggest the science for the vaccine in general was not strong enough - despite the huge weight of evidence from hundreds of independent institutions and millions of people that it prevented disease and death.

column1: This fits into a pattern she regularly sees online
column2: where short clips
column3: single statistics or lines from a scientific study taken out of context can ""completely blow up"" and cause more confusion than straightforward falsehoods.

column1: On the internet
column2: when things go viral
column3: people tend to cherry-pick what they want
column5: potentially leaving people with the impression an intensive care doctor was doubting the science of the vaccine
column6: rather than the much narrower and more complicated point Dr James says he was making.

column1: And her fears were not misplaced.
Dr James's comments were eagerly seized on by those against vaccination
column2: including some promoting false theories such as the virus is a hoax.

Labour and some Tory MPs are demanding immediate answers on whether Boris Johnson attended a drinks event in the Downing Street garden during lockdown.
In heated scenes in the Commons

column3: but can't hide"" from scrutiny over the May 2020 gathering.

column1: And Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross said Mr Johnson must quit if found to have broken Covid rules.
The PM has declined to say whether he went to the drinks.
He will face MPs for what is likely to be a volatile session of Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday.
On Monday
column2: ITV published a leaked email from Mr Johnson's principal private secretary
column3: Martin Reynolds
column4: inviting 100 staff to ""socially distanced drinks in the No 10 garden"" on 20 May 2020 - when lockdown rules in England banned large outdoor gatherings.

column1: The invitation encouraged people to ""bring your own booze"" and ""make the most of the lovely weather"".
Witnesses have told the BBC the prime minister and his wife Carrie were among about 30 people who attended the drinks.
An inquiry - led by senior civil servant Sue Gray - is under way into this event and other gatherings that took place on government premises during 2020.
We should get rid of him…. We should own the situation. We are the Tory party. We are not delivering good governance.""
That stinging verdict from a Conservative MP does not
column2: at least not yet
column3: seem to represent the consensus among the party's ranks on what to do about the current situation in Downing Street.

column1: But the goodwill-to-all-men moment the Christmas holidays promised is very much over.
The subject of conversation among Tories on Tuesday was not the government's planned menu of policy fare for the week

column3: election-winner

Standing in for Mr Johnson in the Commons on Tuesday

column1: But he warned it could be ""paused"" if the Metropolitan Police - which says it is in contact with the government over reports of alleged breaches of Covid rules - decided to carry out its own investigation.
Mr Ellis added that it was not for him to ""pass judgement or to pass sentence"" before Ms Gray's findings were known.
But Labour MPs lined up to recount stories of constituents who had suffered during the pandemic and to accuse the government of hypocrisy.
Ms Rayner said it was disappointing that Mr Johnson was not there in person to respond
column2: adding: ""But his absence speaks volumes
column3: as do his smirks on the media.

column1: The public has already drawn its own conclusions. He can run
column2: but he can't hide.""

And DUP MP Jim Shannon was brought to tears when speaking of the death of his mother-in-law during the pandemic.
SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford called on Conservative MPs to ""force [the PM] from office"" if he did not ""do the decent thing"" and resign.
Few Tory MPs turned up in the Commons to support Mr Johnson
column2: but one who did

column4: said: ""The time of the House is better spent at this moment in time
column5: as we recover from this pandemic... debating how we can build back better and level up.""

I think if [Mr Johnson] knowingly attended what he knew to be party

column1: 218;Downing Street party: What Covid rules were broken?;2022-01-12T14:00:56.000Z;[];['coronavirus lockdown measures'

column1: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has apologised for attending a party in the Downing Street garden during the first lockdown
column2: but said he believed ""implicitly that this was a work event"".

column1: It is the latest in a number of alleged parties to have taken place under Covid restrictions
column2: which are currently being investigated by senior civil servant Sue Gray.

column1: An email
column2: sent to as many as 100 people in Downing Street
column3: invited them to ""socially distanced drinks in the No 10 garden this evening"".

column1: The email
column2: revealed by ITV News
column3: was sent on behalf of Mr Johnson's principal private secretary

column1: It is understood that about 30 people attended the event on 20 May 2020. Two eyewitnesses had already told the BBC they saw Mr Johnson and his wife Carrie there.
In his apology
column2: Mr Johnson told MPs he went into the garden just after 18:00 to thank groups of staff and returned to his office 25 minutes later. He said that the event ""could be said to fall technically within the guidance"".

column1: Throughout the pandemic there has been a mixture of guidance and legal restrictions relating to behaviour likely to spread the virus.
Legal restrictions are underpinned by sanctions - where breaking the law could result in prosecution. Guidance - unless it's also backed up in law - is not enforced by fines or court action
column2: explains Stuart Nolan from the Law Society.

column1: In terms of guidance:
When it came to workplace gatherings
column2: the guidelines said: ""Workers should try to minimise all meetings and other gatherings in the workplace.""

column1: The ""working safely during coronavirus"" guidelines also said only absolutely necessary participants should attend meetings and should maintain 2m separation throughout."" Generally
column2: workers were told to ""reduce the number of people you spend time with in a work setting"".

column1: There is nothing in the guidelines that would suggest that drinking
column2: socialising or other types of work event would have been allowed.

column1: There were also a number of legal restrictions in place in May 2020:
People could not leave their homes - or be outside the place they live - without a reasonable excuse
column2: which included work (where you couldn't work from home)
column3: exercise and getting things like food and medicine.

column1: For people who broke these rules
column2: the police in England could fine them £100 for the first offence which could then double for each further offence up to a maximum of £3

column1: It would be difficult to see how the Downing Street event would have been in line with these rules
column2: argues barrister Adam Wagner.

column1: If you were doing something which wasn't necessary for work then you weren't outside of your house [with] a reasonable excuse and you were potentially committing a criminal offence.""
However
column2: Mr Wagner added that as the prime minister and his wife live in Downing Street they would not have technically left their home to attend the party.

column1: Mr Wagner is involved in a case to bring a judicial review against the Met Police for not investigating the alleged parties.
The law also banned gatherings in a public place of more than two people
column2: unless they were all members of the same household or the gathering was ""essential for work purposes"". However
column3: lawyers have noted that Downing Street is not a public place.

column1: The official gov.uk Twitter account posted this tweet on the same day as the Downing Street garden party.
A number of other gatherings are alleged to have taken place in Downing Street during 2020.
One was alleged to have taken place on 27 November - a leaving party for Cleo Watson
column2: a former aide to Dominic Cummings.

column1: At this point a national lockdown was in force and indoor gatherings with other households were not allowed (unless for work).
This lockdown ended on 2 December and England returned to the tier system of restrictions where there was a specific prohibition on organising an indoor gathering of more than 30 people.
When a Downing Street Christmas quiz took place on 15 December
column2: London was under tier 2 restrictions. These rules banned two or more people from different households from meeting indoors
column3: unless ""reasonably necessary"" for work purposes.

column1: The same rule would have applied when a party - which was joked about in a leaked Downing Street press conference video - was alleged to have taken place on 18 December. At this point London had been moved to tougher tier 3 restrictions.
Furthermore
column2: the government's guidance for the Christmas period specifically said: ""Although there are exemptions for work purposes
column3: you must not have a work Christmas lunch or party
column4: where that is a primarily social activity and is not otherwise permitted by the rules in your tier.""

column1: This same line was also tweeted out by the official gov.uk account on 17 December 2020 in response to a question from a member of the public about whether Christmas parties were allowed in the workplace.
Allegations of Downing Street parties first surfaced in the Daily Mirror
column2: when it reported in early December that a party had been held in Number 10 during the 2020 Christmas period.

column1: In response
column2: Mr Johnson told MPs that that ""all guidance was followed completely in No 10"".

column1: However
column2: after the Downing Street press conference video was leaked - which appeared to confirm a Christmas party took place - Mr Johnson said he understood the public anger.

column1: It goes without saying that if rules were broken then there will be disciplinary action for all those involved
column2: Mr Johnson said.

column1: Later
column2: when details of the Downing Street quiz emerged
column3: Mr Johnson said he ""certainly broke no rules"". Number 10 said that the prime minister ""briefly took part virtually"" to thank staff for their work during the pandemic.

column1: Two people pictured with Mr Johnson - wearing tinsel and a Santa hat - were members of his closer staff who had come in to help him with the technology
column2: according to Downing Street.

column1: Number 10 also insisted that no rules were broken when a photo emerged of the prime minister and his staff with bottles of wine and a cheeseboard in the Downing Street garden from 15 May. Mr Johnson said that the photo showed ""people at work""
column2: which was allowed under the rules.

Boris Johnson is facing calls from senior Tories to stand down as prime minister after he admitted attending a drinks party during lockdown.
The PM apologised for the way he had handled the event in the Downing Street garden in 2020 and said he understood the public's ""rage"" over it.
Cabinet members including deputy PM Dominic Raab rallied round Mr Johnson.
But Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross and senior backbenchers William Wragg and Caroline Nokes called on him to go.
Mr Ross
column2: an MP and an MSP
column3: said he had a ""difficult conversation"" with Mr Johnson after the PM's apology to MPs earlier on Wednesday.

column1: The former minister

column1: The prime minister's admission and apology in the Commons likely bought him a little time.

column2: in perhaps a week or so.

column1: But for many on his own side

column1: Growing numbers of his own MPs want him out

column1: Read more from Laura
At Prime Minister's Questions
column2: Mr Johnson sought to calm anger about reports he had attended a ""bring your own booze"" party at the height of the first lockdown.

column1: He admitted he was at the 20 May 2020 gathering for about 25 minutes
column2: so that he could ""thank groups of staff"" for their hard work.

column1: He said: ""I believed implicitly that this was a work event.""
But he added: ""With hindsight I should have sent everyone back inside.
I should have found some other way to thank them
column2: and I should have recognised that - even if it could have been said technically to fall within the guidance - there would be millions and millions of people who simply would not see it that way.""

column1: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said the PM's defence was ""so ridiculous that it's actually offensive to the British public"" and he called on Mr Johnson ""to do the decent thing and resign"".
The SNP's leader at Westminster Ian Blackford called on Tory MPs to force the PM out - and Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey said he had to go.

column4: releasing our LauncherOne rocket at the right time
column5: sending our customers' satellites on their way to orbit

column1: The UK Ministry of Defence anticipates using Virgin Orbit to launch military satellites in the future
column2: and is building a pool of experience in advance of this happening.

column1: Thursday's mission will be the third overall for British entrepreneur Sir Richard's Long Beach
column2: California-based company.

column1: His 747-and-LauncherOne system has previously put up 19 satellites. The seven on the latest manifest includes one manufactured in Glasgow by Spire Global
column2: which tracks weather conditions from orbit
column3: along with ship and plane movements.

column1: Flt Lt Stannard is scheduled to get matters under way at roughly 12:30 US West Coast time (20:30 GMT).
He'll fly out over the Pacific with the rocket tucked neatly under the left wing of the former Virgin Atlantic jumbo.
About an hour after take-off
column2: at an altitude of 35
column4: the liquid-fuelled booster will be unlatched and go into a freefall.

column1: Roughly four seconds later
column2: as Flt Lt Stannard banks his 747 hard to the right
column3: LauncherOne will ignite its first-stage engine to begin the climb to orbit.

column1: Virgin Orbit wants to run six space missions this year
column2: with two of these planned to operate out of Newquay Airport in Cornwall.

column1: The first of these UK events could happen as early as June or July
column2: although much will depend on how quickly licensing paperwork goes through the UK's Civil Aviation Authority. The CAA's paramount concern is safety and it won't let any launch proceed until it's satisfied all contingencies are covered.

column1: The CAA has 35 staff to assess the technical details of applications. A licence to operate a spaceport is expected to take six to 12 months to process; a licence to operate a rocket system will take longer at nine to 18 months.

The CAA told the House of Commons Science and Technology Committee on Wednesday that so far it was dealing with four formally submitted licensing applications (others from a range of potential spaceport/rocket operators are at a pre-application stage).
However
column2: when asked whether this meant a UK launch was likely this year
column3: the authority's policy director Tim Johnson refused to be drawn.

column1: We absolutely share the government's enthusiasm
column2: and industry's enthusiasm
column3: and commitment to this task. We're open for business
column4: we're processing applications; the key driver of the timetable will be the quality of the applications (and) the evidence presented

column1: We will exercise our duties in the most timely way possible.""

column1: The Norfolk hamlet of Berney Arms was once home to a small but thriving community of 11 families. Today
column2: it lies empty but for an unused pub
column3: an RSPB centre
column4: a closed marsh mill and a railway station. What was it like to live there and what does its future hold?

column1: I would go back and live there tomorrow if I could
column2: says Sheila Hutchinson.

column1: She was raised in Berney Arms
column2: a remote settlement sitting on the north bank of the River Yare near Great Yarmouth.

column1: At one time there were 11 families there
column2: she says.

column1: Livelihoods were eked out largely from the land itself
column2: whether directly at the marsh mill or indirectly from grazing cattle.

column1: The last lifelong residents to leave Berney Arms were Mrs Hutchinson's uncle Stanley Hewitt and his family.
They left in 1988 when their farmhouse was sold to the RSPB.
When we were growing up we had no running water
column2: no electricity and a fireplace in the kitchen
column3: says Mrs Hutchinson.

column1: People have asked me what it was like growing up like that. The answer is simple - we didn't know anything different.""
Drinking water used to come from the roof
column2: through a pipe with a sock on the end acting as a filter and then into a tank.

column1: With no trees or other buildings around
column2: winter winds were ferociously cold
column3: Mrs Hutchinson says.

column1: Water left in a jug overnight would freeze and would have to be heated over a flame in the morning before it could be used.
In the winter months the cold would go right through you
column2: she says.

column1: But I don't remember ever being poorly or having a day off school
column2: the 75-year-old says. ""We were hardy.""

column1: To get to school each day she walked across nearly a mile of marshland before arriving at the railway station
column2: and if caked in mud would she had a flannel and a towel to clean up before getting on the train to go to school in Great Yarmouth.

column1: Author Mrs Hutchinson
column2: who wrote Berney Arms Past and Present with her husband Paul
column3: remembers the breath-taking views from her and her brother's bedrooms
column4: which stretched out to Burgh Castle on one side and the railway station on the other.

column1: Her family's story begins with her grandfather Henry Hewitt
column2: who owned cattle and the farmhouse in Berney Arms. Her father looked after the cows and a living was made selling milk.

column1: The community's primary links with the outside world centred on the railway station.
From the trains that stopped at Berney Arms came the post
column2: the newspapers and - twice a week - the groceries.

column1: If you missed something off your grocery list
column2: she says
column3: ""that was it until the next delivery.""

column1: Today
column2: the station remains open.

column1: Gone is the post
column2: the newspapers and the groceries - to be replaced primarily by people interested in seeing birdlife.

column1: Mrs Hutchinson fears the way of life she was raised in has gone forever in Berney Arms. And she doubts such a community will ever again be formed there.
Asked if that makes her a little bit sad
column2: she says
column3: simply: ""Yes.""

column1: Though if the pub
column2: which closed in 2015
column3: can be successfully brought back to life
column5: there is probably a living to be made from the growing number of visitors coming to explore Berney Arms.

column1: Last year
column2: the railway station at Berney Arms
column3: which has seating for six people
column4: saw the largest rise in passenger numbers of any stop in the UK.

column1: Once the quietest station in the country
column2: Berney Arms saw its passenger numbers rise eightfold from just 42 in 2019-2020 to 348 last year - though the increase is almost entirely explained by the pandemic and the fact the line was closed for much of the year for upgrades and the laying of new track.

column1: The station
column2: which is only accessible on foot
column3: is a request stop on the line between Norwich and Great Yarmouth. It is surrounded by the RSPB's Berney Marshes and Breydon Water reserve.

column1: Jonathan Denby
column2: of Greater Anglia which runs the line
column3: says Berney Arms' continued place on its network is assured.

column1: From an operational point of view
column2: the rail network is there and is part of the fabric of the nation.

column1: It gives people the opportunity to do things both for work and also for pleasure.""
During the week and on Saturdays there are two trains from Norwich stopping at Berney Arms on their way to Great Yarmouth
column2: but just one train which heads the other way. On Sundays
column3: there are four trains running each way between Norwich and Great Yarmouth.

column1: The line on which Berney Arms sits is important to Greater Anglia because of Great Yarmouth. When the summer months come
column2: the Berney Arms route gives the operator a second railway line to ferry tourists into the popular coastal town.

column1: Having another route gives us flexibility
column2: says Mr Denby.

column1: Berney Arms is also a pretty simple station and is low maintenance for us and when you consider we've already had 800 people using it since April 2021 there is potential for growth there too.""
Leisure travel is the area of Greater Anglia's business which has seen the strongest resurgence since the pandemic started.

Mr Denby added: ""I think there's a good chance we will see an increase in passenger numbers at places like Berney Arms because people are increasingly enjoying going outside and into the countryside.""
Most of those who use the service to and from Berney Arms are walkers and birdwatchers.
The RSPB runs a reserve in the hamlet and it has recently benefitted from a major drainage scheme.
You've got to be a special kind of person to come out here
column2: says Ian Robinson
column3: of the RSPB.

column1: But I think once you're out here
column2: it has its own atmosphere - big skies
column3: features like Berney windmill and just the fact that you're on your own
column4: with your own thoughts and with wildlife and the landscape you see around you.""

column1: With additional reporting by Mike Liggins.

column1: Stephanie Jarvis credits YouTube with saving her vast French chateau.
She had bought the 40-room
column2: 16th Century home back in 2005 after pooling resources with a friend.

column1: Such French castles were relatively cheap at the time
column2: so between them they were able to buy one for £590
column4: raising the money by selling both of their two-bedroom London flats.

column1: The plan was to turn the property - Chateau de Lalande
column2: in the Centre-Val de Loire region of northern France - into a bed and breakfast
column3: and hire it out for events.

column1: However
column2: Ms Jarvis admits that she didn't factor in just how expensive it would be to pay for the upkeep of such a huge
column3: old building. ""I didn't realise how much money it would take to run

column1: So
column2: by the start of 2020
column3: the chateau business had yet to make a profit. And then the Covid-19 pandemic arrived

column1: It was going to be the first year that we were in profit for the bed and breakfast
column2: but everything had been cancelled
column3: she says. ""I had no money coming in

column1: Then Ms Jarvis had a brain wave. Since 2018 she had been sporadically posting video blogs about her life at the castle up on social media platform
column2: YouTube
column3: under the channel name
column4: The Chateau Diaries. She had started to do this after appearing in a TV renovation show
column5: called Escape to the Chateau DIY
column6: and found that she liked the experience of talking to the camera about her home.

column1: With the pandemic shutting down everything else
column2: Ms Jarvis decided that she'd now make and publish such videos on a daily basic ""and see how it goes"".

column1: To her surprise
column2: her YouTube channel soared in popularity
column3: going up from 10

column1: This meant that the money she made from the advertisements on her videos jumped from a few hundred euros to many thousands.
It escalated so fast
column2: it was unbelievable
column3: she says. ""I think a lot of people were finding themselves in quarantine
column4: and wanting to see how other people were living through it.""

column1: The channel also gives people this hope that maybe they don't need to follow a traditional path
column2: and then can still make something happen with their lives.""

column1: Ms Jarvis is now able to use the revenue from YouTube
column2: along with the renewed income from the bed and breakfast
column3: to pay four staff to work at the castle.

column1: She also now gets additional funds from a Patreon account that she set up last year. Patreon is an online subscription platform that allows Ms Jarvis' subscribers to pay to view exclusive
column2: extra video content. This is now said to make about £24
column3: 000 per month.

column1: Another couple now making YouTube videos about life owning a French chateau are British designer Anna Mayrhofer and her Italian filmmaker husband Philipp.
They purchased their 18th Century Chateau Le Fleur
column2: in Normandy
column4: using money from the sale of their Parisian apartment. Like Ms Jarvis
column5: they also underestimated the total cost of the renovations that the property would need.

column1: The couple started to post videos at the end of 2020
column2: hoping it would serve as a marketing tool for when the pandemic ended and they could open their bed and breakfast.

column1: Their YouTube channel - How To Renovate A Chateau (Without Killing Your Partner) - now has 133
column2: 000 subscribers
column3: and brings in regular advertising revenue.

column1: It never occurred to us that this could become an income stream as important as the guesthouse
column2: says Mr Mayrhofer.  ""But we get more and more advertising money
column3: and it started to become almost like a salary.""

column1: The couple also launched a Patreon account
column2: which has more than 750 subscribers paying from about £4.50-17.50 per month. Mr Mayrhofer says he and Anna are now so busy making video content it might make more financial sense to slow down the guesthouse side of their business.

column1: For now
column2: we enjoy [making videos]. It encourages us
column3: and it's fun to do

column1: Paris-based estate agent
column2: Patrice Besse
column3: specialises in selling chateaux dotted across France. He says that one in relatively good condition now costs between €800
column8: 000. Cheaper properties require more restoration work
column9: and therefore might end up costing more in the long term.

column1: He cautions that buying a French chateau should not generally be seen as a way to make money. ""Any buyer knows that owning a chateau will not make you rich.""
Instead
column2: he says that owning a chateau is a ""way of life""
column3: and that many buyers care less about the return on their investment
column4: and more about the emotional journey of restoring an old property and the dream of living in one.

column1: Yet he adds that per square metre ""chateaux are the cheapest real estate in France""
column2: especially when compared to the cost of a Parisian apartment. And demand has risen as a result of the pandemic meaning that people want to leave France's big cities.

column1: Fellow estate agent Christophe Chassin adds that the price of French chateaux has increased since the start of the pandemic
column2: due to high demand.

column1: New Economy is a new series exploring how businesses
column2: trade
column3: economies and working life are changing fast.

column1: We made a lot of sales over the past 12 months
column2: says Mr Chassin
column3: who sells mostly to overseas clients from the UK
column5: Australia and South America. ""And we are struggling to renew our portfolio of properties.""

column1: One person who bought a French chateau from Mr Chassin over the past year is American
column2: Julia Leach.

column1: The 30-year-old was inspired to purchase one after becoming an avid viewer of Ms Jarvis' The Chateau Diaries while she lived in New York.
The contrast was stark between the hustle and work culture I was immersed in
column2: and the slower pace of life of Stephanie's videos pulled at my heart
column3: says Ms Leach
column4: who shared Jarvis' videos with her family in California.

column1: So in April 2021
column2: Ms Leach
column3: her partner
column4: sister and their parents pooled their financial resources to buy the 12-bedroom
column5: 13th-Century Chateau du Puy Vidal in Charente

column1: Ms Leach
column2: who previously worked in film and television production
column3: plans to turn the castle into a studio facility for filmmakers. And she naturally has also set up a YouTube channel - Lady of the Chateau Productions - which already has 13

column1: Back at Chateau de Lalande
column2: Ms Jarvis says she can spend 40-60 hours a week filming and editing videos. ""There's nothing else I'd rather be doing
column3: she says. ""I feel more tied to the chateau
column4: but in a really positive way.""

column1: MI5 has issued a rare warning that an alleged Chinese agent has infiltrated Parliament to interfere in UK politics.
An alert from the security service said Christine Ching Kui Lee ""established links"" for the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) with current and aspiring MPs.
She then gave donations to politicians
column2: with funding coming from foreign nationals in China and Hong Kong.

column1: It comes after a ""significant
column2: long-running"" investigation by MI5
column3: Whitehall sources told the BBC.

column1: One of the MPs funded by Ms Lee was Labour's Barry Gardiner
column2: who received over £420
column3: 000 from her in five years - but he said he had always made the security services aware of the donations.

column1: Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey also received a £5
column2: 000 donation when he was energy secretary - but he said the money was accepted by his local association and it was ""the first time he has been given cause to be concerned"".

column1: Home Secretary Priti Patel said it was ""deeply concerning"" that someone ""who has knowingly engaged in political interference activities on behalf of the Chinese Communist Party has targeted parliamentarians"".
But she said the UK has measures in place ""to identify foreign interference"".
The security service said anyone contacted by Ms Lee should be ""mindful of her affiliation"" and its ""remit to advance the CCP's agenda"".
Issuing an alert about an individual is an unusual move for MI5.
It signals that their long-running investigation had led them to become sufficiently concerned that they felt they had to act now.
We have heard about concerns over Russian influence in the past but China
column2: British intelligence officials say
column3: has now become their top priority.

column1: The allegation here is interference - covertly gaining influence - and not espionage (stealing secrets).
And one concern from security officials is that there are not the laws in place to be able to tackle interference.
As a result
column2: they sometimes believe that going public - as they have done in this case - is the best way of disrupting any ongoing risk.

column1: Conservative MP and former party leader
column2: Sir Iain Duncan Smith
column3: brought up the alert in the Commons
column4: confirming it had been emailed out to MPs by the Speaker.

column1: He said it was ""a matter of grave concern""
column2: calling for Ms Lee to be deported and demanding the government make a statement to the House.

column1: Former defence minister Tobias Ellwood also called for a statement in the Commons
column2: adding: ""This is the sort grey-zone interference we now anticipate and expect from China.

column1: But the fact that it's happened to this Parliament
column2: there must be a sense of urgency from this government.""

column1: According to the alert
column2: Ms Lee claimed her involvement with Parliament had been to ""represent the UK Chinese and increase diversity"".

column1: But MI5 said that activity ""had been undertaken in covert coordination with the United Front Work Department [of the CCP]
column2: with funding provided by foreign nationals located in China and Hong Kong"".

column1: The UFWD is alleged to be seeking to ""cultivate relations"" with ""influential figures"" to ensure the UK political landscape is favourable to the CCP and to challenge those that raise concerns about the party
column2: including over human rights.

column1: The security service said Ms Lee had ""extensive engagement with individuals across the UK political spectrum""
column2: including the now disbanded All Party Parliamentary Group
column3: called Chinese in Britain.

column1: But they warned Ms Lee ""may aspire to establish APPGs [parliamentary groups] to further the CCP's agenda"".
Mr Gardiner began getting donations from Ms Lee's law firm
column2: Christine Lee & Co
column3: at the end of 2014.

column1: According to the register of MPs' interests
column2: between then and 2020
column3: he received over £420
column5: mostly covering the costs of employing parliamentary researchers.

column1: Ms Lee's son was also understood to have volunteered for the Labour MP and was later employed as his diary manager.
In a statement
column2: Mr Gardiner
column3: who was a member of the shadow cabinet when Jeremy Corbyn was Labour leader
column4: confirmed he had received the donations and that Ms Lee's son had worked for him.

column1: But he said he had been ""liaising with our security services for a number of years"" about her and they had ""always known
column2: and been made fully aware by me
column3: of her engagement with my office and the donations she made to fund researchers in my office in the past"".

column1: The Brent North MP said she had ""no role"" in who was appointed as his researchers and all donations were ""properly reported""
column2: adding: ""I have been assured by the security services that whilst they have definitively identified improper funding channelled through Christine Lee
column3: this does not relate to any funding received by my office.""

column1: He also confirmed her son resigned from his post on Thursday
column2: and that MI5 had no intelligence that showed he was aware of
column3: or complicit in

column1: Lib Dem leader Sir Ed also received £5
column2: 000 from Ms Lee when he was a minister in the coalition government.

column1: A spokesman for the party said Sir Ed was ""shocked by these revelations""
column2: adding: ""The email from the Speaker of the House of Commons today was the first time he has been given cause to be concerned about a donation to his local party association received in 2013.

column1: The government must make it a national security priority to protect the UK's democracy from threats and interference by foreign actors.
This donation was reported properly and all rules and guidance was followed - as Ed expects is the case with donations made to colleagues across the House.""

column1: Four more US diplomats working in Geneva and Paris have fallen ill with a suspected neurological illness known as ""Havana syndrome""
column2: US media report.

column1: Three diplomats became sick in the Swiss city and one in the French capital last summer
column2: with some 200 people affected over five years.

column1: Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the American government was working to get to the bottom of the mystery.
There are fears an adversary may have targeted diplomats with microwaves.
Mr Blinken said the issue had been raised with Russia but no determination had been made.
Havana syndrome first emerged in Cuba in 2016 and has affected US diplomats
column2: spies
column3: officials and family members
column4: as well as a number of Canadian diplomatic staff deployed in Cuba.

column1: Some of the people who experienced the syndrome were left with dizziness and fatigue for months.
The latest cases include one person who was evacuated from Switzerland to the US for treatment
column2: media reports say.

column1: Mr Blinken told MSNBC in an interview that he had met state department employees around the world who had described their illnesses and how their lives had been disrupted.
People
column2: he said
column3: had been ""directly and powerfully affected"".

column1: To date
column2: we don't know exactly what's happened and we don't know exactly who is responsible
column3: he told the broadcaster.

column1: We are working overtime across the entire government to get to the bottom of what happened
column2: who's responsible
column3: he said.

column1: Russia
column2: China and the US itself are all said to have researched microwaves for military purposes but  Moscow has dismissed accusations it used ""microwave weapons"" against US missions as ""fanciful hypotheses"".

column1: A more innocent
column2: but also unproven
column3: theory is that those who got sick suffered from a mass condition brought on by some stressful underlying situation.

column1: 234;Secret audio sheds light on toppled dictator’s frantic last hours;2022-01-14T00:10:44.000Z;[];['tunisia'];['toppled'

column1: The BBC has obtained extraordinary recordings which we believe to be of phone calls made by a former Middle East dictator
column2: Tunisian president Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali
column3: as he flew out of the country in 2011. These final moments show how his authority crumbled
column4: sealing the fate of his 23-year dictatorship and sparking the region's wave of pro-democracy ""Arab Spring"" uprisings.

column1: The recordings have been forensically analysed by audio experts who found no evidence of tampering or manipulation. Ben Ali died in exile in 2019
column2: but the BBC has also played these recordings to people who know the individuals concerned
column3: and they believe the voices to be genuine
column4: further supporting the authenticity of the recordings. However some of the people concerned strongly dispute their veracity.

column1: If genuine
column2: the recordings give an incredible insight into the change in Ben Ali's mood in the last 48 hours of his regime
column3: as he slowly begins to grasp the true impact of protests rocking his feared police state.

column1: The recordings - extracts of which are included below - begin on the evening of 13 January 2011. The first is a call to a close confidant
column2: believed to be Tarak Ben Ammar
column3: a successful media tycoon who is known for encouraging director George Lucas to film the first Star Wars movie in Tunisia. Earlier that day Ben Ali had made a televised speech to the nation
column4: in an attempt to quash the momentum of mass demonstrations.

column1: Widespread discontent at economic hardship and decades of autocratic rule and corruption had erupted weeks earlier after a young street vendor
column2: Mohamed Bouazizi
column3: set fire to himself when officials stopped him selling produce in the town of Sidi Bouzid. By 13 January about 100 people had died in the protests
column4: which were now overwhelming the streets of the capital.

column1: But Ben Ali sounds reassured when Ben Ammar appears to lavish him with praise.
You were wonderful
column2: this is the Ben Ali that we've been waiting for!"" says Ben Ammar in the recording.

column1: Ben Ali is self-deprecating
column2: saying his speech lacked fluency
column3: but his confidant reassures him.

column1: Not at all… It's a historic comeback. You're a man of the people. You speak their language
column2: his friend says.

column1: This video can not be played
Ben Ali laughs with what sounds like relief. But the speech made to the Tunisian public clearly isn't enough. The next day
column2: protests intensify and threaten to overrun the Ministry of Interior. Arrangements are made for Ben Ali's family to get on a flight out of the country for their own safety - headed to Saudi Arabia - and Ben Ali is then persuaded to escort them
column3: he says.

column1: The content and the timing of the next recordings place Ben Ali on this flight.
He can be heard making a series of increasingly frantic calls to three people - believed to be his defence minister
column2: the chief of the army
column3: and a close confidant - Kamel Eltaief.

column1: He begins by asking someone we understand to be Minister of Defence Ridha Grira about the situation on the ground back in Tunisia. Grira breaks it to him that an interim president is now in place. Ben Ali asks Grira to repeat this information three times
column2: before responding that he will be back in the country ""in a few hours"".

column1: He then calls a man the BBC believes to be close confidant Kamel Eltaief. Ben Ali tells Eltaief that the defence minister has reassured him events are under control.
This video can not be played
Eltaief bluntly corrects this assumption.
No
column2: no
column3: no. The situation is changing rapidly and the army isn't enough

column1: Ben Ali interrupts him to ask: ""Do you advise me to come back now or not?"" He has to repeat the question three more times before Eltaief properly responds.
Things aren't good
column2: Eltaief finally replies.

column1: Ben Ali then makes a call to who we believe to be the chief of the army
column2: General Rachid Ammar. Ammar doesn't appear to recognise the voice on the end of the line. ""I'm the president
column3: Ben Ali has to tell him.

column1: Ammar reassures him that ""everything is ok"". Again
column2: Ben Ali poses the same question he asked Eltaief - should he return to Tunisia now? Rachid tells him it would be better for him to ""wait a while"".

column1: When we see that you can come back
column2: we'll let you know
column3: Mr President

column1: He calls his defence minister once more
column2: again asking if he should return home
column3: and this time Grira is more forthright
column4: telling Ben Ali that he ""cannot guarantee his safety"" if he does so.

column1: Just after midnight
column2: President Ben Ali's plane lands in Jeddah
column3: Saudi Arabia. He orders the pilot to prepare for his return trip
column4: and he and his family are escorted to the King Faisal Palace Guest House.

column1: But the pilot disobeys the order. He abandons Ben Ali and flies back to Tunisia.
Waking in Saudi Arabia the next morning
column2: Ben Ali rings his defence minister again. Grira admits the administration is not in control of what is happening on the streets. He tells Ben Ali that there is even talk of a coup. Ben Ali dismisses this as the action of ""Islamists""
column3: before once more talking about returning home.

column1: This video can not be played
Grira now seems to attempt to level with his boss.
There's anger on the streets in a way that I cannot describe
column2: Grira says. He seems keen to be clear with the president
column3: adding: ""So that you cannot say that I misled you

column1: Ben Ali tries to defend his reputation. ""What have I done to the street? I served it.""
I'm giving you the situation
column2: not an explanation"" Grira replies.

column1: Within hours a new government is formed in Tunisia - one in which many of the same ministers
column2: including Grira
column3: maintained their positions. Ben Ali was never to return to his homeland

column1: Defence Minister Ridha Grira and Army Chief Rachid Ammar declined to comment on the recordings when contacted by the BBC. Ben Ali's confidants
column2: Kamel Eltaief and Tarak Ben Ammar
column3: denied that the calls with them had taken place
column4: with Ben Ammar adding that he had not attempted to reassure the president about his rule.

column1: The BBC has spent more than a year undertaking research into the authenticity of the recordings. They have been analysed by a number of leading audio-forensic experts in the UK and the US who looked for signs of tampering or editing
column2: or 'deep fake' processing which artificially replicates voices. No suggestion of any kind of manipulation could be found.

column1: The BBC also sought to confirm the identity of those on the calls by playing the relevant extracts to individuals who know at least one of the speakers that appear to be heard. Those consulted included three of Ben Ali's top security officials
column2: leaders of his political party
column3: and even a voice-imitator of the president.

column1: All of those approached could identify the speakers and did not raise concerns about authenticity. Other evidence also corroborates the background of these calls
column2: including previous statements by Minister of Defence Grira and Army Chief Ammar that they had spoken to the president while he was on the plane
column3: with Ammar's recollection closely matching the content of his call.

column1: The recordings suggest how an autocrat who oversaw a repressive and feared surveillance state for 23 years had been reduced to confusion and was at the mercy of his ministers' instructions in his final moments in power. In 2011
column2: during his exile in Saudi Arabia
column3: Ben Ali received a life sentence in absentia over the death of protesters during the revolution.

column1: Downing Street has apologised to Buckingham Palace for two staff parties in No 10 on the night before Prince Philip's funeral.
The gatherings
column2: first reported by The Telegraph
column3: took place on 16 April 2021 and went on until the early hours.

column1: The PM's spokesman said it was ""deeply regrettable that this took place at a time of national mourning"".
Boris Johnson was not at either party - but he faces questions over alleged Covid rule-breaking at No 10.
The latest party revelations led to a backlash from opposition parties
column2: who contrasted the behaviour of No 10 staff with pictures of the Queen sitting alone at the Duke of Edinburgh's funeral
column3: due to Covid restrictions.

column1: Labour
column2: the Liberal Democrats and the SNP are all calling for Mr Johnson to resign after he admitted attending a drinks party in the Downing Street garden during lockdown on 20 May 2020.

column1: And Andrew Bridgen has become the fifth Conservative MP to publicly declare they have written to the chairman of the 1922 Committee - which organises Tory leadership contests - to say they have no confidence in the prime minister.
Fifty-four Conservative MPs have to write a letter to trigger a vote.
Meanwhile
column2: the former head of the government's Covid taskforce has apologised for having leaving drinks in the Cabinet Office when she left the civil service on 17 December 2020.

column1: Kate Josephs
column2: who is now the chief executive of Sheffield City Council
column3: said she was ""truly sorry"" for ""the anger that people will feel"".

column1: In a statement on Friday
column2: she added that the drinks event will also now form part of the ongoing investigation into gatherings in government.

column1: Sources have confirmed that this was a separate event to a quiz held for the private office of Simon Case
column2: the UK's top civil servant
column3: on the same evening.

column1: The two staff get-togethers for Downing Street staff on 16 April last year happened at a time when Covid restrictions banned indoor socialising.
They have also been added to the list of gatherings in government buildings being investigated by senior civil servant Sue Gray.
After No 10 apologised for the events
column2: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: ""This shows just how seriously Boris Johnson has degraded the office of prime minister.

column1: The Conservatives have let Britain down. An apology isn't the only thing the prime minister should be offering the Palace today.
Boris Johnson should do the decent thing and resign.""
At this point all Downing Street can do is apologise.
The plan was to buy time waiting for Sue Gray's report but even that became untenable as Boris Johnson was forced to say sorry to the Commons and now to the Queen.
The problem for the prime minister and his team is that they are not in control of this situation
column2: they don't know what's coming next and can only react.

column1: The absurd detail about filling a suitcase with wine in the latest leak has prompted a raft of memes mocking Mr Johnson and his staff. No politician wants to be the object of ridicule.
For now it's clear they're trying to insulate the prime minister
column2: pointing out that he was away when these latest antics took place.

column1: There's no sign his cabinet is plotting against him
column2: but the danger hasn't passed.

column1: Government officials apologised to the Palace in a phone call.
Asked why No 10 had apologised rather than Boris Johnson himself
column2: his spokesman told reporters: ""Well
column3: again
column4: the prime minister said earlier misjudgements have been made and it's right people apologise
column5: as the PM did earlier this week.""

column1: The spokesman says he could not prejudge Ms Gray's inquiry
column2: but added: ""We acknowledge the significant public anger
column3: it was regrettable this took place a time of national mourning.""

column1: Liberal Democrat leader Sir Ed Davey called on Mr Johnson to apologise personally to the Queen ""for the offence he's caused her and millions around the country mourning for loved ones"".
The two parties last April involved around 30 people in total
column2: and are reported to have converged at some point in the Downing Street garden
column3: where they continued past midnight.

column1: Staff were reportedly sent to a nearby shop with a suitcase
column2: that was brought back ""filled with bottles of wine"".

column1: They were both leaving parties: one for the PM's then director of communications
column2: James Slack
column3: and the other for one of the PM's personal photographers.

column1: Mr Slack
column2: who is now deputy editor of The Sun newspaper
column3: has apologised for the ""anger and hurt"" caused by the party
column4: and acknowledged it ""should not have happened at the time that it did"".

column1: At the time
column2: England was under ""step two"" restrictions that stipulated people could not socialise indoors
column3: except with those from their household or support bubble.

column1: People could socialise outdoors in groups of up to six people or two households.

column2: 'cells'
column3: 'planets'

column1: Scientists have discovered more about why space travel makes astronauts anaemic when they return to Earth.
Canadian researchers say 50% more red blood cells are destroyed in space and this continues for however long the mission lasts.
As a result
column2: long voyages to the Moon
column3: Mars and beyond may be a challenge

column1: But their insights could benefit bedridden patients on Earth with the same condition.
Space anaemia"" is something scientists have known about since the very first missions returned to Earth - but exactly why it happens has been a mystery.
Now a small University of Ottawa study of 14 astronauts - including Britain's Tim Peake - on six-month stays at the International Space Station
column2: has found out more.

column1: Using blood and breath samples taken during their missions
column2: the researchers were able to measure red blood cell loss. These cells carry oxygen from the lungs to all parts of the body - and are the key to life.

column1: Our study shows that upon arriving in space
column2: more red blood cells are destroyed
column3: and this continues for the entire duration of the astronaut's mission

column1: While in space
column2: because of weightlessness
column3: this isn't an issue - but back on Earth it means astronauts have reduced bone mass and muscle strength

column1: Three million red blood cells are destroyed per second in space
column2: compared to two million on terra firma. Fortunately
column3: the body can compensate. If it didn't
column4: astronauts would become very ill in space.

column1: But the researchers are not sure how long the body can be in this constant state of repairing itself
column2: especially if it's in space for a lengthy mission.

column1: Even when astronauts in the study returned to living with gravity there was no quick fix
column2: and a year later they were still found to be losing red blood cells at a higher rate.

column1: Despite this
column2: they were able to function normally. Male and female astronauts were equally affected.

column1: If we can find out exactly what's causing this anaemia
column2: then there is a potential to treat it or prevent it
column3: both for astronauts and for patients here on Earth

column1: He sees the anaemia caused by space travel as being ""similar"" to that experienced by patients who've spent months inactive in intensive care with illnesses like Covid.
Anaemia also prevents them exercising and recovering
column2: and his team will research how this mechanism works in future studies.

column1: The findings of the Marrow study
column2: published in Nature Medicine
column3: may mean people who take part in space missions to far-off planets would need to adapt their diets to make more iron
column4: as well as eat more calories for energy.

column1: Screening astronauts and space tourists for blood or health conditions affected by anaemia before spaceflight might also be necessary
column2: the researchers say.

column2: Lord Sainsbury of Preston Candover

column1: During his 40-year career with the firm he covered several roles
column2: becoming a director in 1958 before being promoted to lead the business in 1969.

column1: Lord Sainsbury retired from the company in 1992
column2: becoming its life president.

column1: Sainsbury's current CEO Simon Roberts described him as ""one of the great retailers of his time"".
John Sainsbury started working in his family's business in 1950
column2: initially taking on a role in the grocery department.

column1: In 1980 he was knighted by the Queen for services to the food retailing industry and retired from his role as chief executive and chairman in 1992.
Martin Scicluna
column2: chairman of Sainsbury's
column3: said he would be ""greatly missed"" by all his friends and colleagues.

243;How a colossal block of ice became an obsession;2022-01-15T02:03:48.000Z;[];['earth science'
column2: 'antarctic'
column3: 'icebergs'

column1: Did you develop an obsession during lockdown? Did those long weeks and months take you down surprising avenues? Where did your mind wander?
The Swiss-based British artist Kevin Eason found himself thinking about Antarctica and one particularly large chunk of ice. He'd read an article
column2: by me as it happens
column3: about a 300-billion-tonne iceberg that had recently calved from the east of the continent. D28
column4: it's called; although that's not its only name as I'll explain.

column1: Kevin's interest was piqued by the satellite images that scientists began publishing of this berg
column2: along with the sometimes surprising colours they would choose to render scenes and emphasise contrast.

column1: It started out quite small. Just little studies
column2: the artist recalls.

column1: I found myself taking images that I'd see of D28
column2: dropping them into Photoshop
column3: and making colour samples. I was basically making pantones from Antarctica based on images that were being circulated around the internet.

column1: I spent weeks mixing the paint to match these colours. I guess it was a form of meditation. And then I was bound to the studio
column2: and so it just started developing into something.""

column1: That something is a series of four oil paintings depicting the life of D28. The first picture captures the definitive and distinctive outline of the berg in the days immediately after it broke from the edge of Antarctica's Amery Ice Shelf. The ones that follow are from Kevin's imagination.
The series marks the years 2019
column4: and 2025. We don't know when that final
column6: but it will happen eventually. Icebergs are born to wither and melt away.

column1: Those people who've seen the series have had various reactions
column2: but some of the themes are common. You won't be surprised to learn that when asked to describe an emotion or feeling
column3: the words that viewers used included ""transformation""

column1: And
column2: quite naturally
column3: Kevin's D28 journey has brought environmental issues - and the loss of ice - to the forefront of his mind. Being in Switzerland
column4: this is a very topical concern. Alpine glaciers are retreating rapidly in our warming climate
column5: prompting local people to blanket the ice streams in Summer to try to protect them.

column1: If I can produce a work of art that might have some sort of impact
column2: or assist in some way; that might help slow down consumption or make people consider things a little bit more by taking fewer flights
column3: or driving their cars less - that's got to be a good way to go

column1: My own interest in D28 goes back to the mid-2000s
column2: long before it calved. At that time I was reporting research on the Amery Ice Shelf that sought to predict which part of this vast
column3: floating wedge of ice might break first

column1: Attention had focused on an area that became nicknamed ""Loose Tooth"" because it looked in satellite images like a child's wobbly front tooth.
The team studying the cracks developing in the ice shelf thought a calving might be imminent. It wasn't. Loose Tooth is still there
column2: still wobbling
column3: still hanging on to the Amery. It was the adjacent
column5: 636-sq-km section that came away - the big berg now formally designated D28 (the largest Antarctic bergs are given an official listing by the US National Ice Center).

column1: I joked with the Amery research team
column2: led by Prof Helen Fricker from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography
column3: that perhaps another dental analogy was needed. ""It is the molar compared to a baby tooth
column4: Helen laughed. And the nickname stuck.

column1: People regularly now post satellite pictures of ""Molar Berg""
column2: aka D28
column3: as it bumps and grinds its way around the Antarctic coast. Even astronauts on the space station can see it

column1: A keen observer is Dr Catherine Walker from the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. As a graduate student in the 2000s
column2: she was tasked with studying those cracks in the Amery Ice Shelf.

column1: It was actually sort of sad to see it go
column2: because it was something that I'd had all this time
column3: and then it was gone

column1: I really appreciate Kevin's paintings. I feel like that's my entire career right there.""
There's a growing appreciation of these city-sized bergs (Molar Berg was bigger than Greater London when it broke away).
They dump huge quantities of fresh water into the wider ocean
column2: along with iron and other minerals scraped off the Antarctic landmass. This influences the behaviour of local currents and food webs.

column1: D28/Molar Berg's travels have taken it a full quarter turn around the White Continent. It's now entered the Weddell Sea which is directly south of the Atlantic Ocean.
And it just so happens that it's moving in the direction of what is currently the world's biggest iceberg - a near-4
column2: 000-sq-km monster known as A23
column3: which has been pinned fast to the Weddell seafloor for three decades.

column1: Yep
column2: that's one of mine
column3: too
column4: says Catherine. ""I always watch A23 because we're the same age. It calved in 1986 and it's started to wiggle recently.

column1: What's the fascination with these giant icebergs? I guess it has something to do with their size; they're so much bigger than you can imagine - like Everest or K2. You look at them and wonder: how do they hold themselves together.""
I think that's right. Their great scale is truly awesome. But for me it's also the way such imposing objects
column2: built from snows that originally fell on Antarctica thousands of years ago
column3: and which seem as though they ought to be so permanent
column4: can suddenly disintegrate and fade away in a very short time.

column1: You can follow Jonathan on Twitter: @BBCAmos

column1: Tsunami warnings have been issued in several countries including Tonga
column2: Fiji
column3: and New Zealand
column4: after a giant underwater volcano eruption.

column1: Social media footage from Tonga showed waves washing through a church and several homes. Witnesses said ash is falling over the capital
column2: Nuku'alofa.

column1: Residents there have been urged to move to higher ground.
It is the latest in a series of eruptions of the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Haʻapai volcano.
The eight-minute eruption was so violent it could be heard as ""loud thunder sounds"" in Fiji
column2: more than 800km (500 miles) away
column3: officials in the capital Suva said.

column1: The plumes of gas
column2: smoke and ash pouring from the volcano reached 20km (12 miles) into the sky
column3: said Tonga Geological Services.

column1: Tonga's capital lies just 65km north of Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai. A 1.2m tsunami wave was observed there
column2: according to Australia's Bureau of Meteorology.

column1: In New Zealand
column2: which is more than 2
column3: 300km away
column4: officials have warned of storm surges from the eruption.

column1: The National Emergency Management Agency said parts of the country could see ""strong and unusual currents and unpredictable surges at the shore"".
Local forecaster Weather Watch tweeted: ""The energy release is simply astonishing""
column2: adding: ""Reports of people hearing the sonic booms across New Zealand.""

245;Endemic Covid: Is the pandemic entering its endgame?;2022-01-15T01:47:56.000Z;[];['medical research'
column2: 'coronavirus lockdown measures'
column3: 'vaccination'

column1: Who hasn't let out an exasperated ""Is the pandemic finished yet?"" or a ""When can I just get on with my life?"" over the past two years? I know I have.
The answer to those questions could be... very soon.
There is growing confidence that Omicron could be hurtling the UK into the pandemic endgame.
But what comes next? There will be no snap of the fingers to make the virus disappear. Instead
column2: the new buzzword we'll have to get used to is ""endemic"" - which means that Covid is
column3: without doubt

column1: So
column2: is a new Covid-era truly imminent and what will that actually mean for our lives?

column1: We're almost there
column2: it is now the beginning of the end
column3: at least in the UK
column5: chairman in infection and global health at the University of Liverpool
column6: tells me. ""I think life in 2022 will be almost back to before the pandemic.""

column1: What's changing is our immunity. The new coronavirus first emerged two years ago in Wuhan
column2: China
column3: and we were vulnerable. It was a completely new virus that our immune systems had not experienced before and we had no drugs or vaccines to help.

column1: The result was like taking a flamethrower into a fireworks factory. Covid spread explosively around the world - but that fire cannot burn at such high intensity forever.
There were two options - either we would extinguish Covid
column2: as we did with Ebola in West Africa
column3: or it would die down but be with us for the long term. It would join the swarm of endemic diseases - such as common colds
column6: malaria and tuberculosis - that are always there.

column1: For many
column2: this was the inevitable fate of a virus that spreads through the air before you even know you're sick. ""Endemicity was written into this virus
column3: says Dr Elisabetta Groppelli

column1: I am very optimistic
column2: she says. ""We'll soon be in a situation where the virus is circulating
column3: we will take care of people at risk
column4: but for anybody else we accept they will catch it - and your average person will be fine.""

column1: Epidemiologists
column2: who study the spread of diseases
column3: would consider a disease endemic when levels are consistent and predictable - unlike the ""boom and bust"" waves so far in the pandemic.

column1: But Prof Azra Ghani
column2: an epidemiologist at Imperial College London
column3: says other people are using it to mean Covid is still around
column4: but that we no longer need to restrict our lives.

column1: She thinks we'll get there ""rapidly""
column2: adding: ""It seems like it's taken a long time
column3: but only a year ago we started vaccinating and we're already an awful lot freer because of that.""

column1: The only major curve ball would be a new variant that can outcompete Omicron and cause significantly more severe disease.
It is important to remember that endemic does not automatically mean mild. ""We have some huge killer diseases that we consider endemic
column2: says Prof Ghani. Smallpox was endemic for thousands of years and killed a third of people who were infected. Malaria is endemic and causes around 600
column3: 000 deaths a year.

column1: But we are already seeing the signs that Covid is becoming less deadly as our bodies become more familiar with fighting it.
In the UK there has been a vaccination campaign
column2: a booster campaign and waves of Covid involving four different variants of the virus.

column1: When Omicron has finished and moved through
column2: immunity in the UK will be high
column3: at least for a while
column5: an immunologist at the University of Edinburgh.

column1: The high level of infections has come at a price
column2: with more than 150
column3: 000 deaths in the UK. But it has left a protective legacy in our immune systems. That immunity will wane so we should expect to catch Covid in the future
column4: but it should still reduce the chances of becoming seriously ill.

column1: Prof Hiscox - who sits on the government's New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group - says that means most people won't be badly affected.
Should a new variant or old variant come along
column2: for most of us
column3: like any other common cold coronavirus
column4: we'll get the sniffles and a bit of a headache and then we're OK.""

column1: There will be people - mostly the old and vulnerable - who will die from endemic Covid. So there is still a decision to be made about how we live alongside it.
If you're willing to tolerate zero deaths from Covid
column2: then we're facing a whole raft of restrictions and it's not game over
column3: Prof Hiscox explains.

column1: But
column2: he says
column3: ""In a bad flu season
column4: 200-300 die a day over winter and nobody wears a mask or socially distances
column5: that's perhaps a right line to draw in the sand.""

column1: Lockdowns and restrictions on mass gatherings will not come back and mass testing for Covid will end this year
column2: he expects.

column1: The near certainty is there will be booster vaccines for the vulnerable come the autumn in order to top up their protection through winter.
We need to accept the fact that our flu season is also going to be a coronavirus season
column2: and that is going to be a challenge for us
column3: says Dr Groppelli.

column1: However
column2: it is still uncertain how bad winters will be as the people who die from flu and Covid tend to be the same. As one scientist put it
column3: ""You can't die twice.""

column1: Prof Riley thinks we won't be compelled to wear face masks after Omicron
column2: but they will become ""a much more common sight"" as they are in parts of Asia as people choose to wear them in crowded places.

column1: She adds: ""The likely scenario is life won't look much different to the autumn of 2019
column2: when we all turned up for our flu vaccines.""

column1: While the UK is ahead of most of the world due to a combination of vaccines and a large number of infections
column2: the planet is not remotely close to seeing the end of the pandemic.

column1: Nino Cerruti - one of the great Italian designers and fashion entrepreneurs - has died aged 91.
Reports say he passed away in hospital in Piedmont where he had checked in for a hip operation.
He always insisted on trying on his own creations first. Many of them were kept at the textile factory his grandfather founded in the town of Biella in 1881.
I have always dressed the same person

column1: With his experience in producing excellent fabrics at his family's textile mill

column1: The service was being streamed online when the incident began. One of the hostages was released unharmed six hours later

column1: President Joe Biden was briefed about the developing situation.
The incident began at around 11:00 local time (16:00 GMT) when police were called to the Congregation Beth Israel synagogue. People were evacuated from the area shortly after.

column1: GlaxoSmithKline has rejected three Unilever offers to buy its consumer goods division
column2: including one worth £50bn.

column1: GSK said the proposals ""fundamentally failed"" to reflect the value of the division.
With a successful bid
column2: Unilever - which owns Marmite
column3: Dove and PG Tips - would add Sensodyne toothpaste and Panadol to its list of household brands.

column1: Such a deal would be one of the biggest ever involving London-listed firms.
GSK said in a statement the most recent proposal from Unilever on 20 December contained an offer for £41.7bn in cash and £8.3bn in Unilever shares.
The global healthcare company
column2: which has its headquarters in London
column3: has already been preparing to separate its consumer goods division from its pharmaceutical business in the middle of this year.

column1: The firm has come under pressure from investors for failing to develop a Covid vaccine.
Unilever said in a statement the GSK consumer arm ""would be a strong strategic fit as Unilever continues to reshape its portfolio"".
The consumer goods giant
column2: which became a fully British company in 2020 after previously being separated between the UK and the Netherlands
column3: also approached Pfizer about the potential deal
column4: since the American pharmaceutical giant owns a 34% stake in GSK's consumer goods business.

column1: Neither GSK nor Pfizer has any ideological objection to selling to Unilever. GSK had planned to spin off its consumer business later this year anyway through a demerger creating a separate publicly listed company but always said it would have an open mind to a trade sale to another party if the price was right.
GSK's problem with the Unilever bid is that the price isn't right.
Both Barclays and Goldman Sachs analysts have valued the business at around £50bn. However
column2: that does not include a few important things.

column1: First
column2: the premium you would normally expect to pay for taking control of a business - somewhere in the range of 30% - although that might be reduced by the debt of about £10bn GSK was expected to leave on the books of the consumer business.

column1: Second
column2: the value of the cost savings GSK admits could be made to make the business more profitable.

column1: Third
column2: it may not reflect the higher sales growth targets GSK boss Emma Walmsley has said are possible for the business.

column1: She has also said the benefit of a demerger is current GSK shareholders would get shares in the demerged business so retain their participation in any future growth in the consumer business.
Some will say if higher growth and greater cost reductions are possible
column2: why haven't they happened already? Emma Walmsley has been in charge for more than four years. That's one of the questions activist shareholder Elliot Management has implicitly asked by encouraging other shareholders to agitate for a more radical greater break up of one of the UK's most valuable companies.

column1: The BBC understands the very different ideas on what this business is worth means there are no active and ongoing discussions between GSK and Unilever.
But Unilever's intentions are very clear.
The ""for sale"" sign is now very visible and the elbows will get sharper as this basket of household consumer goods gets closer to the checkout.
Russ Mould
column2: investment director at AJ Bell
column3: said Unilever's chief executive Alan Jope was under pressure because the business had recently missed targets for sales and profit margins.

column1: Unilever has strong cashflow
column2: but the heat is on Mr Jope. He wants to be seen to do something
column3: Mr Mould said.

column1: But this is a high risk deal. Many investors see GSK as underperforming. But at a time when inflation is rising
column2: consumer goods with loyal customers represent a good way for firms to try to manage profits.""

column1: The move was first reported in the Sunday Times.
GSK said its consumer goods division had the potential to increase sales by up to 6% a year in the medium term
column2: and Unilever's offers did not take that into account. It said the proposals were not in the best interests of GSK shareholders.

column1: Preliminary figures show sales for GSK's consumer division reached £9.6bn in 2021.
Other brands in the division include Centrum vitamins
column2: Aquafresh toothpaste and Nicorette gum.

column1: The company has said it is in late stage trails of a Covid vaccine it was developing with the French pharmaceutical firm
column2: Sanofi.

column1: Husband and wife

column1: Homesick

column3: to help them cope with the stresses of lockdown. ""Which was a mental necessity during the pandemic

column2: and Ms Cubuk says the feedback was incredibly positive.

column1: While the huge market-leading delivery apps
column2: such as Just Eat

column1: It was launched at the start of 2020 to link home cooks - people literally cooking from the kitchen in their house or apartment - to customers who want a fresh
column2: homemade takeaway
column3: rather than something from a chain restaurant.

column1: You order via the Woodspoon app
column2: which sends the details to the relevant home chef. Then
column3: when the food has been cooked
column4: it is picked up and delivered by a Woodspoon driver.

column1: Although still only available in the Brooklyn borough of New York
column2: with more than 120 cooks currently on its books
column3: the plan is to expand.

column2: while on the other three days they work on new recipes. Ms Cubik says that they are so busy that they recently had to work on their fourth wedding anniversary.

column1: Yet

column3: both are vegetarian

column1: Before home chefs are accepted by Woodspoon they have to show proof of food safety training
column2: and the company sends someone out to carry out an inspection of their kitchen.

column2: and be subjected to official food hygiene tests.

column1: While Woodspoon is currently focused on US expansion the concept could also work in the UK

column1: With the pandemic closing restaurants for long periods of time
column2: the past two years has been boom time for takeaway delivery apps. The UK's largest
column3: Just Eat
column6: while those at DoorDash jumped more than threefold to $2.9bn (£2.1bn).

column1: Yet

column4: and get all the different dishes delivered together.

column1: That is

column1: One of those at the forefront is US app

column1: To ensure that the food is all cooked and ready for delivery at the same time

column3: all making delivery-only meals.

column1: Our app allows consumers to pick
column2: choose and group their favourite menu items [together] from an array of C3 brands in a single order
column3: says C3 chief executive Sam Nazarian. He describes it as ""the Netflix of food ordering"".

column7: if someone in the household wants sushi

column1: A massive volcanic eruption in Tonga
column2: on Saturday
column3: triggered a tsunami that spread across the Pacific in a matter of hours.

column1: Waves hit Australia
column2: New Zealand and Japan as well as the west coasts of North and South America.

column1: An atmospheric shockwave was detected around the world and a huge ash cloud has covered Pacific islands for hundreds of miles.
Here's what we know about how and why it spread so widely and violently.
Tonga is made up of about 170 islands
column2: many uninhabited
column3: about 2

column1: The volcano
column2: Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Ha'apai
column3: sits 40 miles north of the capital.

column1: On Saturday
column2: the centre of the volcano sank
column3: disappearing under the sea.

column1: About two hours later
column2: it erupted
column3: with devastating force.

column1: When the eruption had ended
column2: almost all of the volcano and the land around it had disappeared.

column1: The eruption set off a massive atmospheric shockwave travelling at about 300m (1
column2: 000ft) per second.

column1: Pressure changes were detected on the other side of the world
column2: in Europe
column3: 15 hours later.

column1: The explosion was heard across the Pacific
column2: from Fiji to Alaska.

column1: Waves from the tsunami spread rapidly across the Pacific.
They took less than five hours to reach New Zealand
column2: about 10 to reach Alaska.

column1: Experts say the tsunami may have been caused by the collapse of debris on the ocean floor and boosted by the pressure wave pushing down on the surface of the water.
The waves continued through Sunday and were still being recorded in Australia on Monday.
Tsunami waves can be much more destructive than normal waves
column2: even when they are not particularly high.

column1: A normal wave might take 15 seconds to wash up the shore and flow back out.
Some of the tsunami waves in Australia were under 1m but lasted almost 30 minutes.
They kept moving onshore for 15 minutes and took about 15 minutes to move back out.
The exact reasons why this eruption was so violent are still being assessed by experts.
Some believe the speed with which the molten magma was blasted out of the volcano may have  played a big part.
When magma filled with volcanic gas is forced through sea water at high speed
column2: there is no time for a layer of steam to cool it.

column1: And this ""fuel-coolant interaction"" causes a massive chemical explosion
column2: researchers say.

column1: Deeper water could have suppressed this - but the volcano's surface was just 150-200m under the sea.
Communications with Tonga have been largely destroyed
column2: making it difficult to assess the scale of the destruction.

column1: Internet and telephone communications are extremely limited and outlying coastal areas remain cut off.
The Red Cross said even satellite phones
column2: used by many aid agencies
column3: had poor service because of the ash cloud.

column1: The organisation estimates up to 80
column2: 000 people may have been affected by the tsunami.

column1: The dust from the volcano could contaminate water supplies
column2: with locals advised to drink bottled water and wear masks.
