column2: Mr Cummings
column3: who was still working in Downing Street at the time of the drinks party on 20 May 2020
column4: said he would swear on oath that he warned the prime minister it would be a rule-breaking event.

column1: He claimed the PM had waved aside his warnings at the time.
Two other former Downing Street officials told the BBC they remembered Mr Cummings telling them on that day he had advised the prime minister not to allow the drinks to go ahead.
Asked about Mr Cummings' claims on a visit to a North London hospital
column2: Mr Johnson said: ""I can tell you categorically that nobody said that this was something that was against the rules
column3: that was in breach of the Covid rules.""

column1: Responding to his latest statement
column2: Labour's deputy leader Angela Rayner said: ""Boris Johnson clearly knows it's the end of the road.

column1: He's the prime minister
column2: he set the rules
column3: he didn't need anyone to tell him that the party he attended broke them.

column1: If he had any respect for the British public
column2: he would do the decent thing and resign.""

column1: In his interview
column2: Mr Johnson repeated the apology he made to MPs last week for ""mistakes"" made over the May 2020 get-together.

column1: As I said in the House of Commons
column2: when I went out into that garden I thought that I was attending a work event.""

column1: He said he had not seen the email sent by a senior aide - his Principal Private Secretary Martin Reynolds - inviting staff to ""socially distanced drinks in the No 10 garden"".
I only saw it the other day. I only saw it when it emerged
column2: said the PM.

column1: What I remember is going out into that garden for a short time and for 25 minutes thanking staff who'd worked on Covid
column2: who were continuing to work on Covid
column3: and then going back to office.

column1: If I had my time again
column2: I would not have allowed things to develop in that way.""

column1: Asked if he had lied to Parliament over the parties
column2: he said: ""No. I want to begin by repeating my apologies to everybody for the misjudgments that I've made
column3: that we may have made in No 10 and beyond
column4: whether in Downing Street or throughout the pandemic.""

column1: He said he would make a further statement on alleged rule-breaking in Downing Street when Sue Gray publishes her report
column2: which is expected shortly.

column1: The massive volcanic eruption and tsunami in Tonga has caused catastrophic damage
column2: with homes destroyed and many communities covered in a thick layer of ash.

column1: The Tongan government says the country has been hit by an ""unprecedented disaster"".
Communications with Tonga have been severely disrupted.
Satellite images and aerial photographs show the scale of the destruction.
The single undersea cable connecting Tonga to the outside world was severed in the eruption.
The port in the capital
column2: Nuku'alofa on the main island of Tongatapu
column3: has been severely damaged
column4: with many buildings near the waterfront completely flattened.

column1: It is thought they were destroyed by the tsunami wave when it hit the island
column2: shortly after the eruption on nearby Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Ha'apai.

column1: Despite the damage on the waterfront at Nukuʻalofa
column2: inland areas are reported to be largely undamaged.

column1: The UN reported extensive damage to property on the western beaches of Tongatapu.
Waves of up to 15 metres hit the area on Saturday.
Reports from the area say 56 houses were completely or seriously damaged
column2: and that the residents have been moved to evacuation centres.

column1: There is also growing concern for residents of smaller
column2: low-lying islands to the north of Tongatapu.

column1: The authorities in Tonga say all the homes on one island
column2: where around 50 people live
column3: have been destroyed
column4: while on another only two houses remain. Other islands

column1: The main airport for the islands
column2: Fua'amotu International Airport
column3: was not damaged
column4: but piles of ash are hindering operations and international aid efforts. Volunteers have been sweeping the runway of the main airport to allow planes to land.

column1: Australia has said the ash must be cleared before it can land a C-130 military plane carrying supplies.
New Zealand is sending two ships
column2: HMNZS Wellington and HMNZS Aotearoa
column3: to the area with water supplies

265;5G phones: How serious is the threat to US flights?;2022-01-18T14:27:50.000Z;[];['mobile phones'
column3: 'air travel'];['phones'

column1: Ten leading US airlines are warning that the imminent rollout of 5G services could be disastrous.
They say the new technology could cause thousands of flights to be delayed
column2: and risks leaving large parts of the US aircraft fleet grounded indefinitely.

column1: 5G relies on radio signals. In the US
column2: the radio frequencies being used for 5G are in part of the spectrum known as C-Band.

column1: These frequencies are close to the ones used by radio altimeters on aeroplanes
column2: which measure the height of the aircraft above the ground
column3: but also provide data for safety and navigation systems.

column1: The concern is that interference from 5G transmissions could stop these instruments from working properly
column2: and cause safety problems
column3: particularly when aircraft are coming in to land.

column1: It is potentially very serious.
In late 2020
column2: the RTCA - a US organisation which produces technical guidance on aviation issues - published a report on the subject.

column1: It said there was ""potential for broad impacts to aviation operations in the United States
column2: including the possibility of catastrophic failures leading to multiple fatalities
column3: in the absence of appropriate mitigations"".

column1: More recently
column2: the US aviation regulator
column3: the FAA
column4: warned that 5G interference could lead to problems with a number of different systems aboard Boeing's 787 Dreamliner.

column1: These could make it difficult to slow the plane down on landing
column2: causing it to veer off the runway.

column1: Planes won't be allowed to use radio altimeters in circumstances where there could be a risk of serious interference.
But that will restrict the ability of some aircraft to land
column2: for example
column3: in poor visibility.

column1: Airlines for America
column2: which represents 10 major carriers
column3: has warned that this could lead to more than 1
column4: 000 flights being delayed or cancelled in bad weather and mean at times ""the vast majority of the travelling and shipping public will essentially be grounded"".

column1: It has also suggested a large part of the US aircraft fleet will be ""deemed unusable"" because of restrictions on their operation.
Not to the same degree. That's because the way in which 5G is being rolled out varies from country to country.
In the EU
column2: for example
column3: networks operate at lower frequencies than those which US providers are planning to use - reducing the risk of interference. 5G masts can also operate at lower power.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: some countries have taken further steps to reduce possible risks.

column1: In France
column2: there are so-called ""buffer zones"" around airports where 5G signals are restricted
column3: while antennas have to be tilted downwards to prevent potential interference.

column1: Regulators in the US have already taken a number of steps.
The FAA has established temporary buffer zones around 50 airports
column2: where 5G providers will limit their activities. But these are much smaller than the zones already being used in France
column3: and US transmitters will operate at significantly higher power levels.

column1: It has also begun identifying which altimeters can be used safely in areas where 5G has been deployed - and those which are not reliable enough and will need to be replaced.
It has also identified airports where GPS systems can be used to guide approaching aircraft rather than radio altimeters.
But the airlines insist this isn't enough: they claim the 5G network should not be activated at all within two miles of affected airports.
Verizon and AT&T have already delayed the 5G rollout twice
column2: and have agreed to the temporary buffer zones mentioned above.

column1: They also pointed out that 5G has already been implemented in some 40 countries.
Last month the US wireless industry body CTIA accused the aviation industry of ""scaremongering""
column2: and warned that delaying the introduction of 5G would cause real economic harm.

column1: UK regulators and airlines do not seem unduly worried.
In a safety notice published in December
column2: the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) said that ""there have been no confirmed instances where 5G interference has resulted in aircraft system malfunction or unexpected behaviour"".

column1: It also stressed that ""different national mobile telecommunication strategies may mean that some [countries] have a higher threat exposure than others"".
The UK regulator says it plans to work internationally to gather further data on the issue.

column1: The Beijing Winter Olympics app that all Games attendees must use contains security weaknesses that leave users exposed to data breaches
column2: analysts say.

column1: The My2022 app will be used by athletes
column2: audience members and media for daily Covid monitoring.

column1: The app will also offer voice chats
column2: file transfers and Olympic news.

column1: But cybersecurity group Citizen Lab says the app fails to provide encryption on many of its files. China has dismissed the concerns.
Questions about the app come amid a rise in warnings about visitors' tech security ahead of the Games
column2: which begin on 4 February.

column1: People attending the Beijing Olympics should bring burner phones and create email accounts for their time in China
column2: cyber security firm Internet 2.0 said on Tuesday.

column1: Several countries have also reportedly told athletes to leave their main devices at home.
The Citizen Lab report said it had found a ""censorship keywords"" list built into the app
column2: and a feature that allows people to flag other ""politically sensitive"" expressions.

column1: The list of words included the names of Chinese leaders and government agencies
column2: as well as references to the 1989 killing of pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square
column3: and the religious group Falun Gong

column1: The analysts noted that these features and security flaws are not uncommon for apps in China but posed a risk to users nonetheless.
Analysts said the ""illegal words"" file appeared currently to be inactive
column2: but it was unclear.

column1: All visitors to the Games are required to download the app 14 days prior to their departure for China
column2: and use it to record daily their Covid status.

column1: For foreign visitors they also need to upload sensitive information already submitted to the Chinese government - like passport details and travel and medical histories.
Citizen Lab said transmission weaknesses in the app's software could lead to easy exploitation of data by a hacker
column2: if targeted.

column1: In a report on Tuesday
column2: Chinese state media outlet Global Times dismissed concerns about the app
column3: saying ""all personal information will be encrypted to ensure privacy"".

column1: It compared the app to one that had been used at the Tokyo Games.
Cyber security firm Internet 2.0 has also warned of potential security risks during the Olympics.
In a report seen by the BBC
column2: it stressed the need for burner phones and reminded people not to use these devices after leaving China

column1: The report looked at some of the technology sponsors of the Games and their products in order to show ""the sophisticated and broad surveillance culture that exists in China"".
One product
column2: a VPN by Qi-Anxin
column3: was able to capture a significant amount of user data
column4: the report said. Under China's national security laws
column5: authorities can request to access this data.

column1: China's national data security laws are not designed with the Western values of privacy and liberty and do not offer the same level of protection
column2: the report said.

column1: Team USA has encouraged its athletes to use a new device
column2: according to USA Today.

column1: A bulletin seen by the US outlet allegedly ""encouraged"" burner phones and rental or disposable computers for members of its team.
Like computers
column2: the data and applications on cell phones are subject to malicious intrusion
column3: infection and data compromise

column1: A violin-maker has used components including steamed pear
column2: berries and spring water to create a vegan violin.

column1: Padraig O'Dubhlaoidh made the instrument
column2: entirely free of animal products
column3: in his Malvern Hills workshop during the coronavirus lockdown.

column1: The body of the bespoke instrument is the first in the world to be registered with The Vegan Society's trademark
column2: said the organisation.

column1: Natural replacements for animal-based glues were used on the £8
column2: 000 violin.

column1: Historically horsehair
column2: hooves
column3: horns and bones have all been used to create instruments
column4: said the Vegan Society which added it was ""incredibly exciting"" to register the violin.

column1: This will be music to the ears of so many violinists who have longed for a high-quality instrument that is free from animal products
column2: said the charity's Ericka Durgahee.

column1: Inlay around the edge of the instrument had been made from ""steamed pear which is dyed black
column2: said Mr Dubhlaoidh.

column1: Wild berries are used to dye the wood inlays and local spring water is gathered to be used in his adhesive.
The craftsman
column2: who has been making violins for 40 years
column3: said a customer had asked him to make a vegan instrument ""some years ago.""

column1: It was an intriguing question
column2: he added. ""I thought how many vegans are there
column3: potential musicians whose ethics won't allow them to play the violin - it must be awful.

column1: The world is changing a lot at the moment... particularly the young generation.. they're making big changes in the world and I'm very proud of it.""
While vegan violin strings and bows are available
column2: it is only the body of the violin that has been registered with the trademark
column3: explained the Vegan Society.

column1: 270;Pacific volcano: Science will explain event's ferocity;2022-01-17T16:08:21.000Z;[];['earth science'
column2: 'volcanoes'
column3: 'tsunamis'

column1: The explosive eruption of Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Ha'apai sent a shockwave around the world.
The event literally touched every corner of the globe as a pressure wave spread out in all directions to complete a full circumnavigation.
Scientists
column2: of course
column3: are now asking themselves why the eruption was so powerful. They also want to understand how the tsunami was created.

column1: The answers to both these questions feed into future hazard preparedness
column2: although to be honest
column3: right now
column4: these finer details are much less important than the immediate needs of nearby islanders.

column1: Their lives have been up-ended by catastrophic flooding and ash fall-out.
Nonetheless
column2: scientific insights will emerge; they're already being assembled.

column1: The name Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Ha'apai (HT-HH) refers to the two island structures that stood about 100m above the Pacific Ocean surface
column2: roughly 65km north of Tonga's capital
column3: Nuku'alofa.

column1: What wasn't apparent to the casual observer was the hidden edifice below-water - a volcanic mountain rising some 1
column2: 800m above the seafloor.

column1: The HT-HH islands represented just the upper-most part of the rim of a caldera - the opening to the volcano - that was 6km across. It was in this submerged caldera that gas-rich magma came into contact with cold seawater to devastating effect.
For Prof Shane Cronin
column2: from the University of Auckland
column3: who's made a detailed study of this volcano

column1: The caldera summit is about 150-200m below sea-level. That's just about the right depth for there to be quite strong
column2: explosive interactions between the magma and the seawater
column3: he told BBC News.

column1: Once you get much
column2: much deeper
column3: then what tends to happen is there's too much seawater
column4: and it suppresses that explosive activity.""

column1: Prof Cronin said a big event had been due. The last major eruption was in the year AD 1100
column2: and prior to that there was a major episode 1
column3: 800 years ago. On that basis the repeat cycle was roughly 900 years. That's now.

column1: The tsunami that followed could have been created in several ways. In the near-field
column2: where waves over one metre high were recorded at the Nuku'alofa tide gauge
column3: some component would have resulted from rock and ash initially thrown high into the sky then descending back down into the ocean to displace its waters.

column1: What scientists can't rule out at this stage is whether the extreme energy in the event didn't also cause some kind of submarine flank failure on the volcano. Something similar occurred at Anak Krakatau in Indonesia in 2018
column2: although that involved a large amount of material above water then becoming submerged.

column1: This is a possibility
column2: for sure
column3: commented Dr Vicki Ferrini from Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory.

column1: In data we collected in 2016
column2: you could see a lot of big solidified chunks that looked like they had slid down the side of the volcano in the past. So
column3: with an explosion of this size
column4: you certainly wouldn't be surprised if further large sections of consolidated material had moved.

column1: The good thing is we have the baseline data to make a comparison when we go back in
column2: but only when it's safe.""

column1: For far-field effects
column2: there is a lot of discussion around whether that shockwave could have contributed to the run-ups recorded in New Zealand
column3: Australia
column4: and at beaches and inlets along both North and South America and in Japan.

column1: The idea is that the sudden change in air pressure punches down on the surface of the ocean.
This can change the elevation in the ocean by millimetres to centimetres
column2: and when this gets closer to land
column3: if the conditions are right
column4: it can generate tsunami. We know this happened for example in the great eruption of Krakatau in 1883
column5: said Prof Dave Tappin from the British Geological Survey.

column1: We're working on it right now. Fortunately
column2: over the past 20 years
column3: we've developed the mathematics to numerically model these events to better understand them.""

column1: What was so remarkable about that pressure wave is just how far it travelled.
The impact on the atmosphere from the explosive eruption was obvious in the earliest satellite imagery as an expanding ring of disturbance moving out in all directions.
Meteorologists
column2: both professional and amateur
column3: immediately recognised that they might be able to detect the signal even on the other side of the world.

column1: In the UK - which is about as far away as you can get from Tonga - the barometers wiggled at the expected moment.
These things travel at the speed of sound
column2: so on Saturday night quite a lot of people lined up expecting something. And that's what happened - a slight increase in pressure (about 1.5 millibars) followed by a decrease lasting about half an hour
column3: explained Prof Giles Harrison from the University of Reading.

column1: The distance from Tonga to the UK is about 16
column2: 500km
column3: and with an interval of about 14 hours - that gives you the sort of speed you would expect

column1: The Reading barometer had recorded a total three pulses by 7am UK time on Monday.
Again
column2: Prof Harrison said there were parallels with the 1883 Krakatoa event. Victorian meteorologists reported similar signals.

column1: In the coming weeks and months
column2: as activity subsides at Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Ha'apai
column3: researchers will be able to get in close to examine the remnants of the two islands. Most of their above-water bulk has gone
column4: not unsurprisingly given the ferocity of the blast.

column1: But the bigger concern is getting assistance to the affected islands in the Tongan archipelago. Satellite imagery returned in just the past day reveals considerable damage.
And there are longer-term problems that come from all that ash. It's going to impact on agriculture and water quality
column2: said Prof Tappin.

column1: The government has admitted that its efforts to insulate the UK from climate change impacts have been inadequate.
The costs of climate change to Britain are ""high and increasing""
column2: it says
column3: and could reach many billions of pounds a year.

column1: Ministers say they'll have to go much further and faster to curb the worst impacts.
It means climate change must be built into all long-term decisions
column2: such as new housing or infrastructure.

column1: The aim should be to avoid costly remedial actions in the future.
The government has also accepted that it must consider low-probability but high-impact events arising from a heating climate.
The report is a response to an analysis of the UK’s vulnerability to climate change by the official advisers
column2: the Climate Change Committee.

column1: Climate change is happening now. It is one of the biggest challenges of our generation and has already begun to cause irreversible damage to our planet and way of life
column2: the report begins.

column1: It earmarks 61 climate risks cutting across multiple sectors of society.
Health and productivity could be affected
column2: it says
column3: with impacts on many households

column1: The report warns of worsening soil health and farm productivity
column2: reduced water availability
column3: and impacts on alternative energy supply.

column1: For example
column2: it notes
column3: unless the UK takes further action
column4: the cost of flood-related damages for non-residential properties is expected to increase by 27% by 2050 and 40% by 2080.

column1: That's with a temperature rise of just 2C - and even that relatively low figure is looking very hard to achieve.
If temperature rises to 4C – which the government’s science advisers say is possible - this increases to 44% and 75% respectively.
The government says it’s already investing to adapt to climate change.
It mentions:
But critics say efforts so far have been diluted by inadequate finance from the Treasury for long-term schemes. Indeed the chancellor didn’t mention climate change once in his Budget.
Green MP Caroline Lucas MP said: ""It's crystal clear that we are moving nothing like fast enough to net zero emissions and the longer we delay
column2: the more it will cost. The government acknowledges the risks. We have yet to see the action plan that will deal with them.""

column1: Ministers admit they must do much more.
Climate Adaptation Minister Jo Churchill said: “The scale and severity of the challenge posed by climate change means we can’t tackle it overnight
column2: and although we’ve made good progress in recent year
column3: there is clearly much more that we need to do.""

column1: Labour's shadow environment secretary Jim McMahon said: ""After more than a decade in power
column2: the Conservatives have failed to build the efficient homes
column3: strengthened flood defences
column4: and resilient natural habitats necessary to tackle the climate crisis.

column1: Their lack of action and empty promises are putting people
column2: nature
column3: and our economy at risk.""

column1: 283;Should social media sites censor misinformation?;2022-01-19T00:08:42.000Z;[];['freedom of expression'
column2: 'coronavirus vaccines'
column3: 'fake news'

column1: How do you solve a problem like bad information?
When it comes to understanding science and making health decisions
column2: it can have life-or-death consequences.

column1: People dissuaded from taking vaccines as a result of reading misleading information online have ended up in hospital or even died.
And inaccurate or completely made-up claims about 5G and the origins of Covid-19 have been linked to violence and vandalism.
But completely removing information can look a lot like censorship
column2: especially for scientists whose careers are based on the understanding that facts can and should be disputed
column3: and that evidence changes.

column1: The Royal Society is the world's oldest continuously operating scientific institution
column2: and it is attempting to grapple with the challenges posed by our newest ways of communicating information.

column1: In a new report
column2: it advises against social media companies removing content that is ""legal but harmful"". Instead
column3: the report authors believe
column4: social media sites should adjust their algorithms to prevent it going viral - and stop people making money off false claims.

column1: But not everyone agrees with that view - especially researchers who are experts in tracking the way misinformation spreads online
column2: and how it harms people.

column1: The Center for Countering Digital Hate (CCDH) maintains there are cases when the best thing to do is to remove content when it is very harmful
column2: clearly wrong and spreading very widely.

column1: The team points to Plandemic - a video that went viral at the start of the pandemic
column2: making dangerous and false claims designed to scare people away from effective ways of reducing harm from the virus
column3: like vaccines and masks

column1: Social media companies were better primed for the video's sequel Plandemic 2
column2: which fell flat after being restricted on major platforms
column3: having nothing like the same reach as the first video.

column1: It's a political question...what balance we see between individual liberties and some form of restrictions on what people can and cannot say
column2: says Prof Rasmus Kleis Nielsen
column3: director of the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism at the University of Oxford.

column1: Prof Nielsen acknowledges that
column2: although it's a relatively small part of people's media diets
column3: science misinformation can lead to disproportionate harm.

column1: But
column2: he adds
column3: given a lack of trust in institutions is a big driver of misinformation: ""I imagine that there are quite a lot of citizens who would have their worst suspicions confirmed about how society works
column4: if established institutions took a much more hands-on role in limiting people's access to information.""

column1: Echoing this concern
column2: the Royal Society says: ""Removing content may exacerbate feelings of distrust and be exploited by others to promote misinformation content."" This ""may cause more harm than good by driving misinformation content...towards harder-to-address corners of the internet.""

column1: The fact that those corners are ""harder to reach""
column2: though
column3: is arguably part of the point. It reduces the risk that someone who is not already committed to potentially harmful beliefs
column5: will be exposed to them by chance.

column1: Some of the violent protests that were driven at least in part by conspiracies had their origin not in obscure corners of the internet
column2: but on Facebook. And there is little clear evidence that removing content drives people further into harmful beliefs.

column1: Scientific misinformation is nothing new.
The incorrect belief in a link between the MMR vaccine and autism came from a published (and later retracted) academic paper
column2: while widespread unevidenced beliefs in the harm of water fluoridation were driven by the print media
column3: campaign groups and word of mouth.

column1: What's changed is the speed at which false facts travel
column2: and the huge numbers of people who can end up reading them.

column1: Rather than removing content
column2: one way suggested by the report's authors of tackling misinformation is making it harder to find and share
column3: and less likely to appear automatically on someone's feed.

column1: This video can not be played
This
column2: Prof Gina Neff
column3: a social scientist at the Oxford Internet Institute explained
column4: was to ""ensure that people still can speak their mind"" - they just aren't guaranteed an audience of millions.

column1: They can still post this information
column2: but the platforms don't have to make it go viral.""

column1: The Institute for Strategic Dialogue (ISD)
column2: a think tank which monitors extremism
column3: points out a substantial proportion of misinformation relies on the appropriation and misuse of genuine data and research.

column1: This is sometimes more dangerous than outright false information
column2: because it can take substantially longer to debunk by explaining how and why this is a misreading or misuse of the data
column3: its spokesperson says.

column1: That's where fact-checking comes in - another tool which the Royal Society supports.

One of the most common pieces of vaccine misinformation over the past year - which the BBC has repeatedly fact-checked - was the notion that people are being harmed in high numbers by the jab. This claim is based on a misinterpretation of real figures.
The ISD says research has shown that a small group of accounts spreading misinformation had a ""disproportionate influence on the public debate across social media"".
Many of these accounts have been labelled by fact-checkers as sharing false or misleading content on multiple occasions
column2: yet remain live.""

column1: The Royal Society did not investigate removing the accounts of ""influencers"" who are especially prolific spreaders of harmful misinformation.
But this is seen as an important tool by many disinformation experts
column2: and research into ISIS and the far-right suggests it can be successful.

column1: When David Icke
column2: a prolific spreader of Covid misinformation as well as anti-Semitic conspiracy theories
column3: was removed from YouTube
column4: research from the CCDH found his ability to reach people was considerably reduced.

column1: While his videos remained on alternative video-hosting platform BitChute
column2: their views fell from 150
column3: 000 on average before the YouTube ban to 6
column5: 64 of his videos had been viewed 9.6 million times.

column1: Research from Cardiff University
column2: found that the de-platforming of Kate Shemirani
column3: a former nurse and prolific spreader of Covid misinformation
column4: decreased her reach in the short term.

Part of the issue is that current models of de-platforming need to be developed. It's not enough to just take down a piece of content
column2: or a small number of accounts
column3: one of the paper's authors - Prof Martin Innes - explains.

column1: Research from organised crime and counter-terrorism shows the need to disrupt the whole network
column2: he says.

column1: But he believes ""this level of sophistication isn't embedded yet"" in the way we tackle disinformation that could put people in danger.

column1: Untreated sewage is being dumped illegally in rivers across the country on a regular basis
column2: analysis shown to the BBC suggests.

column1: It found seven water companies in England and Wales discharged untreated sewage into rivers and the sea more than 3
column2: 000 times between 2017 and 2021.

column1: The water industry admitted action was needed to address the problem.
The fresh data comes a week after MPs warned of a ""chemical cocktail"" of pollutants tainting England's rivers.
The Environmental Audit Committee said raw sewage and microplastics were putting health and nature at risk.
Peter Hammond
column2: a retired professor of computational biology and also a campaigner with Windrush Against Sewage Pollution
column3: said the statistics showed that the water industry was flouting poor regulation by the Environment Agency.

column1: In some cases
column2: multiple sewage works are spilling into the same river causing damage for long periods of time
column3: sometimes spilling as long as four months
column4: six months almost without a break

column1: He calculated that together the seven companies - Southern Water
column2: South West Water
column3: Thames Water
column6: Yorkshire Water and Welsh Water - discharged untreated sewage from 59 treatment works that treat 4.5 million people's wastewater.

column1: Water companies are allowed to discharge untreated sewage into rivers in exceptional circumstances - for example during heavy rainfall.

They can be acting illegally if they discharge when the conditions are dry - this is known as a dry spill. Or they can be breaking the law if they are not treating enough of the sewage before they discharge it - this is known as an early spill.
Prof Hammond looked at data from ""event duration monitors""
column2: which check every 15 minutes on whether a treatment works is discharging untreated sewage into a river. He then compares this data with rainfall data and with the companies' records on how much sewage they're treating.

column1: In response to the report United Utilities
column2: Southern Water and Welsh Water
column3: questioned the accuracy of some of the data while Yorkshire Water said that Prof Hammond had ""fundamentally misunderstood"" the data.

column1: According to the report the sewage treatment works at Dorking run by Thames Water was responsible for the highest number of unpermitted spills.
Untreated sewage was discharged into the River Mole on 223 days over the last four years. Prof Hammond's analysis suggests none of them would have been permitted by the rules
column2: because either the weather was too dry
column3: or not enough of the sewage had been treated properly.

column1: Thames Water said it ''regards all discharges of untreated sewage as unacceptable and will work with the government
column2: Ofwat and the Environment Agency to accelerate work to stop them being necessary and say they are determined to be transparent"".

column1: Prof Hammond said the Environment Agency is failing to detect thousands of illegal spills because it is not scrutinising the available data closely enough.
''It's as if the Environment Agency is looking through a telescope and we're looking through a microscope.""
Water UK
column2: which represents the water companies
column3: said all the water companies agree there is an ''urgent need for action to tackle the harm caused to the environment by overflows"".

column1: An Environment Agency spokesperson said where there was evidence of non-compliance ''we will not hesitate to pursue the water companies concerned
column2: and take appropriate action"".

column1: They added that 1
column2: 300 storm overflows and storm tanks at waste water treatment works have been identified as ''spilling frequently'' and that ''a major investigation into possible unauthorised spills at thousands of sewage treatment works is ongoing"".

column1: Sunday's suicide bombing in Somalia's capital targeted a man who had survived four previous attacks. BBC World Service Africa editor Mary Harper considers why Mohamed Moalimu
column2: who is now recovering in hospital
column3: continues to brave a city wracked by violence.

column1: I have a list of essential information stored on my phone. Right near the top
column2: above my passport number and bank account details
column3: is the name Moalimu
column4: the number 16.5 and the words ""likes blue patterns and white"".

column1: These are the shirt size and preferred colours of my dear friend Mohamed Ibrahim Moalimu
column2: who used to work as the BBC's reporter in Somalia.

column1: Whenever I visit Mogadishu I buy shirts for Moalimu.
I love going to Jermyn Street in London
column2: the Mecca for posh gentlemen's clothes. I sort through the dozens and dozens of colours
column3: patterns and designs
column4: looking for just the right thing.

column1: In fact
column2: I have two such shirts waiting in my suitcase for the next time I go to Somalia.

column1: The problem is
column2: Moalimu might not be there. He is in hospital in Turkey.

column1: He was airlifted there in a little plane. It was not easy to manoeuvre his stretcher up and into the small space.
On Sunday
column2: Moalimu was caught up in his fifth suicide attack. This time he was the direct target.

column1: A suicide bomber ran towards his car and detonated the explosives when he reached the place where Moalimu was sitting.
There was little left of the attacker. The car was a mangled wreck.
I do not understand how Moalimu survived. He has a broken leg
column2: chest wounds and other injuries but he is conscious and lucid.

column1: If you were to meet Moalimu
column2: probably the first thing you would notice is the terrible scars on his face. He got those in 2016 in his second suicide attack.

column1: He was at his favourite seaside restaurant. Fighters from Islamist militant group al-Shabab stormed in from the beach
column2: besieging the place for hours.

column1: Moalimu survived by lying in his own blood
column2: pretending to be dead.

column1: He told me how the militants kicked people's bodies to make sure they had died
column2: shooting those who flinched.

column1: It took months of treatment in Somalia
column2: Kenya and the UK to heal him. The main fear was for his eyes.

column1: It is difficult to relate the character of Moalimu to the dangerous world he lives in
column2: and refuses to leave.

column1: He is gentle
column2: softly spoken and calm.

column1: Mogadishu
column2: and many of the people in it
column3: are excitable
column4: loud and nervy. Not surprising given that the city has been at war for more than three decades.

column1: I was in Mogadishu shortly after Moalimu was caught up in his first suicide attack.
It was in June 2013 when al-Shabab smashed their way into a United Nations compound
column2: spending about an hour inside killing as many people as they could.

column1: Moalimu happened to be driving past when the militants struck. The remains of a suicide bomber landed on his car
column2: smashing the windscreen.

column1: In his usual polite
column2: unassuming way
column3: Moalimu showed me his windscreen
column4: which was well-and-truly smashed up. He drew out a gruesome photo of his car in the aftermath of the attack.

column1: He asked if I thought the BBC might pay for his windscreen to be repaired.
After all
column2: he was working at the time. Reporting
column3: as he so often did
column4: on the violence in his hometown.

column1: There is no way the BBC could cover Somalia the way it does without people like Moalimu.
He now works as a government spokesman
column2: but when he was with the BBC
column3: as well as filing his own reports
column4: Moalimu was always ready to tell people like me exactly what was going on.

column1: To this day
column2: whenever I call him
column3: he starts off with a list of exactly what has happened that day - the assassinations

column1: He does this even when the purpose of my call is to ask him what kind of shirts I should bring him.
When Moalimu was my BBC colleague
column2: he and one other person were the only ones I called before I went to Somalia.

column1: If Moalimu said: ""Don't come"" - I didn't
column2: even if it seemed to be relatively quiet. If Moalimu said: ""Come"" - I came
column3: even if the security seemed a bit ropey.

column1: I trusted Moalimu with my life. He was one of the unsung heroes of my profession.
I find it hard to understand why so much journalism gets attached to the name of one glorious
column2: brave reporter
column3: when there are often many others involved.

column1: The producer
column2: the camera-person
column3: the sound-person and
column7: who knows pretty much everything and upon whom the team almost entirely depends.

column1: Moalimu was one such person
column2: as are a number of other Somali journalists with whom I work and who also risk their lives every day.

column1: After he left journalism I told Moalimu how disappointed I was when he became the government spokesman.
How could such a fair
column2: honest journalist join ""the other side""?

column1: As always
column2: his response was measured.

column1: I want to make a difference. I couldn't do that as a journalist. I need to work from inside the system. I want to be an MP and this is my first step towards that.""
After he took on his new job
column2: I had to develop a more formal relationship with him.

column1: His shirts have also become more formal. They are stiff and white as he now needs to wear them with smart suits.
But whenever I walk down Jermyn Street
column2: I will always think of the joy of choosing shirts for him
column3: trying to match colours and patterns with his serene

column1: Snow has fallen in the Sahara Desert in north-western Algeria as temperatures plummeted to below freezing.
For children from nearby towns such as Mekalis
column2: it was a welcome relief from the scorching heat of the world's largest hot desert.

column1: The ice crystals formed stunning patterns in the desert sands.
Dunes - ideal for sliding - were also partially covered by snow.
The town of Ain Sefra - known as the gateway to the Sahara Desert - also saw snow. Temperatures in the town often reach 35 degrees Celsius in July and August.
Snow is not entirely unknown in the region
column2: which lies between the desert and the Atlas mountains.

column1: This month's snow was not entirely surprising - it also happened in 2021
But the snow on the red sand dunes in December 2016 did come as a surprise. Residents of Ain Sefra said that it was the first time since 1979 they had seen snow
column2: suggesting the phenomenon is now becoming more common.

column1: This video can not be played
Former cabinet minister David Davis has joined calls for Boris Johnson to stand down
column2: telling the prime minister: ""In the name of God
column3: go.""

column1: He said the PM had failed to take responsibility for his actions over lockdown parties in Downing Street.
Mr Davis's remarks came after backbench Tory MP Christian Wakeford defected to Labour
column2: minutes before Prime Minister's Questions began.

column1: The PM batted away repeated calls to quit during the stormy Commons session.
Mr Davis's criticisms and Mr Wakeford's defection come as Mr Johnson is fighting to save his premiership after admitting attending a drinks event in Downing Street during the first lockdown.
So far six Conservative MPs have publicly declared no confidence in the PM
column2: but more are thought to have submitted letters to Sir Graham Brady
column3: chairman of the backbench 1922 committee

column1: There are claims that the threshold of 54 letters needed to trigger a no-confidence vote and leadership election could soon be reached
column2: but no official word has been given.

column1: Scottish Conservative leader Douglas Ross
column2: one of those to call for Mr Johnson to quit
column3: said a no-confidence vote was ""near"" and ""getting closer"".

column1: But a former cabinet minister told the BBC that Mr Wakeford's defection seemed to be backfiring
column2: as his actions had ""provided an alternative target for rage"" among Tory MPs.

column1: Another Tory MP said he had been ""let down by a good friend"" and that his now ex-colleague had ""unified the party"".
The prime minister is urging fellow Conservatives not to pass judgement on him until a report on parties at No 10
column2: by senior civil servant Sue Gray
column3: comes out next week.

column1: In his letter to Mr Johnson
column2: Bury South MP Mr Wakeford said: ""You and the Conservative Party as a whole have shown themselves incapable of offering the leadership and government this country deserves.""

column1: At Prime Minister's Questions
column2: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer welcomed Mr Wakeford to his party and repeated his call for Mr Johnson to quit
column3: saying his ""absurd and unreliable defences"" of No 10 parties were unravelling.

column1: But the most dramatic intervention came towards the end of the session
column2: when Mr Davis told Mr Johnson he had spent weeks defending him from ""angry constituents"".

column1: He added: ""I expect my leaders to shoulder the responsibility for the actions they take. Yesterday he did the opposite of that. So
column2: I will remind him of a quotation which may be familiar to his ear: Leopold Amery to Neville Chamberlain.

column1: 'You have sat too long here for any good you have been doing. In the name of God
A defection is a rare thing. A coup for Labour. A temporary triumph for Sir Keir Starmer.
There were whispers that Christian Wakeford was spotted talking to a former Labour MP over drinks this week
column2: a few murmurs that he might be thinking about taking such a dramatic step.

column1: But for it to happen
column2: to see that crossing the floor moment
column3: is unusual indeed.

column1: Traditionally a defection can in fact unite the party who the MP has left behind - it's so drastic.
But the Wakeford departure adds to the real sense of chaos in Westminster. And the reaction among his now former colleagues elected in 2019 may not follow that traditional path.
Read Laura's analysis in full
The PM said he did not ""know what [Mr Davis] is talking about""
column2: but insisted he took ""full responsibility for everything done in this government and throughout the pandemic"".

column1: Speaking afterwards to the BBC
column2: Mr Davis
column3: the former Brexit secretary
column4: said he had supported Mr Johnson until his interview on Tuesday
column5: when he said he had not been told a party in the Downing Street garden risked breaking Covid rules.

column1: Jake Berry
column2: chairman of the Northern Research Group of Red Wall Tory MPs
column3: most of whom won their seats from Labour at the 2019 general election
column4: said he thought Mr Davis had ""misjudged the mood of colleagues"".

column1: But he added that ""the next few weeks and months"" would prove whether the former minister was correct.
Speaking at the Downing Street coronavirus press conference
column2: Health Secretary Sajid Javid said: ""I can say with full confidence I have observed Covid 19 rules at all times.

column1: My mum lives alone. I couldn't see her. I couldn't go to a close friend's funeral. It wasn't easy but it was the right thing to do
column2: as millions have done up and down the country when they were asked to.""

column1: Who else has used the phrase
column2: 'In the name of God
column3: go'?

column1: The phrase was first used by Oliver Cromwell in the 17th Century.
Conservative MP Leo Amery used the words during a Commons debate in 1940
column2: following the UK's failed campaign against Nazi forces in Norway. Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain resigned two days later.

column1: Ms Gray's team are talking to the PM's former aide Dominic Cummings
column2: who says he warned the PM that the Downing Street garden party in May 2020 risked breaking Covid rules.

column1: Mr Cummings has also accused Mr Johnson - who insists he thought the party was a work event - of misleading Parliament.

column2: Sir Keir said the prime minister's defence requires the public to believe that ""as he waded through the empty bottles and platters of sandwiches
column3: he didn't realise it was a party"".

column1: He added: ""If the prime minister misleads Parliament
column2: should they resign?""

column1: Mr Johnson said: ""[Sir Keir] is continuing to ask a series of questions which he knows will be fully addressed by the inquiry
column2: he is wasting this House's time
column3: he is wasting the people's time.""

column1: The SNP's Westminster leader Ian Blackford said: ""The prime minister is taking the public for fools. Nobody believes him. Will the prime minister finally take responsibility? Resign
column2: go

column1: Here's a view of the UK and Ireland you won't have seen before.
The mosaic is made from imagery acquired by the NovaSar satellite.
Looking somewhat like a cheese-grater
column2: this specialist spacecraft pictures the Earth's surface using radar.

column1: The beauty of this technology is that it detects the ground even when there is thick cloud or
column2: indeed
column3: when it's night-time.

column1: Consequently
column2: this map was assembled by NovaSar in just seven passes.

column1: A traditional optical satellite
column2: which views scenes at wavelengths familiar to our eyes
column3: would struggle to make such a map in so short a time. Britain's famously grey weather would be a constant frustration.

column1: Radar is a very deterministic thing
column2: said Andrew Cawthorne
column3: the director of Earth observation at Surrey Satellite Technology Ltd (SSTL)

column1: You know that when you pass overhead
column2: you're going to get an image without any external influences causing you problems.""

column1: I can't render the full image on this page. The one in my possession is two gigabytes in size. But if you could open it on your computer
column2: you'd see some glorious detail - of cities
column3: bridges

column1: The mosaic corresponds to an area of approximately 1
column2: 500km by 1
column3: 168km (1.75 million square km)

column1: Each pixel represents a square on the ground that's about 50m across
column2: which is really interesting because you can see very clearly the wind turbines out at sea. The turbine units are much less than 50m across
column3: but their towers have hard
column4: metallic surfaces which are excellent reflectors of radar energy
column5: so they show up as brilliant specks.

column1: There's a lot of information in the map. It can be used to study land-uses
column2: for example
column3: to understand the changing urban footprint of Britain or to monitor the types of crops being grown on its agricultural land.

column1: NovaSar was seed-funded by government grant. It is the only sovereign radar capability the UK has.

If Britain falls out of the EU's Copernicus programme with its radar satellite capability (continued membership is currently caught up in a dispute over Brexit trade arrangements in Northern Ireland) then NovaSar will be the only direct space asset the UK can task around the globe to guarantee an immediate image of the ground.
In development at SSTL is a new low-cost radar satellite called CarbSar. It is being developed in partnership with novel antenna designer Oxford Space Systems.
OSS is developing this interesting wrapped-rib antenna and we're developing the front-end radar electronics that attach to that antenna. Quite a lot of the elements are on the bench now being tested
column2: explained Dr Cawthorne.

column1: But although we have the money to build the CarbSar payload
column2: we don't yet have the money to launch it.""

column1: The UK government published its long-awaited space strategy in September
column2: which set out the desire both to remain in the EU's Copernicus programme and to build a constellation of small Intelligence
column3: Surveillance and Reconnaissance satellites.

column1: However
column2: no budget was announced to go with the strategy.

column1: UK space industry figures have told the BBC that if the country's association to Copernicus fails to materialise then the unused subscription should be fully invested in home-grown systems. The sum involved would be €750m (£630m) over seven years.
We could do a lot with that kind of money
column2: said Dr Cawthorne.

column1: You can read more about the UK Space Strategy here.

column2: gone.

column1: Researchers are currently busy trying to gauge the impact A68 had on the environment.
And a team led from Leeds University has been back through all the satellite data to calculate the behemoth's changing dimensions as it moved north from the White Continent
column2: through the Southern Ocean and up into the South Atlantic.

column1: This has enabled the group to assess varying melt rates during the course of the megaberg's three-and-a-half-year existence.
One of the key periods
column2: obviously
column3: was towards the end
column4: as A68 approached the warmer climes of the British Overseas Territory of South Georgia.

column1: This video can not be played
For a while
column2: there were fears the giant block could ground in the surrounding shallows
column3: blocking the foraging routes of millions of penguins

column1: But it never quite happened because
column2: as the team can now show
column3: A68 lost sufficient depth of keel to stay afloat.

column1: It does seem that it briefly touched the continental shelf. That's when the berg took a turn and we saw a small piece break off. But it wasn't enough to ground A68
column2: Leeds's Dr Anne Braakmann-Folgmann told BBC News.

column1: And I think you can see why in the thickness estimates
column2: added co-author Prof Andrew Shepherd. ""By that stage the berg's keel was 141m
column3: on average
column4: and the bathymetry (depth) charts in the area showed 150m. It was a close call in the end.""

column1: By April 2021
column2: A68 had broken into countless small fragments that were beyond tracking. But its ecosystem impacts will have been much longer-lived.

column1: Giant tabular
column2: or flat-topped
column3: bergs are now recognised to have considerable influence wherever they roam.

column1: Their freshwater inputs will alter local currents. And all the iron
column2: other minerals
column3: and even organic matter picked up through their lives and subsequently dropped into the ocean will seed biological production.

column1: The British Antarctic Survey managed to place some robotic gliders in the vicinity of A68 to monitor conditions before the ice mass totally wasted away.
The data retrieved from these and other instruments
column2: although not yet fully analysed
column3: was revealing some interesting features
column4: said biological oceanographer Prof Geraint Tarling.

column1: We think there's a really strong signal in the changing flora of the phytoplankton species around A68
column2: and also in the actual deposition of material to the deeper parts of the ocean. The particle sensor on the glider was picking up some very strong signals of deposition coming from the berg
column3: he told BBC News.

column1: Details of A68's changing shape and freshwater fluxes are contained in a paper published in the journal Remote Sensing of Environment.

column1: Watching the Red Arrows jet across the sky as a young boy
column2: Todd Smith knew that flying was what he wanted to do when he was older.

column1: After five years' training
column2: costing £100
column4: followed by two years working as a flying instructor
column5: he finally landed his dream job in his late twenties - working as an airline pilot.

column1: But in 2019
column2: the travel firm he was working for - Thomas Cook - collapsed.

column1: By this time Mr Smith had become increasingly concerned about the growing threat of climate change
column2: and the aviation sector's carbon emissions.

column1: I started connecting the dots
column2: and was met with an uncomfortable conflict
column3: he says.

column1: I wanted to get involved in [environmental protest group] Extinction Rebellion
column2: but knew it would be career suicide
column3: and I had a lot of debt. It would be easier to return to the industry and pay off the debt.""

column1: Yet with the pandemic grounding aircraft
column2: Mr Smith
column3: who lives in the Berkshire town of Reading
column4: decided to quit his high-flying career for good.

column1: Of course I prefer flying and visiting exotic destinations
column2: and earning a decent salary
column3: says the 32-year-old. ""But when confronted with the climate and ecological emergency
column4: how could I possibly prioritise my needs
column5: when we need to think collectively about how to tackle the biggest existential threat to humanity?""

column1: Mr Smith is now a climate activist. He acts as a spokesperson for Extinction Rebellion and is the co-founder of Safe Landing
column2: a movement of climate-conscious aviation sector workers.

column1: Giving up his dream job was a tough decision
column2: he says. ""I'm doing this out of desperation
column3: not out of choice. Financially I've been really struggling
column4: I'm in a huge amount of debt

column1: But he adds: ""Taking action has been cathartic and eased my anxiety.""
Mr Smith's campaigning comes as a United Nation's climate change panel warned last summer that the world faced increasingly extreme heatwaves
column2: droughts and flooding.

column1: UN secretary-general António Guterres said the study was ""code red for humanity"". Last October
column2: the UK pledged to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. This target will require big growth and investment in the low-carbon economy.

column1: Mr Smith is far from the only person to leave a previous job due to concerns about the environment.
After working in the oil and gas industry in Denmark for 10 years
column2: Nader Beltaji has moved to a low-carbon career. He now works as a project manager at renewable energy giant RWE.

column1: I actually did my master's thesis on solar power and I wanted to go into that direction
column2: but at the time there weren't many opportunities that caught my attention
column3: says the 33-year-old who now lives in Wiltshire. ""Now the landscape has completely changed.""

column1: Currently working on the construction of an offshore wind farm off north east England
column2: Mr Beltaji says he has more job satisfaction these days.

column1: Climate change is certainly very much in the news
column2: and offshore wind is part of the UK's big energy strategy
column3: so it's good to be part of that
column4: and know you're working on delivering the targets
column5: he says. ""Oil and gas feels like quite a dying industry.""

column1: Rachel Bowcutt used to work in the UK's dairy industry
column2: which is known for being carbon intensive. The UN estimates that the dairy sector's global carbon dioxide emissions total some 1.7bn tonnes annually. That is more than the aviation sector's pre-pandemic 915m tonnes.

column1: Previously
column2: Ms Bowcutt was operations manager for the Royal Association of British Dairy Farmers for two years
column3: before quitting to take up a job at perhaps the organisation's nemesis - The Vegan Society.

column1: She went vegan after reading reports
column2: such as this from Oxford University
column3: saying that a vegan diet ""is probably the single biggest way to reduce your impact on planet Earth"".

column1: Ms Bowcutt says she had also started to feel uncomfortable about the dairy industry and its practices after watching a session at a work conference about the optimum time to take calves away from their mothers.
It all felt a bit unnecessary in terms of animal welfare and the environmental impact. It got to the point where I thought this isn't for me anymore
column2: and I wondered if there was an equivalent organisation for vegans - and the job came up.""

column1: Ms Bowcutt
column2: who lives in Leamington Spa
column3: in Warwickshire
column4: started at the Vegan Society last year. ""I have much more confidence about the work I'm involved in. I can see the benefits
column5: it's easier to promote and a subject matter I really believe in.""

column1: The move to low-carbon jobs is urgently needed
column2: argues Friends of the Earth climate campaigner Denis Fernando.

column1: There is a climate emergency
column2: and we need drastic action to make things happen
column3: so we'll [need to] see more of a push towards green workforces
column4: he says. ""Green jobs create jobs. Everyone wins.

column1: There's a strong understanding towards moving towards green and low-carbon jobs
column2: and an overall trend of people who want to do it
column3: but we are deficient in terms of green skills.

column1: There's intention
column2: but government policy could do more to quickly get more apprentices so they can start building skills. It can't be done to scale unless the government gives more resources to local councils.""

column1: New Economy is a new series exploring how businesses
column2: trade
column3: economies and working life are changing fast.

column1: A government spokesperson says: ""The UK is capitalising on the green industrial revolution
column2: with over 56
column3: 000 clean jobs created and supported in the UK's green industries since the launch of the prime minister's Ten Point Plan.

column1: These range from electric vehicle manufacturing in Sunderland
column2: hydrogen facilities in Teesside
column3: to new floating offshore wind farms and factories in Wales and Scotland.

column1: To build on this
column2: we are ensuring people have the right skills for employment in Britain's new low carbon industries
column3: through measures ranging from green skills boot camps
column5: as we support new British industries

column1: Mr Fernando says green jobs have multiple benefits
column2: including reducing the impact on the climate and restoring nature
column3: and can involve millions of us.

column1: Green jobs could be anything from working on renewable wind turbines or ecology
column2: but also bicycle repair
column3: customer service at a railway station or a warehouse manager for a freight warehouse going by rail rather than air.

column1: We really need try to think of the big agenda which everyone can participate in.""

column1: I've never doubted Covid-19 vaccination... until now.""
Jerome doesn't follow news closely on Twitter
column2: using the site mainly to tweet about sports and books he's enjoying.

column1: The 41-year-old bus driver
column2: from Quebec has mostly supported local Covid restrictions
column3: although he admits to growing ""fed up""

column1: His feed reveals him mildly grumbling about his children's home-schooling
column2: among posts about favourite authors and Canada's national football team.

column1: But casually scrolling on the social-media site
column2: one Monday early in the new year
column3: he came across a video clip appearing to show the head of Pfizer suggesting his vaccine provided no protection at all against Omicron.

column1: Albert Bourla could be seen saying: ""We know that the two doses of the vaccine offer very limited protection
column2: if any.""

column1: Jerome tweeted: ""If this video is legit
column2: it has to sound off some alarms somewhere
column3: no?""

column1: But the clip had been taken out of context from a longer interview
column2: with Yahoo Finance
column3: in which Mr Bourla had been discussing high infection rates with Omicron.

column1: A Pfizer representative clarified he had been referring to research suggesting while ""two doses of [Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid vaccine] may not be sufficient to protect against infection with the Omicron variant""
column2: vaccinated people were thought to still be protected against severe disease.

column1: Several studies suggest vaccines
column2: even when they do not protect against infection
column3: lessen the impact of the Omicron variant
column5: and significantly reduce the chances of ending up in hospital or dying.

column1: Jerome told BBC News he was generally wary of things he saw online
column2: and on looking into the video further had realised the clip was a ""small part of the whole interview"".

column1: It was clear to me that small clip probably shouldn't be taken into account to shape my conclusion
column2: he said.

column1: But he had ""almost slipped into being manipulated"".
I was really surprised and shocked
column2: you know
column3: I just almost couldn't believe what I was hearing

column1: And from that brief window during which he'd expressed doubts about vaccination
column2: his account was flooded with comments from people he characterised as the ""anti-vax community"".

column1: I have never had so many notifications on my Twitter
column2: he said.

column1: People were telling me things like
column2: 'Oh
column3: well
column5: it's about time you wake up.'""

column1: Jerome was also sent countless links to further misinformation
column2: claiming ""unbelievable side-effects from the vaccines"".

column1: As is common online
column2: people were taking valid points - the vaccine isn't very good at protecting against catching Omicron or it comes with a very small risk of extremely rare side-effects - and making big leaps to much stronger claims - the vaccine is unsafe or completely ineffective - not supported by the evidence.

column1: Posts also left out crucial information - in vaccinated populations people have much milder infections or the virus itself comes with much greater risk than the vaccine of side-effects
column2: including blood clotting
column3: heart inflammation and death.

column1: Many posts also made promises of fellowship and community
column2: calling him ""brother"". Jerome describes himself as living a happy and contented life - but can see how someone seeking ""that sense of belonging"" could be more easily swayed.

column1: It made me realise how easily people are manipulated through false sources of information
column2: he said.

column1: In an online newsletter
column2: writer Jordan Schachtel quoted part of Mr Bourla's comments to imply two doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine now offered only ""very limited protection
column3: if any"" against Covid-19.

column1: The tweet Jerome initially saw casting doubt on the vaccine
column2: appears to have referenced this newsletter.

column1: Other social-media posts
column2: videos and podcasts also directly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter but took it further
column3: suggesting Mr Bourla's comments cast doubt on whether the vaccine was ""safe and effective"".

column1: Several posts also referred to unrelated comments by Mr Bourla
column2: on the US news channel CNBC
column3: that vaccines ""don't have the safety profile that we hope we can achieve with [mRNA] technology"".

column1: However
column2: on this occasion
column3: he had not been talking about Covid vaccines at all.

column1: A full transcript of the interview clearly shows Mr Bourla was talking about another vaccine - against the shingles virus - Pfizer plans to update.
Mr Schachtel's newsletter initially made this mistake and later corrected it - but not before these comments had been picked up by former US congressman Ron Paul
column2: who has a large social-media following.

column1: In a YouTube video
column2: Mr Paul explicitly referenced Mr Schachtel's newsletter when he repeated claims Mr Bourla had said the Covid vaccine was not safe and provided no protection against Omicron.

column1: Claims Pfizer had ""admitted... current vaccines 'do not work'"" or ""offer 'zero' protection against Covid-19""
column2: linking to Mr Paul's YouTube clip
column3: then spread across numerous online platforms.

column1: Research by independent scientists and public health experts has shown the positive impact vaccinations are having in preventing serious illness - particularly against the Omicron variant.
One study suggests people three months after a second vaccine dose are 70% less likely to develop severe disease from an Omicron infection
column2: dropping to 50% after six months.

column1: Another has found double-vaccinated people are 65% less likely to be admitted to hospital with Omicron than those unvaccinated.
Also
column2: many countries with high rates of vaccination have been experiencing very high Covid infection levels but far fewer deaths than during previous peaks.

column1: Fake endorsements from the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are being used on social media to promote Bitcoin-related investment schemes.
Photos and bogus interviews with Prince Harry and Meghan and other celebrities are being used to attract investors.
The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) says it is increasing worries about scam advertisements.
The number of consumers reporting possible scams to the watchdog has risen by more than 400% in five years.

column2: there were more than 34
column3: 000 reports from consumers with suspicions about possibly fraudulent investment offers

column1: People should be very wary when they see investment ads offering high returns
column2: even if they appear to be endorsed by celebrities
column3: a spokeswoman for the financial services regulator said.

column1: The watchdog warns of growing concerns about get-rich-quick scams being advertised through social media or search engines.
Fabricated interviews with Prince Harry and Meghan have previously been used in investment claims - and there appear to be new attempts to use their names in online articles promising instant profits
column2: shared on social-media platforms.

column1: People earning millions from home by using Harry and Meghan latest advice
column2: says one of the latest fake headlines
column3: in a story also using the logos of news brands
column8: Good Morning Britain and the Guardian.

column1: Another was headlined: ""Harry and Meghan shocked everyone in the studio by revealing how they making an extra £128
column2: 000 every month.""

column1: Articles claim falsely that in TV interviews the couple backed investment schemes related to Bitcoin and crypto-currency trading.
I let the software run and my profits stacked up like pancakes
column2: a supposed investor is quoted as saying.

column1: It feels incredible having money rush in this fast and hard.""
Another says: ""My ex-girlfriend dumped me because I was too poor.
Now I'm a multi-millionaire and I have an even better girlfriend.""
The online articles carry bogus claims of the backing of other wealthy figures
column2: including Bill Gates
column3: Sir Richard Branson and Mark Zuckerberg.

column1: The investment articles
column2: seen by the FCA
column3: appear to be linked to a website in Eastern Europe.

column1: The website was contacted but has not replied - and the online link now goes to a general feature on the Royal Family.
Representatives of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have been alerted.
The FCA wants consumers to be more aware of the threat of scams and to check if a company is regulated in the UK and on the financial-services register.
If it isn't
column2: you are very unlikely to have any protection if things go wrong
column3: the FCA spokeswoman said.

column1: Action Fraud
column2: the national reporting centre for fraud and cyber-crime
column3: says scammers are using social media to target a younger age group.

column1: This can involve ""fake testimonials"" and pictures of famous people to ""help the investment seem legitimate""
column2: it says.

column1: In the financial year between April 2020 and March 2021
column2: there were were 500 investment frauds found using bogus celebrity endorsements
column3: with losses of over £10m

column1: Citizens Advice director of policy Matthew Upton said the ""consequences can be truly devastating"".
These schemes are becoming ever-more sophisticated and can leave people feeling incredibly vulnerable and isolated - to the point where they can't even tell their family and friends what has happened
column2: he added.
