column1: 309;Joe Biden one year on: Has the United States become ungovernable?;2022-01-19T13:51:50.000Z;[];['us politics'
column2: 'long reads'
column3: 'joe biden'];['world'

column1: One of Joe Biden's central election campaign themes was restoring unity to an angry and divided nation. Twelve months after assuming office
column2: things aren't any better
column3: writes Nick Bryant.

column1: Long before the sun had risen over the dome of the US Capitol on the day that Joe Biden was sworn in as president
column2: technicians on the inaugural platform tested the teleprompter he would later read from by scrolling through America's most celebrated sermon:

column1: Four score and seven years ago
column2: our fathers brought forth on this continent
column3: a new nation
column5: and dedicated to the proposition that all men are created equal. Now we are engaged in a great civil war
column7: or any nation so conceived and so dedicated

column1: When I first saw the lines of the Gettysburg Address on those screens in front of the presidential podium
column2: I thought it must be some kind of sick joke. However
column3: the words of Abraham Lincoln could hardly be described as being out of place. Washington
column5: looked that morning like a military encampment.

column1: Troops had slept overnight in the corridors of Congress to protect it from seditionists
column2: just as their forebears had done in Lincoln's day. The scaffolding of the inaugural platform had been used only two weeks before as a staging post for the January 6th insurrection. The Confederate flag had even been held aloft in the halls of US power
column3: as American once again fought American.

column1: So the question posed by the country's 16th president seemed especially pertinent as the 46th occupant of the office prepared to assume power - could this country long endure?
Rather than speaking that day of national renewal
column2: a platitudinous staple of presidential inaugurals
column3: Joe Biden focused on national reunification. And though it was three words from his address that instantly entered the history books
column5: it was three short sentences that set out his presidential mission statement: ""Bringing America together. Uniting our people. And uniting our nation.""

column1: A year on
column2: however
column3: that plea for national unity sounds more like magical thinking. Far from coming together
column4: the United States is in an even more perilous state of disunion. Often it feels as if the only thing that unites the nation is mutual loathing. America seems to be engaged in a forever war with itself.

column1: Over the past 12 months
column2: tensions have escalated over longstanding points of divergence
column3: such as abortion rights. The country has found new things to argue about
column4: such as vaccine mandates. It has also discovered new ways of fighting old battles. The conflict over critical race theory
column5: the latest front in the country's left-right culture wars
column6: is a novel way of carrying on the centuries-old debate over the legacy of slavery and segregation.

column1: During the past year
column2: moments with the potential to help bridge divides
column3: namely the conviction of Derek Chauvin
column4: the former police officer who murdered George Floyd
column5: have been supplanted by events that ended up hardening divisions. The trial of Kyle Rittenhouse
column6: the teenager acquitted of murder after shooting dead two men during racial unrest in Kenosha
column8: was an obvious case in point.

column1: To those who believed he should be convicted
column2: Rittenhouse was a homicidal vigilante who recklessly waded into a racial protest carrying a military-style semi-automatic weapon. To his supporters
column3: he was a patriot and American hero - one far-right website labelled him ""Saint Kyle"".

column1: The teenager became the latest poster boy of polarisation. The debate surrounding his trial degenerated into a rage-filled ruckus of overlapping and interlocking arguments about gun control
column2: self-defence laws
column3: policing and double standards in the criminal justice system. As is now the norm in US society
column4: policy questions involving complex and nuanced issues were thrashed out in the midst of a firestorm
column5: often in the most binary and emotive terms.

column1: On the Richter scale of American division
column2: however
column3: the Rittenhouse trial was only a moderate quake. The aftershocks of January 6th continue to be far more seismic. Rather than becoming a moment of Trumpian repudiation
column4: the Capitol Hill insurrection ended up having a radicalising effect on the conservative movement. The so-called ""big lie"" that Trump won the election
column5: a fringe conspiracy theory in the hours after Joe Biden was declared the victor
column6: has since been adopted as mainstream Republican thinking.

column1: What we are now witnessing is something without precedent in modern America - a former president
column2: who continues to enjoy widespread backing from his party
column3: refusing to accept the result of a clear-cut presidential election. Nor did the assault on democracy
column5: end on the night of January 6th.

column1: In the past year
column2: Republican-controlled legislatures in more than a dozen states have passed restrictive voting laws. Laws have also been enacted making it easier to interfere in a partisan way with election administration
column3: part of what Democrats claim is a a slow-motion coup to regain the White House at the next presidential election. Polling suggests
column5: that more Republicans think that democracy is under attack than Democrats

column1: Free and fair elections
column2: the very mechanism designed to peacefully resolve disputes in a civil society
column3: are themselves now at the centre of a society-splitting dispute. And at the core of that row is something even more fundamental
column4: the failure to agree even on incontrovertible facts - in this case the objective truth that Biden won.  How can there be unity
column5: in a country stewing in misinformation and conspiracy theories
column6: when there is no longer a shared sense of reality? Truth is usually a prerequisite of reconciliation.

column1: Some fear that January 6th was a foreshock
column2: a prelude to an even more deadly eruption.

column1: That explains the attention being paid to a series of recent books raising the spectre of further civil conflict and political unrest. In How Civil Wars Start: And How to Stop Them
column2: the political science professor Barbara F Walter describes her country as an ""anocracy""
column3: a mix between a democracy and an autocracy
column4: and warns of further militia violence. In Divided We Fall
column7: fears states might even decide to secede from the union
column8: the precipitant in the mid-19th Century of the American Civil War. The intellectual descendants of the plethora of books written since the turn of the century on US decline
column9: they form part of a new genre - studies devoted to the prospect of American disintegration.

column1: Few American scholars think the country is on the verge of a full-scale conflagration
column2: a Civil War 2.0
column3: in which compatriots would take up arms against each other on fields of battle that would become modern-day equivalents of Fort Sumter and Antietam.  The more likely scenario
column4: given the uptick in militia activity and the incendiary tone of political discourse
column5: is of sporadic acts of political violence akin to the white supremacist rally in Charlottesville or the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing. Yet even this lesser possibility is alarming.

column1: Late in the  2020 presidential campaign
column2: Joe Biden actually travelled to Gettysburg to sound the alarm about the violent potentialities of division. ""The country is in a dangerous place""
column3: he warned
column4: speaking against the backdrop of a battlefield where tens of thousands of Americans ended up as casualties. ""Once again
column5: we are a house divided."" Yet a president who cast himself as a consensus-builder
column7: has not even managed to unite his party

column1: As Biden is well aware
column2: more battles loom on the near horizon. Sometime in 2022
column3: the Supreme Court will deliver its highly anticipated ruling in Dobbs vs Jackson Women's Health Organisation
column4: which could overturn the constitutional right to abortion and lead to an even more balkanised America. The mid-term congressional elections are another potential flashpoint. Even in the event of a conflict with Russia over Ukraine or a clash with China over Taiwan
column5: it is hard to imagine a patriotic surge strong enough to bring the country together. On the contrary
column6: much like the coronavirus pandemic and January 6th insurrection
column7: a military confrontation would more likely expose the nation's fissures.

column1: On inauguration day a year ago
column2: you could almost hear the relief in Joe Biden's voice when he reassured his country
column3: and the world
column4: that democracy had prevailed. But in his two set-piece speeches of this new political year - one marking the anniversary of January 6th and the other delivered in Georgia demanding the passage of voting rights legislation - it was possible to detect both an air of resignation and a strident partisan tone. Both may well be an indication that he knows in his heart of hearts that his reunification project has failed
column5: and that national healing is beyond him. Historians may one day view this as a personal failing. But I suspect many will be more sympathetic. After all
column6: could any president heal a broken land that looks increasingly ungovernable?

column1: Maybe the best that can be hoped for as the country approaches its 250th anniversary on July 4th
column3: is for it to remain in a state of largely peaceful co-existence: that its cold civil war will never become hot. As for whether the country can long endure? It is still an open question.

column1: Nick Bryant is the author of When America Stopped Being Great: A History of the Present. He now lives in Sydney

310;Apple AirTags - 'A perfect tool for stalking';2022-01-20T00:13:46.000Z;[];['apple'];['apple'
column2: 'didnt'
column3: 'stalking'

column1: This video can not be played
Amber Norsworthy lives in Mississippi with her four children.
It had just turned 3pm when she got home on 27 December. She received a notification on her phone.
My phone made a ding that I'd never heard before""
column2: she says.

column1: The notification told her that an unknown device had been following her movements.
Ms Norsworthy
column2: who's 32
column3: went on to the 'Find My' app on her iPhone.

column1: It showed me my whole route. It said 'the last time the owner saw your location was 15:02' and I was like
column2: 'that's now
column3: I'm at home'.""

column1: She rang the police
column2: who told her they didn't know what to do. She has yet to find the device
column3: which she believes is somewhere in her car. She says Apple Support was able to confirm it was an AirTag. ""I watch my surroundings very closely now

column1: The BBC has spoken to six women in the US who say they have been tracked using Apple AirTags.
The button-sized devices are designed to work with Apple's 'Find My' network to locate lost items. But there have been multiple reports in the US of the devices being used to track people.
Apple told the BBC: ""We take customer safety very seriously and are committed to AirTag's privacy and security.""
The company also says AirTags have better security features than rival products. However
column2: there is growing evidence that they are being used for criminal activity across the US.

column1: Apple launched AirTags last April. They're small
column2: smooth and circular - and took inspiration from other tracking products on the market
column3: like Tile.

column1: The idea is that they can be attached to luggage or keys - anything you could lose. You can track an item to within 0.1ft. But in the wrong hands
column2: they can be used for a different purpose.

column1: If you create an item which is useful for tracking stolen items
column2: then you have also created a perfect tool for stalking
column3: says Eva Galperin
column4: Director of Cyber-Security at the Electronic Frontier Foundation.

column1: I have personally talked to several people who have found AirTags in their possession
column2: she says.

column1: Apple was aware
column2: long before it released AirTags
column3: that they could be used for criminal activity. On releasing them
column4: Apple said that ""AirTags are designed to track items not people"".

column1: They created a series of safeguards that
column2: they said
column3: would protect people from being tracked.

column1: People with an iPhone would be alerted if an unregistered AirTag was moving with them. And the AirTags would make a beeping noise when separated from an owner for a period of time.
In December
column2: the company also released an app which Android users can download. Tracker Detect allows users who aren't on the iOS operating system to be notified of a rogue AirTag.

column1: But for several reasons
column2: many people believe these safeguards don't go far enough.

column1: Anna Mahaney is from Georgia. She was alerted to an unknown device after she'd gone to the shopping mall.
I was pretty freaked out and I went to try to disable it. Every time I did that
column2: it said it couldn't connect to the server."" She went to an Apple Store
column3: where they suggested she should turn off her location settings.

column1: When she went to the local police
column2: they told her there had been another similar report in her area. She believes the device is somewhere on her car.

column1: The BBC has spoken to six women who all say they have been tracked with AirTags. One said she had found an AirTag taped to the inside of a bag. Others haven't been able to locate the tags.
All of them have questions about whether Apple is doing enough to stop their products from tracking people.
Apple says AirTags will make a beeping sound between 8-24 hours after a device is detected moving with an unregistered phone. But it's easy to register an AirTag
column2: and then disable it.

column1: Anna Mahaney says Apple Support told her this could be why she hasn't been able to find the AirTag: ""It looks like what could have happened in my case was that the person that owns the AirTag tracked me until I got home
column2: and then they turned off the AirTag.""

column1: This isn't the only potential loophole in Apple's AirTag safeguards. Apple's app
column2: designed for Android users to find an unwanted AirTag
column3: has been downloaded by a tiny percentage of Android phones

column1: The BBC asked Apple for figures on how many times the app has been downloaded on Google Play
column2: Android's default app store. Apple didn't say
column3: but Google Play puts the figure at around 100
column4: 000 downloads. To put that into context
column5: there are around 3 billion active Android devices around the world.

column1: Apple says that if you don't have an iPhone
column2: people will be notified with another safeguard - a beeping sound that plays after an unwanted AirTag is detected. But there are problems with this too.

column1: AirTags emit a 60 decibel beep. and it's really easy to muffle."" says Eva Galperin. ""I could muffle it just by closing it in my fist. I could muffle it by putting it between two couch cushions. It's impossible to hear by putting it
column2: say
column3: under your car bumper.""

column1: And the noise will only begin to play after eight hours. Critics argue that by then it is too late.
In Bloomingdale Illinois
column2: one police force has warned local residents about AirTags: ""We thought it was important to notify the people in our community that this is somewhat of an issue."" says Frank Giammarese
column3: director of public safety at Bloomingdale Police.

column1: Technology is great but unfortunately... some people have misused that.""
There is an argument that Apple is being unfairly targeted. It's easy to buy tracking devices on the internet.
The BBC asked its major competitor
column2: Tile
column3: what it was doing to protect the public from being tracked with its devices. Tile replied that it was ""developing a solution"" which would identify an unknown device near people. But that solution hasn't been released yet.

column1: The counter-argument is that AirTags are just very good at being located by a registered iPhone. The 'Find My' network uses almost a billion Apple devices around the world - and their Bluetooth connectivity - to create accurate and long-range tracking.
I want Apple to require these devices to ask permission before you can be followed
column2: says Anna Mahaney. ""With 'Find My Friends'
column3: if my husband wants validation
column4: I have to okay that and give it to him. I cannot rationalise why a stranger can follow me and I don't have to give consent.""

column1: Amber Norsworthy believes AirTags should not be sold until Apple can work out how to better alert people: ""They should stop selling them for a period of time until they can work out some safety boundaries.""
Eva Galperin believes Apple needs to create better safeguards: ""I want them to work with Google in order to give Androids the same level of detection automatically in the background
column2: as they already have for iPhones.""

column1: The BBC put these criticisms to Apple
column2: who said: ""We take customer safety very seriously and are committed to AirTag's privacy and security…If users ever feel their safety is at risk
column3: they are encouraged to contact local law enforcement
column4: who can work with Apple to provide any available information about the unknown AirTag.""

311;Was South Africa ignored over mild Omicron evidence?;2022-01-20T00:08:25.000Z;[];['south africa'
column2: 'omicron variant'
column3: 'coronavirus pandemic'];['africa'

column1: South African scientists - praised internationally for first detecting the Omicron variant - have accused Western nations of ignoring early evidence that the new Covid variant was ""dramatically"" milder than those which drove previous waves of the pandemic.
Two of South Africa's most prominent coronavirus experts told the BBC that Western scepticism about their work could be construed as ""racist
column2: or
column3: at least
column4: a refusal ""to believe the science because it came from Africa"".

column1: It seems like high-income countries are much more able to absorb bad news that comes from countries like South Africa
column2: said Prof Shabir Madhi
column3: a vaccine expert at Johannesburg's University of the Witwatersrand.

column1: When we're providing good news
column2: all of a sudden there's a whole lot of scepticism. I would call that racism.""

column1: Prof Salim Karim
column2: former head of the South African government's Covid advisory committee and vice-president of the International Science Council agrees.

column1: We need to learn from each other. Our research is rigorous. Everyone was expecting the worst [about Omicron] and when they weren't seeing it
column2: they were questioning whether our observations were sufficiently scientifically rigorous
column3: he said
column4: while acknowledging that the sheer number of new mutations in Omicron may have contributed to an abundance of scientific caution.

column1: South Africa's latest wave of Covid
column2: which began in late November 2021
column3: is now declining as sharply as it once rose and is likely to be declared over

column1: There are still concerns that the infection rate could spike again following the reopening of schools
column2: but
column3: overall
column4: the country's Omicron wave is expected to last half as long as previous waves.

column1: By early last month
column2: scientists and doctors here were already sharing anecdotal evidence indicating that Omicron
column3: while highly contagious
column4: was resulting in far fewer hospital admissions or deaths than the Delta wave.

column1: The predictions we made at the start of December still hold. Omicron was less severe. Dramatically. The virus is evolving to adapt to the human host
column2: to become like a seasonal virus
column3: said Prof Marta Nunes
column4: senior researcher at the Vaccines and Infectious Diseases Analytics department of the University of Witwatersrand.

column1: The WHO continues to warn against calling Omicron ""mild
column2: pointing out that its high transmissibility was causing a ""tsunami"" worldwide
column3: threatening to overwhelm health systems.

column1: But South African scientists are sticking by their data.
The death rate is completely different [with Omicron]. We've seen a very low mortality rate
column2: said Prof Karim
column3: who pointed to the latest data showing hospital admissions were four times lower than with Delta
column4: and the number of patients requiring ventilation was similarly reduced.

column1: It didn't take even two weeks before the first evidence started coming out that this is a much milder condition. And when we shared that with the world there was some scepticism
column2: Prof Karim added.

column1: It has been argued that Africa - or at least some parts of the continent - may be experiencing the pandemic differently due to demographics and other factors. South Africa's average age
column2: for instance
column3: is 17 years younger than the UK's.

column1: But scientists in South Africa insist that any demographic advantage the population might have in terms of battling Covid is outweighed by poor health. Excess deaths in South Africa during the pandemic now sit at 290
column3: 000 people - which is more than double the UK figure.

column1: The fact is that South Africa has got a much more susceptible population than the UK when it comes to severe disease. Yes
column2: we've got a younger population… but we've got an unhealthier population because of a higher prevalence of other co-morbidities including obesity and HIV
column3: said Prof Madhi.

column1: Each situation and each country has some unique characteristics. But we've learned how to extrapolate from one setting to another
column2: said Prof Karim.

column1: The figure of 290
column2: 000 excess deaths has not been confirmed as an accurate reflection of the pandemic's toll in South Africa. It is three times the number of official Covid-19 deaths.

column1: But scientists here believe a majority of those excess deaths are probably due to the pandemic. Half of them occurred during the Delta wave
column2: but
column3: so far
column4: only 3% transpired during the Omicron wave

column1: South Africa's government declined to introduce tighter restrictions during the Omicron wave and bitterly criticised foreign governments for their initial imposition of strict travel bans from the region.
Scientists here have generally welcomed the government's light-touch response
column2: and now argue that other countries might do well to follow its example.

column1: We believe the virus is not going to be eradicated from the human population. We must now learn how to live with this virus and it will learn how to live with us
column2: said Prof Nunes.

column1: The [low death rate from Omicron] shows we're in a different phase of the pandemic. I'd refer to it as a convalescent phase
column2: said Prof Madhi.

column1: He observed that South Africa had
column2: ""for all intents and purposes""
column3: stopped quarantining and contact tracing
column4: and he urged the government to stop testing for Covid-19 at a community level too
column5: saying it was unnecessary and amounted to pointless ""bean counting"".

column1: Instead
column2: he said the priority should be to minimise the number of people who are hospitalised by Covid-19.

column1: Prof Madhi also expressed concern that mixed messages about South Africa's growing success in fighting the pandemic could ""really diminish confidence in vaccines [despite the fact that] we know vaccines prevent severe disease"".
Although South Africa lags far behind countries like the UK in terms of vaccination rates
column2: at least three-quarters of the population now enjoys significant protection from a combination of prior infections and vaccinations.

column1: Prof Karim acknowledged that Omicron's high transmissibility was causing temporary problems for countries like the US
column2: but
column3: citing South Africa's own experience
column4: he said ""the good thing is that because [the infection rate] has gone up that fast
column5: it'll go down that fast too
column6: so the pressure on hospitals will be much less"".

312;False banana: Is Ethiopia's enset 'wondercrop' for climate change?;2022-01-21T06:47:45.000Z;[];['plants'
column2: 'agriculture'
column3: 'climate change'

column1: Scientists say the plant enset
column2: an Ethiopian staple
column3: could be a new superfood and a lifesaver in the face of climate change.

column1: The banana-like crop has the potential to feed more than 100 million people in a warming world
column2: according to a new study.

column1: The plant is almost unknown outside of Ethiopia
column2: where it is used to make porridge and bread.

column1: Research suggests the crop can be grown over a much larger range in Africa.
This is a crop that can play a really important role in addressing food security and sustainable development
column2: said Dr Wendawek Abebe of Hawassa University in Awasa
column3: Ethiopia.

column1: Enset or ""false banana"" is a close relative of the banana
column2: but is consumed only in one part of Ethiopia.

column1: The banana-like fruit of the plant is inedible
column2: but the starchy stems and roots can be fermented and used to make porridge and bread.

column1: Enset is a staple in Ethiopia
column2: where around 20 million people rely on it for food
column3: but elsewhere it has not been cultivated
column4: although wild relatives - which are not considered edible - grow as far south as South Africa
column5: suggesting the plant can tolerate a much wider range.

column1: Using agricultural surveys and modelling work
column2: scientists predicted the potential range of enset over the next four decades. They found the crop could potentially feed more than 100 million people and boost food security in Ethiopia and other African countries
column3: including Kenya

column1: Study researcher Dr James Borrell
column2: of the Royal Botanic Gardens
column3: Kew
column4: said planting enset as a buffer crop for lean times could help boost food security.

column1: It's got some really unusual traits that make it absolutely unique as a crop
column2: he said. ""You plant it at any time
column3: you harvest it at any time and it's perennial. That's why they call it the tree against hunger.""

column1: Ethiopia is a major centre of crop domestication in Africa
column2: home to coffee and many other crops.

column1: Climate change is predicted to seriously affect yields and distribution of staple food crops across Africa and beyond.
There is growing interest in seeking new plants to feed the world
column2: given our reliance on a few staple crops. Nearly half of all the calories we eat come from three species - rice
column3: wheat and maize.

column1: We need to diversify the plants we use globally as a species because all our eggs are in a very small basket at the moment
column2: said Dr Borrell.

column1: The research is published in Environmental Research Letters.

column1: An astrophysicist has been killed in a ""reckless"" shooting while visiting his girlfriend in the US state of Georgia.
At 02:00 local time (07:00 GMT) on Sunday
column2: officers were called to an apartment block in Clairmont Road in Brookhaven
column3: Atlanta.

column1: Dr Matthew Willson
column3: from Surrey
column5: was found in bed with a single gunshot wound to the head.

column1: The Foreign Office said it was ""supporting the family of a British man following his death"".
Brookhaven Police said the shooting of Dr Willson
column2: from Chertsey
column3: was ""random"" and involved the ""reckless discharge of firearms"".

column1: Dr Willson ""was in town from England visiting loved ones when the incident occurred
column2: police said.

column1: Police told local news station WSB-TV2 in Atlanta that it was ""a senseless act"" and Dr Willson was ""a completely innocent victim"".
Investigators also said he had just flown in to Atlanta.
Officers had earlier been called to a neighbouring block of flats after reports of gunshots. They received a second call regarding a ""person being shot"" while they were checking the area.
Dr Willson was a former PhD student at the University of Exeter in the south-west of England.
The university said in a statement that Dr Willson was a ""much-loved member of our astrophysics team"".
It added: ""Our hearts go out to his family
column2: friends and colleagues. We are offering support to colleagues at the university who will also want to commemorate his life.""

column1: Dr Willson also worked as a postdoctoral researcher at Georgia State University between 2017 and 2019
column2: the university said.

column1: No suspects have been arrested and police are seeking information from the public. Authorities are offering a cash reward for tips that lead to an arrest.
Sgt Jake Kissel from Brookhaven Police described the location of the shooting as ""a generally safe area"".

Sgt Kissel told BBC Radio Surrey that officers ""immediately responded to the priority call of someone being shot and that's where they met with a female caller who was rendering aid to her boyfriend who had been shot dead"".
He said: ""We are asking for our public's help in assisting us with this investigation.
Our investigators are currently following up on all leads to include potential video
column2: eyewitness accounts as well as the evidence that was left on scene.""

column1: At least 100 people have been killed or wounded in an air strike by the Saudi-led coalition which hit a detention centre in Yemen.
The incident happened when a facility was struck in Saada
column2: a stronghold of the rebel Houthi movement
column3: on Friday.

column1: It followed nights of intensified bombing raids in the wake of a deadly Houthi attack on the UAE
column2: a Saudi ally.

column1: Saudi Arabia has led a coalition of Arab states in a war against the rebels since 2015 which has devastated Yemen.
Tens of thousands of civilians
column2: including more than 10
column3: 000 children
column4: have been killed or wounded as a direct result of the fighting.

column1: Millions have been displaced and much of the population stands on the brink of famine.
Hours after the air strike
column2: rescue workers were still pulling bodies out of the rubble
column3: and hopes of finding survivors are fading
column4: says BBC Middle East correspondent Anna Foster.

column1: The exact death toll is unclear. Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) said at least 70 people were killed
column2: though the number is expected to rise.

column1: Houthi-run television showed pictures from the scene of men clearing debris with their hands and of wounded at a local hospital. MSF said one hospital had received more than 200 casualties.
There are many bodies still at the scene of the air strike
column2: many missing people
column3: Ahmed Mahat
column5: told AFP news agency. ""It is impossible to know how many people have been killed. It seems to have been a horrific act of violence.""

column1: Further south
column2: three children were killed as they were playing football when an air strike hit a telecommunications facility in the rebel-held port city of Hudaydah
column3: Save the Children aid agency said.

column1: There was a near countrywide internet outage around the same time
column2: which Houthi media blamed on the attack on the telecommunications site.

column1: Saudi Arabia said the coalition had carried out air strikes in Hudaydah but did not mention the attack in Saada.

The coalition has stepped up air strikes since the Houthis carried out a rare drone and missile attack on the UAE on Monday. Three civilians were killed in what was the first deadly attack of its kind in the emirates.

318;Like a drone that you sit in – but would you feel safe?;2022-01-21T01:11:52.000Z;[];['transport'
column2: 'drones'
column3: 'air travel'];['wings'

column1: Peter Ternstrom was about nine years old when he first saw the movie
column2: Return of the Jedi
column3: at the cinema. The scene in which Luke and Leia take to hover-bikes on a high-speed chase through a forest left a particular impression on him.

column1: Absolutely
column2: that has been an important inspiration for me
column3: says Mr Ternstrom
column4: who co-founded Swedish firm Jetson with Tomasz Patan.

column1: Recently
column2: his company released a video of its prototype personal flying machine
column3: the Jetson ONE
column4: in action. The clip quickly clocked more than 12m views on YouTube in about four weeks.

column1: The filming location
column2: a desert-like area
column3: was deliberately chosen for its sci-fi feel. It is actually a military training ground in Poland.

column1: A helmeted pilot sits in the centre of what looks like a large drone
column2: with its multiple spinning rotors. The craft zooms across the landscape
column3: blowing up dust.

column1: This is an electric vertical take-off and landing vehicle
column2: or eVTOL. Personal eVTOLs are among the smallest rideable aircraft around and generally have capacity to transport just one passenger - the pilot.

column1: The vehicle's diminutive size helps to keep down their price tag but there is another advantage for firms seeking to sell them. In the US
column2: the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) says that ultra-light vehicles - which weigh less than 254lbs (115kg) and have a maximum speed of 55kts (63mph; 101km/h) - can be flown without a pilot's certificate.

column1: This is the route that Jetson and a number of other firms are taking in order to get their products on to the market. But will these new-fangled flying machines actually be safe
column2: especially if just about anyone can buy one?

column1: Mr Ternstrom for one
column2: is being slightly more cautious than he's legally required to be. The first Jetson ONEs will sell in 2023
column3: if all goes to plan
column4: but the founder says he wants the first owners to be people who hold

column1: If you have previous experience
column2: we have said
column3: 'OK
column6: he explains. These people will be ""ambassadors"" for the brand
column7: he says. Everyone who buys one
column11: will also get a two-day training course in Tuscany

column1: There has certainly been lots of interest from prospective owners. Three and a half weeks after the firm published its video
column2: Jetson had taken pre-orders for 118 aircraft.

column1: The Jetson ONE currently offers 20 minutes of flight time on a fully charged battery. But in a couple of years' time
column2: Mr Ternstrom predicts this will rise to 30 minutes
column3: thanks to better battery technology. As for safety
column4: the drone is built with crumple zones around the pilot's seat to cushion the impact of a low-altitude crash.

column1: The vehicle can also continue flying after losing one of its propellers - though pilots in such situations will be prompted to land immediately.
Plus
column2: on-board software will attempt to automatically prevent dangerous flying behaviour. The software slows the vehicle down as it approaches the ground
column3: for instance
column4: and uses a Lidar (light detection and ranging) system to sense how far away the ground actually is.

column1: But Mr Ternstrom knows that there is still the potential for things to go wrong
column2: which is partly why he has stipulated that the first owners must have some flying experience.

column1: This is a machine made for mischief
column2: basically
column3: he adds. ""I want them to be very responsible.""

column1: More technology of business:
No eVTOL aircraft are currently certified to fly in the UK
column2: though the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) expects that the first flights of such vehicles could begin within five years - and this is likely to be for commercial rather than personal operation.

column1: With that in mind
column2: it is vital that a strong safety culture is built into the heart of eVTOL vehicles
column3: says David Tait
column4: head of innovation at the CAA.

column1: The Jetson ONE is far from the only vehicle of its kind in development. The US-based company Opener will also soon bring its aircraft
column2: the single-seater BlackFly
column3: to market.

column1: A spokeswoman for the firm says safety is Opener's first priority. ""General adoption of eVTOL technology is not possible without it
column2: she adds. New owners will have to take a training course before the company allows them to fly.

column1: There's also the TeTra Mk5
column2: which uses a combination of rotors and fixed wings to power itself. It also carries just one person but is too heavy to be classed as ultralight. However
column3: it comes as kit-aircraft so must be assembled by the new owner
column4: meaning that TeTra can sell the vehicle in the US
column6: without having to obtain full aircraft certification.

column1: That's why we're producing the kit planes
column2: says Tasuku Nakai
column3: chief executive at TeTra.

column1: Some companies however
column2: are going for full aircraft certification which can be a long process. Including AIR
column3: an Israeli firm
column4: which is designing a two-seater eVTOL. Chief executive and co-founder Rani Plaut says his company has been working with the FAA for nearly two and a half years. The certification process takes so long partly because electric propulsion is a relatively new frontier for flying machines

column1: AIR's vehicle
column2: the AIR ONE
column3: is designed to continue flying even if it loses one rotor

column1: If worst comes to worst
column2: we have a ballistic parachute system
column3: says Mr Plaut. He says the firm aims to deliver its first vehicles to customers in 2024

column1: Many of these vehicles still require hundreds of hours of test flights
column2: to ensure they fly as intended. And it remains to be seen exactly how responsible their eager new owners will be when they take them out for a spin.

column1: We know that most aircraft accidents are caused by the user. Hopefully the manufacturers will put into place certain safeguards in the system to limit the ability for a user to put the aircraft in an unsafe operating condition
column2: says Darrell Swanson
column3: director of Swanson Aviation Consultancy.

column1: The relatively easy route to market that these very small eVTOLs are taking will get them into people's hands quickly
column2: and allow early adopters to have some fun
column3: says Mr Swanson.

column1: That's all well and good in the near-term
column2: he says. But if these aircraft are to play a role in improving urban mobility for city populations
column3: they will have to carry more passengers
column7: ""the price will go up and it'll be seen as elitist.""

column1: For now
column2: Mr Ternstrom is happy to market the Jetson ONE purely as a recreational vehicle. It is for having fun
column3: he says. After all
column4: practically everyone has had that thrilling dream where they can fly.

column1: This thing makes that dream possible
column2: he says. ""It's just awesome. I love it.""

319;Tonga volcano: Plume reached half-way to space;2022-01-21T16:15:56.000Z;[];['earth science'
column2: 'volcanoes'
column3: 'tonga volcano and tsunami'

column1: An indicator of the great power of last Saturday's volcanic eruption in Tonga is the height reached by its plume.
UK scientists examining weather satellite data calculate it to be around 55km (35 miles) above the Earth's surface.
This is at the boundary of the stratosphere and mesosphere layers in the atmosphere.
Dr Simon Proud
column2: from RAL Space
column3: said these were ""unheard-of altitudes"" for a volcanic plume.

column1: The most powerful eruption in the second half of the 20th Century came from Mount Pinatubo in 1991. Its plume is thought to have climbed to roughly 40km.
However
column2: it's possible today's more accurate satellites would have given a higher altitude for the Philippines event
column3: cautioned Dr Proud
column4: who is affiliated to the UK National Centre for Earth Observation.

column1: To work out the position in the sky of the plume from Tonga's Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Ha'apai volcano
column2: data from three weather satellites - Himawari-8 (Japan) GOES-17 (USA) and GK2A (Korean) - was used.

column1: Because they're all at different longitudes
column2: we can use the parallax between their views of the eruption to determine altitude. This is a pretty well established technique for storm cloud heights
column3: and should actually work better here as the altitude [and hence parallax] is greater

column1: Only a small part of the cloud is seen to get to 55km. This is most likely water vapour
column2: rather than ash
column3: that was pushed upward at the head of the updraft. The main umbrella of the plume is at 35km. A lower plume feature is evident in the lowest layer of the atmosphere - the troposphere.

column1: The so-called Kármán line
column2: which is often quoted as the atmospheric boundary with outer space
column3: is at 100km.

column1: US space agency scientists calculated the explosive force to be equivalent to 10 megatons of TNT
column2: which would have made the Tonga event 500 times as powerful as the nuclear bomb dropped on Hiroshima
column3: Japan
column4: at the end of World War Two.

column1: Prof Shane Cronin
column2: from Auckland University
column3: New Zealand
column4: believes a special set of conditions came together at the underwater volcano to drive a big explosion.

column1: A key factor
column2: he said
column3: was the depth below the ocean surface at which gas-rich magma came into contact with seawater - at just 150-250m.

column1: When the magma came out
column2: there was not much pressure on it [from the water above]
column3: he told the BBC's Science In Action programme on World Service Radio.

column1: The gases expanded and blasted the magma apart. And then
column2: as those little fragments of hot magma at 1
column3: 100 degrees encountered the cold seawater at 20 degrees
column4: it flashed the seawater around those particles into steam. And when you do that
column5: when you flash water into steam
column6: you basically expand the volume by 70 times. So you supercharge your eruption.""

column1: Early data suggests the Tonga event could have measured as high as five on the volcanic explosivity index (VEI). This would certainly make it the most powerful eruption since Pinatubo
column2: which was classified at six on the eight-point scale.

column1: The Philippines volcano famously dropped Earth's average global temperature by half a degree for a couple of years. It did this by injecting 15 million tonnes of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere. SO2 combines with water to make a haze of tiny droplets
column2: or aerosols
column3: that reflect incoming solar radiation.

column1: However
column2: Dr Richard Betts
column3: the head of climate impacts at the UK Met Office
column4: said Hunga-Tonga Hunga-Ha'apai would not have the same effect.

column1: Pinatubo did have a noticeable effect
column2: but the Hunga-Tonga volcano's emissions were more than 30 times smaller at less than half a million tonnes of sulphur dioxide
column3: so we don't expect that to have a cooling effect
column4: even though it made a huge bang when it went off

320;Franco Mulakkal: Hundreds write to Kerala nun who lost rape case against bishop;2022-01-21T00:51:06.000Z;[];['sexual violence'
column2: 'rape in india'
column3: 'india'];['franco'

column1: Letters of support have been pouring in for an Indian nun after a bishop she had accused of repeatedly raping her was cleared by a trial court last week.
For the past two days
column2: my social media timeline has been full of handwritten messages of support for the 50-year-old nun  who had accused Bishop Franco Mulakkal of raping her 13 times between 2014 and 2016.

column1: Most of the posts are from women
column2: including activists
column3: feminists
column4: journalists and celebrities in the southern state of Kerala and many contain hashtags such as #withthenuns and #avalkoppam - a Malayalam-language word which means ""with her"".

column1: The letters pledge support to ""the nun in her fight for justice"" - sometimes they just carry words of encouragement or snatches of poetry
column2: or contain drawings and artwork.

column1: In these dark times
column2: you are that ray of hope to millions
column3: one wrote quoting Emily Dickinson. Another quoted from Still I Rise
column4: Maya Angelou's poem that's become an anthem for feminists across the world.

column1: Many wrote in saying they ""believed"" her words even though the trial court judge did not.

The accusations of rape against Bishop Franco have made headlines in India. The case shocked one of the country's oldest Christian communities and sparked widespread protests after the nun alleged that the Catholic Church had ignored her complaints.
A powerful priest
column2: Bishop Franco was arrested only in 2018 after a group of nuns sat on a hunger strike outside the Kerala high court. The Vatican temporarily relieved him of his duties. A month later
column3: he was freed on bail.

column1: Over the years
column2: the woman had been shamed on social media and one local politician was chastised by the National Commission for Women after he described her as a ""prostitute"".

column1: Bishop Franco denied the charges against him and last Friday a trial court in Kottayam city found him not guilty.

Additional Sessions Judge (ASJ) G Gopakumar said there were ""exaggerations and embellishments in the statement of the victim"" and the prosecution had failed to prove the charges against the bishop. He also spoke of rivalry in the church.
When it is not feasible to separate truth from falsehood
column2: when grain and chaff are inextricably mixed up
column3: the only available course is to discard the evidence in toto. This court is unable to place reliance on the testimony of the nun... so I acquit the accused

column1: The verdict shocked many
column2: but once the 289-page order became publicly available
column3: it led to massive outrage in India with many pointing out that the judge seemed to be questioning the woman's conduct and moral character.

column1: When I read the judgement
column2: I was shell shocked. I have only two words to describe it: judicial porn
column3: historian and feminist researcher J Devika told the BBC.

column1: The order was not just to exonerate the bishop
column2: it was also to demoralise the survivor and the other nuns who had supported her. It contains graphic descriptions of sexual acts and assault as narrated by the nun. The judge even details a breast examination she underwent. What was the need for any of that?"" she added.

column1: A former Kerala high court judge called the verdict ""a clear case of miscarriage of justice"" and many activists and lawyers criticised it for focusing on the woman's conduct.

Many asked if there was an appropriate way for rape victims to behave and the case drew comparisons with the acquittal last year of former magazine editor Tarun Tejpal that led to accusations of victim shaming.
In the case of the Kerala nun too
column2: ASJ Gopakumar asked why she had not stayed back at her sister's home after attending a religious event there but returned to the convent with the accused.

column1: The Indian Supreme Court has repeatedly ruled that in rape cases
column2: the judges must not comment on the behaviour or character of the woman and the only question they should ask is - did the accused commit rape?

column1: But you get the sense the nun was on trial here
column2: says Ms Devika.

column1: The judge completely ignored the social setting in which the alleged crime happened. In the church
column2: even the senior-most nun has to defer to the junior-most priest. And Bishop Franco is a very powerful man. But the judge overlooked that power dynamic.""

column1: Now as the state readies to appeal against the order in the high court
column2: there has been an outpouring of support for the nun.

column1: Some of us came together and said let's do something to support her and five other sisters who have been helping her
column2: to keep their morale up
column3: said Athira Sujatha
column4: a public policy professional and activist and one of the organisers of the letter-writing campaign.

column1: On Wednesday morning at 11am - the exact time on Friday when ASJ Gopakumar had pronounced his order in court - Athira posted a letter on Instagram announcing the campaign.
Your steadfast support to upholding justice by talking truth to power has been an extraordinary feat of hope and courage - not just to the survivor in this particular case but to survivors
column2: bystanders and witnesses everywhere
column3: she wrote.

column1: Within two hours
column2: she told the BBC
column3: they had received about 200 letters. In 24 hours
column5: 000. Many others shared their letters on Facebook

column1: Many addressed their letters to ""Sister X"" (the nun) while many expressed gratitude to the ""Sisters"" - five nuns who have been a pillar of support for her.
Many of them wrote about their personal experiences
column2: saying that the nun's fight had given them the courage to speak out too.

column1: Girls like me across this seemingly unjust land are praying for you... You are loved
column2: respected and honoured. There 'will' be light at the end of this really dark tunnel
column3: wrote popular singer Chinmayi Sripada.

column1: Filmmaker Geetu Mohandas wrote: ""It will by no means be an easy task
column2: but you can
column3: and indeed you will

column1: One woman drew pencil sketches of the nuns with a message in Malayalam applauding them: ""Your courage and persistence is unparalleled. No movement to get justice is a lost cause.""
Athira says when they put out the message asking people to mail their letters
column2: they were apprehensive about what sort of letters they would get.

column1: But we have not received one single negative message. People understand that the sisters need our support and they are all offering encouragement and solidarity.""
In her letter written in Malayalam
column2: Ms Devika compared the sisters to fireflies.

column1: There may be sceptics who say that the fireflies cannot beat the night... Please tell them... If millions of fireflies get together
column2: they may beat this unending night
column3: she wrote.

column1: The Taliban can threaten with a whisper. After 20 years of violent struggle
column2: and the loss of tens of thousands of civilian lives
column3: they took power here using brutal force.

column1: Even so
column2: Afghan women refuse to be intimidated.

column1: Tamana Zaryabi Paryani is one of those women. It takes raw courage to stand up to armed men who want to take away almost everything you have achieved in life.
Last weekend
column2: she joined dozens of others to demand the right to work and the right to an education. The protesters were pepper-sprayed by Taliban fighters
column3: and a number said they had been stunned by electric shocks.

column1: After making their voices heard
column2: they returned home. Some feared they had been followed.

column1: On Wednesday night
column3: armed men entered Tamana Paryani's apartment block in Kabul's Parwan 2 neighbourhood. She was alone at home with her sisters. The men began to kick the door.

column1: Please help
column2: the Taliban have come to my house
column3: my sisters are at home
column4: Ms Paryani pleaded on a video posted to social media.

column1: We don't want you here now
column2: she screamed. ""Come back tomorrow
column3: we can speak tomorrow

column1: You can't see these girls at this time of night. Help
column2: the Taliban have come to my house
column3: she said before the video ended.

column1: Since the Taliban took power on 15 August
column2: women have complained that they are now prisoners in their own homes.

column1: And even there they are not safe. It is a violation of Afghan culture to enter a home that contains only women.
But having dismissed women police officers
column2: the Taliban do not have female personnel available to question women.

column1: Tamana Paryani has been missing for two days now. I went to her apartment to try and trace her.
There was no-one inside the home. A large muddy boot-print was still visible on the front door.
Neighbours said Ms Paryani had been taken away along with two of her sisters
column2: and no-one has been to the apartment since. They would say only that ""an armed group"" had taken the sisters.

column1: Other women protesters were targeted that night. Another
column2: Parawana Ibrahimkhel
column3: is also missing. Still

column1: In an interview with the BBC on Thursday
column2: Suhai Shaheen
column3: who hopes to become the Taliban's ambassador to the UN
column5: they would say they have detained them
column6: and if that is the allegation they will go to court and they will defend themselves... This is something legal
column7: but if they are not detained
column8: and they are making such fake scenes and shooting films in order to seek asylum abroad.""

column1: This video can not be played
One of Miss Paryani's friends told a different story.
From a safe location
column2: in an interview with the BBC
column3: she said
column4: ""I told her as soon as possible
column6: take this more seriously you are in danger… When I got home
column8: also a protester - I don't want to mention her name - she was crying that Tamana had been arrested by the Taliban and that she had released a video on social media.""

column1: It is not known if the authorities are looking for the women.
Most of the world refuses to recognise the Taliban as the legitimate rulers of Afghanistan. More than half the population is going hungry because of Western-imposed sanctions.
Under Taliban rule Afghanistan has become the only country in the world which publicly limits education on the basis of gender
column2: which is a major sticking point in the Taliban's quest for legitimacy
column3: and in the lifting of sanctions. The regular protests by women highlighting the issue are a source of embarrassment to the group.

column1: Regardless of who has Tamara Paryani
column2: her sisters and her friends
column3: the Taliban are collectively punishing Afghan women.

column1: Over the past 20 years women here have cast off cultural and family prejudice to live more freely -  decades of progress the Taliban appear determined to destroy.

The crew from Darlington removed the rim and freed Edward after his head got lodged in the potty.
It was not your 'bog' standard rescue
column2: said the County Durham and Darlington Fire and Rescue Service.

column1: Somehow
column2: he had managed to get his training seat stuck round his head
column3: but our crews got to work quickly and managed to release him in no time.""

column1: Some 90 tonnes of US ""lethal aid"" has arrived in Ukraine
column2: amid tensions over Russia's troop build-up on the border.

column1: It was the first shipment of a recently approved package of US military aid for Ukraine
column2: and included ammunition for ""front-line defenders"".

column1: The delivery followed US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv this week
column2: where he warned of a tough response if Russia was to invade.

column1: Moscow has denied any plans to attack or invade Ukraine.
US President Joe Biden approved the $200m (£147.5m) security support package in December.
The US embassy in Kyiv said the shipment demonstrated its ""firm commitment to Ukraine's sovereign right to self-defense"".

The United States will continue providing such assistance to support Ukraine's Armed Forces in their ongoing effort to defend Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity against Russian aggression
column2: it wrote on Facebook.

column1: Ukrainian Defence Minister Oleksiy Reznikov thanked the US for the aid.
The shipment arrived hours after Russia's foreign minister and his US counterpart held what they called ""frank"" talks to try to reduce the chance of a wider conflict in Ukraine.
Russia has seized Ukrainian territory before
column2: annexing the Crimean peninsula in 2014. Since then
column3: some 14
column4: 000 people have been killed and at least two million fled their homes because of fighting between the Ukrainian army and Russian-backed rebels. A fragile peace agreement was made in 2015.

column1: Now
column2: the head of the military defence alliance Nato has warned there is a real risk of a fresh conflict in Europe after an estimated 100
column3: 000 Russian troops amassed on the border.

column1: Moscow has denied it is planning an invasion
column2: but President Vladimir Putin has issued demands to the West which he says concern Russia's security
column3: including that Ukraine be stopped from joining Nato.

column1: He also wants Nato to abandon military exercises and stop sending weapons to eastern Europe
column2: seeing this as a direct threat to Russia's security.

column3: 'outrage'

column1: Shots have been heard near the presidential palace in Burkina Faso's capital amid a mutiny by soldiers.
Gunfire has also been heard at several barracks in Ouagadougou
column2: with soldiers demanding the sacking of military chiefs
column3: and more resources to fight militant Islamists.

column1: Hundreds of people came out in support of the troops
column2: forcing authorities to introduce a night time curfew.

column1: The government said the crisis had been contained.
It dismissed rumours of a new coup attempt
column2: just over a week after 11 soldiers were detained for allegedly plotting a coup.

column1: It is the latest sign of growing discontent with President Roch Kaboré's government over its failure to quell the Islamist insurgency that has devastated the West African state since 2015.
Protesters in support of the soldiers set fire to the ruling party's headquarters.
Gunshots were heard at military camps in the west and south of the capital
column2: and at an air base near the main airport.

column1: Soldiers convicted of a coup attempt in 2015 are imprisoned at the camp in the west
column2: known as Sangoule Lamizana.

column1: Shooting was also heard at military bases in the northern towns of Kaya and Ouahigouya
column2: the US embassy said.

column1: The mutineers made several demands
column2: including:

column1: In a televised address to the nation earlier
column2: Defence Minister Barthélémy Simporé said there were ""localised
column3: limited"" incidents ""in a few barracks""
column4: and none of the ""republican institutions"" had been targeted.

column1: Gen Simporé urged people to continue with their normal activities
column2: saying the government would release further information in due course.

column1: The location of President Kaboré is unclear
column2: but the defence minister denied rumours circulating on social media that he was under arrest.

column1: Internet monitoring group NetBlocks said that access to the web had been disrupted.
The killing of 53 people by suspected jihadists in November heightened public outrage against the government
column2: and raised fears that the military would take power - just as it had in neighbouring Mali in May.

column1: On Saturday
column2: dozens of people were arrested in Ouagadougou for holding a banned rally to protest against what they described as the government's inability to deal with the militants.

column1: Mr Kaboré
column2: a former banker and prime minister
column3: became president after winning elections in 2015.

column1: The polls were the first since long-serving ruler Blaise Compaoré went into exile a year earlier following a popular uprising against his rule.

column1: 340;The people deciding to ditch their smartphones;2022-01-24T00:27:05.000Z;[];['addiction'
column2: 'life'
column3: 'mobile phones'

column1: In a world where many of us are glued to our smartphones
column2: Dulcie Cowling is something of an anomaly - she has ditched hers.

column1: The 36-year-old decided at the end of last year that getting rid of her handset would improve her mental health. So
column2: over Christmas she told her family and friends that she was switching to an old Nokia phone that could only make and receive calls and text messages.

column1: She recalls that one of the pivotal moments that led to her decision was a day at the park with her two boys
column2: aged six and three: ""I was on my mobile at a playground with the kids and I looked up and every single parent - there was up to 20 - were looking at their phones
column3: just scrolling away

column1: I thought 'when did this happen?'. Everyone is missing out on real life. I don't think you get to your death bed and think you should have spent more time on Twitter
column2: or reading articles online.""

column1: Ms Cowling
column2: who is a creative director at London-based advertising agency Hell Yeah!
column3: adds that the idea to abandon her smartphone had built up during the Covid lockdowns.

column1: I thought about how much of my life is spent looking at the phone and what else could I do. Being constantly connected to lots of services creates a lot of distractions
column2: and is a lot for the brain to process.""

column1: She plans to use the time gained from quitting her smartphone to read and sleep more.
About nine out of 10 people in the UK now own a smartphone
column2: a figure broadly replicated across the developed world. And we are glued to them - one recent study found that the average person spends 4.8 hours a day on their handset.

column1: Yet a small
column2: but growing number of people
column3: enough is enough.

column1: Alex Dunedin binned his smartphone two years ago. ""Culturally we have become addicted to these tools
column2: says the educational researcher and technology expert. ""They are blunting cognition and impeding productivity.""

column1: Mr Dunedin
column2: who lives and works in Scotland
column3: says another reason behind his decision was environmental concerns. ""We are wasting exponential amounts of energy producing exponential amounts of CO2 emissions

column1: He has become happier and more productive since he stopped using a smartphone
column2: he says. Mr Dunedin doesn't even have an old-fashioned mobile phone or even a landline anymore. He is instead only electronically contactable via emails to his home computer.

column1: It has improved my life
column2: he says. ""My thoughts are freed up from constantly being cognitively connected to a machine that I need to feed with energy and money. I think that the danger of technologies is that they are emptying our lives.""

column1: Lynne Voyce
column2: a 53-year-old teacher and writer from Birmingham
column3: has moved in the opposite direction - she started using a smartphone again last August after a break of six years.

column1: She says she was reluctantly compelled to buy one again due to having to deal with QR codes in restaurants
column2: and so-called Covid passports
column3: plus making it easier to keep in touch with one of her daughters who lives in Paris.

column1: But she plans to give up it up again
column2: if she can. ""After the pandemic
column3: and when Ella [her eldest daughter] isn't living abroad
column4: I might try and give it up again. It sounds like an addiction

column1: When Ms Voyce first abandoned her smartphone back in 2016 it was to help encourage her daughters to reduce the time they spent on their handsets.
They were glued to their phones. I thought the only way to stop it was to get rid of my own phone. And it made all the difference.
For example
column2: we'd got to a restaurant
column3: and they would no longer see me pick up my phone.""

column1: Not having a smartphone ""took a lot of pressure off my brain"" she says
column2: ""I didn't feel like I had to instantly answer things or be available when out"".

column1: Yet
column2: while some worry about how much time they spend on their handset
column3: for millions of others they are a godsend.

column1: More than ever
column2: access to healthcare
column3: education
column4: social services and often to our friends and family is digital
column5: and the smartphone is an essential lifeline for people
column6: says a spokesperson for UK mobile network Vodafone.

column1: We also create resources to help people get the most from their tech
column2: as well as to stay safe when they're online - that's hugely important.""

column1: However
column2: Hilda Burke
column3: a psychotherapist and author of The Phone Addiction Workbook
column4: says there is a strong link between heavy device usage and relationship issues
column6: our ability to switch off and relax

column1: Many people have a constant drip feed of requests coming their way via their device
column2: many with a false sense of urgency.

column1: They feel unable to lay boundaries down
column2: with the result that they feel compelled to check their emails and messages last thing at night and first thing in the morning.""

column1: If getting rid of your smartphone seems too much but you are concerned that you spend too much time on it
column2: there are other measures you can take to reduce your usage.

column1: While it might initially seen counterintuitive
column2: more apps are emerging to curtail mindless scrolling.

column1: For example
column2: Freedom lets you temporarily block apps and websites so you can focus more. And Off The Grid enables you to block off your phone for a certain time period.

column1: New Tech Economy is a series exploring how technological innovation is set to shape the new emerging economic landscape.

Ms Burke says it would be useful if more people monitored how much time they spend on their smartphone. ""Starting to realise exactly how much time you're frittering away each day on your phone can be a powerful wake-up call and catalyst for change.""
She also advises carving out short periods when you have your phone switched off or left at home
column2: and gradually increase the wait period till you check it again.

column1: Finally
column2: she recommends choosing an image or a word that represents what you would rather be doing - if only you had more time - as your phone's screensaver.

column1: Considering most of us check our phones 55 times per day and some of us even 100 times
column2: this is a great visual reminder of a more valuable way to spend your precious time
column3: she says.

column1: Some of those wounded were seriously injured
column2: police said on Twitter.

column1: Heidelberg is a university town in the southwest of Germany.
Police have asked people to avoid the area so rescue workers and emergency services are able to move around freely.
Germany has been hit in recent years by a spate of attacks
column2: mostly carried out by jihadists or far-right militants.

column1: The country has some of the strictest gun laws in Europe
column2: and school shootings are rare. Anyone under 25 is required to pass a psychological evaluation before getting a gun licence.

column1: German newspaper Bild reported that the shooter was a student at the university
column2: and had opened fire in the lecture hall before turning the gun on himself.

343;Indoor PM birthday event was held during lockdown
column3: 'boris johnson'

column1: Downing Street has admitted that staff gathered inside No 10 to celebrate Boris Johnson's birthday when the first Covid lockdown was still in place.
ITV News reports up to 30 people attended the June 2020 event
column2: sang Happy Birthday and were served cake.

column1: No 10 said staff had ""gathered briefly"" to ""wish the prime minister a happy birthday""
column2: adding that he had been there ""for less than 10 minutes"".

column1: Rules at the time banned most indoor gatherings of more than two people.
ITV News said the birthday event had taken place in the Cabinet Room just after 2pm on 19 June 2020
column2: adding that it had been a surprise for Mr Johnson after he returned from an official trip to a school in Hertfordshire.

column1: It also reported that family and friends had been hosted in the prime minister's residence that evening.
But a No 10 spokesperson said: ""This is totally untrue. In line with the rules at the time the prime minister hosted a small number of family members outside that evening.""
Under the Covid restrictions at the time
column2: up to six people could gather outside
column3: in a socially distanced manner.

column1: But gatherings inside of two or more people were still not permitted indoors
column2: except for certain reasons such as work or education.

column1: A No 10 spokesperson said: ""A group of staff working in No 10 that day gathered briefly in the Cabinet Room after a meeting to wish the prime minister a happy birthday. He was there for less than 10 minutes.""
But Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: ""This is yet more evidence that we have got a prime minister who believes that the rules that he made don't apply to him.
And so we have got a prime minister and a government who spend their whole time mopping up sleaze and deceit.""
Sir Keir also repeated his call for Mr Johnson to resign.
The reports of a party for the PM's birthday come as senior civil servant Sue Gray is compiling her report into gatherings on government premises during Covid restrictions.
It is expected to be published later this week.

column1: 348;Hippos can recognise their friends' voices;2022-01-24T18:41:19.000Z;[];['animals'];['strangers'
column2: 'tell'
column3: 'apart'

column1: Wild hippos are noisy creatures
column2: their calls travelling long distances across lakes and rivers.

column1: But until now the precise function of the loud ""wheeze honks"" the animals make has been a mystery.
Scientists studying hippos at a nature reserve in Africa say the distinctive honks enable the large mammals to tell friend from foe.
And the team says the animals can probably recognise individuals from their ""voices"".
Study leader
column2: Prof Nicolas Mathevon
column3: from the University of Saint-Etienne
column5: has studied the sounds animals make across the world

column1: He said hippos have a wide vocal repertoire
column2: including grunts
column3: bellows
column5: but very little is known about their social communication.

column1: ""In their call
column2: there is information about the identity of the individual - so they have 'voices' - and they are able to recognise each other by their voices
column3: he said. ""This recognition ability supports the social relationships between individuals.""

column1: To find out more about hippo communication
column2: French researchers recorded the sounds of hippos living in the Maputo Special Reserve in Mozambique.

column1: The wheeze-honk is the most common hippo call and the loudest- travelling as far as 1km
column2: according to the study.

column1: The biologists recorded the wheeze-honks of hippos and broadcast these from the shore of lakes to see how other individuals responded.
They found hippos could tell apart friends
column2: neighbours and strangers from their voices. In addition to telling apart friend from foe (or
column3: at least
column5: the animals can probably distinguish between individuals
column6: according to the researchers - though they can't be absolutely certain of this.

column1: And despite appearing to be lounging around on the water
column2: the large mammals were clearly paying close attention to their surroundings and responded immediately to the broadcasts.

column1: The animals responded more aggressively to unknown hippos - with quicker
column2: louder and more frequent calls
column3: often accompanied by territorial displays of dung spraying.

column1: Prof Mathevon said it was important to learn more about the biology and behaviour of hippos to help avoid human-animal conflicts.
The knowledge might also assist with conservation
column2: he said
column3: as wild hippos are sometimes moved from one location to another to keep local populations healthy.

column1: The work may inspire conservationists to make recordings to allow local hippos to get used to the voice of the new ones before they arrive
column2: he added.

column1: Hippos are not yet endangered in the wild
column2: but their numbers are plummeting fast. They are a source of animal-human conflict
column3: with hippos causing hundreds of human deaths a year.

column1: The research is published in Current Biology.
