349;The aurora hunters who chase the Northern Lights;2022-01-23T09:37:41.000Z;[];['photography'
column2: 'northern lights'];['vividly'
column3: 'night'

column1: This video can not be played
Some people are prepared to stand for hours in the freezing cold on a winter's night to watch and capture the Northern Lights. Meet the aurora hunters.
Michelle Cumming has been fascinated with the Northern Lights since she saw the phenomenon for the first time in September 2020.
I've made last minute dashes in my unicorn PJs
column2: says the 42-year-old
column3: who lives in Moray on Scotland's north east coast

column1: And I've had my backpack and flask prepared to go aurora hunting.
I often take my dog Dexter with me
column2: wrapping him up in a fleece blanket while we stand and watch the aurora. There have been several 1am excursions.""

column1: Michelle
column2: who works in admin at Moray Council
column3: says her first encounter was during a walk on a beach at Lossiemouth.

column1: That night blew me away
column2: she says. ""Not only did the aurora show but it danced.

column1: What I remember most vividly from that night is not only my awe at seeing such a sight
column2: it was the chorus of wonder from the spectators in the darkness further down the promenade.""

column1: The aurora is a natural phenomena caused by geomagnetic storms from the Sun. It can appear in the sky as rays of light which shimmer and ""dance"".
Dark autumn and winter nights offer the best chance of seeing displays - if skies are clear - and there are websites
column2: apps and social media groups providing forecasts and alerts for when they might occur.

column1: In the UK
column2: Scotland is one of the best places to see the aurora but powerful displays have also been visible from England
column3: Wales and Northern Ireland.

column1: Aberdeenshire-based Jacquie Murray also tries to see the aurora whenever possible.
I first encountered the aurora in 1986 driving a bus from Aberdeen to Peterhead
column2: she says.

column1: I stopped the bus to allow the passengers to see it.""
Jacquie
column2: a health and safety inspector with an energy company
column3: took a keen interest in photography six years ago - mainly to capture images of the aurora.

column1: She says: ""I have at times seen myself standing in the freezing cold in minus temperatures a good four to six hours either waiting or watching.
You have to be keen and willing to drive to areas where there is little or no light pollution
column2: check for clear skies
column3: be patient - and look north.""

column1: Chris Cogan is among the lucky ones who can see the aurora pretty much from his doorstep
column2: living in the small community of Muie in Sutherland in the Highlands.

column1: The 54-year-old joiner says: ""I sometimes go out for 15 minutes
column2: take a few photos and go back in as the conditions or aurora are not the best.

column1: Some nights I will watch the green arc of the aurora form
column2: grow bigger and spread nearer to me and I will wait until she 'lets go' - aurora spotters' term for when it starts dancing and putting up huge beams.

column1: This can be a few hours waiting.""
Chris says some people may have seen the aurora without realising it.
To the human eye they're just white light
column2: like fog with stars on the horizon
column3: but a camera or phone pick up the colour

column1: Some very powerful auroras
column2: the human eye can see the green or orange.""

column1: Alan Tough
column2: an Elgin-based whisky industry chartered engineer
column3: is another keen Northern Lights photographer.

column1: He has been interested in astronomy since he was a boy
column2: and remembers staying up to watch Neil Armstrong take his first steps on the moon.

column1: Alan is a member of the British Astronomical Association and regularly sends reports and photographs to its aurora section. Like some other aurora hunters
column2: he also frequently submits images to BBC Weather Watchers.

column1: He says: ""Despite growing up under the dark skies of Speyside
column2: I didn't see my first aurora until
column3: probably

column1: I've been seriously photographing the aurora ever since I got my first digital camera back in 2003.""
He has also seen the lights in Canada
column2: Iceland and Norway - and he and his wife were almost shipwrecked while sailing back from the Arctic Circle on a Northern Lights cruise in 2019.

column1: There are always eager new recruits to the band of people prepared to put up with freezing weather to catch a glimpse of the lights' ethereal glow.
Among them is Desiree Ventura
column3: who lives in Aberdeen - a city with a song about the aurora.

column1: I've been hunting the aurora for a couple of years now
column2: says the content creator and amateur photographer
column3: who is originally from Italy.

column1: Last year
column2: she photographed the lights for the first time but the display was only visible as a faint glow on her camera.

column1: Then earlier this month she saw it for the first time with her own eyes from near Newburgh on the Aberdeenshire coast.
It was such a strong event and the whole display was clearly visible to the naked eye. I was so excited
column2: says Desiree.

column1: The show lasted for over an hour
column2: but it was so spectacular that I didn't even realise I had been standing there for that long.""

column1: Dawid Gierszewski
column2: a 46-year-old window cleaner
column3: has seen the aurora from Aberdeen beach.

column1: He says: ""The aurora is a wonderful sight. It is evidence of how beautifully the world was created.
Sometimes I stay outside for three to four hours waiting for or watching the aurora.""
The solar activity behind the aurora peaks in cycles of about every 11 years
column2: and Caithness Astronomy Group chairman Gordon Mackie says the next few years could offer more opportunities for seeing it.

column1: The 53-year-old chemist
column2: who lives in Thurso
column3: says: ""With the next peak due in a couple of years time we should see a good number of displays over the next four years.

column1: For a few years around solar activity peak
column2: sightings from the north of Scotland are fairly common.

column1: During the last peak in activity I was seeing the aurora more than 30 times a year.""
And he added: ""A good display is a magical sight likely to be remembered for a very long time.
I've seen it fill the entire sky numerous times - you look up in awe
column2: mesmerised by the dancing lights.""

column1: 352;Climate change: 'Fragile win' at COP26 summit under threat;2022-01-24T17:56:25.000Z;[];['intergovernmental panel on climate change'
column2: 'cop26'
column3: 'paris climate agreement'

column1: COP26 President Alok Sharma has warned that progress made during the summit is at risk of ""withering on the vine"".
Mr Sharma said that the agreements reached at the Glasgow climate meeting had been a ""fragile win"" for the world.
But unless the commitments made are turned into action this year
column2: the chances of keeping global temperatures in check will be lost.

column1: Quoting from the popular film
column2: Don't Look Up
column3: he said this was no time to ""sit tight and assess"".

column1: The UN's COP26 climate summit in November ended with a deal being struck in a bid to stave off severe climate change. This pact was the first ever UN climate deal to explicitly plan to reduce coal - the worst fossil fuel for greenhouse gases.
But the pledges didn't go far enough to limit temperature rise to 1.5C
column2: seen by scientists as the threshold for dangerous impacts from global warming.

column1: Twelve weeks to the day after the start of COP26 (so named because it was the 26th meeting of the Conference of the Parties)
column2: Alok Sharma delivered his first major speech since the gathering
column3: at a Chatham House event in Central London.

column1: Mr Sharma is essentially in charge of the negotiations process until the next major conference
column2: COP27
column3: in Egypt in November.

column1: He highlighted the fact that
column2: despite the pandemic
column3: and frayed international relations
column4: countries had worked together at COP26 to deliver the Glasgow Climate Pact.

column1: That agreement
column2: he said
column3: was a significant achievement.

column1: In Glasgow
column2: countries had agreed to return with new and improved carbon-cutting plans for 2030 by the time of the next major summit in Egypt in November.

column1: The hope is that every nation will increase their national efforts in line with limiting global warming below 1.5C.
Mr Sharma also underlined the progress made in Glasgow on getting rid of the most polluting fossil fuel.
When my team and I were deliberating on whether we should aim to consign coal power to history
column2: I was warned we would never get the word 'coal' in a COP text
column3: Mr Sharma said.

column1: ""Yet every country at COP has agreed to phase-down coal power.""
But the achievements in Glasgow will not survive if global leaders don't take concrete action this year
column2: he explained.

column1: Unless we honour the promises made
column2: to turn the commitments in the Glasgow Climate Pact into action
column3: they will wither on the vine

column1: We will have mitigated no risks. We will have seized no opportunities. Instead
column2: we will have fractured the trust built between nations. And 1.5C will slip from our grasp. So my absolute focus for the UK presidency year is delivery.""

column1: Mr Sharma outlined four key priorities for this year
column2: the first of which involves getting countries to increase their actions on cutting carbon. He would be concentrating on getting the richer G20 group of nations to do more.

column1: There must also be a renewed focus on helping countries to adapt to climate change
column2: and to make advances on the issue of loss and damage.

column1: Money was critical to progress
column2: he reiterated.

column1: Come November
column2: leaders of the richer countries must be able to show that the $100bn (£74bn) promised every year from 2020 would finally be delivered.

column1: At a number of points in his speech
column2: Mr Sharma referred to the South African deal put together at COP26.

column1: Countries
column2: including the UK
column3: are stumping up the cash for South Africa to transition away from coal. Mr Sharma indicated that this approach may well be used again.

column1: Where we can support them
column2: as we're doing with South Africa
column3: in going from coal to a clean energy transition
column4: that's something that developed countries are going to have to do

353;James Webb telescope parked in observing position;2022-01-24T19:24:24.000Z;[];['astronomy'
column2: 'nasa'
column3: 'european space agency'

column1: Thirty days after it was launched
column2: the James Webb telescope has arrived at the position in space where it will observe the Universe.

column1: The Lagrange Point 2
column2: as it's known
column3: is a million miles (1.5 million km) from Earth on its nightside.

column1: Webb was finally nudged into an orbit around this location thanks to a short
column2: five-minute thruster burn.

column1: Controllers back on Earth will now spend the coming months tuning the telescope to get it ready for science.
Key tasks include switching on the observatory's four instruments
column2: and also focusing its mirrors - in particular
column3: its 6.5m-wide segmented primary reflector.

column1: There's a pretty intensive effort to take all of those 18 segments from their current state and get them to act as one big mirror
column2: and also to get the secondary mirror into its optimised condition
column3: explained Charlie Atkinson
column4: the chief engineer on Webb at Northrop Grumman
column5: the American aerospace company that co-led the telescope's development with the US space agency (Nasa).

column1: We do this using the science images
column2: which is why we need to get the science instruments activated and checked out with some initial calibration work
column3: he told BBC News.

column1: Webb
column2: billed as the successor to the famous Hubble Space Telescope
column3: was launched on 25 December by an Ariane-5 rocket from French Guiana.

column1: Its overarching goals are to take pictures of the very first stars to shine in the Universe and to probe far-off planets to see if they might be habitable.
Europe's Ariane-5 gave the new observatory a near-perfect trajectory and velocity to get it out to L2. Even so
column2: two course correction burns were necessary
column3: with the third on Monday tipping Webb into its planned parking position.

column1: This video can not be played
The Lagrange Point 2 is one of five gravitational ""sweet-spots"" around the Sun and Earth where satellites can hold their position with few orbital adjustments
column2: thus conserving fuel.

column1: The other advantage is that Webb will not experience at L2 the big swings in temperature and light endured by space telescopes positioned much closer to Earth.
This is vital for the mission. It's designed to view the cosmos in infrared light and must maintain therefore constant super-cold conditions for its hardware.
Infrared light has waves that are just longer than those of visible light. ""Seeing"" in the infrared will allow the telescope to
column2: for example
column3: look through dust to the see stars that would otherwise be obscured.

column1: Webb will now circle L2
column2: keeping the Earth and the Sun in a near-straight line.

column1: L2 is pseudo-stable
column2: said Jean-Paul Pinaud
column3: who leads the Northrop engineers that keep Webb on track.

column1: The flight operations team is preparing routine station-keeping burns. They'll be doing those every 20 days or so with the trajectory calculations provided by our flight dynamics team. We'll set them up in a similar way
column2: and then fire the thruster. But the burns will be quite small.""

column1: Hidden behind a big sunshield
column2: Webb's optics and instruments will soon cool to about -230C (some sections of the telescope are already there). When that happens
column3: controllers will switch on Webb's Near Infrared Camera (NIRCam) to take a picture of a test star to begin the process of aligning the big mirror.

column1: We know when we first focus on a star in space
column2: we'll actually see 18 different spots of light because the 18 individual mirror segments won't be aligned
column3: said Nasa instrument systems engineer Begoña Vila.

column1: But we'll adjust the mirrors to bring all the spots together to make a single star that's not aberrated and good for normal operations.
It's a long process. It can take up to three months during commissioning
column2: and we are ready to do that
column3: she told BBC News.

column1: Focusing involves driving small actuators
column2: or motors
column3: on the back of the 18 segments of the primary mirror to harmonise their curvature. The current misalignment
column5: will be brought down to one measured in nanometres - a factor of a million improvement.

column1: Similar adjustments will be applied to the 74cm-diameter secondary reflector which sits out in front of the primary mirror and is used to bounce light back towards the instruments.
So far
column2: the Webb mission has not put a step wrong. The launch and journey out to L2 passed off without incident.

column1: And even the complex business of unfolding the telescope after it came off the top of the Ariane rocket was made to look like the easiest of rehearsals.
We were thrilled with the precision and success of all those deployments
column2: said Kyle Hott
column3: the mission systems engineering lead at Northrop.

column1: It's pretty incredible to think that it was all just a concept on paper decades ago
column2: and now it's actually here
column3: arriving at L2. Morale is high and we're so very excited.""

column1: Taylor Swift has criticised Damon Albarn
column2: lead singer of Blur and later of Gorillaz
column3: after he said that she doesn't write her own music.

column1: Talking to the LA Times
column2: Albarn replied to the interviewer calling Swift ""an excellent songwriter"" by stating ""she doesn't write her own songs"".

column1: Swift responded on Twitter: ""I was such a big fan of yours until I saw this.""
I write all of my own songs. Your hot take is completely false and so damaging.""
Albarn said in the interview that he prefers Billie Eilish
column2: who he called a ""really interesting songwriter"".

column1: I'm more attracted to that than to Taylor Swift. It's just darker - less endlessly upbeat. Way more minor and odd. I think she's exceptional.""
Eilish co-writes her songs with her brother
column2: producer Finneas.

column1: When the interviewer said that Swift co-writes her music
column2: Albarn responded: ""That doesn't count. I know what co-writing is. Co-writing is very different to writing. I'm not hating on anybody
column3: I'm just saying there's a big difference between a songwriter and a songwriter who co-writes.""

column1: There was a swift backlash on Twitter
column2: including from producer Jack Antonoff
column3: who has worked with Swift extensively.

column1: Albarn later apologised
column2: writing to Swift on Twitter: ""I totally agree with you. I had a conversation about songwriting and sadly it was reduced to clickbait. I apologise unreservedly and unconditionally. The last thing I would want to do is discredit your songwriting. I hope you understand.""

column1: This is not the first time Albarn has caused controversy when criticising pop stars. He once reportedly called Adele ""insecure"" after they had worked together on music that was never released.
It ended up being one of those 'don't meet your idol' moments
column2: she later told Rolling Stone.

column1: And the saddest thing was that I was such a big Blur fan growing up. But it was sad
column2: and I regret hanging out with him.""

column1: Albarn later denied calling her insecure
column2: stating the reports were concocted from someone overhearing a conversation with a friend.

column1: Climate change is threatening to destroy treasures buried in the UK as the soils that protect them dry out.
A Roman toilet seat
column2: the world's oldest boxing glove
column3: and the oldest handwritten letter by a woman are some of the extraordinary objects discovered in at-risk British peatlands.

column1: It means climate change could undermine our understanding of our past
column2: say archaeologists.

column1: About 22
column2: 500 archaeological sites in UK may be in danger.

column1: The problem is that changing weather patterns are drying out some peatlands - the waterlogged soils that cover about 10% of the UK.
Because peat contains very little oxygen
column2: organic materials like wood
column3: leather and textiles do not rot. They can survive for thousands of years
column4: preserved by the stable anoxic chemistry of the soil.

column1: But if the soils dry
column2: oxygen can enter the system
column3: kick-starting the process of decomposition. If that happens artefacts can

column1: Excavating these potentially huge sites could cost hundreds of millions of pounds and take decades
column2: by which time they may have been badly damaged.

column1: The trustees of Magna
column2: a Roman fort alongside Hadrian's Wall
column3: fear the process is already under way at the site.

column1: The warnings come as celebrations for the 1
column2: 900th anniversary of the start of construction of the wall begin this week.

column1: The land at Magna has subsided by up to a metre in places in the past decade. It is evidence of ""desiccation"" - the drying of the peat layer - fears Dr Andrew Birley
column2: the chief archaeologist at the site.

column1: It means ""an historical time capsule"" is at risk
column2: he says
column3: because only a tiny part of the site has so far been excavated.

column1: This place has the potential to be quite frankly
column2: amazing
column3: Dr Birley believes. ""Pretty much everything the Romans used here for 300 or 400 years could have been preserved in more or less the same state it was thrown away

column1: Another fort a few miles along Hadrian's Wall gives an idea of the astonishing objects that could lie hidden at Magna.
Digs at Vindolanda have uncovered the world's oldest boxing gloves - so well-preserved that you can still see the imprint of the boxer's knuckles on one.
More Roman footwear has been discovered here than at any other site in the world.
It is also the source of the oldest handwritten message by a woman found anywhere.
In the note
column2: Claudia Severa
column3: the wife of the commanding officer of a nearby fort
column4: invites her friend Lepidina to her birthday party on 11 September about 1

column1: Oh how much I want you at my birthday party
column2: writes Claudia. ""You'll make the day so much more fun. I do so hope you can make it. Goodbye
column3: sister

column1: Day-to-day objects like this provide a unique connection to the lives of ordinary people in ancient times.
This sort of stuff doesn't normally survive
column2: "" says Dr Birley
column3: who works at both sites. ""It can give us amazing insights into what life was really like here on the Northern frontier almost 2

column1: He says the priority at Magna now is to try to work out what is happening underground.
Boreholes have been dug
column2: and electronic equipment measures the water flow and temperature every hour.

column1: At Teesside University
column2: Dr Gillian Taylor is analysing the chemicals in soil cores from the site to try to understand the processes at work.

column1: It would be a ""catastrophe"" for any organic artefacts if the peat dries
column2: she says. ""The risk is they will disappear. We will lose our heritage if we don't look at what's occurring now.""

column1: Fearing the worst
column2: Dr Birley is planning to dig the first test trenches at the site next year. As a small charity
column3: it's the earliest they can start given the cost and labour needed.

column1: He says if it looks like the condition of the peat is changing rapidly and the treasures could be lost
column2: a full excavation may be necessary.

column1: And changing weather patterns are not just threatening the survival of Roman remains. Experts estimate that there are about 22
column2: 500 archaeological sites in or beneath peat in the UK.

column1: Dr Rosie Everett
column2: of Northumbria University
column3: is part of a team that has been assessing the effect of climate change on peatland archaeology across the UK.

column1: She says a host of historic sites in peatlands are under threat
column2: covering the entire sweep of the country's history.

column1: There are Palaeolithic pathways up to 12
column2: 000 years old
column3: and Bronze Age burial sites as well as the remains of more modern settlements and industrial activities.

column1: Peatlands represent such a small part of the ecology of Britain
column2: but they have massive potential to tell us about our past
column3: says Dr Everett.

column1: While an archaeologist working at a ""dry"" site might find 10% of what was once there
column2: at a peatland site they may find as much as 90% of the material culture of ancient communities
column3: say archaeologists.

column1: The loss of peatlands would have big implications for the understanding of the country's history but also for our climatic history and our environmental history
column2: says Dr Everett.

column1: That's why she believes there should be greater efforts to protect them.
Dr Birley agrees. ""If we lose places like this
column2: we lose that direct connection to the people who lived in this island 2000 years ago
column3: he says.

column1: We lose the chance to learn as much as we can about them. And we lose part of our own heritage and part of our own history.""

The Metropolitan Police have launched an investigation into parties held in No 10 during the coronavirus pandemic.
Commissioner Cressida Dick said they were looking into ""potential breaches of Covid-19 regulations"" in Downing Street and Whitehall since 2020.
She said the investigation was launched as a ""result of the information provided by the Cabinet Office inquiry team""
column2: led by civil servant Sue Gray.

column1: The Cabinet Office said Ms Gray's own inquiry would continue.
But it is not yet clear if the police investigation will lead to delays in its publication.
The news comes after fresh allegations of a birthday party being held for the PM in June 2020.
Downing Street has admitted that staff gathered inside No 10 to celebrate Boris Johnson's birthday when the first Covid lockdown was still in place.
But ministers have disputed the number of people attending
column2: and called for ""patience"" while Ms Gray's inquiry is carried out to establish the facts.

column1: The first thing is to have a sense of proportion.
When you hear the words ""Met Police
column2: investigation
column3: criminal
column4: Downing Street"" that sounds incredibly dramatic.

column1: This is a big development in this story but we are talking about the potential issuing of fixed penalty notices - fines - we are not talking about big criminal trials or people going to prison.
So it is important to keep that sense of perspective.
There are also lots of things we don't know about this police investigation.
We don't know how many of those high-profile parties are now being investigated and crucially we don't know if they were parties attended by the prime minister.
We don't know if the prime minister is in the frame for being interviewed by the police.
So
column2: lots of unanswered questions but it means this is going to rumble on at a much higher volume for a lot longer.

column1: 362;Ukraine: How will we know if war has started?;2022-01-25T11:09:57.000Z;[];['ukraine conflict'

column1: Everyone is trying to second-guess President Vladimir Putin's intentions in Ukraine. The US is pulling embassy staff out as fears rise of looming conflict. But maybe it's already started
column2: writes security and defence expert Jonathan Marcus.

column1: The risk of an all-out war between Russia and Ukraine dominates the headlines.
All the obvious questions are being asked. Will Russia attack? Is President Vladimir Putin determined upon war come what may? Or can diplomacy secure peace?
But we cannot see inside President Putin's mind.
So here's another question - how will we know when hostilities commence?
The answer seems obvious.
Clearly massed Russian tank formations crossing Ukraine's frontiers
column2: or a massive rocket barrage or air strikes against Ukrainian positions
column3: would mark a dramatic escalation in the crisis and a shift to a new phase of the conflict.

column1: The first alarms will come from the Ukrainian military itself
column2: but Western satellites and intelligence-gathering aircraft may well spot the preparations for an imminent offensive.

column1: There will probably be clear signs of an impending onslaught
column2: says Michael Kofman
column3: an expert on the Russian military at the US-based Center for Naval Analyses.

column1: Among them are ""the manning of formations""
column2: he says
column3: since a lot of what has been deployed is heavy equipment rather than the troops themselves. Other signs could be ""the dispersal of forces
column4: an influx of logistical and support elements
column5: and a shift in fixed-wing and rotary aviation"".

column1: This video can not be played
But the question can also be answered in another way and for this we need to stand back and view the Russian campaign against Ukraine in its entirety.
We need to look at the full toolkit available to Moscow and assess how it is being used. And in this light
column2: when you ask -  how will we know if the conflict has started  - then the answer may be that it already has.

column1: Hostilities have actually been under way for some years.
Let's start from where we are.
Russia already occupies Crimea - part of Ukraine - and it provides practical assistance to anti-Kiev rebels in the Donbas region.

Indeed it was the intervention of Russian armoured and mechanised units against Ukrainian forces in 2014 that prevented the pro-Russian rebels' defeat. Sporadic fighting has continued ever since. All sides supposedly support an international peace effort there
column2: but little progress has been made.

column1: Beyond this pressure there is also the threat to employ overwhelming military force.

The build-up of Russian combat formations around Ukraine's borders is extraordinary.  This includes a significant deployment of forces to Belarus - which also shares a border with Ukraine - which might provide a closer jumping-off point for an assault towards the Ukrainian capital Kiev itself.
This build-up is referred to by Russian spokesmen as an exercise and in no sense threatening. But its scale
column2: the nature of the units deployed
column3: and the gradual arrival of supplies and other ""enablers"" suggest that this is much more than routine manoeuvres.

column1: Analysts have followed the build-up using civilian satellite photos. Numerous phone videos have been put online showing trains of equipment heading towards Ukraine or Belarus. And assessments of social media postings
column2: correlated with the units seen to be on the move
column3: provide a remarkable insight into what is going on.

column1: Irrespective of what Moscow may say
column2: Ukraine and its friends in the West have every reason to be worried.

column1: The next tool available to Moscow is an attempt to influence the narrative.
On the one hand Russia says it is not preparing for war
column2: though it very much looks as though it is. But
column3: just as importantly
column4: it has a story to tell - a narrative - where far from Ukraine being the victim
column5: it is in fact Russia itself that is threatened.

column1: This is the substance of the documents handed over to the US which seek to halt and in some ways reverse Nato expansion and create a new sphere of influence for Moscow.
While some aspects of Russia's concerns
column2: like talks on strategic and other weapons systems
column3: are widely seen as a good idea
column4: on Nato enlargement it is unlikely to get any change - and it probably knows this.

column1: But the narrative has another purpose too. It is the story that Russia tells to try to shape the way the whole Ukraine crisis is discussed
column2: not just by Western governments or its own citizens
column3: but by you and me

column1: By all fair and rigorous independent analysis Russia is preparing for war with Ukraine
column2: whatever its official spokesmen may say.

column1: There are other possibilities in the Russian toolbox too. Cyber-attack and subversion
column2: for example. Ukraine certainly has been the subject of the former. Just over a week ago a number of government websites were hit though it was far from clear where the attack came from.

column1: More recently the UK Government has claimed evidence that Moscow has selected individuals to form a new government in Kiev - though whatever the suspicions
column2: there has been no conclusive public evidence confirming Moscow's hand in such activities.

column1: Michael Kofman says that a cyber element could be an important part of any Russian attack
column2: because they can cripple critical infrastructure and disrupt Ukraine's ability to coordinate a military effort.

column1: When Russia seized Crimea we heard a lot of talk about ""hybrid"" and ""grey-zone warfare"" and the alleged deniability of the operation
column2: whose participants
column3: though uniformed

column1: But there was no doubt who these troops were. And Crimea was seized with old-fashioned military force
column2: rather than by some esoteric deception.

column1: What is under way at present is the essence of ""grey-zone warfare"" - the blurring of the boundary between peace and war.
That's not how we tend to view things in the West.
But the Russian military has articulated a sophisticated doctrine that sees war and peace as a continuum where different tools are applied at different stages
column2: sometimes in sequence
column3: sometimes together
column4: though with the same strategic aim.

column1: And that ultimately is why the conflict has already been joined. The only question is how far along the ""grey zone"" continuum President Putin is willing to go.
Jonathan Marcus is a former BBC defence & diplomatic correspondent and an honorary professor at the Strategy and Security Institute at Exeter University

column1: Pfizer and BioNTech have started clinical trials of a new Covid vaccine which targets the Omicron variant.
The companies plan to test the protection gained from the new vaccine as a booster jab and as three separate jabs in unvaccinated people.
More than 1
column2: 400 adults are expected to be enrolled in the trial
column3: likely to be in the United States.

column1: US company Moderna is planning to begin trials of its own Omicron-specific shot soon.
Oxford University and AstraZeneca have also started working on a new version of their vaccine.
Vaccine developers had always planned to tweak their original Covid vaccines as new variants emerged
column2: but the arrival of the fast-spreading Omicron strain in the last two months has hastened that process.

column1: Many countries have now offered a booster or third dose of their original vaccine
column2: which has been shown to provide a good level of protection against serious illness and death - even against Omicron.

column1: But protection against infection and mild symptoms is much lower and could decline more quickly.
Staying vigilant against the virus requires us to identify new approaches for people to maintain a high level of protection
column2: and we believe developing and investigating variant-based vaccines
column3: like this one
column4: are essential in our efforts towards this goal
column6: senior vice-president and head of vaccine research and development at Pfizer.

column1: Prof Ugur Sahin
column2: CEO and co-founder of BioNTech
column3: said new data indicated that ""vaccine-induced protection against infection and mild to moderate disease wanes more rapidly than was observed with prior strains"".

column1: This study is part of our science-based approach to develop a variant-based vaccine that achieves a similar level of protection against Omicron as it did with earlier variants
column2: but with longer duration of protection.""

column1: The companies say they expect to produce four billion doses of their Covid-19 vaccine this year
column2: and this number will include doses of the updated vaccine if trials suggest it is needed.

column1: In the trial of the new vaccine
column2: 615 adults will receive two doses of the current Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine
column3: followed by one or two doses of the Omicron-targeted jab.

column1: A second group of 600 who received three doses of the current vaccine will get another of the current one or the Omicron vaccine.
Finally
column2: a small group of 200 unvaccinated adults will receive three doses of the new Omicron-targeted shot.

column1: 368;Africa Cup of Nations: A football celebration overshadowed by tragedy;2022-01-26T00:23:35.000Z;[];['africa today podcasts'];['major'
column2: 'impressions'
column3: 'africa'

column1: In our series of letters from African writers
column2: Algerian-Canadian football journalist Maher Mezahi
column3: who is in Cameroon to cover the Africa Cup of Nations
column4: reflects on how the recent deaths of fans at a stadium has left him with mixed feelings about the tournament.

column1: When I was first asked to do a piece about my impressions about the tournament in Cameroon
column2: I had wanted to compile a list of the things that make it so special and sets it apart from other major football competitions.

column1: I was planning to celebrate African football.
After all
column2: Afcon is a special tournament
column3: adored by everyone on the continent and intrinsically linked to pan-African values.

column1: The first two in 1957 and 1959
column2: for example
column3: were used in part as a statement against apartheid in South Africa.

column1: Players
column2: fans and journalists have all spoken about how it is closer to the true spirit of football
column3: rather than the more sanitised and corporate tournaments elsewhere.

column1: There is also the warm and friendly atmosphere as well as the pride that Afcon creates in all countries across the continent.
Amongst the positive things are the medical protocols to deal with Covid-19
column2: including pulmonary scans.

column1: These are among the strictest in world football and intended to prevent any medical emergencies.
On the terraces
column2: everyone lauds the carnival-like atmosphere that African football supporters manage to generate.

column1: Recognisable super fans are present at every biennial championship.
Take Tunisia's ""Reda The Elephant""
column2: who covers his belly in body paint and has the best goal reactions
column3: or Ivory Coast's ""Petit Bamba""
column4: who orchestrates the National Elephants' Supporters Committee dance moves.

column1: The atmosphere is so pure
column2: says Alex Cizmic
column3: an Italian freelance journalist
column4: who has often been amazed at the relaxed atmosphere around the teams.

column1: In 2019 in Egypt
column2: I was fortunate enough to attend one of the Uganda Cranes' training sessions. When it was over
column3: I had a chat with star striker Farouk Miya
column4: who I had never met before
column5: he recalls in a surprised tone.

column1: Then I arranged a quick call with his former coach Milutin Sredojevic
column2: who I was in contact with. It all felt very familial.""

column1: And smaller nations have shone.
The Gambia and Comoros were debutants in this edition of the tournament
column2: and they have done their nations proud.

column1: Before The Gambia played their first match against Mauritania
column2: I asked a Gambian friend to write down what he felt as the anthem was playing.

column1: I felt a real sense of pride
column2: love for country
column3: and honour hearing the Gambian national team anthem for the first time

column1: When the first goal went in
column2: I couldn't do anything. Deep inside of me I was just proud
column3: knowing what the goal means. It really united our country.""

column1: But in one evening
column2: all of the positive aspects of the Afcon have been overshadowed by a tragedy of unspeakable proportions.

column1: As hosts Cameroon were set to play their second round match against Comoros at the new Olembé Stadium in the capital
column2: Yaoundé
column3: a bottleneck began to build outside.

column1: At around 19:30 local time
column2: just half an hour before kick-off
column3: thousands of fans were stuck in a crush that ended up killing eight people

column1: I had arrived at the stadium earlier in the afternoon
column2: but even several hours before the match started
column3: the incessant cordoning off of spectators was irritating.

column1: I have been to football matches in seven African countries and every time I make the same observation: there are so many police officers and so little safety.
For a stadium with a capacity of 60
column3: it seemed extremely odd that journalists
column4: supporters and everyone who was not a VIP were being ushered in through the same gate outside the campus.

column1: This video can not be played
Covid-19 testing and screening for vaccines further slowed down passage into the stadium.
I did not know what had transpired until late in the second half when a colleague nudged me in the ribs and whispered: ""There's trouble outside.""
We ran out
column2: but there was nothing to see.

column1: The only evidence of any problems was a handful of shoes and articles of clothing strewn on the ground.
A few minutes later rumours of deaths began filtering through.
In the press room
column2: journalists began sharing documents that listed the victims as well as videos of the tragedy.

column1: The following morning the Confederation of African Football (Caf) accepted shared responsibility for the incident and presented its condolences to the families.
But matches were not postponed and the tournament is continuing.
I do not think games should have taken place on Tuesday - the day after the tragedy.
It seemed disrespectful to the families
column2: and everyone involved in the competition is still trying to process what happened.

column1: It does not feel like a time to talk about or celebrate football.

column1: 374;Downing Street parties: Boris Johnson vows to fight on as MPs await Sue Gray report;2022-01-26T21:16:15.000Z;[];"['coronavirus lockdown measures'

column1: This video can not be played
Boris Johnson has vowed to fight on as prime minister after facing fresh calls to quit over lockdown parties in Downing Street.
MPs are still waiting to see the findings of civil servant Sue Gray's inquiry into the events
column2: which had been expected on Wednesday.

column1: At Prime Minister's Questions
column2: Sir Keir Starmer called on the PM to keep a promise to publish the report in full.

column1: Mr Johnson replied that he would ""do exactly what I said"".
Downing Street has said it is their ""intention"" to publish the report in the format in which Mr Johnson receives it.
The BBC understands that Ms Gray's report is essentially completed
column2: but she has not yet sent it to the prime minister.

column1: It seems likely MPs may have to wait until Thursday - or beyond - to see the report.
Mr Johnson has said he will give the opposition parties time to study its contents before he makes a Commons statement on it.
Separately
column2: the Metropolitan Police have launched an inquiry into potential Covid-law breaking in Downing Street
column3: after being handed details of parties by Sue Gray.

column1: At a stormy Prime Minister's Questions
column2: Sir Keir said the prime minister had previously told MPs that ""all guidance was followed"" in Downing Street over gatherings during Covid lockdowns.

column1: The Labour leader added: ""So since he acknowledges the ministerial code [governing standards of behaviour and forbidding ministers from misleading the Commons] applies to him
column2: will he now resign?""

column1: Mr Johnson replied: ""No.""
He accused Sir Keir of being ""relentlessly opportunistic throughout"" the pandemic by shifting his position on lockdowns
column2: whereas he had got all the big decisions right.

column1: Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle had to step in several times to calm shouting MPs down
column2: threatening some with expulsion from the chamber.

column1: Amid continued noise
column2: Sir Keir said: ""The prime minister's continual defence is 'Wait for the Sue Gray report'. On 8 December he told this House
column3: 'I will place a copy of the report in the library of the House of Commons'.

column1: His spokesperson has repeatedly stated that means the full report
column2: not parts of the report
column3: not a summary of the report
column5: can the prime minister confirm that he will publish the full Sue Gray report as he receives it?""

column1: Western powers are threatening severe economic sanctions against Russia if it were to invade Ukraine.
Western diplomats are refusing to be explicit about specific penalties to keep Russia guessing and maximise their deterrent effect. So what sanctions might the West be planning?

One measure being considered would be to exclude Russia from the system known as Swift - a global financial messaging service. It is used by many thousands of financial institutions in more than 200 countries.
Boris Johnson told MPs that banning Russia from this would be a ""potent weapon"". It would effectively make it very hard for Russian banks to do business overseas.
This sanction was used against Iran in 2012 and the country lost significant oil revenues and a large chunk of foreign trade.
But this sanction would have an economic cost for countries like the United States and Germany whose banks have close links to Russian financial institutions.
The US could ban Russia from financial transactions involving US dollars. Essentially
column2: any western firm that allowed a Russian institution to deal in dollars would face penalties.

column1: This would mean that Russia would be extremely limited in what it could buy and sell around the world.
This could have a huge impact on Russia's economy as most of its oil and gas sales are settled in dollars.
Western powers could take action to block further Russia's access to international debt markets.
The ability of Western institutions and banks to buy Russian bonds is already restricted - those curbs could be tightened.
This would deprive the country of access to finance that it needs to grow its economy. The country's cost of borrowing might rise and the value of the Rouble might fall.
Russia has prepared for this by reducing the amount of debt held by foreign investors.
The US could simply blacklist some Russian banks
column2: making it almost impossible for anyone in the world to conduct transactions with them.

column1: Moscow would have to bail out the banks and do what it could to avoid inflation rising and incomes falling.
This would
column2: though
column3: have a major negative impact for western investors with money in those Russian banks.

column1: The West could restrict the export of key commodities to Russia.
The US could
column2: for example
column3: stop companies selling any goods containing American technology

column1: This could involve
column2: in particular
column3: semiconductor microchips
column4: which are used in everything from cars to smart phones

column1: This would target not just Russia's defence and aerospace sectors
column2: but whole swathes of its economy.

column1: Russia's economy is hugely dependent on selling gas and oil overseas. The sales are huge source of revenue for the Kremlin.
The West could make it illegal for countries and companies to buy oil from the big Russian energy giants such as Gazprom or Rosneft.
A new gas pipeline under the Baltic Sea from Russia to Germany - called Nord Stream 2 - could be abandoned. It is ready to start operations but still awaiting regulatory approval.
But
column2: any curbs on Russian gas would raise prices across Europe
column3: much of which is dependent on energy from the east.

column1: New sanctions could be targeted at individuals
column2: including not only associates of Vladimir Putin but also the Russian President himself.

column1: This would most likely involve punishing acts of hostility against Ukraine or threatening its sovereignty or territorial integrity.
Asset freezes and travel bans are the most likely options. But many such sanctions are already in force and have yet to change much Russian behaviour.

The hope of US and European powers is that Russia's elite would put pressure on Mr Putin if they were unable to access their wealth in foreign countries and educate their children in western schools and universities.
Some sanctions could be imposed to restrict the ability of Russian individuals to invest and live in London.
Such is the scale of Russian money in banks and property in the UK that the capital has been dubbed ""Londongrad"".
The UK government claims it is tackling this problem with ""unexplained wealth orders""
column2: which require people to say where their cash has come from.

column1: But only a handful of these orders have ever been used. Some US organisations want the White House to push the UK harder on this.
The main difficulty for the West is to decide what sanctions should be imposed and when. There are differences between countries on this.
How much should the sanctions depend on the scale and nature of any Russian attack? If
column2: to quote President Biden
column3: there was a ""minor incursion""
column4: what sanctions would be justified? And who should deploy them?

column1: When asked about this
column2: US officials say there is unity of purpose but admit there might be a ""division of labour"" with different countries imposing different sanctions.

column1: Russia could also mitigate the impact of western sanctions by looking to China and other allies for support.
The bottom line is that the most effective economic sanctions often come at a high price for those who impose them. There are trade-offs and not everyone in the West is willing to acknowledge them.

column1: There's a police investigation and an official inquiry into rule breaking under Boris Johnson's roof is coming any day - Monday seems most likely now
column2: since you ask
column3: although you'd be forgiven for giving up trying to set your watch by it.

column1: The report is likely to be grisly
column2: acutely embarrassing for No 10 and for the civil service
column3: with the expectation that the subsequent Met investigation will lead to a fair number of people who worked in No 10 receiving fixed penalty notices for flouting the regulations they designed and set themselves.

column1: The Conservatives have slipped in the polls
column2: many dozens of Tory MPs are deeply fed up and there has been
column3: for weeks
column4: open discussion of whether or not it might be time for the party to move him on.

column1: And whatever you think of the saga
column2: whether it's silly frippery
column3: or whether it enrages you and brings back terrible memories of suffering during lockdown
column4: the fact that No 10 is having to spend so much time and focus on battling through means inevitably
column5: other important decisions or debates are getting squeezed out.

column1: One Tory figure working with the government on various policies says: ""Government is totally gummed up - it's horrible
column2: nothing gets done or signed off.""

column1: Why then
column2: as another bumpy week draws to a close
column3: are Boris Johnson's closest supporters not at their wits' end?

column1: After weeks of allegations and claims and political mess
column2: a band of his longstanding political friends now have what they seem to believe is a decent operation in place to shore him up.

column1: The prime minister has been seeing ""possibles"" and ""undecideds"" in Parliament - MPs who might be tempted to withdraw their support
column2: or haven't yet made up their minds.

column1: Boris Johnson himself is said to be ""not in a bad place"" about what's going on
column2: buoyed by a feisty outing at Prime Minister's Questions on Wednesday.

column1: What his former adviser and old friend Guto Hari told us on BBC Newscast: ""What he did was remind not only the opposition of what they are up against when he is on form
column2: but reminded anyone sitting behind him or alongside that front bench what they would be up against if they try to take the leadership of him.

column1: It was a display of the alpha male gorilla in the jungle.""

There was no sign whatsoever of the contrite or apologetic impression Boris Johnson has sometimes given in the last few days - a display perhaps designed to show those who want him gone that he will fight and fight.
It's hardly the first time he's had to wriggle through controversies. Here he was confessing to his strategy many years ago:
I've got a brilliant new strategy
column2: which is to make so many gaffes that nobody knows which one to concentrate on
column3: he told the BBC's Booktalk in 2006.

column1: They cease to be newsworthy
column2: you completely out-general the media in that way
column3: and they despair.""

column1: He added: ""You shell them
column2: you pepper the media... you've got to pepper their positions with so many gaffes that they're confused.

column1: It's like a helicopter throwing out chaff
column2: and then you steal on quietly and drop your depth charges wherever you want to drop them.""

column1: This video can not be played
But the odds are so different now.
He's the PM
column2: not the London mayor or a backbench MP
column3: and his leadership has been significantly damaged in the past couple of months.

column1: Getting through this is not just going to be about wisecracks here and there.
There's an expectation too that the government will finally publish its plans for ""levelling up"" next week.
The white paper has long been pencilled in for the start of February and ministers may use it to show that they are
column2: to use a phrase beloved by Boris Johnson
column3: ""getting on with the job"".

column1: His allies also find comfort in the fact that the rebels are not centrally coordinated. Ministers have confronted them with questions about what their plan really is
column2: accusing them of ""student politics"".

column1: The Brexiteers who worked together to bring down Theresa May had a plan to install Boris Johnson.
They were largely bound by ideology and the notion that Mr Johnson should take over.
The groups this time are scattered
column2: and don't have one idea
column3: or one candidate

column1: Yet the disparate nature of the discontent doesn't mean that the prime minister can be remotely sure he'll get safely through
column2: because it makes it harder for anyone in the Tory Party to see what's in the undergrowth.

column1: It's not clear how many secret letters calling for a leadership vote have been submitted.
One Johnson ally
column2: Conor Burns
column3: jokes that the Royal Mail couldn't bank on making any money if they're relying on Tory MPs sending them in.

column1: But if it hits the threshold of 54 and it comes to a confidence vote
column2: the estimates of what might happen are wild.

column1: One of Johnson's camp suggested to reporters they might have the support of as many as 300 Tory MPs out of 359.
Right now that seems extraordinarily optimistic.
Another member of the government who has done the numbers calculated there could be more than 160 votes against
column2: so he'd just scrape through.

column1: But some government ministers say privately they wouldn't back him
column2: and he could even lose.

column1: In other words
column2: bluntly
column3: no-one really has a clue.

column1: In the last few days
column2: Boris Johnson has tried to show that he is still the biggest beast in the political jungle.

column1: But the threats to him are still very real
column2: and as one former minister says
column3: the ""assassins are lurking in the bushes"" now.

column1: The expectation across Whitehall is that Sue Gray's long-anticipated report would be passed to Downing Street on Wednesday.
So why hasn't it appeared
column2: and what is it likely to find when it does?

column1: The announcement of the Met Police investigation has inserted a spanner in the works - especially as all contentious evidence had been given to the police by the cabinet office last week.
And there had been liaison throughout the internal inquiry.
It's understood the Met Police Commissioner Cressida Dick examined the evidence at the weekend.
While the Met has not objected to the report being published - since any action they take could be limited to issuing fixed penalty notices
column2: and not lead to a criminal trial - Downing Street has said reassurances were now being sought that none of the content would cut across police work.

column1: I am told by Whitehall sources that Sue Gray is determined that the report she submits to Downing Street will be in a form that can allow for it to be published by No 10 in full.
What she wants to avoid are last minute redactions
column2: or a report that focuses on the least egregious events
column3: while leaving everything that's contentious to the police.

column1: Sue Gray has built a formidable reputation within the civil service and will not want to be undermined by allegations of a whitewash
column2: or a less than thorough job.

column1: So it is perfectly possible that minor redrafting or reworking could be undertaken which achieves the twin aims of ensuring the police would have no last minute objections
column2: while not skirting round some of the findings about more controversial gatherings in government buildings.

column1: According to sources close to the Gray team
column2: there has not been any political interference to adjust the content
column3: so that is not the cause of delay.

column1: The prime minister will certainly see the full report before it is published but will not have a veto over its content.
And there has been no attempt by civil service trade unions to delay the report or ask for retractions.
Only very senior civil servants will be named and those who will be named have already been informed.
But it's not impossible that more junior staff individually may have raised concerns that while they are not going to be identified
column2: the information in the report might make them nonetheless too easy to identify.

column1: Insiders also maintain that while the whole process has been a difficult one for Ms Gray
column2: she would push back against any informal attempts by other senior civil servants to alter the tone of the report
column3: or to dilute the findings.

column1: According to those who know Sue Gray's track record - as the former director general in charge of propriety and ethics in Whitehall - she holds her fellow civil servants to very high standards.
From those close to the process
column2: it would be difficult for her to conclude that Downing Street is being well run.

column1: While she cannot recommend any action be taken against politicians
column2: she can be very critical about the civil service leadership in Downing Street
column3: and of the culture in the building.

column1: She is unlikely to mince words
column2: and her report could subsequently trigger disciplinary action against some staff.

column1: It will almost certainly make difficult reading for senior people - including some who have so far not been mentioned prominently in public.
Of course
column2: there is little doubt that supporters of Boris Johnson would find it convenient to blame the advisers and indeed the longer any delay
column3: some of those supporters may go on the front foot and call for reforms in the operation.

column1: As for the prime minister
column2: the terms of reference which Sue Gray was given may work to his advantage.

column1: As head of propriety and ethics
column2: when she dealt with complaints against ministers she would form a judgment on whether the minister or the complainant was the more reliable witness.

column1: But as she has been restricted now to establishing the facts
column2: she will reach no such judgment.

column1: So
column2: for example
column3: if the former aide Dominic Cummings told her that Boris Johnson was warned that the 20 May 2020 gathering was a rule-breaking social event and the prime minister maintains he was not
column4: she will not form a judgment on who is most likely to be telling the truth.

column1: Of course
column2: if she were to have written evidence in the form of a WhatsApp or email message read by the prime minister
column3: simply setting out the facts could be damaging for Boris Johnson.

column1: But those close to the 'save Boris' operation aren't expecting a 'smoking gun' - instead
column2: they say
column3: it's more likely there will be 'contestable' claims.

column1: While the prime minister hasn't seen the report
column2: he will have a sense of where it is going through the interviews he and staff have given to the inquiry.

column1: Those who expect very firm conclusions - especially where politicians are concerned - are likely to be disappointed.

And those internal and external opponents of Boris Johnson slavering at the prospect of WhatsApp messages and potentially embarrassing photographs from inside Downing Street being made public are likely to remain unsated.
Sue Gray won't be publishing all the evidence she has received
column2: or handed to the police.

column1: But those close to the process say it could be that some of the evidence could be incorporated verbatim into the report where it fits the narrative and perhaps provides a salient example of the prevailing culture.
Ultimately any decision on law-breaking is for the police
column2: not for Sue Gray - so it is perfectly possible that hers will not be the final word in this political drama.

column1: A bizarre race against time is under way for the US Navy to reach one of its downed fighter jets - before the Chinese get there first.

column2: and crammed with classified equipment - and
column3: as it is in international waters

column1: Whoever gets there first
column2: wins.

column1: The prize? All the secrets behind this very expensive
column2: leading-edge fighting force.

column1: Seven sailors were injured when the jet came down on Monday after it struck Vinson's deck during a military exercise.
It is now lying on the ocean bed
column2: but what happens next is a mystery. The Navy will not confirm either where it came down or how long it will take to retrieve it.

column1: China claims almost the entire South China Sea and has increasingly taken steps to assert that claim in recent years
column2: refusing to recognise a 2016 international tribunal ruling saying it had no legal basis.

column1: National security experts say Chinese military would be ""very keen"" to get to the jet but a US salvage vessel looks to be at least 10 days away from the crash site.
That's too late

column3: because the black box battery will die before then
column4: making it harder to locate the aircraft.

column1: It's vitally important the US gets this back
column2: she says. ""The F-35 is basically like a flying computer. It's designed to link up other assets - what the Air Force calls 'linking sensors to shooters'.""

column1: China doesn't have that technology so getting their hands on it would give them a huge leap forward
column2: she says.

column1: If they can get into the 35's networking capabilities
column2: it effectively undermines the whole carrier philosophy.""

column1: Asked if there were echoes of the Cold War here
column2: she says: ""It's all about who's the biggest dog in the park! This is basically The Hunt For Red October meets The Abyss - it's a brilliant three-act play.""

column1: Ms Austen
column2: a former adviser to the US Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and former senior Nato and EU diplomat
column3: said she believes any attempt by China to try to claim salvage rights was them ""stress testing"" the US.

column1: It comes at a vulnerable and dangerous time following what some perceived as a disorganised and disastrous Afghanistan pull-out
column2: she believes.

column1: There is no doubt China wants this plane

column5: a China affairs analyst and security fellow at the Truman Project.

column1: I think they would want to see actual parts of the plane

column1: The US Navy acknowledged in a statement that a recovery operation was under way following the ""mishap"" aboard USS Carl Vinson.

So how would the retrieval actually work?
A team from the US Navy Supervisor of Salvage and Diving would attach bags to the jet's fuselage which will then be slowly inflated to raise the wreckage.
This operation will be more difficult if the airframe is not largely in one piece.
The aircraft was likely to have been armed with at least a couple of missiles carried either on its wings or in the internal weapons bay which could also complicate recovery.
There is precedent for these winner-takes-all military cat and mouse games.

column2: at the height of the Cold War

column1: Two years earlier

column1: And it is widely believed that China got its hands on the wreckage of a secret US ""stealth"" helicopter that crash-landed in the raid on Osama bin Laden's compound in 2011.
Mr Barros said: ""We are sure the Chinese military got to see the onboard equipment and software then.""
The Guinness World Record-holding deepest successful salvage operation was the raising of the wreckage of a US Navy transport aircraft from the floor of the Philippine Sea in May 2019.
It was some 5
column3: 500 ft) below the surface

column2: of course
column3: is to destroy the jet to stop it getting into the hands of Beijing.

column1: The easiest thing to do would be to torpedo it!"" said one military officer.

column1: US President Joe Biden has affirmed that he will appoint an African-American woman to the top US court for the first time in history.
She will take up a seat to be vacated by liberal Justice Stephen Breyer
column2: who will retire in June.

column1: Appearing with Mr Breyer on Thursday
column2: Mr Biden promised a replacement with the ""experience and integrity"" needed for the role.

column1: He said he'll announce his nominee by the end of February. Three judges are considered top contenders.
Ketanji Brown Jackson
column3: is widely believed to be the top contender to replace Justice Breyer.

column1: Born in Washington DC
column2: Ms Jackson currently serves on the influential US Circuit Court of Appeals for the DC circuit. Three current justices previously served on the court.

column1: Previously
column2: Ms Jackson also served as a district court judge in DC from 2013 to 2021.

column1: The jurist has two degrees from Harvard University
column2: which she attended as an undergraduate and as a law student
column3: once serving as editor of the Harvard Law Review.

column1: Ms Jackson has also clerked for three federal judges in the past
column2: most notably Justice Breyer himself from 1999 to 2000.

column1: In January 2021
column2: she was among President Biden's very first judicial picks
column3: to fill the court seat vacated by his current Attorney General Merrick Garland.

column1: At that confirmation hearing
column2: former House Speaker and Republican vice-presidential candidate Paul Ryan introduced her; Mr Ryan is a relative by marriage.

column1: Our politics may differ
column2: but my praise for Ketanji's intellect
column3: for her character

column1: Leondra Kruger
column3: is in her eighth year on the California Supreme Court.

column1: Born to a Jamaican immigrant mother and a Jewish father
column2: the Pasadena native is a graduate of Harvard University and Yale Law School
column3: where she was the first black woman to serve as editor of the Yale Law Journal.

column1: Ms Kruger previously worked in the Obama Department of Justice
column2: from 2007 to 2013.

column1: During her tenure
column2: she argued 12 cases before the US Supreme Court as deputy to the Solicitor General
column3: the official who represents the government before the high court.

column1: She reportedly twice turned down offers to serve as the Solicitor General.
The jurist also once clerked for late Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens.
Julianna Michelle Childs
column3: has served on the federal bench in South Carolina since 2010.

column1: She also previously served as a circuit court judge in the state.
Unlike Ms Jackson and Ms Kruger
column2: Ms Childs did not attend an Ivy League school
column3: instead going to the University of South Carolina Law School.

column1: In private practice
column2: she was the first black female partner at a major law firm in the state.

column1: Congressman Jim Clyburn
column2: an influential black politician in the state whose endorsement of Mr Biden is widely credited with turning his 2020 campaign around
column3: has advocated for Ms Childs to be nominated because of her unorthodox resume.

column1: Most recently
column2: Mr Biden nominated Ms Childs to the DC Circuit Court of Appeals.

column1: Black women make up only about three percent of the federal judiciary
column2: according to data from the Federal Judicial Center
column3: the court system's research arm.

column1: Dr Taneisha Means
column2: a political science professor at Vassar College
column3: who researches race and judicial politics
column4: says that a history of racism
column5: sexism and elitism in the legal profession contributes to the scarcity.

column1: Black law students are often left on the outside looking in because they did not go to an Ivy League university
column2: or because they never clerked for a federal judge
column3: said Dr Means
column4: meaning few ever become eligible for the high court.

column1: Ms Means added that a gruelling confirmation process in the US Senate likely makes federal judgeships even less palatable. Recent analysis indicates non-white nominees often face much longer waits than their white counterparts to be confirmed by the mostly white chamber.
Strengthening the diversity of the judicial branch has been a key priority for the Biden administration.
The Senate confirmed 40 new district and appellate judges last year
column2: the most for a president in his first year since Ronald Reagan in 1981. Among them are the first openly LGBT female judge
column3: the first Muslim American judge and five black women.

column1: Russia has moved about 100
column2: 000 troops - equipped with everything from tanks and artillery to ammunition and air power - to Ukraine's border but denies it is planning an invasion.

column2: 000 Russian personnel are permanently stationed near Ukrainian territory.

column2: the Russian defence ministry released pictures of military units on their way to a training site in Rostov
column3: close to Ukraine's border.

column1: Some newly arrived units have travelled almost 4

column1: But some Western analysts say it is not clear that Russia has assembled everything needed for a ground invasion.
They point to the absence of fully manned mobile field hospitals in some areas.
The arrival of medical staff
column2: they say

column1: Satellite images provide additional clues.
The presence of troops can sometimes be detected by the colour of tents.
Those occupied are heated
column2: melting the snow on their roofs and appearing darker from above.

column1: Armoured vehicles can be identified by their shapes.
And tyre tracks or mud indicate vehicles on the move.
A Russian force of several thousand has been moved to Belarus for a joint military exercise that will reach its peak between 10 and 20 February.
The country's leader
column2: Alexander Lukashenko
column3: supports Russian President Vladimir Putin.

column1: The Ukrainian capital
column2: Kyiv

column1: And Western observers say the exercise

column3: could provide an opportunity to rehearse a mission against Ukraine.

column1: Images posted online claim to show military equipment
column2: including armoured vehicles
column3: tanks and rocket systems

column1: And Russia has announced the deployment of advanced Su-35 fighter planes to Belarus
column2: along with air-defence systems
column3: munitions and medical support.

column1: Russia is holding worldwide naval drills

column1: Six Russian Navy vessels
column2: capable of landing main battle tanks
column3: personnel and armoured vehicles

column1: But it is unclear whether the Black Sea and the Ukrainian coast may be their intended destination.

Some analysts say an amphibious landing by Russian troops would be extremely difficult and the naval forces may be a ""feint"" to draw Ukrainian ground forces away from more likely routes of attack on land.

column1: World leaders and survivors are marking Holocaust Memorial Day with remembrance services and events.
It honours the six million Jewish people murdered during the Holocaust
column2: alongside the millions of other people killed under Nazi persecution of other groups.

column1: The day also marks the 77th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp
column2: in what was then-Nazi-occupied Poland.

column1: Set up in 1940
column2: Auschwitz was initially intended to house Polish political prisoners - but it eventually became the largest of the Nazis' extermination camps
column3: where Adolf Hitler's plan to kill all Jewish people - the ""Final Solution"" - was put in to practice.

column1: About 1.1 million people were murdered there
column2: mostly Jewish.

column1: Here are some of the memorial events that took place during this year's Holocaust Memorial Day.
German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier (above
column2: centre)
column3: the Speaker of Israel's Knesset parliament
column5: (left) and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz (right) laid wreaths at the concrete steles of Berlin's Holocaust Memorial.

column1: Flags of the European Union
column2: Israel and Germany were flown at half-mast in Berlin.

column1: President of the lower house of the German parliament Baerbel Bas addressed a memorial ceremony at the Bundestag
column2: in Berlin (below).

column1: Mr Levi also spoke at the Bundestag.
In Brussels
column2: survivor Margot Friedlander (below
column3: left) sat next to European Parliament President Roberta Metsola to address a special plenary session.

column1: French Prime Minister Jean Castex (centre) visited the Auschwitz-Birkenau camp
column2: now a museum
column3: in Oswiecim

column1: He joined survivors in placing candles at the ""death wall""
column2: where Nazi SS soldiers shot and killed several thousands.

column1: In Austria
column2: Chancellor Karl Nehammer (below
column3: left) and Israel's Foreign Minister
column5: (right) attended a commemoration ceremony at the Mauthausen Memorial
column6: the site of a Nazi concentration camp.

column1: Mr Lapid also visited the Shoah Wall of Names memorial
column2: in Vienna's Ostarrichi Park (below).

column1: In Belgrade
column2: members of the Serbian army's Honor Guard joined a memorial service at the monument for victims of the Nazi concentration camp Sajmiste.

column1: Events were also held earlier in the week.
In York Minster's Chapter House
column2: 600 candles were laid out in the shape of the Star of David.

column1: Landmarks were lit up in purple in commemoration
column2: including the Penshaw Monument near Sunderland in north-east England.

column1: 393;Why Germany isn't sending weapons to Ukraine;2022-01-28T22:01:46.000Z;[];['germany'
