column1: Germany's refusal to send weapons to Ukraine has puzzled and angered some allies. But the reasons why Europe's most powerful country is standing back are historical and complex.
There's a great grassy plain to the east of Berlin where the soil tells terrible stories.
As farmers plough
column2: their blades disturb human bones
column3: weapons; the fragments of one of the most brutal battles of World War II.

column1: It was spring 1945. Hitler was hiding in a bunker in Berlin
column2: his troops in retreat. Soviet forces advanced from the east across the plain but
column3: above them on a hill called the Seelow Heights
column4: the Nazis had taken up a defensive position.

column1: It was
column2: by all accounts
column3: a muddy
column4: chaotic bloodbath. The Soviets eventually prevailed
column5: hastening the end of the war

column1: To visit the memorial at Seelow Heights is to understand how deeply entrenched this country's history remains in the minds of many Germans - and how the horrors of the twentieth century still influence its foreign policy today.
It is one of the reasons Germany has refused to send weapons to Ukraine
column2: prompting a furious response from politicians there.

column1: This is
column2: by and large
column3: a nation of pacifists.

column1: An annual survey reveals that most Germans believe diplomatic negotiation is the best way to resolve conflict. German troops rarely participate in anything other than peacekeeping missions; there are few exceptions - and they were controversial - including the Balkans in the 90s and
column2: more recently
column3: Afghanistan.

column1: It's also
column2: ironically
column3: one of the world's biggest arms exporters (though its output is dwarfed by that of the US and Russia). And it has strict controls over where weapons are sent
column4: even if Angela Merkel's government was sometimes accused of not sticking to those rules.

column1: Germany has a longstanding policy of restraint when it comes to military conflict of all sorts and weapons export is seen as fuelling conflict rather than reducing conflict
column2: says Thomas Kleine-Brockhoff from the German Marshall Fund. ""This longstanding policy says that Germany does not export arms into conflict zones.""

column1: Germany has departed from that principle
column2: to arm Peshmerga fighters battling IS in Northern Iraq. But the situation in Ukraine is different
column3: he says. The reason is history - the Nazi killings of millions of people in Ukraine and Russia.

column1: To export arms into the bloodlands that Germany helped to create
column2: to supply one part of the bloodlands with arms… against the other part of the bloodlands… is an anathema in the German political debate.""

column1: The situation on the Ukrainian border is testing Germany's new coalition government.
Chancellor Olaf Scholz - who probably thought Covid would be his greatest challenge - is now under pressure from his international allies to shift his country to a new
column2: more hawkish position.

column1: His government - a coalition of Social Democrats
column2: Greens and Free Democrats - came to power at the end of last year promising a values-based foreign policy and even stricter constraints on arms exports.

column1: Resisting calls - even from some within that government - to send weapons to Kiev
column2: Chancellor Scholz has instead paid for a field hospital
column3: offered to treat wounded soldiers in Germany and is sending five thousand helmets to Ukraine.

column1: Because there's another reason for Germany's reluctance - many here simply don't believe that sending weapons will solve the crisis.
Scholz's foreign minister
column2: Green politician Annalena Baerbock
column3: points out that Germany is a financial donor to Ukraine and believes that is more effective than sending arms.

column1: I do not think it's realistic to believe such weapons exports could turn around the military imbalance. The best protection is to prevent further aggression. The strongest weapon
column2: if you want to use that word
column3: is that we
column7: make clear every new aggression will have massive consequences.""

column1: Chancellor Scholz favours the dialogue-based approach pursued by his predecessor. Angela Merkel was instrumental
column2: along with President Macron of France
column3: in setting up the so-called Normandy format under which Germany
column5: Ukraine and Russia aimed to establish a ceasefire in Eastern Ukraine. It's hoped that same format might work now.

column1: Nils Schmidt
column2: foreign affairs spokesman for the chancellor's social democrats
column3: says ""France and Germany are mediators and I think it's not very appropriate for a mediator nation to send weapons to Ukraine
column5: because we are trying to promote a diplomatic solution.""

column1: And Germany is well placed for such diplomacy. Chancellor Scholz may not have Mrs Merkel's clout with President Putin. But
column2: thanks to their histories
column3: Germany's relationship to Russia is unlike that of many other Western countries.

column1: This video can not be played
Thousands of German firms do business there. Many Germans - including Angela Merkel - grew up behind the Iron Curtain
column2: learning Russian at school. Her ability to communicate regularly with Vladimir Putin when other leaders could not
column3: was often attributed to their shared experience of life in the Communist East.

column1: What puzzles - and angers - many around the world (and a fair few in Germany too) is why Chancellor Scholz isn't playing his most obvious card.
The two countries' economic ties are perhaps most controversially embodied in the Nordstream 2 pipeline
column2: which
column3: if and when it comes online
column4: would double the amount of Russian gas coming into Europe via Germany.

column1: Chancellor Scholz is under pressure to scrap the project by way of a sanction against Russia. That he has not yet done so is
column2: critics argue
column3: emblematic of Germany's self-interest.

column1: It's a sore topic for his government. His social democrats
column2: who say the pipeline is a private economic project
column3: are behind it. But his partners
column5: say it's political and the Greens would dearly love to let it go.

column1: Mr Scholz has indicated that
column2: should Russia invade Ukraine
column3: all options will be on the table
column7: prompting some to wonder whether history will judge him canny or weak and hesitant.

column1: It's wise to have a certain level of strategic ambiguity so that Putin cannot start calculating which price he would have to pay in case of doing this or that
column2: says Nils Schmidt. ""That's why is so important to have all these options on the table.""

column1: And
column2: in the meantime
column3: as Vladimir Putin tests the nerves of the West
column4: Germany faces fundamental questions about its pacifist instincts.

column1: Even towards the end of the Merkel era
column2: calls were growing for Germany to take on a more substantial military role on the world stage.

column1: And
column2: as visitors to Seelow Heights
column3: who imagine the screams of Katyusha rockets and the shouts of dying men
column5: Germany knows very well what is at stake - and the cost of getting it wrong.

column1: A British ""hitman"" has been found guilty of conspiring to kill a Pakistani dissident in the Netherlands.
A court in London heard Muhammad Gohir Khan was offered £100
column3: 000) to carry out the murder in Rotterdam last year.

column1: However he failed to track his target down
column2: and was arrested on his return to the UK.

column1: Now a jury has given a unanimous guilty verdict of conspiracy to murder and he is set be sentenced in March.
The intended victim
column2: Waqass Goraya
column3: has told the BBC he is sure the Pakistani intelligence services were ultimately behind the plot and that it forms part of a wider crackdown on dissenting voices both inside and outside Pakistan.

column1: Pakistani officials would not comment on the case.
Gohir Khan
column2: from east London
column3: had racked up debts of more than £200
column4: 000 whilst running a cargo company. He was working as a delivery driver for a supermarket
column5: but reacted enthusiastically when he was contacted about a ""job"" in Europe by a contact in Pakistan.

column1: Khan claimed in court that he initially did not know what the job entailed
column2: but he used fishing analogies in a WhatsApp conversation with a middleman man named as Muzzamil who was to take 20% of the fee.

column1: Is it a deep sea fish or just tuna?"" Khan asked. Muzzamil
column2: who was also known as ""Papa"" because of his resemblance to cartoon character ""Papa Smurf""
column3: replied

column1: Their grim intent was made clear when Khan discussed needing a ""tool"" or gun for the job
column2: whilst at another point Muzzamil wrote about the target: ""It's not a SHARK… A little fish… Little knife / hook / worm with a string is enough.""

column1: The man they planned on killing was Waqass Goraya
column2: a prominent social media activist and critic of the Pakistani military and government
column3: living in Rotterdam in the Netherlands. He was abducted and tortured whilst visiting Pakistan in January 2017 by suspected members of the intelligence services
column4: and told the BBC he was convinced they had now attempted to have him killed in Europe.

column1: They don't like being called out for enforced disappearances or their torture cells
column2: he said
column3: adding: ""It shows their cowardice. They are scared of people talking. People who are unarmed
column4: with nothing but a pen or keyboard. They are more scared of them than the people with guns.""

column1: Pakistan's powerful military did not respond to requests for comment
column2: whilst the country's information minister refused to discuss the case.

column1: Government officials claim there is no clampdown on freedom of speech in Pakistan and the army denies interfering in politics
column2: but human rights groups have repeatedly raised concerns about a series of violent attacks in Pakistan on journalists and activists who accuse the military of manipulating the country's electoral system.

column1: The threat to Pakistani dissidents extends to those outside the country too.

Ayesha Siddiqa is an academic who has written extensively about the Pakistani military. In January 2019 she received a visit and letter from police in Britain warning of ""credible information"" that her life was in danger if she travelled back to Pakistan.
Dr Siddiqa shared the letter with the BBC
column2: and said her own inquiries had led her to find out
column3: ""there was a contract on my head given to some Afghan warlords to be eliminated on return to Pakistan… if the temperature was raised I could be targeted in the UK as well.""

column1: Like Mr Goraya
column2: Dr Siddiqa told the BBC she believed the Pakistani intelligence services were behind the threat.

column1: I have no one else to suspect.""
Three other Pakistanis living in the UK confirmed to the BBC they had contact with the police over the possibility of them being targeted in Britain.
One of them
column2: Fazal Khan
column3: is a lawyer whose 14 year-old son Sahibzada Umer Khan was amongst the victims of a massacre at a school in the northern Pakistani city of Peshawar by militants in 2014.

column1: Since then
column2: he has filed numerous court petitions involving Pakistan's military authorities
column3: most recently criticising them for their soft treatment of one notorious former militant leader
column4: who was kept under ""house arrest"" before mysteriously escaping.

column1: As a result of his activism Mr Khan has faced threats from extremists and
column2: he believes
column3: the security services. In July 2020 Mr Khan survived an assassination attempt in Pakistan and later fled to the UK.

column1: Last April
column2: British police warned him of a threat to his life
column3: advising him to maintain a ""low profile"" and not to venture into public places.

column1: Mr Khan told the BBC two plainclothes officers gave him an ""emergency police number"" and said
column2: ""you are in our system
column3: if you feel anything abnormal then give us a call and an armoured vehicle will arrive to rescue you"".

column1: The officers did not specify the exact nature of the threat
column2: but Mr Khan believes it must be linked to the Pakistani security services
column3: describing being forced to live ""a life of fear"".

column1: Others elsewhere in Europe have also been warned by Western intelligence agencies
column2: including Taha Siddiqui
column3: a journalist who escaped an abduction attempt in Islamabad and now lives in France.

column1: At Kingston Crown Court
column2: the jury heard Gohir Khan and the middleman Muzzamil discussed the possibility of further ""jobs"" after killing Mr Goraya.

column1: Waqass Goraya had been told in 2018 of threats to his life by the FBI. In February last year
column2: before Gohir Khan had even travelled to the Netherlands
column3: he was rushed out of his home in Rotterdam by Dutch intelligence agents and taken to a secure location.

column1: The operation targeting him at times appeared amateur and poorly organised
column2: with Khan bemoaning delays in the process as ""dysfunctional"". Meanwhile
column3: Khan produced fake doctored receipts and invented a fictional ""crew"" accompanying him in order to try to extract more money for the hit.

column1: Testifying in court
column2: Khan
column3: who was at times tearful
column4: came across as a bumbling opportunist
column5: describing for example how he crashed a car in Rotterdam within minutes of renting it as he wasn't used to driving on the right hand side of the road.

column1: When attempting to bypass Covid travel restrictions in order to travel to the Netherlands in June 2021
column2: Khan asked a contact to pretend to be his brother living there.

column1: On arrival
column2: however
column3: he was questioned by a border official who called the ""brother"" on the phone and asked him how old Khan was in order to verify his identity. Unable to answer
column5: and Khan was denied entry to the country.

column1: A few days later
column2: Khan made the trip for a second time and was finally able to reach Rotterdam. He purchased a 19-inch knife and staked out what he believed was Mr Goraya's home. However
column3: he soon realised the address he had been provided with was wrong.

column1: Muzzamil assured him that his ""boss"" had received a video of Mr Goraya at the address around six months earlier
column2: but unable to locate him Khan returned to London. On leaving Rotterdam he was questioned by a Dutch border force officer about his trip.

column1: Struggling for an answer
column2: Khan replied that he had been ""touristing""
column3: leading the officer to refer him to police in Britain. They arrested him and eventually found his message history with Muzzamil.

column1: In court
column2: Khan insisted he never planned to go ahead with the murder and simply wanted to extract money from Muzammil
column3: telling police he only bought a knife in Rotterdam to cut bread and fruit with. The prosecution argued he fully intended to carry out the killing and the jury agreed
column4: convicting him of conspiracy to murder.

column1: The Pakistan-based ""client"" who had ordered the hit was never named in court
column2: though Muzzamil referred to a ""big boss"" who gave a green light to the operation and who he had worked with for around 20 years.

column1: Muzzamil's full identity has not been disclosed either
column2: though he appears to be a British national living in Pakistan. Police officials said the case remains an ""active investigation"" and appealed for anyone with information about Muzammil to contact them.

column1: Mr Goraya is urging the UK authorities to further investigate the case and all those involved.
It should not stop here… They have to go after the people who transferred the money
column2: who ordered the hit.""

column1: He has no doubt that trail will eventually lead to the same Pakistani intelligence services he accuses of torturing him five years ago. He
column2: along with other campaigners
column3: also want Swedish and Canadian officials to re-open investigations into the deaths of two Baloch dissidents in 2021
column4: both of which were found not to be suspicious.

column1: Some activists worry Britain's close diplomatic relationship and co-operation with the Pakistani authorities on counter-terrorism will lead them to play down the significance of the episode.
Mr Goraya
column2: however
column3: is determined

column1: Threats and intimidation don't work
column2: he told the BBC. ""It makes people resilient. It makes their voice louder.""

column1: 397;How streaming services left us with too much to watch;2022-01-27T00:38:12.000Z;[];['coronavirus pandemic'];['plus'
column2: 'titles'
column3: 'robust'

column1: The stunning growth of video streaming services like Netflix
column2: Amazon Prime Video and Disney Plus
column3: has transformed how we watch movies and TV shows.

column1: Here we speak to industry insiders
column2: from producers to executives
column3: to get their take on future trends for the so-called ""streamers"" sector.

column1: One of these is film producer
column2: Miranda Bailey
column3: who found that when her new movie premiered at this month's Sundance Film Festival there was a catch.

column1: Due to Covid restrictions
column2: the film - God's Country
column3: starring Thandiwe Newton - could not be shown on a cinema screen at the annual event in the small Utah town of Park City. Instead
column4: it had to be streamed to the festival's virtual attendees.

column1: Obviously it's a great disappointment
column2: to me and the other filmmakers
column3: to not have the experience of showing our movie to an audience of indie film lovers at Sundance

column1: Historically
column2: filmmakers show their new movies at Sundance and other festivals
column3: to get cinema distribution deals. The focus has shifted to streaming platform contracts
column4: or deals for distribution in cinemas and streaming simultaneously.

column1: Ideally
column2: the filmmakers I work with would be sure to secure some sort of theatrical [cinema] run
column3: says Ms Bailey. ""But with the pandemic right now that seems to be a promise no outlet can truly fulfil.

column1: Fortunately there are a plethora of streaming platforms with brilliant original content who care about indies
column2: and are spending money for award campaigns like traditional [cinema] distribution used to do.""

column1: The video streaming sector has become a huge part of the entertainment industry - a dominance partly driven by cinemas being shut down during the pandemic.
The world's largest platform
column2: Netflix
column3: had 222 million subscribers at the end of last year
column5: Amazon Prime Video had 175 million viewers in 2021
column6: while Disney Plus' base topped 118 million.

column1: These vast user numbers are supported by studies that show a growing number of people now prefer to watch new release movies at home
column2: rather than go to a cinema. One report last October found that this was now the case for 71% of Americans.

column1: At the same time
column2: we now stream TV shows at a time of our choosing more often than we watch programmes as they are broadcast by a traditional
column3: linear channel such as BBC 1 or Channel 4.

column1: The convenience of on-demand viewing is obvious
column2: but Lisa Holme
column3: group senior vice president of content and commercial strategy at US television company
column5: fears consumers are now put off by the sheer number of streaming services available.

column1: We now have a lot of content available across six or eight major streaming services
column2: of which [our] Discovery Plus is one
column3: she says. ""I think consumers are now finding themselves a bit overwhelmed by the choice.""

column1: Ms Holme adds that some people are ""feeling confused and annoyed"" that they have to go to multiple streaming services to get all the content that they want.
For the US
column2: figures show that 46% of homes with broadband subscribe to four or more video streaming services. While in the UK
column3: one study found 65% of homes subscribe to two or more of the providers.

column1: Phil Hopkins
column2: president of niche streaming channel Fandor
column3: says in a crowded market like this standing out from the competition is crucial. His service specialises in showing independent or classic movies

column1: The biggest challenge is that there are a lot similarities to the main streaming services
column2: and they're not really doing much in the way of separating themselves to have their own identity
column3: he says.

column1: Mr Hopkins thinks that among the big players in streaming
column2: Disney Plus is on the most robust footing. ""They have such an amazing legacy [of Disney titles to show]
column3: he says. ""But I don't know how many other streaming platforms can survive on their own merits... eventually people are going to get fatigue and look elsewhere for something that's unique and different.""

column1: At streaming site Paramount Plus
column2: its plan is to accelerate its popularity using live channels
column3: a new feature where its most popular shows and movies go out at scheduled times on 20 genre-themed channels - mimicking traditional TV channels.

column1: Even in the era of on-demand
column2: there is clearly a strong consumer appetite for reimagined linear channels that provide effortless
column3: lean-back entertainment
column5: president and chief executive of ViacomCBS Streaming

column1: Whereas at streaming app Struum
column2: its plan is to make life easier by offering streams from numerous other providers all in one place. This means if you sign up you can access 25 sites
column3: from the likes of the BBC

column1: Viewers want to find that next gem of a show or unknown movie
column2: says Lauren Devillier
column3: chief executive of Struum. ""We provide a curated experience so people can 'go deep' on a particular subject.

column1: You love documentaries? We have hundreds. True crime? LGBTQ? We have all of it for you in one subscription
column2: making simple what might otherwise be confounding.""

column1: New Tech Economy is a series exploring how technological innovation is set to shape the new emerging economic landscape.
Paul Erickson
column2: senior analyst at market research firm Parks Associates
column3: says the growth of streaming services was fuelled by the pandemic and continues today despite the general relaxation of lockdown rules.

column1: Yet
column2: he cautions that subscription growth in the streaming video market has already begun to slow. He says many consumers are now experiencing ""subscription overload"" and becoming more discriminating with their spending.

column1: But as the streaming services wrestle each other for our affections
column2: what does it mean for cinema chains? Are they doomed?

column1: Far from it
column2: says Paul Serwitz
column3: president of US firm Landmark Theatres. He points out that attendances ""steadily increased"" in 2021. ""[And] expectations are for cinema attendance to continue increasing as consumer confidence improves with the Covid evolution

column1: But Tearlach Hutcheson
column2: vice president at US cinema chain Studio Movie Grill
column3: says while regular film goers have returned to cinemas
column4: ""it is the casual movie goer who hasn't"".

column1: US National Public Radio TV and media critic Eric Deggans says cinemas will need to improve the experience for film goers to compete with streaming.
We're always going to have movie theatres but what form are they going to take? How many of them are there going to be and what kinds of films are they going to show? All of that is up in the air.""

column1: A 35-year-old man has been found guilty of stalking British number one tennis player Emma Raducanu.
Amrit Magar from Edgware was convicted at Bromley Magistrates' Court on Friday and will be sentenced at a later date.
Magar was captured on door camera footage at the 19-year-old player's south London home
column2: where she lives with her parents
column3: leaving notes and cards.

column1: In a statement to the court
column2: reported by the Daily Mail
column3: Raducanu said she was now fearful of going out alone.

column1: Since all this has happened
column2: I have felt creeped out. I feel very apprehensive if I go out
column3: especially if I am on my own

column1: Because of this I feel like my freedom has been taken away from me. I am constantly looking over my shoulder. I feel on edge and worried this could happen again. I don't feel safe in my own home which is where I should feel safest.""
Magar visited Raducanu's home a number of times during December last year.
On one occasion
column2: the former Amazon delivery driver left a hand-drawn map to show the tennis player he had walked 23 miles from his house in north-west London to reach her.

column1: He also left her a note which read ""you deserve love"".
Raducanu
column2: the reigning US Open champion
column3: was named BBC Sport Personality of the Year in December.

column1: 403;Climate change: Key crops face major shifts as world warms;2022-01-26T19:02:29.000Z;[];['intergovernmental panel on climate change'
column2: 'coffee'
column3: 'cop26'

column1: The parts of the world suitable for growing coffee
column2: cashews and avocados will change dramatically as the world heats up
column3: according to a new study.

column1: Key coffee regions in Brazil
column2: Indonesia
column3: Vietnam and Colombia will all ""drastically decrease"" by around 50% by 2050.

column1: Suitable areas for cashews and avocados will increase but most will be far from current sites of production.
The authors say that greater efforts must be made to help farmers adapt.
Coffee is one of the world's most important crops
column2: not just as key beverage but as a livelihood for millions of small farmers.

column1: And thanks to growing consumer preferences in richer countries
column2: demand for avocados and cashews has increased substantially in recent decades.

column1: While the threat to coffee from climate change has been well documented in recent years
column2: there is little information about how rising temperatures will impact avocados and cashews.

column1: In this study
column2: the authors looked at how rising temperatures and changing rates of precipitation will impact the three crops over the next 30 years. The researchers have also
column3: for the first time
column4: incorporated information about land and soil characteristics.

column1: Coffee is the most susceptible crop to high temperatures. In those countries accounting for the majority of the world's production of Arabica - the dominant coffee variety - suitability for growing the crop will decrease by around half by 2050 - a ""drastic"" reduction
column2: according to the report.

column1: Some key areas will see a heavier impact. In the lowest temperature scenario
column2: there would be a reduction of 76% in Brazil's most suitable areas for coffee. In Colombia it would shrink by 63%.

column1: Some regions at the northern and southern ends of today's growing areas will become more suitable
column2: including Argentina
column3: South Africa
column4: China and New Zealand among others.

column1: But according to the authors
column2: this doesn't mean that these new regions can easily replace the current sites.

column1: The key message for those that are in the main producing regions today is that farming systems have to adapt to the changing conditions
column2: said lead author Roman Grüter
column3: from Zurich University of Applied Sciences.

column1: If there is already coffee grown in a new area where it is just about possible with some management options
column2: it might get easier or might be possible to expand but it doesn't mean that we will get perfect coffee growing regions within 10 years or so.""

column1: For cashews
column2: the picture is different. Overall
column3: the areas of the world that are highly suitable for growing the crop will increase by 17%.

column1: However
column2: in some of the countries that currently are reliant on cashews as a key cash crop the news is not good. India loses significant areas of suitability
column3: while Benin loses half its suitable areas under the lowest modelled increase in temperature.

column1: For avocados
column2: the picture is also complicated - especially in the biggest producing countries.

column1: Mexico
column2: the world's largest producer
column3: sees a major increase in suitable lands
column5: Peru - another major grower - loses around half its suitable areas under the same climate model.

column1: While the rise in temperatures and changes in rainfall patterns might make some areas more suitable
column2: the authors are concerned that a major shift to develop these crops in new regions might see more forests converted to farmland or a rise of invasive species.

column1: In regions that might get more suitable for growing those crops
column2: it is important to make sure that there are no negative environmental impacts such as deforestation
column3: said Roman Grüter.

column1: In all of these changes
column2: the local stakeholders
column3: the local communities have to get involved in these changing processes. It should be really participatory.""

column1: A temperature rise of around 1C over the past 30 years has seen farmers in Sicily turn to a range of new crops more suited to warmer conditions.
One of them is Andrea Passanisi
column2: who grows avocados close to Mount Etna. Along with other producers
column3: this change has been very successful for Andrea.

column1: However
column2: as temperatures continue to rise
column3: growing conditions are getting more difficult.

column1: The real climate change here is in the seasons
column2: he told BBC News.

column1: Once it was cold in November and December
column2: now it is January or February - that is not good for avocados.""

column1: Increased levels of drought and intense downpours are also challenging for farmers.
If you grow on land that's not suitable for avocado
column2: it's the end
column3: Andrea said.

column1: We will continue to grow
column2: as we have good land
column3: but we will not have as much fruit.""

column1: While the changing temperatures might seem to be bad news for current growers of these crops
column2: there are some active steps that producers can take that could mitigate climate change.

column1: It is possible that some regions where avocados are currently grown the use of the genetic variability of avocado might help
column2: said Dr Joaquin Guillermo Ramirez Gil
column3: from the National University of Colombia
column4: who wasn't involved in the new study.

column1: This species has three 'races' with different geographical origins
column2: which makes it quite 'plastic' to adapt to different climatic conditions.

column1: There are also local adaptations and new management alternatives such as the use of bio-stimulants and nanotechnology-based products as a basis for reducing stress due to extreme weather conditions.""
The research has been published in the journal Plos One.

405;The scramble for cargo aircraft as shipping costs soar;2022-01-28T00:08:44.000Z;[];['boeing'
column2: 'airbus group'
column3: 'transport'

column1: Last summer
column2: as the shipping supply crisis worsened
column3: a cargo aircraft in Italy was rapidly loaded with thousands of lipsticks. They were bound for the US

column1: Mehir Sethi
column2: chief executive and founder of California-based beauty brand True + Luscious
column3: says she had relied on sea freight for years. It had always been reliable.

column1: But to get those 15
column2: 000 lipsticks to her customers on time
column3: her only option was to pay to send them by air.

column1: At great pain to myself
column2: we had to do it for two time-sensitive shipments. These were goods that were already committed to retailers.""

column1: The lipsticks were flown-in at a slight loss to the business
column2: but she says it was worth it to keep the clients.

column1: Firms have been making thousands of decisions like this in recent months. And there is no sign of let-up yet.
We have used a lot of air freight
column2: which we're not excited about
column3: but it's a necessary thing with the challenges we're all being faced with
column5: chief financial officer for sportswear brand
column7: on an earnings call in November.

column1: The Eastman Chemical Company similarly reported resorting to air freight to ship specialty plastics.
A US Census Bureau service called USA Trade Online
column2: that tracks cargo flows in and out of the country
column3: notes in the first 10 months of 2021
column4: 78.9 million kg of car parts were sent by air from Asia to the US - a staggering increase from the 3 million kg shipped during the same period in 2020.

column1: More technology of business:
Sending goods by air has always been expensive. But now it is more expensive than ever.
Air freight costs from Asia to North America ""have hit levels I've never seen before
column2: $15 (£11) per kg which is just insanely high
column3: says Greg Knowler
column4: senior Europe editor at IHS Markit's Journal of Commerce.

column1: Delays affecting sea freight are partly to blame for this but so is the huge fall in passenger flights since the start of the pandemic.
More than half of all the air freight in the world usually travels via 'belly cargo' in the holds of passenger planes. But with far less of that space available
column2: airlines have been scrambling to convert passenger aircraft into freighters
column3: and bring older models out of retirement.

column1: AirBridgeCargo Airlines
column2: a subsidiary of Russian air freight specialist
column3: Volga-Dnepr
column4: is boosting its fleet with an additional six aircraft
column7: says has been a ""peak season we never had before"".

column1: Backlogs at airports  have ""rolled over like [a] snowball since early autumn
column2: he adds.

column1: Some carriers
column2: such as Air Canada
column3: have also rushed cargo aircraft into service sooner than planned - before they've even had a chance to finish their paintwork

column1: Manufacturers
column2: including Airbus
column3: have been inundated with requests to convert former passenger aircraft to carry more cargo
column4: just to get additional capacity into the sky. The process includes removing the passenger seats and installing larger doors.

column1: We're seeing a lot of people buying these conversions
column2: they're sold out for the next two to three years
column3: says Crawford Hamilton
column4: head of marketing for freighter marketing at Airbus.

column1: That's something that we were not in a position two years ago to say.""
While air freight only represents roughly 1% of the entire freight market in terms of volume
column2: it accounts for about 35% of the value. Sometimes
column3: expensive products such as consumer electronics and fashion goods that have a short market life are sent by air. Plus
column5: planes have carried countless loads of vaccines and personal protective equipment.

column1: Airbus has also launched a new air-cargo service using its five-strong fleet of BelugaST aircraft
column2: also known as flying whales thanks to their huge fuselage.

column1: The question is whether demand for air freight will remain strong
column2: even if the pandemic subsides. With lots of aircraft permanently converted to carry freight
column3: and belly cargo capacity rising once again
column4: Robert Mayer at Cranfield University questions whether there might be too much capacity in the market half a decade from now.

column1: Yet aircraft manufacturers seem confident. Airbus expects rising demand for dedicated cargo carriers in the coming years - and it has just launched the A350F aircraft in anticipation of that.
It can carry as much cargo
column2: in terms of volume
column3: as a Boeing 747 but is 40% more fuel efficient. This is achieved partly through the use of lighter materials
column4: composites and titanium in the body of the aircraft.

column1: Boeing
column2: too
column3: is bullish. It forecasts that the number of air freighters will grow globally by 60% between now and 2039. If correct

column1: Tom Sanderson
column2: director of product marketing at Boeing
column3: says it may introduce a freighter variant of its latest wide-bodied passenger jet
column5: but it would be ""multiple years"" before it came into service.

column1: More freight might move by air in the coming years but that could lead to an unwelcome rise in emissions unless aviation gets greener.
Both Boeing and Airbus are currently testing ""sustainable aviation fuels""
column2: including biofuels from renewable sources that can be used on existing aircraft instead of fossil fuel-based propellants.

column1: Small electric planes will are also likely to become more common. DHL Express has ordered 12 fully electric aircraft from Eviation
column2: for example.

column1: Besides the prohibitive cost
column2: one thing that puts Ms Sethi off using air freight more often to fly in her beauty product is the environmental impact.

column1: It would definitely bother me
column2: just the sheer increase in our carbon footprint as a company if we were to rely on air freight
column3: she says.

column1: Like many others
column2: she is reconsidering her reliance on global supply chains. She has decided to source some of her products from suppliers closer to home
column3: to avoid shipping problems in the future.

column1: Some of the orders we were placing to our Italian manufacturer will now go to our New Jersey manufacturer
column2: she says.

column1: I just can't cut it too close any more.""

Mason Greenwood has not responded to the social media allegations.

column1: 419;How the high cost of living is hitting Singapore's poor;2022-01-31T00:02:24.000Z;[];['singapore'
column2: 'asia'
column3: 'asia pacific'

column1: In South East Asia you don't get much more of a staple food than chicken rice. Found in almost every food court and hawker centre
column2: it is considered one of Singapore's national dishes.

column1: Daniel Tan
column2: who owns six chicken rice stalls
column3: has previously charged $2.20 (£1.60) for a small portion. But Covid has seen the cost of his ingredients rise sharply.

column1: The price of chicken has gone up by 50% and vegetable costs have more than doubled since January 2020
column2: he says.

column1: We've been absorbing the costs for a significant period of time
column2: he tells me as we meet at one of his OK Chicken Rice stalls in the north of Singapore.

column1: When the pandemic hit our first thought was this was a short-term emergency - six months
column2: maybe a year - so we held [prices] for as long as we can because we were hoping for the whole thing to be over.""

column1: But when his electricity bills also jumped
column2: Mr Tan decided it was time to raise prices. ""A thousand dollar electrical bill for a chicken rice store really is not sustainable
column3: he says.

column1: If I go on any further
column2: either my staff are not paid or I have to close down some stores and that's not what we want to do.""

column1: Due to border closures and new employment regulations
column2: Mr Tan has faced staff shortages and higher salaries
column3: which all feed into rising costs for his business.

column1: The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) says global food prices rose 28% in 2021.
The last time food prices were this high was in 2011
column2: when policymakers were actually warning about a global food crisis
column3: says Dr Abdul Abiad of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).

column1: These latest price rises are due to higher energy costs
column2: which affect food and fertiliser production
column3: with global supply chain issues compounding the problem.

column1: Even in a wealthy nation like Singapore
column2: it means that the number of families seeking help has increased.

column1: What we have seen when we make the door-to-door deliveries is that young families [with] both husband and wife working a part-time job or in the gig economy - these were the families that got impacted when Covid hit and all the part-time work dried up
column2: says Nichol Ng
column3: co-founder of Food Bank Singapore.

column1: It is not just the poorest 10% of the population who now need help
column2: she says: ""It has slowly crept to maybe 20% of the population including middle income families that might not even know where to get help in the first place.""

column1: And it is also not just higher food prices that are affecting those in need. ""Due to Covid
column2: everybody's self-awareness about looking after themselves in terms of hygiene has increased
column3: says Ms Ng.

column1: But higher palm oil prices mean that shampoos
column2: hand soaps and sanitisers have also become a lot more expensive.

column1: Up to 20% of our requests thus far
column2: especially starting from the second half of last year
column3: has been pivoting towards personal hygiene products

column1: Ms Ng is also concerned that the current wave of inflation does not seem to be temporary. ""In the past
column2: at certain times of the year
column3: you might see these price surges but it seems that this inflation is going to be persistent - and none of us really have that crystal ball to understand when it is going to end

column1: Elsewhere in the region the impact of higher prices is even more severe. The latest FAO report shows more than 375 million people in Asia faced hunger in 2020
column2: an increase of 54 million from the previous year.
the Global Food Banking Network saw the number of families needing help increase by more than 130% to 40m
column3: with half of them living in Asia.

column1: This is despite the fact that food price increases in Asia have been more muted than in the US or Europe
column2: where inflation has soared to levels not seen in decades.

column1: There are several reasons for this
column2: including a good rice harvest in 2021
column3: says the ADB's Dr Abiad. While maize prices rose 44% last year and wheat by 31%
column4: rice prices dropped 4% . ""So rice being the main staple in many Asian economies contributed to a food price inflation being lower in the region

column1: Asian nations also produce a lot of their own food
column2: which has been sold in domestic markets rather than being exported. Governments have also been working to ensure that food supplies have been stable
column3: says Dr Abiad.

column1: In the Philippines
column2: for example
column3: liberalisation of rice imports has allowed the supply of rice to improve which has kept prices low.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: China has been stockpiling various important food products
column3: which has resulted in it bucking the trend
column4: with the country's food prices falling in 2021.

column1: But it has also led to criticism that the world's second biggest economy
column2: which accounts for 20% of global population
column3: is hoarding supplies as it is estimated to hold 69% of the world's corn reserves
column4: 60% of its rice and 51% of its wheat by mid-2022
column5: according to the US Department of Agriculture.

column1: Singapore imports the majority of its foodstuffs
column2: but so far big supermarket chains like NTUC FairPrice have decided not to pass on higher prices to consumers.

column1: To keep the prices of key products stable
column2: the firm says it is employing various strategies including ""stockpiling of daily essentials
column3: forward buying and diversifying our import sources to over 100 countries"".

column1: NTUC FairPrice also has more than 2
column2: 000 own-brand products such as rice
column3: oil
column4: toiletries and cleaning products that it says are at least 10% cheaper than comparable popular brands.

column1: Mr Tan of OK Chicken Rice
column2: who also owns three mini supermarkets
column3: says smaller retailers tend to take their cue from larger rivals when pricing goods.

column1: They act like a central bank to the rest of the grocery players in Singapore. The good thing about it is that inflation doesn't spike up as much during a crisis but the bad side effect is that entrepreneurship is stifled and only semi-government players can survive
column2: he says.

column1: The question is
column2: after the whole thing is over how many smaller players are left?"" asks Mr Tan.

column1: Global food prices are expected to remain high this year and the FAO's David Dawe says this is of concern for Asian governments because price hikes have not yet worked their way through the system.
If global prices continue to rise
column2: there will be an impact
column3: especially for lower income families who spend bigger proportion of their income on food.""

column1: Economists like Mr Dawe and Dr Abiad remain optimistic that Asian countries will continue to be shielded from double-digit food inflation.
But for those on the ground
column2: like Mr Tan and Ms Ng
column3: the issue feels more acute. They wonder whether higher prices
column5: will linger on just as the pandemic has.

column1: Two police officers have been shot dead in western Germany during a routine traffic stop.
At 04:20 local time (03:20 GMT) the officers stopped a vehicle in the Kusel district in Rhineland-Palatinate
column2: a state on the French border.

column1: A 29-year-old male officer and a 24-year-old female officer were shot dead at the scene. The latter was still a student at police academy.
Police have launched a manhunt for the perpetrators.
Roads in the area remain closed and authorities have urged people not to pick up hitchhikers
column2: saying at least one suspect is armed. Officers have also expanded the hunt to the neighbouring state of Saarland.

column1: Some details of the incident are unclear. As yet there is no description of the attackers
column2: the vehicle
column3: or the direction they fled
column4: and police have not suggested a possible motive.

column1: German newspaper Bild reports that the officers sent two radio messages from the road.
In the first
column2: the officers reportedly said that they had stopped a suspicious vehicle and discovered dead game in the boot.

column1: A second message followed soon after
column2: the paper added. ""They're shooting at us!"" the officers reportedly said
column3: before radio contact broke off.

column1: By the time reinforcements arrived the female officer was already dead
column2: local media report. Her colleague died soon after.

column1: Sabrina Kunz
column2: state chairwoman of the police union
column3: said their thoughts are with the relatives and colleagues of the dead.

column1: We are living through the true nightmare of all police officers
column2: she said
column3: adding she was ""stunned"" by what had happened.

422;Downing Street parties: What is the police investigation?;2022-01-31T15:37:20.000Z;[];['boris johnson'
column2: 'metropolitan police service'
column3: 'cressida dick'

column1: The Metropolitan Police is now known to be investigating 12 gatherings held in Downing Street and Whitehall during the coronavirus pandemic.
The exact number was revealed in an update on a separate inquiry into the parties
column2: being carried out by senior civil servant Sue Gray.

column1: Ms Gray has published the initial findings of her inquiry into the parties.
It lists 16 alleged parties or gatherings held by government staff during Covid restrictions.
She says that police are investigating all but four of these
column2: and consequently
column3: she is ""extremely limited"" in what she can say.

column1: Those being looked into by the Met include a gathering on 13 November 2020 held in the No 10 Downing Street flat
column2: where the prime minister and his wife live. They are also looking at a gathering in the No 10 Cabinet room on 19 June 2020
column3: to mark the PM's birthday.

column1: Last week
column2: the Met asked for the Gray report to leave out details of parties being investigated by police
column3: to ""avoid any prejudice to our investigation"".

column1: This led to some claims that the most serious allegations against Downing St staff - and possibly the prime minister - could be watered down.
Met Commissioner Dame Cressida Dick said her officers would not normally investigate past breaches of Covid-19 regulations.
But she said retrospective investigations were carried out for ""the most serious and flagrant type of breach"" where there was evidence and certain criteria were met
column2: including:

column1: This video can not be played
In some ways this is a very straightforward investigation for the police
column2: says BBC home affairs correspondent Daniel Sandford.

column1: Much of the legwork will have been done and the police need to decide who was at the events and whether they had a good reason to be there
column2: he says.

column1: This is not a multi-month investigation
column2: this is something that should be containable in a small number of weeks.""

column1: The investigation will be carried out by the Met's long-standing Special Inquiry Team - the UK's principle counter-political corruption unit.
The unit has previously carried out more than 170 investigations - such as people using a position of political power for their own gain
column2: misconduct in public office and electoral fraud.

column1: Under the Coronavirus Act
column2: Covid breaches are classified as summary offences.

column1: This means they do not come with prison sentences
column2: but are punishable by fines.

column1: During the summer of 2020
column2: the Met Police had the power to fine people £100 for the first Covid offence (lowered to £50 if paid within 14 days). Fines for subsequent offences could then double
column3: up to a maximum of £3

column1: Failure or refusal to pay the fine could result in being prosecuted and having to go to court.
However
column2: the fact the police are investigating Downing Street events does not mean ""fixed penalty notices will necessarily be issued in every instance and to every person involved""
column3: Dame Cressida said.

column1: Asked by journalists whether the prime minister was willing to be interviewed by officers
column2: his spokesman responded: ""Anyone asked to will cooperate fully as you would expect.""

column1: Back in 2006
column2: Tony Blair became the first prime minister to be questioned by police in the course of an investigation.

column1: The investigation was into allegations that peerages were given out in return for donations.
Mr Blair was not interviewed under caution
column2: so he was treated as a witness rather than a suspect.

column1: In July 2007
column2: it was announced that no-one would face charges.

column1: The prime minister said he welcomed the Met's announcement because it would ""help to give the public the clarity it needs and help to draw a line under matters"".
His spokesman said Mr Johnson did not think he had broken the law.
Opposition parties have repeated their calls for him to resign.

column1: 426;Newcastle's Covid response documented through photography;2022-01-30T01:27:18.000Z;[];['tom warburton photography'
column2: 'newcastle city council'];['covid'
column3: 'photography'

column1: An amateur photographer who found himself at the centre of the Covid-19 pandemic has told how he documented the response in Newcastle.
Tom Warburton
column2: director of city futures at the council until his recent retirement
column3: has spent almost two years capturing the highs and the lows as the city ""really pulled together"".

column1: Armed with his camera
column2: he started the project on 16 March 2020 when council managers were called for a briefing at the Civic Centre - the first socially-distanced event they had seen.

column1: One week later
column2: the prime minister announced the first national lockdown.

column1: Registered as a key worker and a keen photographer since he was a teenager
column2: Tom said when Covid arrived he knew it was going to be a ""big story"".

column1: We knew it would be a significant episode for the city
column2: he said.

column1: It was clear to us that the reaction of the local communities
column2: and how the city responded could and would make a real difference.""

column1: In the early stages this was the need for emergency food and support to families struggling in lockdown
column2: as well as PPE supply to care homes
column3: and keeping key council services going such as bin collections and social care.

column1: Later
column2: it moved on to preparing the city to reopen safely
column3: economic support for businesses and helping the NHS roll out the vaccination programmes.

column2: moving on from capturing the council's response
column3: Tom worked to broaden the range of subjects - visiting hospitals

column1: The Covid ICU ones are probably the most poignant
column2: he said.

column1: Tom has moved back to Cumbria where he grew up - but the project is continuing.
He would like to photograph stories from the city's faith communities
column2: the education sector
column3: voluntary groups and families of those who lost someone to Covid.

column1: He then hopes to donate the collection to the Tyne and Wear Museum and Archive Service.
Tom said: ""I'm glad I've done it. It was on top of my day job and I was actively involved in several of the projects you see photographed
column2: so sometimes I felt overwhelmed by the whole thing.

column1: But looking back I'm just amazed and immensely proud of the people involved in keeping the city functioning for these two years.""
He also paid tribute to the ""millions of unsung heroes who just leant in and kept things going"" in cities around the world.

column1: This video can not be played
Sue Gray has blamed a ""failure of leadership"" for allowing parties to take place in Downing Street when the country was under strict lockdown.
In long-awaited findings
column2: the senior civil servant says some events ""should not have been allowed to take place"".

column1: Ms Gray investigated 16 separate gatherings - including three that were not previously known about.
Boris Johnson said he accepted the findings in full
column2: as he faced questions and criticism from MPs.

column1: In Ms Gray's findings
column2: she confirms that the Metropolitan Police is investigating 12 events - on eight separate dates - for alleged Covid-rule breaking.

column1: These include the 20 May 2020 ""bring your own booze"" event in the Downing Street garden
column2: which the PM has apologised for attending
column3: and the PM's birthday party on 19 June 2020.

column1: And the police are also investigating a gathering on 13 November 2020 at Mr Johnson's Downing Street flat.
Asked by Labour MPs if he was at that party
column2: Mr Johnson said he would not give a ""running commentary"" on something that was being investigated by the police.

column1: Ms Gray says she has been ""extremely limited"" in how much she can say by the Met's inquiries
column2: and she could not publish a ""meaningful"" report at this stage.

column1: But she does make pointed criticisms of the culture in Downing Street among senior civil servants and staff
column2: adding that some of the gatherings did not observe the high standards ""expected of the entire British population at the time""
column3: and that too little thought was given to how they might appear to the public.

column1: There were failures of leadership and judgement by different parts of No 10 and the Cabinet Office at different times
column2: she writes.

column1: Some of the events should not have been allowed to take place. Other events should not have been allowed to develop as they did.""
This video can not be played
She adds that the ""excessive consumption of alcohol is not appropriate in a professional workplace at any time""
column2: likely to be a reference to reports of drunken behaviour in the Number 10 garden and staff filling a suitcase with bottles of wine
column3: and recommends a ""robust"" policy on alcohol consumption.

column1: The report is crucial to Mr Johnson's premiership
column2: which has been rocked by weeks of damaging headlines about parties in Downing Street and other government buildings.

column1: Many Conservative MPs had said they were waiting for its findings to decide whether to try to oust him from office.
If at least 54 of them submit letters of no confidence to the 1922 Committee
column2: representing backbench Tory MPs
column3: they can set up a vote on his position.

column1: Mr Johnson addressed a meeting of the committee on Monday evening
column2: after which cabinet minister Jacob Rees-Mogg said the ""mood was positive"".

column1: A long-standing critic of the prime minister said there was little chance of opponents gathering the signatures needed to trigger a vote
column2: but called the party ""deluded"".

column1: In his Commons statement earlier
column2: the PM vowed to learn from Ms Gray's initial findings
column3: saying: ""I get it and I will fix it.""

column1: I am sorry for the things we simply didn't get right and also sorry for the way this matter has been handled
column2: he said
column3: as he promised a shake-up of the way Downing Street is run.

column1: Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said the British people believe Mr Johnson should ""do the decent thing and resign"" but he is ""a man without shame"".
The SNP's leader at Westminster
column2: Ian Blackford
column3: was ordered to leave the Commons chamber after accusing the prime minister of lying to MPs about the events.

column1: This video can not be played
The PM said he would create a specific Office of The Prime Minister
column2: carry out a review of the civil service code of conduct and bring in measures to improve the way government works.

column1: He faced repeated opposition calls to resign after his statement
column2: and to publish the Gray report in full.

column1: Some Tory MPs backed the PM
column2: but others joined in with criticisms.

column1: His predecessor as prime minister and Tory leader
column2: Theresa May
column3: said: ""The Covid regulations imposed significant restrictions on the freedoms of members of the public.

column1: They had a right to expect their prime minister to have read the rules
column2: to understand the meaning of the rules and indeed those around him to have done so too and to set an example in following those rules.""

column1: Former cabinet minister Andrew Mitchell told MPs that the prime minister no longer had his support.

Aaron Bell - reported to be among backbench Tory MPs to be calling for a no-confidence vote - sad he had followed strict Covid restrictions at his grandmother's funeral and asked Mr Johnson: ""Does the PM think I am a fool?""
Ms Gray was forced to rewrite her report after the Met asked last week for only ""minimal reference"" to be made to events they are looking at
column2: in order to ""avoid any prejudice to our investigation"".

column1: The leading investigator
column2: Commander Catherine Roper
column3: said officers had been handed ""well over"" 500 pieces of paper
column4: and more than 300 photographs so far.

column1: They expect to approach in writing
column2: or via email
column3: individuals ""identified as having potentially breached""

column1: Downing Street said the PM would ""ask Sue Gray to update her work in light of what is found"" by the Metropolitan Police
column2: when they have finished their inquiries.

column1: He will publish that update
column2: added a spokesperson.

column1: There are 14% more tree species than previously thought
column2: according to what researchers are calling the first ""scientifically credible"" estimate.

column1: Of the 73
column2: 300 estimated species
column3: the researchers predict there are 9
column4: 200 that are yet to be discovered.

column1: But most rare species are in tropical forests
column2: fast disappearing because of climate change and deforestation.

column1: The study is based on a database of tens of millions of trees in more than 100
column2: 000 forest plots around the world.

column1: The researchers used statistical techniques to predict the likely number of tree species
column2: correcting for gaps in existing data.

column1: The findings suggest more must be done to protect the incredible life forms needed for food
column2: timber and medicine and to fight climate change by sucking carbon dioxide from the air.

column1: Lead researcher Dr Peter Reich
column2: of the University of Minnesota in St Paul
column3: said the findings highlighted the vulnerability of global forest biodiversity.

column1: Our data will help us assess where biodiversity is the most threatened
column2: he told BBC News.

column1: This is in the tropics and subtropics of South America
column2: Africa
column3: Asia
column4: and Oceania and those are places where we discovered hotspots of known and unknown rare species.

column1: Knowing about these hotspots
column2: hopefully
column3: can help prioritise future conservation efforts.""

column1: South America - the continent with the most ""missing"" species - has about 43% of the total number
column2: followed by:

column1: Diverse natural forests are the most healthy and productive
column2: important to the global economy and to nature.

More than 140 international researchers worked on the study
column2: in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences journal.

column1: Dr Yadvinder Malhi
column2: of the University of Oxford
column3: said tropical forests were the ""global treasure chests of biodiversity"" and significant absorbers of carbon dioxide emissions

column1: Sue Gray's initial report might be short on detail. But what she makes perfectly clear is that even the bare bones of what went on in Downing Street and the Cabinet Office during lockdown were unacceptable in her view.
In Whitehall speak
column2: to say there were ""serious failures"" in leadership is near-condemnation.

column1: Ms Gray reveals that three new gatherings took place that weeks of reporting have not previously uncovered - and she confirms that a dozen of them are being investigated by the police.
Most risky for No 10
column2: we can now be sure that three events the police are looking into were ones Boris Johnson himself attended.

column1: There's an investigation
column2: too
column3: into what happened not just in the government buildings
column4: which are a warren of multiple rooms
column5: but a gathering in the private flat above the shop.

column1: What's also fascinating is that Ms Gray repeatedly makes the point that what went wrong matters not just because it was ill-advised in the office
column2: but because the public were being asked to make their own sacrifices during this period.

column1: That's why all of this has concerned so many members of the public. That's why so many Tory MPs have been angered by what went on.
By Ms Gray's counting - after interviewing more than 70 people - on 16 occasions
column2: some of those who worked at the heart of government did not obey those rules.

column1: Forget all the process around what and when the report would be published
column2: the back-and-forth with the Met
column3: the claims and denials.

column1: This is an official verdict that Downing Street will try to move on from
column2: but not all of the public
column3: not all of his MPs

437;Sue Gray: Boris Johnson focused on saving his own skin
column2: says Keir Starmer;2022-02-01T09:15:25.000Z;[];['conservative party'
column3: 'coronavirus lockdown measures'

column1: Boris Johnson is focused on ""saving his own skin"" rather than key issues
column2: after findings into No 10 lockdown parties were published
column3: Sir Keir Starmer says.

column1: The update delivered by Sue Gray blamed a ""failure of leadership"" for rule breaking in Downing Street.
Mr Johnson met Tory MPs on Monday to reassure them about his premiership and to promise a shake-up in No 10.
But the Labour leader accused the PM of becoming distracted from problems like the cost of living crisis.
Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab defended his boss
column2: telling BBC Radio 4's Today programme he had ""expressed contrition for his overall responsibility""
column3: and had a plan to fix the running of No 10.

column1: But fellow Tory MP Andrew Mitchell told the same programme the PM was running government like a ""medieval court""
column2: and he was doing ""great damage"" to his party.

column1: Metropolitan Police officers are looking into 12 events for alleged breaches of lockdown rules
column2: including three the PM reportedly attended and one in his flat.

column1: In her partial report
column2: released on Monday
column3: senior civil servant Ms Gray said she had been ""extremely limited"" by the police investigation in how much she could say
column4: so a ""meaningful"" report could not be released yet.

column1: She will publish an updated report on lockdown parties in No 10 once police finish their inquiries
column2: Downing Street has said.

column1: A number of Conservative MPs had said they are waiting for Ms Gray's full report to decide whether to try to remove the PM from office.
But Leader of the House Jacob Rees-Mogg claimed the ""mood was positive"" in the party after Mr Johnson addressed a meeting of the 1922 Committee of Conservative backbench MPs on Monday evening.
Speaking to BBC Breakfast
column2: Sir Keir said the Mr Johnson had become distracted by trying to save his own premiership.

column1: He said: ""So many people are worried about issues such as their energy bills
column2: which are going through the roof
column3: and the prime minister is spending all of his time saving his own skin.

column1: We now know that he had a meeting planned with the chancellor last week to discuss energy bills
column2: but that was cancelled because he was having meetings to save his own job.""

column1: But Mr Raab insisted the government was ""getting on with the job""
column2: despite the ongoing investigation.

column1: [The PM] recognised that
column2: as Sue Gray said
column3: the standards expected in No 10 were not as they should have been

column1: He said he did take responsibility and he apologised
column2: and he provided a plan of action.

column1: But if you look at the big judgement calls... the prime minister has got these right. This government has got a plan.""
Asked if Mr Johnson had admitted to breaking any of the rules himself
column2: Mr Raab said: ""The prime minister has been very clear that he acted in good faith at all times.""

column1: It was only 12 pages
column2: but there was one very damaging and difficult conclusion in the terse summary of Sue Gray's report.

column1: It is there now in black and white for all to see - there was rule breaking at the top of government when the country was living through lockdown.
The prime minister's original claim that all the guidelines were followed seems almost farcical now.
Downing Street's early dismissals of the claims
column2: even some of Mr Johnson's allies admit
column3: now seem ill-advised. The Tory leader was savaged in the Commons
column4: including by some of his own side
column5: the disbelief and despair led by the former occupant of his address.

column1: The publication
column2: however
column3: has not toppled over an overwhelming set of dominoes.

column1: There are Conservative MPs who are incandescent. There is also a band of loyalists determined to help him stay on
column2: almost whatever happens next.

column1: Read more analysis here.
On Monday in the Commons
column2: some of the PM's backbenchers expressed support for him - but others issued stinging rebukes in light of the findings.

column1: Former Prime Minister Theresa May asked if he had read or understood the Covid rules created by his government
column2: or whether he ""believed they did not apply"" to No 10
column3: while ex-cabinet minister Andrew Mitchell said the PM no longer had his support.

column1: This video can not be played
Speaking to Today on Tuesday
column2: Mr Mitchell warned the issue of parties was ""a crisis that is not going to go away and is doing very great damage to the party""
column3: saying: ""It is more corrosive in my judgement than the expenses scandal was and it will break the coalition that is the Conservative Party.""

column1: The former government whip also criticised the PM's running of No 10
column2: telling the BBC: ""I think the problem is that Boris [Johnson] is running a modern government like a medieval court.

column1: You need to rule and govern through the structures
column2: through Whitehall
column3: through the cabinet for National Security Council.

column1: Many of us thought he would govern in the way he did when he was Mayor Of London
column2: through being a chairman of a board
column3: running a very good team - that is not what has happened here.""

column1: In his meeting with Tory MPs on Monday evening
column2: the prime minister promised he would make changes to his political operation
column3: perhaps later this week.

column1: This is expected to include the departure of some back room staff
column2: and possibly a new chief whip to replace Mark Spencer
column3: with some limited ministerial moves
column4: BBC political editor Laura Kuenssberg said.

column1: No 10 has also indicated that it will support the formation of new policy groups of backbenchers to feed views more directly into government.
Mr Johnson also told MPs that the Australian pollster
column2: Lynton Crosby
column3: would be making a return to the operation. There is no detail from Downing Street on what his role will be.
