column1: Myanmar is seeing increasingly deadly battles between its military and organised groups of armed civilians
column2: new data suggests. Many of those fighting the military are young people who have put their lives on hold since the junta seized power a year ago.

column1: The intensity and extent of the violence - and the co-ordination of the opposition attacks - point to a change in the conflict from an uprising to a civil war.
Violence is now spread across the country
column2: according to data from conflict monitoring group Acled (Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project). Reports from the ground also suggest the fighting has become increasingly co-ordinated and has reached urban centres which have not previously seen armed resistance to the military.

column1: Although precise death tolls are hard to verify
column2: Acled - which bases its data on local media and other reports - has collated figures to suggest about 12
column3: 000 people have been killed in political violence since the military seized power on 1 February 2021. Clashes have grown deadlier month on month since August.

column1: In the coup's immediate aftermath
column2: most civilians died as security forces cracked down on nationwide demonstrations. Now
column3: however
column4: the rising death toll is a result of combat - as civilians have taken up arms - Acled figures show.

column1: UN Human Rights chief Michelle Bachelet agreed in an interview with the BBC that the conflict in Myanmar
column2: also known as Burma
column3: should now be termed a civil war and called on the UN Security Council to take ""stronger action"" to put pressure on the military to restore democracy. She said the international response to the crisis had ""lacked urgency"" and described the situation as ""catastrophic""
column4: warning that the conflict now threatened regional stability.

column1: The groups fighting government forces are known collectively as the People's Defence Force (PDF) - a loose network of civilian militia groups largely made up of young adults.
Hera (not her real name)
column3: had just finished high school when she joined anti-government protests following the coup. She has put university plans on hold to become a PDF platoon commander in central Myanmar. She says she was motivated to join the PDF after the high-profile death of student Mya Thwe Thwe Khaing who was shot during the February 2021 protests. Hera's parents were initially concerned when their daughter began a PDF combat training course
column4: but they relented when they realised she was serious.

column1: They told me: 'If you really want to do it
column2: do it to the end. Don't give up halfway.' So I talked to my trainer and fully joined the revolution five days after the training.""

column1: Before the coup
column2: people like Hera had grown up enjoying a degree of democracy. They deeply resent the military takeover and are being supported and trained by other ethnically-driven militias in the border regions who have been fighting the military on and off for decades.

column1: The BBC used figures from Acled
column2: the non-profit organisation
column3: which collects data on political violence and protests around the world. It draws on news reports
column4: publications by civil society and human rights organisations
column5: and security updates from local and international organisations.

column1: While Acled does not independently verify each news report
column2: it says its data on fatalities are continually updated as new information about events and fatality estimates become available. This is due to the difficulty in capturing all relevant events in a conflict zone where reports can often be biased or incomplete
column3: as well as Acled's policy of recording the lowest estimates reported.

column1: However
column2: it is impossible to get a fully accurate picture of events given both sides are engaging in a fierce propaganda war. Journalists' reporting is also heavily restricted.

column1: The BBC's Burmese Service also collected information on fatalities from clashes between Myanmar's military and the PDF from May to June 2021. This was consistent with trends in Acled's data.
The PDF is made up of people from all walks of life - farmers
column2: housewives
column3: doctors and engineers. They are united by a determination to overthrow military rule.

column1: There are units across the country
column2: but it is significant that young people from the Bamar ethnic majority in the central plains and cities are taking the lead - joining forces with youths of other ethnicities. This is the first time in Myanmar's recent history that the armed forces have faced violent opposition from young Bamars.

column1: Many [civilians] have gone into these militias or created these so-called peoples' defence forces
column2: Ms Bachelet told the BBC. ""So that's why for a long time
column3: I've been saying that
column4: if we're not able to do something more strongly about it
column5: it will echo so much the Syria situation.""

column1: Nagar
column2: a former businessman who controls several PDF units in the Sagaing Region in central Myanmar
column3: told the BBC that it is not an equal fight. The PDF began with only catapults
column4: although they have since made their own muskets and bombs. The heavily armed military has aerial firepower - used frequently in recent months. It can procure weapons from countries openly supportive of the junta - including Russia and China.

column1: An open source investigation by Myanmar Witness - shared with the BBC - confirmed that Russian armoured vehicles were unloaded in Yangon a few weeks ago.
But the PDF's strength is its support on the ground in local communities. What began as grassroots resistance has become more organised
column2: daring and battle-hardened. The exiled National Unity Government (NUG) has helped set up and lead some PDF units - and keeps in touch with others more informally.

column1: The PDF have homed in on soft government force targets
column2: such as police stations and poorly-staffed outposts. They have seized weapons
column3: and have bombed junta-owned businesses including telecom towers and banks.

column1: Nagar says the PDF have no choice but to take on the future of the country themselves. ""I think resolving the problems at a round table no longer works today. The world is ignoring our country. So I will arm myself.""
Hera
column2: who joined the PDF with her older sisters
column3: says their aim is to ""root out the military dictatorship"".

column1: The military has killed innocent people. They destroyed people's livelihoods
column2: properties and possessions. And they terrorise people. I can't accept that in any way.""

column1: There have been several incidents of mass killings of civilians by the military
column2: including the deaths of at least 40 men in July - and the killing of more than 35 men
column3: women and children in December.

column1: The BBC has spoken to a man who survived another attack by the military - also in December - by playing dead. Six men - unable to run away when soldiers entered their village in Nagatwin in central Myanmar - were killed. Three of them were elderly and two had mental health conditions
column2: villagers say. The man who survived says junta troops were looking for resistance fighters.

column1: This video can not be played

The widow of one of the dead men says her husband's body showed signs of torture. ""They killed an old man who couldn't even speak well enough to explain. I will never forget it. I cry whenever I think about it
column2: she told the BBC.

column1: The military rarely gives interviews
column2: but in an exclusive interview with the BBC in late 2021 junta spokesman
column3: Zaw Min Tun
column4: described the PDF as terrorists - using the label as justification for action against them.

column1: If they attack us
column2: we have ordered [our troops] to respond. We are trying to secure the country and the regions by using appropriate force in order to achieve a reasonable level of security
column3: he said.

column1: It is difficult to estimate the exact number of fighters on either side. Officially
column2: Myanmar's military numbers about 370
column3: 000 troops - but in reality it could be much smaller. There have been fewer recruits in recent years - and also defections since the coup. Similarly
column4: it is difficult to get an accurate assessment of the number of people in the PDF.

column1: In addition to the units formed by the NUG
column2: some PDF members are being trained
column3: sheltered and even armed by ethnic armed groups operating along the border. Some of the groups had signed ceasefires with previous governments - those ceasefires have now broken.

column1: The PDF has now publicly apologised to ethnic militias for previously believing military propaganda that the groups had wanted to dismantle the country. The PDF is now unanimously calling for a future federal state in which everyone will have equal rights.

A nun - who knelt in front of a police frontline in March 2021 to protect protesters in the wake of the military coup - has told the BBC that the political upheaval since the takeover has had a seismic effect on the lives of the public.
Children can't go to school. Education
column2: health
column3: social and economic and livelihood - everything has gone backward
column4: says Sister Ann Rose Nu Tawng.

column1: Some aborted children because they couldn't provide for them due to the poor economy. Parents can't guide their children properly because of livelihood difficulties.""
But the nun says she admires the young people who have joined the fight.
They are brave. They don't mind [sacrificing] their own lives in working to achieve democracy
column2: for the good of the country
column3: to get peace and to get this country liberated [from military rule]. I praise them
column4: I'm proud of them and I respect them.""

column1: Additional reporting by Rebecca Henschke and Becky Dale. Design by Jana Tauschinski.

column1: 445;Why cows may be hiding something but AI can spot it;2022-02-01T00:01:25.000Z;[];['rspca'

column1: As cow number 2073 makes her way out of the milking shed and passes in front of a nearby camera
column2: the computer identifies her and watches every step.

column1: She is only on screen briefly but here is a slight unevenness to her gait
column2: which she is trying to hide.

column1: A human might not notice that something is wrong but the machine picks it up.
Really
column2: we want to completely replace any manual watching of animals when the cow sleeps
column3: or she eats
column5: co-founder and chief executive of CattleEye.

column1: His firm's technology automatically detects early signs of lameness in cattle. It is confined to milking sheds
column2: for now
column3: but is already being rolled out on dairy farms
column4: mostly in the US and UK. About 20
column5: 000 cows are currently under the system's watch.

column1: Farms are increasingly turning to automation for many reasons - among them
column2: to cover labour shortages. But new tech also offers potential improvements in animal welfare and a reduction in emissions
column3: says Mr Canning.

column1: We've actually calculated
column2: that if you can reduce lameness levels by 10% on a farm
column3: there's a saving of half a tonne of carbon per cow per year

column1: Lameness is caused by injuries or infections and can be very painful. Lame cows produce less milk and if it goes untreated it can mean that they end up being culled.
University of Liverpool researchers have studied CattleEye's system on three farms to check its accuracy.
In research funded by the firm (which is yet to be peer-reviewed)
column2: Prof George Oikonomou and his team compared mobility scores for cattle made by two human experts with those made by CattleEye. They found that the technology was roughly 80-90% in agreement with the two experts - in terms of judging which animals were lame.

column1: When 84 of the cows were subsequently checked for foot problems
column2: the researchers found the AI system had performed slightly better than a human expert in terms of selecting those that had tissue damage in their hooves among the animals it had designated as lame.

column1: A separate study
column2: also led by Prof Oikonomou but funded by the Welsh government's Farming Connect scheme
column3: found the introduction of CattleEye at one Welsh dairy farm with 300 cows
column4: saw the proportion of animals with mobility issues fall from 25.4% to 13.5% after six months.

column1: CattleEye is just one system bringing higher levels of automated surveillance to farms. Other devices for tracking their health include Moocall sensors.
These are strapped to a cow's tail and indicate when they are about to give birth. The sensors pick up a characteristic up and down motion of the cow's tail that occurs prior to calving.
Yet
column2: there are plenty of farms that have not yet adopted these technologies. Dr Sarah Lloyd
column3: her husband and family
column4: run a farm in rural Wisconsin with about 400 cows. All of the milk they produce goes for cheese production.

column1: The cost of the technology just can't be borne by our milk price
column2: she says. Her husband Nels Nelson prefers to work ""with his sleeves rolled up"" rather than rely on machines
column3: she adds. He's not anti-tech but the family don't see a benefit in investing in AI-based systems.

column1: Others take a different view. Dr Jeffrey Bewley is an analytics and innovation scientist at the dairy cattle breed organisation
column2: Holstein Association USA. He grew up on a Kentucky dairy farm and has studied the industry ""my entire life"". He has done some consulting work for farm tech firms
column3: though not for CattleEye.

column1: He says there are tell-tale signs of lameness in cattle that farmers will spot - cow's back might arch a little bit
column2: her head may bob or the length of her strides will get noticeably longer or shorter.

column1: But lameness is something that cows naturally try to hide because they have evolved as prey animals. So
column2: technology that helps the farmer spot the earliest subtle signs of lameness could be useful
column3: he explains.

column1: The animal charity RSPCA says it welcomes new technologies for monitoring cattle
column2: as identifying lameness can be quite subjective for human observers and so such systems could make mobility scoring more accurate.

column1: But the organisation says that since these are novel technologies and their validity is still developing ""they cannot replace regular mobility scoring using a valid
column2: reproducible method"".

column1: More technology of business:
AI will gradually play a bigger role on our farms - but exactly to what extent is unclear
column2: and whether it will really improve conditions for the animals themselves?

column1: I've been in several bulk barns
column2: several dairies that are shifted to robotics and the cows are just friendlier. You can walk among them and they don't seem to be excited at all
column3: says Jack Britt
column4: professor emeritus at North Carolina State University
column5: who has consulted for various farm tech companies.

column1: Yet
column2: not all interventions have to be high tech. Simply adding grooves to the concrete on which cows walk to and from the milking shed
column3: can improve their stability and reduce their chance of becoming lame

column1: Nonetheless
column2: he predicts in 50 years' time 90% of the human labour on farms will be replaced by machines.

column1: It is not a vision shared by Dr Lloyd. While she accepts it can be challenging to find human farm workers
column2: she would rather keep trying than turn to machines. ""I'd prefer to have more human eyes working on farms and making a living
column3: she says.

column1: That's important for the economic life and social life of our community.""
Prof. Steven Pinker tries to make sense of the situation...

column2: 'dry'

column1: Prof Yael Hanein sticks a number of electrodes to the left side of my face.
Move your eyes
column2: blink
column3: smile. Now try to relax
column4: she says. ""We will see if you are a good or bad liar shortly.""

column1: Prof Hanein and colleague Prof Dino Levy lead a team at Israel's Tel Aviv University that have developed a new method of lie detection.
They say they have identified two types of liars - those who involuntarily move their eyebrows when they tell a fib
column2: and those that cannot control a very slight lip movement where their lips meet their cheeks.

column1: Their software and its algorithm can now detect 73% of lies and they intend to improve that as they develop the system. ""When you try to conceal a lie
column2: one of the things you try to avoid is any sort of body reaction
column3: she says.

column1: Prof Levy adds: ""But it's very
column2: very hard for you to conceal a lie with this technology.""

column1: Methods of lie detection have probably been around for as long as tall tales have been told. One of the first documented examples comes from 1000BC in China
column2: where a suspect would have to fill his or her mouth with dry rice.

column1: After a period of time the grains would be checked
column2: and if they remained dry then the person was determined to be guilty. The theory was that if the individual had indeed lied he or she would be fearful or nervous
column3: and therefore have a dry mouth.

column1: The early 20th Century saw the invention of the first lie detection machines or polygraphs. The most well-known of these is the ""analogue polygraph""
column2: which typically has three or four ink-filled needles that dance round on a strip of moving paper.

column1: The suspect has sensors attached to their fingers
column2: arms and body and the machine then measures breathing rate
column3: pulse
column4: blood pressure and perspiration as they answer a series of questions.

column1: Yet there are continuing concerns about the accuracy of these machines and whether it is possible to fool them. So researchers and technology firms around the world are working to develop more high-tech polygraph systems.
At Erasmus University in Rotterdam
column2: Netherlands
column3: Dr Sebastian Speer and his team are using an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) machine to spot if someone is lying or cheating. They do this by looking out for colour changes in brain scans in response to questions.

column1: Essentially we see [different] areas [of the brain] that are more strongly activated [light up on the scans] when someone decides to cheat or to be honest
column2: says Dr Speer.

column1: One high-tech lie detection system already in use is EyeDetect from Utah-based firm Converus. This focuses on involuntary eye movements to detect lies.
A subject is asked to answer a number of true or false
column2: or yes and no
column3: questions. As they do so
column4: eye tracking software watches and studies their responses. The result is then provided within five minutes
column5: and it claims to be 86-88% accurate.

column1: Converus (the world is Latin for ""with truth"") says EyeDetect is now used by more than 600 customers in 50 countries
column2: including over 65 US law enforcement agencies and nearly 100 worldwide.

column1: Chief executive Todd Mickelsen says the test is being utilised by authorities and firms to screen for numerous things: ""These could include prior crimes
column2: drug use past or present
column3: unreported disciplinary action

column1: Meanwhile police detectives can use EyeDetect to ask specific questions regarding a crime.
It is important to stress
column2: however
column3: that the legality of lie detectors varies greatly from country to country

column1: New Tech Economy is a series exploring how technological innovation is set to shape the new emerging economic landscape.
In the UK
column2: polygraphs have been used by the probation service ""in the management of people convicted of sexual offences"" since 2014. And they are now being trialled regarding domestic abuse offenders.

column1: But the results of polygraph tests cannot be used in criminal cases in the UK's three separate legal systems - England and Wales
column2: Scotland and Northern Ireland.

column1: At the same time
column2: UK employers are allowed to offer a lie detection test to staff
column3: but this has to be optional.

column1: In the US
column2: the rules differ from state to state
column3: with the further complication of US-wide federal law on top.

column1: For instance
column2: California allows lie detection test evidence in state-level criminal court cases if both sides agree
column3: yet in New York state it is not allowed under any circumstances. And US police forces cannot require that a suspect or arrested person undergoes a test.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: The Federal Employee Polygraph Protection Act prevents firms from putting job applications through a test.

column1: Former CIA officer Christopher Burgess cautions that lie detectors should not be been seen as the be-all and end-all for proving the guilt or innocence of criminals - or spies.
It's one tool used during the interrogation phase of an investigation
column2: he says. ""Evidence is how liars
column3: scoundrels
column4: cheats and fabricators are sussed out.""

column1: Mr Burgess
column2: who is now a security analyst
column3: adds that the devices are not completely accurate
column4: and says that he himself was once wrongly implicated by a false test result back in the mid 1990s.

column1: As more high-tech lie detection systems enter use
column2: he says there remain ""ethical and moral questions"".

column1: Back at Tel Aviv University
column2: the researchers hope that the electrodes will eventually be replaced by video cameras and software able to spot a liar from a distance or even via an internet link
column3: based on facial muscle movements.

column1: In the bank
column2: in police interrogations
column3: at the airport or online job interviews
column4: high-resolution cameras trained to identify movements of facial muscles will be able to tell truthful statements from lies

column1: After my interrogation I ask if I have passed.
You're not a very good liar
column2: the two professors jest.

column1: It was only 12 pages
column2: but there was one very damaging and difficult conclusion in the terse summary of Sue Gray's report.

column1: It is there now in black and white for all to see - there was rule breaking at the top of government when the country was living through lockdown.
The prime minister's original claim that all the guidelines were followed seem almost farcical now.
Downing Street's early dismissals of the claims
column2: even some of Mr Johnson's allies admit
column3: now seem ill-advised. The Tory leader was savaged in the Commons
column4: including by some of his own side
column5: the disbelief and despair led by the former occupant of his address.

column1: The publication
column2: however
column3: has not toppled over an overwhelming set of dominoes.

column1: There are Conservative MPs who are incandescent. There are also a band of loyalists who are determined to help him stay on
column2: almost whatever happens next.

column1: And late on Monday
column2: they were not suddenly full of new panic that it was all about to fall apart - indeed
column3: after what they believe was a better outing for Mr Johnson in private in front of his MPs on Monday night
column4: they believe the would-be rebels who want to see him gone don't have any meaningful new momentum.

column1: Remember the process that Tory MPs can use to trigger a contest for their leader is secret
column2: so no-one can be sure how near or far the malcontents are from the threshold of 54 private letters which would press the button on a contest.

column1: It cannot have been easy for many of them to endure Keir Starmer's stand-out speech in the Commons on Monday
column2: when he quoted Thatcher at them
column3: urging them to act to end what seems to him

column1: Yet Boris Johnson's helped by the fact the report has not yet named any specific names. The verdict was damning
column2: but not personal
column3: the criticisms sharp but general.

column1: And those who want him gone are also hindered by the fact that they don't yet agree on who or what should come next if they summon up the courage to take action. One minister who is certainly in that camp described it as 'the battle of the Alamo
column2: we can see what's coming
column3: and we know the captain is leading us badly
column4: but we don't yet know who to pass the baton to'.

column1: Yet Downing Street is not clear of danger. Sue Gray's findings put this whole mess back under the public's nose. How the polls shift in the coming days and weeks will help shape Downing Street's fortunes
column2: for good or for ill.

column1: The embarrassment of the coming police report could dramatically make things even worse. Events that we know he attended are now officially under police investigation
column2: including one in his own home
column3: the Downing Street flat. And extraordinarily the police are even confirming publicly how many photographs and pieces of evidence they have.

column1: Boris Johnson has reduced the fever in his party by making his MPs a set of promises - to change his team in Number 10
column2: potentially some expect a new chief whip
column3: a few ministerial moves as well as departures of some of his backroom staff.

column1: He's promised the return of the campaigner Lynton Crosby
column2: which doesn't at this stage seem like a formal new appointment
column3: more like a vow that he'll take stronger advice.

column1: Many rational MPs seem to have resolved to leave Mr Johnson on probation - break the commitments he made to them and that could quickly change.  For now it seems the prime minister has survived the day. Yet in time
column2: his MPs will judge whether just getting through is enough.

column1: 450;The myth of a 'super-charged' immune system;2022-02-01T20:31:27.000Z;[];['immune system'];['self'
column2: 'matter'
column3: 'supercharged'

column1: Suddenly we are all talking about immunity - but how much do we really understand? Science writer and YouTuber Philipp Dettmer unpicks one of the most common misconceptions.
Next time you wake up feeling a bit under the weather
column2: spare a thought for the army of soldiers fighting millions of enemies on your behalf.

column1: Inside the fortress of your body.
While intruders attack hundreds of thousands of your cells
column2: your immune system is organising complex defences
column3: communicating over vast distances and dishing out a swift death to millions

column1: All the while you are standing in the shower
column2: mildly annoyed at being sick.

column1: What you are feeling - the snotty nose
column2: the raised temperature
column3: the sore throat
column4: the general feeling of being a bit ""off"" - is actually the effect of this battle going on out of sight.

column1: The immune system is complicated in the sense that climbing Mount Everest is a nice stroll through nature. It is the most complex biological system in the human body
column2: other than the brain.

column1: And it's being talked about now more than ever before. The pandemic has introduced a new vocabulary into our lives. We talk about natural immunity in people who have recovered from Covid and immunity from vaccines.
Jabs
column2: boosters
column3: side effects... these are suddenly subjects of conversation as common as the weather.

column1: But talking more about immunity doesn't necessarily mean we understand it more. Let's take an example. Perhaps the biggest misconception is the preoccupation society has with attaining a strong
column2: ""super-charged"" immune system.

column1: The internet is filled with products that promise to do exactly that. From infused coffee to protein powder
column2: from mystical roots dug up in the Amazon rainforest to vitamin pills
column3: the list is endless.

column1: But what a lot of people fail to understand is that the immune system can be dangerous. It's not a thing we want to be unleashed inside us without limits.
In a world where self-improvement is big business
column2: the idea of charging up your immune system is very appealing - but it's not a strong immune system we want
column3: but a balanced one that keeps all the different systems in check.

column1: We are talking about a complex and interconnected collection of hundreds of bases and recruitment centres all over your body. They are connected by a superhighway
column2: a network of vessels
column3: as similarly vast and omnipresent as your cardiovascular system.

column1: On top of organs and infrastructure
column2: billions of immune cells patrol either these superhighways or your bloodstream and are ready to engage your enemies when called upon. Billions more sit guard in the tissue of your body that borders your outsides waiting for invaders to cross them. There are also trillions of protein weapons that you can think of as land mines.

column1: Your immune system also has dedicated universities where cells learn who to fight and how
column2: complete with the largest biological library in the universe
column3: able to identify and remember every possible invader that you may ever encounter in your life.

column1: At its very core
column2: the immune system is a tool to distinguish the other from the self. It does not matter if the other means to harm you or not. If the other is not on a very exclusive guest list that grants free passage
column3: it has to be attacked and destroyed because the other might harm you.

column1: You've probably got the picture by now - it's a highly complex system made up of many different components. A well-functioning immune system is very good at using just the right amount of force for any given infection. So the idea of strengthening these systems to be more aggressive is ridiculous.
Instead of a rugby player smashing into things
column2: you want it to be a ballet dancer - highly trained
column3: precise and able to strike with ease but dancing in harmony with the music.

column1: There is an old Greek word homeostasis
column2: the balance of all things
column3: which is what we should strive for.

column1: It's such an intricate system
column2: so many things could go wrong if it was made more powerful. It could overreact to a minor infection. This misunderstanding is partly because people lack a good mental image of what the term means. They think of it as an energy shield that you can charge up. But it's not a thing at all
column3: it's a multitude of things.

column1: In reality
column2: nobody knows how many cells of which kinds and at what activity level are necessary to have your immune system work optimally. Anybody who says that they know what is needed is probably trying to sell you something.

column1: At least for now
column2: there are no scientifically proven ways to make your immune system more aggressive through a superfood or pill. And if there were
column3: it would be very dangerous to use them without medical supervision.

column1: People prefer easy
column2: quick solutions but health depends on very boring things that people don't want to hear. Exercise
column3: a balanced diet and reduced stress. We all know these are good for us but we don't want to do it.

column1: The most important thing is to eat a diet that provides you with all the vitamins and nutrients your body needs
column2: for example fruits and vegetables. Your immune system constantly makes many billions of new cells and they need feeding.

column1: The positive health effects of even moderate regular exercise have been known for a long time. Good circulation allows your cells and immune proteins to move more efficiently and freely
column2: which makes them do their job better. Exercise can also slow down its decline in old age.

column1: Leading less stressful lives has tangible benefits to our health in many ways
column2: and one of them is the immune system. Without going into too much detail
column3: stress can set off chains of events that disrupt the work and the balance of that system.

column1: So why do some people seem to get colds and flus more than others? There are three reasons for that.
The reality is we are not the same. Lifestyle choices do matter. Maybe you smoke or you don't eat as well as others. Maybe you have a very stressful job or a job that exposes you to viruses
column2: or perhaps you just don't get off the couch.

column1: And there's genetics. Everyone is a bit different. One person might be better at fighting viruses and another better at fighting bacteria.
And thirdly there's perception. Everyone claims to know someone who says they never get sick but that's not true.
So maybe the next time you do wake up with a runny nose or a bit of a sweat
column2: spare a thought for the army of helpers that's keeping you alive.

column1: And instead of cursing your luck
column2: maybe give thanks.
